column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Members of the South African Municipal Workers Union protested in Johannesburg, causing damage and tipping over bins. Police responded by fring teargas and rubber bullets. 9 people were injured.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Parliament was forced to suspend its business due to an ongoing strike by employee members of the National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union (Nehawu). Protesters sang and danced forcing Parliament to close.
About 100 residents of the Tsunami informal settlement in Delft marched to the Western Cape legislature, demanding electricity.

column7: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union
column17: A group of teachers from a Hout Bay school showed their opposition to the Western Cape Education Departments new collaboration schools pilot project during a protest.
Angry residents of Bale village, near Musina, protested outside the Masisi police station to demand answers.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: NEHAWU continued to protest outside parliament.

column7: MDC-T: Movement for Democratic Change (Tsvangirai Faction)
column17: Supporters of the main Zimbabwean opposition party threw plastic bottles at a Zimbabwean consular official after marching on the consulate to hand over a memorandum.
Angry residents of Khayelitsha Site C blocked railway tracks and roads, and burned tyres after their electricity connections were cut by a Metrorail team.

column7: CAMB: Chrystalis Academy Marching Band; Women (South Africa)
column17: About 150 people from Mitchells Plain marched against gender-based violence to start the annual 16 Days of Activism for No Violence Against Women and Children campaign.
Rocks and bricks were flung through the air outside a Pietermaritzburg taxi rank in a protest against the 'no cash in taxis' campaign.
Feelings ran high during a protest by taxi operators in the Port Elizabeth city centre when business owners were blocked from entering and leaving their premises.
Hundreds of pensioners took to the streets of Pretoria and marched on the Union Buildings to hand over a memorandum calling on government to address their issues.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union; Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Members of SAMWU marched through the Johannesburg CBD' leaving streets strewn with rubble and burning rubbish. Paramedics treated seven Pikitup workers after police opened fire on them with rubber bullets
A group of about 100 paramedics flocked to the streets, marching from Dales Park to the KZN Legislature, to hand over a memorandum to government officials.
Residents marched from KwaMsane township to the Mtubatuba office of the mayor where they handed over a memorandum to mayor Israel Nyawo.
A flash mob hit the streets of Pretoria as the Viva Foundation took to the streets to raise awareness around violence against women and children.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Police used rubber bullets and teargas as Pikitup protesters ran for cover in Braamfontein. A torrent of stones, refuse and glass bottles rained down as the protesters fought back.

column7: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union
column17: Teachers took to the streets throughout Mpumalanga after drawn-out talks with the Department of Basic Education came to naught.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Parliamentary workers continied to protest outside parliament where NEHAWU officials were attempting to negotiate.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Around 100 striking workers walked to the Labour Court to try and convince the judge that the interdict, which bars them from protesting inside, not be made permanent.
A meeting addressed by Kgosi Nyalala Pilane was disrupted by angry protesters in Moruleng, North West.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Police had to close the Nelson Mandela bridge as Samwu members marched to Pikitup offices in Braamfontein. Workers were turned back and Samwu accused police of firing at them with rubber bullets unprovoked.
Hundreds of activists marched in Johannesburg urging their government to reduce its share of carbon emissions, ahead of the UN COP21 climate conference in Paris.
A man was shot dead in the KwaMashu Hostels, KwaZulu-Natal police said on Monday. The Area has been prone to political violence and killings

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: The ANCYL in Soweto's Mzala branch dedicated a march to raise awareness against woman and child abuse to a young woman brutally killed, allegedly by her former boyfriend.
More than 1 000 Capetonians took to the streets as part of the global climate march on the eve of the COP21 climate talks that begin in Paris.
About 1 500 supporters of KwaZulu-Natal premier Senzo Mchunu converged on the African National Congress's provincial headquarters in Durban on Monday.
While Woolworths held their AGM, protesters demonstrated outside the Cape Town Building. The protesters were part of the BDS movement.
Residents protested outside the Chatsworth Magistrate's Court in protest over the man accused of raping a young girl.
Equal Edcation members picketed outside the departments Zwelitsha offices, demanding better schools

A house and a church belonging to a woman who claims to be a prophet has been set alight by angry community members in Dzimauli, east of Polokwane, after she allegedly kidnapped a girl and forced her to abandon her studies.
Two suspects were killed in Polokwane when community members caught them after a house robbery.
About 200 DA supporters were bused into the city centre and marched to the ANCs office in Cape Town.
Four members of the Red Ants crew - who have been contracted to clean up the CBD - were shot at point-blank range, possibly by stiking Pikitup workers. No fatalities.
A Eastern Cape man was murdered at Umlazis notorious Glebelands hostel. This was another killing in and around the hostel.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Strikes by National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union (Nehawu) continued as 500 protesters descended onto the parliamentary precinct in a show of solidarity.
About 100 Mfuleni residents marched to the provincial legislature to voice their concerns about corruption and mismanagement in the housing allocation process.
Residents of KaNyamazane near Mbombela barricaded the N4 to Mozambique and Swaziland with burning tyres, tree trunks and trucks.
Angry protests continued outside the Chatsworth Magistrate's Court in protest over the man accused of raping a young girl.
A march to the Union Buildings was intended to celebrate disability in which many people living with disabilities face a daily struggle.
About 50 Klipheuwel residents marched on the Western Cape legislature to demand basic services and development of their area.

column7: SJC: Social Justice Coalition; Women (South Africa)
column17: Khayelitsha residents took to the streets as part of a Social Justice Coalition (SJC) campaign to mark the 16 days of protest against violence against women and children.
Students and staff protested at UNISAs Pretoria campus, calling on all council members who have served for more than two terms to step down.
About 100 people were protesting on the R43 near Delmas and barricaded the road in protest.
Two buses were burnt during a protest at Sekhukhune in Limpopo.
About a hundred municipality workers on temporary contracts for the Msunduzi municipality downed their tools and protested outside the KaMagwayi depo.
A mob, being evicted from their homes, went on the rampage and attacked and lotted foriegners shops
Angry residents marched to the Manenberg police station to express dissatisfaction and anger at police.
Residents of Duncan Village protested, demanding that electricity be restored to their homes.
A suspected ATM card scammer was attacked and killed at Lorraine Village shopping centre near Tzaneen in suspected vigilante violence.
The chairman of Winston Zinziva branch, Lazarus Baloyi (ANC), was beaten up and injured after being accused of being a sellout.

column7: ANCWL: African National Congress Womens League; Women (South Africa)
column17: A march organised by the ANC Womens League was held in Port Elizabeth to mark 16 days of non-violence.

Close to 150 sangomas burnt traditional incense in front of the Department of Health offices in Pretoria, where they demonstrated against draft proposals by Minister Aaron Motsoaledi to regulate their practice
A Community fed up with the crime spree of a marauding gang of suspected illegal immigrants beat up and killed four men in a revenge attack.
More than 100 protesters disrupted a municipal infrastructure and engineering event, refusing to leave until the money allegedly owed by the metro to Masakeni Construction was paid.

column7: PHMSA: Peoples Health Movement of South Africa
column17: Residents marched to the legislature, protesting a new Bill which they say will no longer recognise community health committees.
A group of protesters delivered a memorandum to the ANC offices in ward 53 in aMaoti.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Striking Licening staff, protested (toy-toyed) outside a Johannesburg office.

One person has been killed and two others injured after their vehicle collided with one of the trucks that had been burnt down by protesting community members in Steelpoort, near Burgersfort, Limpopo.
A woman was killed outside the Glebelands hostel while on her way to her home in Mega Village.
A peace march was held in an attempt to quell tension at Glebelands hostel.
A body of an unknown man was found outside the Glebelands hostel.
Residents in Kosovo informal settlement in Philippi took the law into their own hands when they allegedly beat a 30-year-old man to death. They had accused him of raping a woman.
Residents of Wolwerivier had picketed outside the Civic Centre in Camps Bay.
Residents of Mankweng in Limpopo staged protest and forced shops to close on Monday amid demands that the local Polokwane municipality reverse a council motion to cut water.
About 30 Nelson Mandela Bay DA activists protested outside the council chambers.
The Chinese community in South Africa took to the streets in Johannesburg in protest against rising crimes.
Thousands of Capetonians and visitors to the Mother City expressed their dissatisfaction with President Jacob Zuma on Wednesday as they marched the streets as part of the #ZumaMustFall campaign.
In Plettenberg Bay, about 300 people gathered in the main road where they held posters

Four Ekurhuleni metro police vehicles had their tyres slashed and an elderly woman was arrested after stripping during a stand-off between police and residents of Delmore Gardens in Boksburg who were trying to invade municipal land.
The #ZumaMustFall march in George came to an abrupt end as heavy rain forced 200 protesters to disperse.
Thousands marched against corruption in Johannesburg.
Since Wednesday, protesters have been taking to the streets on the road leading to Kruger National Park, pelting motorists and damaging cars.
Protests were held in the big metropolitan municipalities of Johannesburg, Tshwane, Port Elizabeth and Cape Town
Thousands of South Africans have arrived at the Union Buildings as part of nationwide protest calling for the removal of President Jacob Zuma.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: Workers, aligned to NUMSA, took part in a protest over an allegedly late bonus payment.
Since Wednesday, protesters have been taking to the streets on the road leading to Kruger National Park, pelting motorists and damaging cars.
A man died after residents of the Vusimuzi squatter camp near Kempton Park assaulted him for allegedly stealing a pair of soccer boots.
Approximately 300 demonstrators handed a memorandum to the municipality in Fish Hoek, demanding land to build their shacks.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Pikitup workers went on strike again, taking to the streets and burning rubbish.
A group of 84 refugees and immigrants allegedly burnt a tent and cut a fence on a farm that have been staying at.
Since Wednesday, protesters have been taking to the streets on the road leading to Kruger National Park, pelting motorists and damaging cars.
Clashes between rival groups within AmaMpondo have claimed the life of one man and left three others seriously injured near Lusikisiki
A man was abducted and beaten by members of a Neighbourhood Watch, perhaps as a result of suspected drug behaviour.
A woman is fighting for her life after she was shot at Glebelands hostel on Tuesday night.
When the police intervened in the community dispute, a crowd of about 300 people attacked them and their vehicle with bottles and stones; 1 person was injured.
Police intervened in a situation when they arrived on the scene to find a crowd assaulting three people who were accused of stealing.
Four carriages were gutted and two were damaged when a stationary train was set alight at Cape Town station.
A small but determined group of activists stood their ground in an ongoing bid to remove the ""roar of fun"" from the visiting McLarens Circus in Port Elizabeth.
Three people were killed inside a house when a group of unknown men entered a room and opened fire at them. The motives for the attack are unknown.
Chaos erupted in Mdantsane when hundreds of people who had illegally occupied empty RDP houses clashed with metro police.
Activists staged a protest outside Pietermaritzburg over the killing of a Bengal Tiger.
Residents in the Mdantsane and Mbekweni areas burnt down an empty RDP house following a series of dramatic evictions ordered by Buffalo City Metro (BCM).
Three people were injured when villagers returning from a mass meeting opposing mining on the Pondoland Wild Coast were attacked by about 10 men armed with knobkerries and pangas.
Soweto ANC leader Siphiwe Zulu was shot by unknown gunmen on New Years Eve.
A man who ran over a child was subsequently beaten by the community outside Vereeniging.
Two alleged thieves were beaten, tied up and drowned in a dam in Marikana after they robbed a shop owned by a foreign national.
Police fired smoke grenades to separate two ANC factions before they came to blows over a march against corruption in Rustenburg. The factions threw bottles and stones at each other and police.
Two factions of the ANC violently clash, throwing bottles and stones at each other. One group was marching about alleged corruption while the other faction sought to block the march.
Traffic came to a grinding halt on the main route into Durban as about 100 buses blocked off all the lanes in protest over payment for December.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: Protesters, supported by the ANCYL, protested at th Durban Undersea Club on the beachfront.

A group of Kagiso residents protested. The protestors burnt two private vehicles and blocked several roads with burning tyres. When police arrived, they fired rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. No arrests or injuries were reported.

ANC regional secretary Tokyo Mataboge was assaulted by a group of ANC members allegedly sympathetic to Madibeng local municipality executive mayor Jostina Mothibe. The attack occurred during a meeting at a community hall in Brits on January 6
Supporters of the Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) tried to disrupt the symbolic handing over of houses in Marikana near Rustenburg in North West.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: ANCYL marched outside the Standard Bank headquarters in Johannesburg to protest the racist remarks of an employee at the bank.

Police arrived to investigate proceedings at a kangeroo court. Angry residents however are alleged to have pelted police vans with stones. Police responded by firing live ammunition, shooting one person dead
2 men, alleged to have stolen two goats, were assaulted with sticks and fists and also pelted with stones while they attending the kangeroo court proceedings.
A man who was fleeing an angry crowd was killed after he landed in front of a moving car near Umlazi in Durban.

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: University of Pretoria students and workers disrupted registration during a protest against outsourcing. Led by the EFF Student Command, protesters vandalised the building and dumped rubbish on the floor.
Protesters have shut down the University of South Africas (UNISA) Sunnyside Campus, expressing their dissatisfaction with management.

Community activists and parents at Austerville Primary School, in Wentworth, are calling for the sacking of the newly appointed principal. Protesters first took to the streets on Monday, demonstrating outside the school, and continued on Thursday.
Registration at Wits University was disrupted after students resumed picketing under their #FeesMustFall campaign at the campus.
CPUT students writing exams at Walter Sisulu University (WSU) were forced to stop after students from that institution started protesting for free education.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: About 300 people gathered at the entrance to the KwaZulu-Natal coastal resort town of Scottburgh ahead of a march against racism.
At the University of Johannesburg, a scene reminiscent of last years protests played out as students and private security guards clashed outside the campus
Private security guards allegadly used violence to remove students who were occupying building at Wits University
Demonstrators took to the streets and spent the night burning tyres and branches on the road.
During the court appearances of 4 murder suspects, Farmers and ANC members hurled water bottles and rocks at one another. Police contained the situation.

After the killing of Anwar Solomons, a group of about 50 residents went after his suspected killer and found him in a house. They began to assault him until a policeman came to his rescue, firing several shots in the air to disperse the crowd.

Students and contract workers demonstrated outside the Univeristy in Pretoria and UNISA. However, they were met by aggressive police officers and soon found themselves on the wrong end of stun grenades; three workers sustained minor injuries
Hundreds of service delivery protesters in Chintsa East shut down the towns main access road to demand the municipality provide them with housing, water and electricity.
Several people were arrested after municipal offices, a clinic and a fire station were set alight during violent service delivery protests in Waterval. These arrests likely took place after the riot.
Parents and community members blockaded the entrance of a school outside Robertson. During the protest, they chained the front gates, preventing any learners or staff from entering the premises.
At Mfuleni Primary School, about 300 parents staged a sit-in, demanding that their children be placed.
Protesting students and outsourced workers at the University of Pretoria (UP) picketed outside campus
A group of 287 people have been arrested for throwing stones and damaging property at the Marabastad Home Affairs department.
About 350 angry residents marched to the Port Elizabeth City Hall to demand an improvement in service delivery in their ward.
Several people were arrested after municipal offices, a clinic and a fire station were set alight during violent service delivery protests in Waterval. These arrests likely took place after the riot.

Community activists and parents at Austerville Primary School, in Wentworth, are calling for the sacking of the newly appointed principal. Protesters first took to the streets on Monday, demonstrating outside the school, and continued on Thursday.

Workers marched through the streets towards the TUT main campus. A cleaner at Protea Hotel had his wheelie bin taken from him and when he protested, he was attacked and chased inside the building. They were ordered to retreat and when they stood their ground, police opened fire, firing rubber bullets and tear gas into the crowd.
The Cape Town Rastafarian community protested outside Woodstock Police Station.
Parents staged a sit-in in attempts to enrol their children in the Mfuleni school.
MyCiTi bus users protested in front of a bus stop in Tafelsig, Mitchells Plain, complaining it was of a poor standard, compared to those in other suburbs.
About 300 students protested outside a campus of the Thekwini College in Durban
Unisa and the University of Pretoria remained closed as protests continued at the two institutions.
Chanting DA members presented a memorandum of grievances outside the provincial legislature, demanding Fransman vacate his position as leader of the ANC in the province.
An angry crowds of ANC supporters protested and subseuqently ripped a giant #ZumaMustFall banner off the side of a building in Cape Town.
During a protests in Cape Town and the removal of the #ZumaMustFall poster, ANC supporters allegedly assaulted a civilian.
A man suspected of stealing a TV set was murdered during a vigilante attack in Bardale informal settlement in Mfuleni at the weekend.
During ANC Branch Meetings in Gauteng, members were attacked in the towns of Winterveld and Bronkhorstspruit.

column9: ANC: African National Congress; Women (South Africa)
column17: At an ANC branch general meeting in Hammanskraal, women were apparently assaulted by bouncers who burst into the venue. They said they had been slapped and dragged out of the meeting.
During ANC Branch Meetings in Gauteng, members were attacked in the towns of Winterveld and Bronkhorstspruit.

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: At the UNISA Sunningdale campus, protesters aligned to the EFF Student Command protested. A recycling bin was reportedly set alight during the protest.
At the University of Pretoria, petrol bombs were thrown at a truck at the university, causing minimal damages. The actions was part of ongoing protests at Universities throughout Pretoria.
A community leader was ambushed and beaten up in Philippi by residents.

column7: ANC: African National Congress; Women (South Africa)
column17: A group of about 16 women stripped naked and stormed into the offices of the ANC in Pretoria, in protest over the events which took place on the 16th January 2016
Protest action reportedly took place at the Acadia campus of TUTs. These protests are part of ongoing protests led by students and outsourced workers.

Hundreds of Ethiopians living in South Africa protested outside the Pan-African Parliament (PAP) in Johannesburg, demanding that African legislators help them intervene in stopping alleged human rights violations in Ethiopia.
Students and workers protesting at the University of Pretoria (UP), defying a court interdict that ordered them to be at least 150m away from the institution.
More than 40 ANC members from ward 41 in Zwelitsha demonstrated outside the parties Dr WB Rubusane regional offices.
About 30 independent drivers for Coca-Cola staged a protest outside the Competition Tribunal in Pretoria.
Protesters took to the national highway (N2) in Cape Town. The road was closed and some tires were allegedly burnt.
Protesters demonstrated outside the Pietermaritzburg Magistrate's Court where a man charged with the murder and dismemberment of a Maqongqo teenager appeared briefly.
A protest was held at Eskoms Megawatt Park head office in Sunninghill by the Democratic Alliance.
Hundreds of people, angry at the installation of prepaid meters, blocked roads and damaged infrastructure at an Eskom service centre in Zola last week.
Protests broke out again on the National Highway next to Barcelona informal settlement. Residents are furious that portable and communal toilets havent been cleaned for weeks.
Animal activists in East London, supported by the East London Animal Warriors, have staged demonstrations before every performance at the Mclarens circus.
Parents demonstrated at the Avondale School in Atlantis. They are demanding the construction of a new building.
The admissions office at NMMU was temporarily shut down by about 25 students who staged a protest.
A dispute over the allocation of government houses led to the N2 being temporarily shut after protesting residents blocked the road with burning tyres in Ethembeni, KwaDukuza.
Protests continued on the roads next to Barcelona. While police arrived there were no reports of contact between the protesting residents and the police.
Parents protested outside a school in Philippi. Approximately 200 parents, students and teachers stood outside the school gates forcing the school to shut down.
An angry mob has assaulted a lawyer at a South African courthouse where he represented two men accused of murdering a young girl.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: ANC Youth League (ANCYL) members carrying bananas marched on the DAs headquarters in Gardens yesterday, burnt the provincial ruling parties flag and an effigy of Penny Sparrow.

Hundreds of angry pupils and their parents attacked a Limpopo circuit office. Pupils and parents threw stones, broke down the gate, and smashed windows at the local circuit office, forcing employees to flee. No one was injured during the violence.

Tshwane Metro Police officers fired rubber bullets at protesters outside of Tshwane Mayor Kgosientso Ramokgopas parent's home in Atteridgeville in Pretoria. Tyres were set alight, bricks were also packed in the road and protesters threatened to burn down Ramokgopas own home.

At least 500 people protested in Kempton Park, Johannesbury after a Nigerian man was killed while in police custody. Police respnded with by firing stun grenades and rubber bullets at protesters. Several people were injured during the incident.
A police officer was accidentally killed by an angry community, during a funeral, when he was mistaken for being a criminal.
Some residents of Kagiso went on a rampage in protests against their removal to a new area where the government planned to build RDP houses for them.
An ANC councillor was assaulted by angry community members, leaving him with head wounds and a broken finger.

Two men were shot dead in Inchanga. Although the motives are unknown, there is speculation that the killings were politically motivated. Five others were injured, 10 cars were damaged, and tyres were slashed.

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: Workers continued to protest at the Tshwane University of Technology (TUT) in pursuit of their demands under the banner of #OutsourcingMustFall.
The Walter Sisulu University's Butterworth campus was shut down following renewed protest action.
Residents of an informal settlement, near Lenasia, blocked streets with bricks and burning tyres in protest against poor service delivery.
At the Mahikeng campus of the North West Univesity, the campus was disrupted by protesting students.
A group of about 70 residents marched to the home of Buffalo City Metro councillor in Mdantsane Township.
Protests continued as protesters clashed with police in Kagiso. Nine people were arrested during the clashes. The rioters were demanding RDP houses.
In Lenasia, parents and pupils have protested the racism of the principal.
Masiphumelele High School learners boycotted school and instead marched to the Department of Education in Fish Hoek.

In Lusikisiki, protests turned ugly as residents allegedly stoned vehicles and houses. Police intervened in which residents responded by hurling stones at the 20-strong police. Reports of injuries have been noted, including the injury of a ward counciller.

Farm evictions in Paarl turned violent when workers pelted the police with stones to prevent them from evicting two families at the Lynquedoch farm. One person was reportedly injured, while several others were arrested.

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: Protesters forced Tuts University to remain closed in ongoing fees protests.
Mentally and physically-disabled UCT students spoke out about their exclusion and feelings of alienation on campus at a peaceful protest held at UCT.
Protests entered a third day in Kagiso. During the events, a police vechile drove over a man, killing him. The rioters were demanding RDP houses from the government.
Thousands of DA supporters marched for jobs in the Johannesburg CBD.

A 5000-strong crowd marched on the police station from two directions. As tensions flared, community members, who were not part of the mob, were also pelted with rocks. Police shot rubber bullets and tear gas at the demonstrators.
Following the attack on protesters, police opened fire with rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse the violent groups.

Protesters, including workers and students, gathered at Tuts University in ongoing fees protests. Following, these protesters were attacked by SASCO members who emerged with bricks and bottles, which they began to throw at the workers who were sitting down. One worker was injured and was bleeding heavily.
Eskom workers, supported by NUM and NUMSA, embarked on a work stoppage protest in in Booysens, Pretoria.
About 10 students, believed to be members of the Stellenbosch Fees Must Fall movement, protested outside the Admin building of Stellenbosch Univeristy.

Several hundred residents of a Durban hotel went on the rampage. Residents barricaded the road with burning tyres and rubbish bins and when police tried to control the crowd, protesters threw stones at them and looted shops.
More than 100 disgruntled residents protested outside the East London City Hall demanding electricity connections and the removal of their ward councillor.
Residents gathered in Lusikisiki in continuing protests over the appoitment of a local councillor. Residents gathered and blocked the road but there are no reports of violence or arrests.

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: Workers and students defied a court order and contiued to protest out the campus of Tuts University in Pretoria.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Workers, aligned to SAMWU, held a demonstration in Braamfontein outside Pikitup offices after members were called in for a disciplinary hearing.
Outside the land claims court in Randburg, Johannesburg, protesters wearing green Afra T-shirts protested and waved placard to highlight the lack of land reform.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: About 100 people protested outside the Western Cape Legislature in Cape Town, demanding that Avondale Primary School in Atlantis be made safe for learning.
After a teacher incited violence amongst different racial groups in a school, a riot ensued in which desk and chairs were broken.
Protesters demonstrated outside the Wynberg Magistrates Court to protest against recent murders in the area.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Thousands of Cosatu members staged a picket outside the Treasury offices in Pietermaritzburg to protest new tax regulations.

At a SACP event in Turfloop in Limpopo, ANC members allegedly disrupted the meeting, collapsing the marquee in which the meeting was being held, disconnecting the power supply and switching off the sound system.
Chaos erupted at an annual meeting in Port Elizabeth when rugby officials fought their way past security officials and disrupted the meeting in protest.

Land Invaders protested at a site in Etwatwa, many of whom were EFF members. During negotiations between police and land invaders, Red Ants official arrived and began to destroy temporary homes without consulting or discussing the issue with anyone. This prompted the land invaders to charge at the Red Ants with sticks. The situation was diffused before it could degenerate into more violence.
In Mthatha, a man was killed, three people were severely injured and three houses were torched when residents took revenge on suspected gang members after the killing of a 19-year old taxi driver.

Tensions between ANC factions in Stinkwater, north of Pretoria, continue to simmer with party members attacked. Shots were fired into the home of the Tshwane MMC for corporate services and her son had to seek refuge in a shop owned by his father. One man was hit and is reportedly in critical condition in hospital.
As of Feb.20 Maake had witnessed three incidents of vigilante justice involving the killing of a suspected criminals. Other incidents coded separately.

Parents, led by the Nationalist Coloured Party, protested in Sidwell in the Neslon Mandela Metropolitan Area. A heavy police presence prevented them from entering the buillding in which one protester was allegedly injured by police when the protesters attempted to get through the wall of police officers.
Bus drivers blocked road throughout Durban, inclding major roads in Umlazi in protest over salaries.

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: Workers, supported by the EFF Student Commanda,have protested on the first day of University at Tuts in Pretoria.
Bus drivers blocked road throughout Durban, inclding major roads in Kwamashu in protest over salaries.
A soldier was stoned to death in Hartbeespoort Dam near Brits. The deceased was allegedly a full-fledged soldier in the SANDF.
A Khayelitsha teenager has been found dead in an open field after an alleged vigilante attack but local residents.
Students and Parents protested in Kwadukuza over the arrest of two students.
Protesters gather outside the Umzimkulu court to protest against the killing of two children.
ANC and SACP supporters protested and almost clashed outside a court house of 5 accused murderers in Camperdown, KZN.
Parents and Teachers demonstrated outside the Westville High School in Port Elizabeth as part of ongoing protests in the region.

At the Tshwane University of Technology, outsource protests turned ugly when police fired teargas and stun grenades at protesting workers and students. Some protesters fleeing from police then started stoning private cars that they came across.
R2K protesters took to the streets in their hundreds to protest the electrictiy hikes by ESKOM.

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Students (South Africa)
column17: About 30 students, security and cleaning staff, many of whom are EFF supporters, have been arrested during a protest at the Steve Biko Campus in Durban.
Protesters blocked all the exits in and out of the town of Sabie as a result of electricity being cut. Police disperse the rioters with rubber bullets.
Health workers protested in front of the managing-directors office at the Dora Nginza Hospital with placards saying ""Quangule must fall"".
The National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) picketed outside Afrisam Mine near Ulco in the Northern Cape, accusing it of racism.

column7: SWEAT: Sex Workers Education and Advocacy Taskforce
column17: Members of SWEAT gathered outside the Western Cape High Court to protest against the slow trail of murder suspects.
Nurses at the Empilweni Tuberculosis Hospital in New Brighton started protesting because their hospital has no chief executive.

Parents and Students continued protest action when they burnt tyres and started fires. When the police arrived, the tension rose and tear gas was used in response to protesters throwing stones at police.
Hundreds of people gathered outside the Natal Zoological Gardens near Camperdown to demand that Opal, an orangutan, be moved from solitary confinement to a better facility.
A man believed to have engaged in break-ins in the area was killed by suspected vigilantes.
DASO members began to stage a sit-in protest at the NMMU in Port Elizabeth.
The first day of lectures at NMMU were disrupted by protest action. DASA continued to stage a sit-in protest at the university.
Khoisan leaders protested outside Parliament, trying to force their way inside to demand feed-back on a range of grievances. Fires were reportedly also set aligned in traditional ceremony.
About 300 angry Silvertown shack dwellers blockaded the main roads into the township, using various items, in protest over service delivery.
Motorists had to find alternative routes after Mayville residents blockaded part of King Cetshwayo Highway complaining about a lack of electricity.
Service delivery protests have been going on since Monday the 8th in Riverlea.
Pupils and parents descended on the office of the Education Department in Zwelitsha to protest over school administration.
Durban University of Technology students had barely sat down for their first class when protest action by the SRC forced the suspension of the academic programme.
Residents held a picket in Newlands East over housing allocation.
DASO members continue to protest by staging a sit-in protest at NMMU.
Four people were arrested in the latest education-related protests in Bethelsdorp. Protesters burnt tyres and blocked the road in the Bethelsdorp area.
EFF members demonstrated outside the Constitutional Court in Braamfontein to protest the Nkandla Scandal gripping the country.
About 200 DA supporters gathered outside the Despatch town hall to protest the water leaks in Nelson Mandela Bay area.
Service delivery protests have been going on since Monday the 8th in Riverlea.
A suspected housebreaker was killed by a mob in Tickyline Village near Tzaneen after a pensioner was robbed

column7: Police Forces of South Africa (1994-) Prison Guards; Vigilante Group (South Africa)
column17: A correctional officer has been arrested for participating in a mob attack in Worcester which left one man dead.
Hundreds of Masiphumelele High School pupils staged a protest outside the school, barricading the gate with burning tyres and calling for the removal of the principal.
Operations at Walter Sisulu Universitys (WSU) Buffalo City Campus (BCC) in East London came to standstill when students disrupted lectures and protested.
Butterworth was on lockdown as hundreds of residents, led by the Mnquma Forum Against Corruption, took to the streets demanding that the Mnquma mayor, municipal manager and speaker be removed.
Stones were hurled at police and passers-by by community members in Robert Sobukwe Drive (near Bishop Lavis) after a suspected gang member was arrested.
Protesters took to the streets, burning tyres, in New Brighton over service delivery.

column7: AMI: Alternative Mining Indaba; Students (South Africa)
column17: Two peaceful demonstrations took place in Cape Town. The first saw a sit-in outside the International Convention Centre in Cape Town, supported by the Alternative Mining Indaba and the Economic Justice Network. In the second event, students of Uxolo High School and Sizimisele Technical High School marched to the Western Cape Department of Education in Cape Town.

column7: SALIPSWU: South African Liberated Public Sector Workers Union
column17: Workers and Cleaners downed tools and held peaceful protests outside UKZNs Howard and Westiville campuses. A memorandum was handed over by the South African Liberated Public Sector Workers Union

column7: DASO: Democratic Alliance Students Organisation; SASCO: South Africa Students Congress
column17: DASO and SASCO members continue to protest by staging a sit-in protest at NMMU.
Parents protested outside a school in Dunoon over the lack of space in the local schools.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: ANCYL members protested outside the offices of The Witness Newspaper in Pietermaritzburg.
Protesters took to the streets, burning tyres in Riverlea. Police responded by firing rubber bullets at the protesters

column7: SALIPSWU: South African Liberated Public Sector Workers Union
column17: Workers and Cleaners downed tools and held peaceful protests outside UKZNs Howard and Westiville campuses. A memorandum was handed over by the South African Liberated Public Sector Workers Union
Right2Know protesters are banned from protesting outside parliament so launch an anti-Zuma protest alongside Bhunga Avenue Kewton instead.
About 60 employees of Lafarge South Africa gathered at the companies Lichtenburg plant to protest after an agreement on their demands was not reached during negotiations.
A march took place in Pretoria by the #ZumaMustFall movement in a series of nationwide marches for the state of the union address.

column7: SPRM: Seskhona Peoples Rights Movement; EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters
column17: Ses'khona People's Rights Movement have taken to the streets despite the group only having permission for a gathering in Cape Town. Protesters attempted to beak through a police fence but were held back. There were reports that stones and bottles were thrown at police. Later in the day, police clash with rioting EFF supporters during an anti-Zuma demonstration in central Cape Town.

Residents took to the streets over water bills in Turfloop in Limpopo. The protest was met with burning tyres, timbers and drainage pipes, causing the police to use teargas and rubber bullets to disperse the protesters.
About 250 residents blocked roads with burning tyres in New Brighton over the lack of service delivery.

column7: #ZumaMustFall; PAC: Pan African Congress; Students (South Africa)
column17: Peaceful demonstrations were held in Cape Town by #ZumaMustFall, PAC and students.
About 60 #ZumaMustFall protesters took to the streets in Durban.
Two of three suspected robbers were killed after residents of Maake village attacked them for allegedly robbing a local supermarket.
Hundreds of ANC members rallied in East London and threatened to make the city ungovernable if the party leadership does not dissolve its regionals structure.
About 100 residents frustrated by train delays torched a minibus taxi and overturned two delivery vehicles before police arrived and arrested one person.

Service delivery protesters blocked the R72 near Zuney, just outside Alexandria. Some motorists attempted to move the branches the protesters used to block the road but were chased off without reported injuries.
A group of nurses marched to the SA Nursing Council in Pretoria to demand better working conditions, before marching on to the department headquarters after no official would hear their grievances.
Some students built a shack on the UCT campus as part of the #RhodesMustFall protest against a lack of student housing at UCT.

Hundreds of residents demonstrated against poor service delivery, using burning tires and other material to block roads. They clashed with police, who used tear gas, stun grenades, and rubber bullets to disperse them.
Students protested on the DUT campus following a student suicide related to a rejected funding application on Friday. The students were dispersed by police using stun grenades and pellet guns.
Protests over fees hit the DUTs Pietermaritzburg campus as well as its Durban campus, following a student suicide over a rejected funding application.
During service delivery protests, some residents in the Booysen Park area attempted to clear a blocked road and ended up in a clash with the protesters who were largely Xhosa.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: As many as 500 SAMWU members marched in Pietermaritzburg against casual labour. They demanded that contract and casual labourers be made permanent employees.
About 60 high school students led by an EE representative protested outside the Department of Education offices in King Williams Town to demand their matric certificates.

Students at WSU have engaged in violent protests between Feb.16-17, burning university property and vehicles, and looting cafeterias. The campus was shut down in response to the ongoing violence on Feb.16, with students being told to vacate their residences until calm could be restored.

The #RhodesMustFall ""Shackville"" protest at UCT escalated after students broke into some residences and burnt university art and vehicles before police were able to intervene and disperse the protesters with stun grenades, while arresting 8. At least 6 students were suspended following the violence. At least 2 buildings were hit by petrol bombs, including the office of the Vice-Chancellor, although reports conflicted on whether this occurred during the protests on Feb.16 or 17.

Residents of Sabie protested to demand a vacant piece of land be given to them to build houses. During the protests a truck was burnt, roads were barricaded, and the residents threatened to set fire to a number of buildings, including the local hospital.

9 students, including an SRC leader, were arrested as private security and police cracked down on a protest by outsourced workers at the University of KwaZulu-Natal. The students were allegedly throwing stones at buildings and were protesting illegally.
#FeesWillFall student protesters protested to demand the suspesion of academic programmes so that the process of clearing debt, registration and residence placement can be completed.
North West Universitys Mahikeng Campus was shut down after ""enraged students demanded that suspended SRC president Benz Mabengwane be reinstated.""

Students at WSU have engaged in violent protests between Feb.16-17, burning university property and vehicles, and looting cafeterias. The campus was shut down in response to the ongoing violence on Feb.16, with students being told to vacate their residences until calm could be restored.

A group of 30 UCT students occupied the universities administrative building to protest against the arrest and suspension of students in relation to the recent #RhodesMustFall ""shackville"" protests. They left half an hour later.

column7: DENOSA: Democratic Nursing Organisation of South Africa; Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Around 1000 DENOSA members protested against the bad treatment of nurses in the province in Bhisho.
Between 150 to 200 protesting employees of the High Court in Pietermaritzburg demanded that their grievances be addressed by picketing inside the building.

A group of residents of Kanana in Hammanskraal took to the streets and marched to give a memorandum to their ward councillor after other residents of the area started building shacks illegally on empty land.

Students picketed outside the Western Cape Department of Education offices, demanding the end of the collaborative schools pilot project which is believed to be leading to the privatization of education.
A bus was set on fire during violent protests on the Wits University campus.

Scuffles broke out between students at the University of Pretoria over the institutions language policy. Members of the ANC, AfriForum Yotuh, the PYA and the EFFSC were all present. It was not clear which groups were involved in the clash. Later police arrived and clashed with the students who armed themselves with stones and set at least one tire on fire. 14 students were then arrested.
Nine people were arrested after protests on February 18 which saw residents plunder the home of two alleged murder suspects.
Residents of the Reeston area barricaded the only school in the area with tires and trees to demand housing and a meeting with their councillor.
AN EFF member was stabbed in the stomach during clashes with ANC members outside the Provincial government complex in Nelspruit.

Residents of Phagameng in Modimolle protested and blocked roads, including those between Modimolle and Naboomspruit, over water shortages. The protests later became violent, with police and demonstrators fighting for hours. The protesters threw rubble at police and forced stores to close, while the police opened fire with rubber bullets. At least 3 protesters were injured.
Angry pupils of Tshehlwaneng in Jane Furse burned classrooms and staffrooms while vandalizing others during a protest against the principal, who they say assaults them.

Residents from Schoemansdal, Driekoppies, Jeppes Reef, Buffelspruit and other areas marched to the Schoemansdal police station to protest the slow pace of police investigations into car thefts in the area.

column9: SANCO: South African National Civics Organization
column17: 9 people were arrested in Cofimvaba following a clash between ANC members and Nyanisweni residents led by SANCO members during a protest related to house demolitions.
A handful of ANC members protested outside the Western Cape legislature ahead of the State of the Province address by the premier.
14 people were arrested after protests at the University of Witwatersrand led to a bus and a mattress being set on fire.
A group of residents of Pharare Village in the area of Maake killed a man who was accused of being responsibl for a series of break-ins recently.

Two opposing protests occurred outside the Parys town magistrates court, one in favour of the 4 farmers charged with shooting two black men after they attacked an elderly landowner, and the other made up of about 200 black demonstrators in favour of the death penalty for the farmers.
Thousands of ANC supporters marched for ""unity, democracy"" and against racism in Pretoria.

Students protested on the University of Pretoria campus to demand the end of instruction in Afrikaans. The students burned tires and threw rocks at police, who responded with rubber bullets. The protests also spilled onto nearby streets. The EFF says that 27 students were later arrested.
500 youths from the YFN marched from the Pier 14 shopping centre to Nelson Mandela Bays city hall to demand a crackdown on crime.
Between Feb.20-21, Vigilantes in Schoemansdal arrested five people suspected of being criminals who have been caused trouble in the area. Two of them were beaten to death and then set on fire.
Between Feb.20-21, Vigilantes in Schoemansdal arrested five people suspected of being criminals who have been caused trouble in the area. Two of them were beaten to death and then set on fire.

About 100 students caused disruptions throughout the Durban University of Technologys campus, discharging fire extinguishers, throwing stones, destroying property and attacking people over a lack of accommodations.
Gauteng Councillor Mbuyiselo Dokolwane was shot dead in Freedom Park in Johannesburg. It was not clear what led to the shooting.
Disgruntled residents of Shakas Head village torched their ward councillors home and car and barricaded the N2 highway near Ballito over the ANCs nomination of a candidate they disagreed with.

column16: Cape Times; AOL News; Cape Argus
column17: Classes at UWC have been disrupted and university property damaged in three days of protests against outsourcing between Feb.22-24. #FeesMustFall protesters and outsourced workers clashed with police and university security during the protests.

column16: The Journalist (South Africa); Daily Vox (South Africa); Herald (South Africa)
column17: Student protesters were attacked by spectators when they attempted to occupy a Rugby pitch during a match. The protests were in support of outsourced workers on strike at the university. Police later arrived to restore calm. Some injuries were reported.

Violence broke out between black students, largely from the EFF, and white students, largely aligned with Afriforum, over language policy and larger issues over how the University of Pretoria should be run (e.g. renaming it to the University of Tshwane). Both groups fought and threw stones at each other, with at least two students injured. Police attempted to separate them, and at least 29 students werwe arrested.
4 people were arrested after two Metrorail trains were torched and two others pelted with stones in Pretoria. 5 buses were also burned. It is not clear what motivated the vandalism.
A group of protesters blocked a road in Zwide with burning tires to demand the resignation of the Ward 25 councillor.

Residents of Siqalo, a poor informal settlement near Mitchells Plain, who worked for Silver Solutions blocked Vanguard Drive with portable toilets and burning tires, as well as damaged traffic lights, during a 48 hour protest over working conditions

Students at Jan Masibi Middle School in Disaneng village near Mafikeng, rioted in their school, breaking windows and damaging ceilings until police were called to get them under control. They say they were angry about assaults carried out by the schools teachers.
A group of about 50 social work graduates marched in their graduation gowns from Nangoza Jebe Hall in New Brighton to the Social Development offices in Struandale for employment.

Residents of Phagameng township near Modimolle engaged in violent protests over service delivery and demands that their mayor and councillors step down. Some youths burned tires while police used rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse the protesters.
After an anti-land invasion unit began demolishing structures in an open field in Parkwood Estate, residents retaliated by throwing stones at police and burning tires. 4 people were later arrested.

A group of concerned parents picketed the Sosebenza Primary School in Khayelitsha following allegations that the principal and staff are corrupt. Some arguments broke out when the principal came outside, but no violence was reported.

column16: Cape Argus; AOL News; Cape Times
column17: Classes at UWC have been disrupted and university property damaged in three days of protests against outsourcing between Feb.22-24. #FeesMustFall protesters and outsourced workers clashed with police and university security during the protests.

""1 woman was shot dead and another wounded in Dunoon when police allegedly opened fire on a taxi"" which was carrying the two women employed at a Nandos franchise. It is not clear why the police opened fire on the taxi.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Thousands of Buffalo City Metropolitan Municipality workers organized by SAMWU marched to East London city hall demanding a salary increase and back pay.
""Scores of people living in an informal settlement destroyed government houses that were under construction in Sir Lowrys Pass"" which were meant for residents of the area waiting for housing.
Taxi drivers blockaded entrances to Tongaat after a man was arrested for intimidating an alleged ""lift club operator"".

Several students at the Mafikeng campus of the NWU were injured when they clashed with campus security. The students were allegedly attempting to disrupt an event to inaugurate a new SRC. A car belonging to a security company and two buildings, including an administrative one, were torched by students during the incident, who also threw rocks.

column16: Cape Argus; Cape Times; AOL News
column17: Classes at UWC have been disrupted and university property damaged in three days of protests against outsourcing between Feb.22-24. #FeesMustFall protesters and outsourced workers clashed with police and university security during the protests.

More than 400 residents from various Mhlontlo municipalities took to the streets to demand the removal of the political leadership of their wards and for the municipality to be placed undr administration. Police later arrived and threw stune grenades, causing some protesters to flee.

Residents of Siqalo, a poor informal settlement near Mitchells Plain, blocked Vanguard Drive with portable toilets and burning tires, as well as damaged traffic lights, during a 48 hour protest over service delivery.

Striking workers demanding full-time employment engaged in violent protests on the Westville campus of the University of KwaZulu-Natal. The protesters threw rocks at vehicles and flipped at least one campus security vehicle.

Hundreds of University of Pretoria students walked silently on the universities campus, which had been closed due to recent protests, in a #PrayerWalk to ""seek divine intervention to resolve racial tensions"" at the institution.

Violent protests occurred on the University of Free States campus after the institution did not force the vice chancellor to resign. Police used stun grenades and rubber bullets to disperse the protester, and arrested several of them.
A group of at least 3,000 protesters engaged in violent service delivery protests in Folweni, attacking municipal offices with petrol-bombs and damaging at least one municipal vehicle.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Hundreds of municipal workers, organized by SAMWU, marched through the streets of Johannesburg to demand an end to corruption within municipal structures and call attention to salary and tax concerns.
Between Feb.25-26, 16 houses were petrol-bombed and at least 100 others damaged by community members who were prevented from illegally moving into the structures in the Sir Lowrys Pass area.
Violent protests over service delivery continued in Phagameng in the Modimolle area.
Between Feb.25-26, 16 houses were petrol-bombed and at least 100 others damaged by community members who were prevented from illegally moving into the structures in the Sir Lowrys Pass area.
A group of residents of Endlovini informal settlement in Khayelitsha closed down a Somali shop after a protest on the 27th February 2016.
In response to Cape Towns annual gay pride march, a few hundred supporters of Alternative Inclusive Pride protested against the main event, accusing it of excluding lesbians and black people.
Residents and police of Boksburg engaged in a motorcycle procession to protest against police killings in the area.

At a community meetingin Austerville, a group of unhappy residents disrupted a Q&A session. The dispute culminated clashes and fist-fights occurring between residents, government officials and local security.
A 23-year-old man accused of killing a woman was attacked and set alight by an angry mob in Tibanefontein, Limpopo
A small group of Campaign Against Canned Hunting, and Beauty Without Cruelty supporters picketed outside the Rhebokskloof Wine Farm in Paarl.

About 500 students marched at TUTs Soshanguve campus. Forming a human chain on the streets of the township north of Pretoria, the students sang songs as they protested. Although security was present, there was no violence reported.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: About 100 Bhisho Legislature employees downed tools and protested outside ANC caucus offices against its next planned MPL.
Workers demanding an end to outsourcing clashed with officers of a private security company which had been hired by the University of the Western Cape.

Violence broke out at the Tshwane University of Technology (TUT) when striking outsourced workers clashed with their working colleagues. Four workers were attacked by the striking guards. The guards retaliated, but sustained injuries and were taken to hospital.

On 1 March 2016, around 500 residents of the Mandela informal settlement destroyed several foreign national shops in east of Johannesburg (Gauteng). The attacks started after a Pakistani national shop owner allegedly shot and killed two residents earlier the week after he refused to accept the return of some meat. [size=around 500]
A group of outsourced workers at Unisa in Pretoria downed tools and protested over a wage dispute.
Fourteen Nigerians fled Wolseley after crowd marches against them, loots their shops, and accuses them of murder and drug-dealing.
About 100 nursing students from Cape Peninsula University of Technologys Athlone campus marched to the Provincial Legislature to protest a cut in the number of their bursaries.
protests in Folweni resulted in the destruction of a newly built fire station.
Hundreds of College of Cape Town (Crawford) students protested at the Athlone Campus because they had not received their full bursaries.
More than 200 disgruntled members of the taxi industry rode in a cavalcade through the streets of George in protest.

Joburg motorists were confronted by an angry mob from the Jeppe Hostel who surrounded their vehicles and demanded that they turn around. A truck and a bakkie were torched, with police who tried to intervene pelted with stones and debris by a group from the George Goch Hostel who had congregated in Ruven Road near the M2 highway.
A protest over electricity in Delft, turned violent after protesters blocked the N2 and Symphony Way setting vehicles alight. Three protesters were arrested. No injuries have been reported.
About 200 Rastafarians protested outside the Parliament buildings in Cape Town.
Grahamstown residents, marched to the towns police station, following the alleged harassment on 19 February of vocal student activist Lihle Ngcobozi.
Protests took place in the the Cape Town CBD by residents of Gugulethu.
Reclaim the City campaigners marched through Sea Point in protest against the provinces sale of a R135 million property to the Phyllis Jowell School.
Protests continued at the Crawford campus in Athlone by students unhappy with the transport allowances.
Violence erupted when a group of residents torched five RDP homes in New Horizons, claiming the communities concerns over housing issues had fallen on deaf ears.
EFF and Afriforum members gathered in Stellenbosch in a tense stand-off. No violence or clashes were reported in the peaceful displays.
Residents went on the rampage and blockaded sreets in Gerena rental village in Polokwane.
A group of about 300 students are protesting for an increase in bursary payouts at the Boland College in Strand
An Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) tent was allegedly set alight in Ennerdale, south of Johannesburg.
Protests started at the King Sabata Dalindyebo college in Elliotdale when 60 students did not receive some of their final year results.

Protest action has taken place. Eight students are arrested after one lecturer is allegedly held hostage and property is damaged in protest action at the Northlink college in Bellville. No direct interactions between demonstrators and police mentioned during the actual protests.
A school and shop were set alight at Masakona village in Limpopo, allegedly by a group opposing governments plan to include them under a new municipality.
Unidentified people suspected of being striking municipal workers have burnt two vehicles belonging to the City of Tshwane (CDB) in separate attacks.

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: Protesting students and workers disrupted the last day of the fifth annual Research and Innovation Week at UNISA in Pretoria.
A group protesting Vumani blockaded roads and pelted police vehicles with rocks. Police fired rubber bullets to disperse protesters who had blockaded the road.
In Plettenberg Bay, protesters continued to take action burning tyres on the streets.
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country: Ethekweni
Protests which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country: Taung
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country:Mogalakwena
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country: Nelson Mandela Bay
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country: Melmoth.
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country: Jozini, Ethekweni.
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country: Wentworth.
In Ward 5, Amahlathi Municipality protesters burnt registration materials, including a scanner and voters roll.
In Plettenberg Bay, protesters continued to take action allegedly throwing tyres at passing cars.

column16: Congress of the People (South Africa); Business Live (South Africa)
column17: Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country:Denver
Staff were withdrawn from two voter registration stations in Khayelitsha, Cape Town after a group of protesters apparently tried blocking the entrances.
Two EFF party members were hospitalised following a mob attack by apparent ANC members during voter registration in the Nkomazi region, Mpumalanga.
In Mitchells Plan, community members turned on police clashing some officials and damaging police vehicles.
Protests in Ennerdale have continued over local elections.
Police were called into Mhlontlo district, as residents forced polling stations to close.

Three voter registration stations were forced to close following community protests in the area of Pampierstad. Residents protesting over demarcation issues stormed the three tents used as temporary registration centres on Saturday. They destroyed the tents, equipment and documents, including the voters roll.
Police were called into Mazeni after angry residents shut down a locale school where voting registration was taking place.
Protest action took place during voter registration at Weenen in KZN.
During voter registration, residents in Wonderkop prevented voters from registering. People were protesting over lack of jobs anf high unemployment in the area.
Protests relating to different matters prevented the opening of two Independent Electoral Commission of South Africa (IEC) stations in Marite, Mpumalanga.
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country: Northampton
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country: Jozini
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country: Musina
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country: Maluti-a-Phofung
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country: Butterworth
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country:George Koch
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country: OR Tambo
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country: Organge Farm
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country: Mafikeng
Protest continued into their second day during voter registration in Orange Farm. Police responded by firing tear gas and rubber bullets in an attempt to disperse the crowd.
Protested which affected voting stations occurred throughout the country and continued into its second day: Jozini, Ethekweni.
An angry crowd in Samora Machel, Philippi destroyed a scrap metal business, accusing the owner of responsibility for a car accident in which three school children were hurt.
In protest action in Umlazi, residents allegedly threw rocks at an ambulance which was trying to assistance someone in trouble.

column6: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column9: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: An ANC Youth League (ANCYL) regional chairperson allegedly kicked and throttled his comrade until he suffered internal bleeding in Katlehong.
Angry ANC members blockaded roads in KaNyamazane township outside Mbombela with burning tyres, stones and bricks and the N4 freeway. Protesters reportedly threw stones at police vehicles.
In Mhlontlo, residents of Ward 8 boycotted registration and attempted to shut down voting stations, but police were called immediately
Residents held protests at Nompumelelo Township in Beacon Bay after rubbish had not been collected for weeks.
On the 6th March, protester took to the streets in Mandeni, KZN.
Protests continued in Strand as students gather outside the campus buildings
Police fired rubber bullets to disperse protesters who wre intimidating Independent Electoral Commission officials, blocking roads and stonging police vehicles
Protests over voter registration continued for a second day in Jozini. Reports indicate the burning of a house and vehicle of the councillor in Jozini.
On 7 March 2016, a foreign national was shot and killed by unidentified individuals in Katlehong (Gauteng). Xenophobic tensions were registered during the week in the region.
Protests continued at the King Sabata Dalindyebo college in Elliotdale.
A group of people held a demonstration outside the Western Cape Education Departments (WCED) office in the Cape Town CBD.
Protests continued at the Northlink College in Bellville by angry students.
Protests by community members turned violent when four factories, a truck, two vehicles and five containers were set alight. Police vehicles were also damaged by the protesters.
After several shacks were destroyed, community member took to the streets. They burnt waste and debris on the road, stopping vehicles as they demanded that the unit halt the demolition
Ongoing protests at the King Sabata Dalindyebo college in Elliotdale descended into violence when students clashed with private security and police forces.

column7: BAF: Black Academics Forum; Teachers (South Africa)
column17: UCTs Black Academic Caucus (BAC) has held silent protests at the university.
Protests continued at the Northlink College in Bellville by angry students.
Protesters continued to protest in Isithebe where property and a truck was burnt. Vehicles were also pelted with stones in the third day of protest action.
Hundreds of Capetonians gathered at Tokai Forest for a silent march a day after the murder of 16-year-old Franziska Blichliger
Residents from the informal settlement Zandspruit, on Johannesburgs East Rand, were rioting, burning tyres and throwing rocks.
Protests continued at the Northlink College in Bellville by angry students.
The home of the Mokgophong mayor was under heavy police guard after protesters attacked the house with stones.
As night descended, protests turned violent as petrol bombs were thrown and a factory was damaged.
Angry farmworkers who say they were unfairly dismissed from a farm in Philippi have blockaded the gates of the farm, preventing the sale of produce.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: NEHAWU members protested outside the Bhisho Legislature over the appointment of an ANC MPL.
Members of the organisation Trans Collective disrupted the RhodesMustFall exhibition at UCT. Students smeared photographs with red paint and blocked the entrances to the exhibition.

A large crowd of protesters demanded the release of 120 prisoners as protests continue in Isithebe. Police responded with tear gas and rubber bullets. Later, petrol bombs were thrown and a factory was damaged.
Streets signage and sidewalk barriers were damaged as residents of Malusi informal settlement near Pretoria North suburbs went on a rampage, blocking major roads and burning tyres.
Residents from Ward 41 staged a sit-in at the offices of the Housing Development Agency (HDA) in Port Elizabeth.

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: Violence erupted outside the UNISA main campus in Pretoria as students blockaded roads in violation of the court order obtained by the university. Police responded and dispersed the protesters with rubber bullets.

Police arrested fourteen people and fired tear gas and stun grenades in Gelvandale after parents protested, blocked the road and obstructed traffic. A member of the Nationalist Couloured Party was one of the arrested.

Angry residents of Gomora informal settlement in Daspoort, Pretoria have taken to the streets to protest over a lack of service delivery. Streets were blocked with burning plastic bins, vehicle tyres and stones

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Workers protested under the banner of the SA Municipal Workers Union (Samwu) as they made their way from various Pikitup depots across Joburg central to Samwu House in the Joburg CBD.
After student attempted to disrupt classes, private security clashed with protesting students.
Angry housing contractors stormed the Port Elizabeth Wool Exchange Building, disrupting a human settlements workshop for contractors who had been allocated projects.
Residents of Modimolle renewed their protest as the area were blocked with large rocks and burning tyres.
Protesters took to the streets in anger over service delivery on the main routes linking Mqanduli to Coffee Bay and the Zithulele Hospitalin the Eastern Cape.
Workers are suspected of being responsible for the destruction of basement offices in the administration building at Stellenbosch University.
The parents of more than 100 pupils at a small school outside Grabouw participated in a protest march.
At Stellenbosch University, striking workers rioted at the campus, trashing parts of a building and turning over dustbins.
Desperate parents locked teachers out of Funiwe Primary School near King Williams Town and protested in the pouring rain.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Pikitup Workers, aligned to SAMWU, clashed with police, who used stun grenades, in the Johannesburg CBD in ongoing protests. One injury was reported.

Around 11 March 2016 (as reported), a man was killed and four others were injured by unidentified armed individuals in Katlehong (Gauteng). Several foreign-owned shops were looted and destroyed. [size=no report]
Supporters, angry about the death of a murdered teen, gathered and held placards outside the Wynberg Magistrates court.
In protest, workers stormed the East London City Hall on March 11 to demand an hourly R5 allowance and backpay from 2011.
A group of investors protested outside Durban Magistrates court demanding their money be paid back.
Residents have been protesting in Mookgophong.
A group of mothers gathered for a mass breast-feeding protest at Edgars in Cavendish Square, Claremont.
Students have been protesting in King Williams Town since Monday 14th March.

Protests continued in Mookgophong as streets were barricaded and four houses were set alight. Police also came under attack with petrol bombs thrown at a Nyala vehicle. In the ensuing chaos, one man was killed and 22 people were arrested.

About 1,000 people, aligned to the ANC, protested in Durban's Folweni area, blocking traffic and torching a lorry. Later, a fire station ans school office were burnt and police cars damaged. In response, police arrested 10 people.

Taxi Drivers have been protesting and destroying property since the 14th March in Joe Slovo informal settlement in Cape Town. Cars were stoned, a delivery truck set alight, the MyCiTi Phoenix station damaged and Democracy Road barricaded with burning tyres.
Angry parents, who attended a meeting in Port Elizabeth, became rowdy and started singing in protest. Some even blocked the exit through which the media were attempting to leave.
ANC and SACP members protested outside the Constitutional Court, in Johannesburg, over the release of Chirs Hanis murder.
Community members, lead by the MCPA, marched to the Mpukunyoni Traditional Council offices in protest against what they deem corrupt leadership.
The SJC (Social Justice Coalition) held a march from Town Two Clinic to Harare in Khayelitsha.
A MyCiTi bus operating along Route 251 in Century City was stoned as Taxi drivers continued to strike.
Students have been protesting in King Williams Town since Monday 14th March.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Police threw stun grenades at protesters wearing NEHAWU t-shirts in Port Elizabeth.
On the 15th March, the leader of the previous days protest was attacked at his home resulting in his trucking being destroyed.
A man was shot and killed at the Glebelands hostel, Umlazi in another killing in the troubled area.
Protesting Zandspruit residents destroyed a petrol station shop near their informal settlement in northern Johannesburg.
Taxi Drivers staged a march in the Johannesburg CBD against Uber, which they claim is operating illegally.
A police armoured vehicle was set alight, at least two police officers were wounded and businesses were looted when irate residents of Zandspruit informal settlement against electricity cuts.
A man was murdered by a group of community members because he was accused of carjacking on the 16 March 2016 in Zimbane Valley, Mthatha
Port Elizabeth College DA Students Organisation members protested outside the institutions main entrance saying they had been cheated out of two seats on the Students Representative Council.

column7: PASMA: Pan Africanist Student Movement of Azania; Students (South Africa)
column17: About 500 people, lead by PASMA and SASCO, chanted outside the administration office at the Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT) Cape Town campus earlier today demanding the removal of the vice-chancellor.
A mob attempting to torch a police station in ongoing protests in Folweni, KZN. A Municipal vehicle was also torched as police fired stun grenades to disperse the crowd.

column7: DENOSA: Democratic Nursing Organisation of South Africa; Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: A small group of nurses, under the banner of the Democratic Nurses Organisation ofSouth Africa (Denosa), MARHED to the provincial legislature in Cape Town.
A large group of bus operators, supported by the Ses'khona People's Rights Movement, marched to the Cape Town Civic Centre.
Students have been protesting in King Williams Town since Monday 14th March.
Two houses were vandalised after a scuffle broke out between two rival groups (ANC and the UDM) in Veeplaas, Port Elizabeth

A liquor store and other shops were damaged in the riots and several cars were burnt out in ongoing protests in Zandspruit. Although there was a large police presence no reports of violence or arrests have been made.

column7: PASMA: Pan Africanist Student Movement of Azania; Students (South Africa)
column17: More than 500 student protesters disrupted lectures at the Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT) again to demand the removal of the universities vice-chancellor, Prince Nevhutalu
Numerous Shoprite workers protested against poor pay and their employment through labour brokers in Pretoria.
Teachers, students, parents and community members came out in their numbers to march against vandalism and crime in Lwazi Primary School in Gugulethu.
Hundreds of residents protested in Mookgophong over lack of services and the removal of a municipal leader.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: A DA Mayor was beaten with a knobkierie when workers, aligned to SAMWU, forced their way into his office and damaged property in Willowmore during a strike.
About 100 protesters held a picket outside the Wynberg Magistrate's Court.
KwaZulu-Natal police have arrested 16 people after they allegedly stoned a murder suspect to death at Candover near Mkhuze.
Hundreds of women in Alberton, Gauteng donned their sneakers to take part in the Global Million Women health March for Endometriosis.
A group of young people spent the day protesting outside the St George Hotel in Pretoria where the African National Congress national executive committee (NEC) members were meeting.
Residents and gangsters in Elsies River turned on firefighters who were trying to extinguish two cars set alight by gang members. They threw stones at the firefighters, forcing them to leave the area
A Reverand and a group of children from Biko Village near Reeston marched for 1.5km in support of people struggling to get jobs and coping with falling out of the economy.

The MyCiTi Dunoon station in Dunoon was attacked and vandalised by protesters. Protesters threw rocks and objects at the station building, causing damage to the glass panels and exterior of the building.
On 21 April 2016, a man who allegedly stabbed his girlfriend to death died in police cells, after he too was knifed in an ensuing mob justice attack in Mbekweni.
Two men were attacked by a group in Table View in an alleged vigilante attack. Reports said one of the victims was killed.
