Police fired shotgun rubber rounds and stun grenades to prevent protesters from further damaging a MyCiTi bus station and attacking officers. A petrol bomb was also thrown at a MyCiTi bus station
Riot police dispersed a mob of angry protesters who stoned cars and barricaded the R104 near Lethabong in Tshwane.
Metro Police said the area was relatively quiet after tyres were set alight by protesters in ongoing violence in Dunoon.
An anti-mining activist and the chairman of the Amadiba Crisis Committee was assassinated in his house in Mbizana.

column7: SATAWU: South African Transport and Allied Workers Union
column17: About 200 South African Transport and Allied Workers Union (SATAWU) members from Prasa marched to the offices in Cape Town station.
About 200 municipal rubbish removal workers disrupted morning rush-hour traffic in Umlazi in protest. There were no immediate reports of damages or injuries.
Pikitup workers continued their strike as they emptyed rubbish bins on the streets of the Johannesburg CBD in front of metro police.
100 angry Port Alfred residents gathered outside court in Port Alfred to protest violence against women and children.
An attack took place at a mine near Ulundi, resulting in an employee sustaining serious burn wounds to his left hand and an office block being burnt.
Nearly 400 protesters assembled on the sports field in Dunoon.
About 100 eThekwini municipality security guards stormed a meeting in Durban and inserted their pay grievances on the agenda.
Tyres were burnt and rubble strewn on the road during protest action in Glendale on the KZNs north coast.
In the latest vigilante attack, a man was killed in Khayelitsha, after he and an accomplice tried to rob a shop.
Protests outside the houses of drug dealers started in Ennerdale (1st day).
Municipal ANC officials stormed the house of an elderly women and damaged her property in Malende in Kwa-Zulu Natal.
In Siyabuswa, a government official was killed in what is thought to be an assassination-styled killing.
Residents marched for the second day (2nd of 3 days) to the homes of suspected drug-dealers in Ennerdale, South of Johannesburg.
In ongoing strikes, Pikitiup workers threw rocks at temporary workers. One man was stabbed in the violence several vehicles were damaged.
Protests outside the houses of drug dealers continued into their 3rd day in Ennerdale (3rd day).
A municipal worker, attending to a complaint, was killed and another injured while on a job at the weekend in Palm Ridge, Ekurhuleni.

On 29 March 2016, several foreign owned shops were looted by unidentified individuals in Katlehong (Gauteng). Locals were reportedly saying that foreign nationals were not welcome in the area. [size=no report]

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: SAMWU union leaders led hundreds of striking employees in a protest march in the Joburg CBD ahead of the start of their disciplinary hearings.
About 80 protesting taxi drivers and conductors blockaded the N2 and R102, at the Tugela Bridge on the KwaZulu-Natal North Coast.
A strike by taxi drivers has turned violent in the Durban city centre, with police firing teargas, shops closing and reports of looting.
Equal Education members marched 38km from New Hanover to Pitermaritzburg over two days.
Tyres and tarred poles were set alight last night as violent protests erupted in Mfuleni in Cape Town.
About 200 Port Elizabeth residents blocked roads in protest at delays in housing on the R334 and R335 roads in Port Elizabeth.

The Soweto house of the Joburg member of the mayoral committee (MMC) for environment and infrastructure services Matshidiso Mfikoe has been petrol-bombed. This is in the wake of soured relations between the SA Municipal Workers Union (Samwu) and Pikitup, which falls under Mfikoe's portfolio.
Protests began in Kliptown, Soweto on Wednesday night over electricity supply.

column7: Private Security Forces (South Africa); Students (South Africa)
column17: In protest action, a clash between private and protesting campus security guards broke out at the Walter Sisulu University in Mthatha. A stray bullet hit a student on the hand during the clash.

In violent protest action, a Daily Dispatch truck was attacked and damaged in the evening by unhappy rioters in Colchester. Police had to use stun grenades and fire rubber bullets to disperse angry protesters.
A small group of people, lead by a PAC activist, marched to to the Grand Parade to commemorate the 1960 protest against the pass laws when 30,000 people marched to the city centre from Langa.
Equal Education members marched 38km from New Hanover to Pitermaritzburg over two days.

In protest action over electricity, residents protested on the streets during the night. Reports claim that police had fired rubber bullets at the protesters after they had blocked roads with burning tyres and thrown stones at them.

Members of the Mfuleni community just outside of Cape Town attacked a Councillors home and set fire to the community hall. Almost 1 000 people blocked roads during the day by burning rubbish. They also threw rocks at vehicles passing by and assaulted some people.
About 500 protesters demanding employment from local mines have barricaded the R31 road between Kuruman and Hotazel with burning objects and rocks

EFF and ANC members clashed in Marikana in the build-up to local elections. One person is alleged to have been shot, another was stabbed several times and a vehicle torched as political infighting amongst political parties intensifies.
33 people were arrested during violent protest action in Port Shepstone. Police were forced to fire rubber bullets at disruptive taxi drivers in which property was allegedly damaged.
The Gauteng SACP, ANC, COSATU, SANCO supported by several organisations held a successful protest march to the Kgosi Mampuru Correctional Service Centre in Pretoria.
Two journalists and two members of a staunch anti-mining group on the Transkei Wild Coast were allegedly assaulted in Bizana when they were attacked at about 5pm.
A mob has attacked a 24-year old man and killed him in a vigilante-styled attack in a village near to Tzaneen.

A group of community members damaged state-owned properties at Mahikeng Police Station in which three state owned motor vehicles and a door of the police station were damaged. 15 suspects were arrested during which one of them was found in possession of a petrol bomb
Family members and residents reeling from the robbery and killing of businessman Daniel Jacobs, took to the streets in Motherwell in a march to highlight the scourge of crime in the area.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Members of the Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) in Mpumalanga picketed on the N4 toll in Middelburg.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Members of the Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) in Mpumalanga picketed on the N4 toll plaza in Ermelo.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Members of the Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) in Mpumalanga picketed on the N4 toll plaza at Nkomazi.
More than 200 residents in Port Elizabeth took to the streets, blocking major roads to protest against delays in the rebuilding and refurbishment of houses that had been promised by the municipality.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: A Pikitup truck was stoned in the Johannesburg CBD in ongoing protest action led by Pikitup workers affiliated with SAMWU.
Police used rubber bullets to disperse hundreds of angry residents blocking the R394 between Ntabankulu and eMaXesibeni (formerly known as Mount Ayliff). 10 people were arrested.
Protests disrupted lectures at the University of the Witwatersrands Braamfontein campus. In the chaos, students set alight seats in a Wits lecture hall, causing extensive damage

column7: IPOB: The Indigenous People of Biafra
column17: The Indigenous People of Biafra (Ipob) marched to Parliament to ask for help in securing the release of its leader Nnamdi Kanu.

column9: BPSA: The Bolsheviks Party South Africa
column17: Bolsheviks Party SA leader Seun Mogotji was shot and wounded at his home in Ntwane, Limpopo.

Violence started in Atteridgeville when residents protested as home owners started cutting off the illegal connections they had made. Protesters began throwing stones at homes and setting fire to the electrical poles they had formerly used to connect their shacks to.

column7: PAWUSA: Public and Allied Workers Union of South Africa; Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Provincial community health workers, led by Pawusa, closed a Bathurst clinic to protest not being given permanent employment or benefits.

In Elliotdale, a hostile group of rural villagers blocked the main road to Elliotdale, leaving schoolchildren, teachers, residents and civil servants stranded. Police used rubber bullets to disperse the protesters.
Led by Equal Education, hundreds of learners marched in King Williams Town to protest ack of education services.

column7: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union
column17: AMCU members, who have been striking for three weeks, used violence and damaged property. During the strike, 57 people were arrested by police.
A pickup truck was burnt and shops looted during an illegal protest in Boitumelong near Bloemhof. Four people were arrested by police.
Municipality property, its garden and three vehicles were damaged in violent protests in Paarl. Police arrested 23 people after the demonstration in connection with the violence.
Striking workers protested outside Old Mutual in Pinelands over pay increases.
On the road between Mthatha and Butterworth, protesters blocked the road, downed electricity poles and burnt water pipes in Dutywa in frustration over service delivery.
The house of a member of the Democratic Transport and Allied Workers Union was burnt down in Khayelitsha on April 6.
Philippis farming community staged a protest outside an event in protest over the aquifier.
Violence continued in Atteridgeville as residents left Broken glasses, rubbish, rocks blocking roads and burnt electricity poles after protest action.
200 residents protested outside the Blue Downs Magistrates Court as the two men accused of killing Kuils River mother Zarah Hector made their second appearance.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: COSATU in KwaZulu-Natal staged an e-toll protest, with just over 100 picketers gathering outside offices at the Marriannhill Toll Plaza

column7: SATAWU: South African Transport and Allied Workers Union; #GangsterismMustFall
column17: Metrorail workers, supported by SATAWU, held a protest at the Cape Town train station. At the same time, anti-gangsterism protesters and members of the #GangsterismMustFall shouted at the Cape Town civic centre, demanding to meet mayor Patricia de Lille in person at a picket.
Residents held a march to hand in a memorandum to the municipality and are demanding the Lekwa-Teemane local municipal council in the North West be dissolved.
A protest march took place and was led by the South African Communist Party (SACP) in Koster. The community is accusing the local Kgetleng municipality of alleged corruption.
Violence has erupted in Vuwani Limpopo as protesting residents intensify their action against the upcoming voter registration. Property was damaged in the violence.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Hundreds of workers affiliated to SAMWU protestedin the Johannesburg CBD, tossing garbage onto the streets and breaking concrete rubbish bins.
Classes at Lilitha Nursing College in East London were suspended, following student protests.

Protest action in Du Noon resulted in the disruption of MyCiti buses in Cape Town. It is understood that police used stun grenades earlier in the morning and several roads in the area were blocked off after fires were started by some protesters.

10 Metrorail were destroyed in suspected arsen attack in Cape Town. Although the attackers are unknown, the arsen occurred during a labour dispute between Metrorail and the South African Transport and Allied Workers Union (Satawu).
A man has been shot and wounded by the police who fired rubber bullets at protesters who were blocking roads with burning debris in Ennerdale.
On the last weekend of voter registration, protests erupted throughout the country: Estcourt.
A group of African National Congress (ANC) supporters has prevented the opening of a voting station in Kuyasa in Khayelitsha, Cape Town.
On the last weekend of voter registration, protests erupted throughout the country: Mfolozi.
On the last weekend of voter registration, protests erupted throughout the country: Ladysmith.

On the last weekend of voter registration, protests erupted throughout the country: Mbekweni. Officials closed stations in Mbekweni after disgruntled residents ransacked registration points and torched at least two tents.

On the last weekend of voter registration, protests erupted throughout the country: Mossel Bay. Officials closed stations Mossel Bay after disgruntled residents ransacked registration points and torched at least two tents.

On the last weekend of voter registration, protests erupted throughout the country: Mthatha. 26 people were arrested by public order police for allegedly forcefully closing a voting station and denying access to IEC staff.

On the last weekend of voter registration, protests erupted throughout the country: Ntabankulu. Six people were arrested for allegedly digging trenches on the gravel road with the intention of blocking other community members from registering to vote.
On the last weekend of voter registration, protests erupted throughout the country: Khayelitsha.
On the last weekend of voter registration, protests erupted throughout the country: Mqanduli.

On the last weekend of voter registration, protests erupted throughout the country: Wellington. A voting tent was reportedly burnt down in protests by residents and 23 arrested were reportedly made by police.
Protests continued in Vuweni as protesters burned 10 vehicles, including two police vans, during clashes with police
On 11 August 2016, demonstrators assaulted a Somali shopkeeper and vandalised his shop in Drieziek during a demonstration.

Protest action erupted in the streets of Drieziek over service delivery and lack of rubbish collection. A large group barricaded roads with debris, including large rocks and sticks. A boy was shot during the protest by a Somali shopkeeper as he sought to protest his shop from looting.
Protest action erupted in the streets of Tembisa. Reasons for the protest are unknown.

New political party, the Khoisan Revolution, marched to the offices of the Independent Electoral Commission of SA (IEC) in Upington in the Northern Cape over alleged irregularities with voter registration.
Residents from informal settlements in Mdantsane took to the streets, burning tyres and blocking roads while demanding houses from Buffalo City Metro. At least 5 people were arrested by the police.
Schools remained closed as protest action continued in Vumani over the reallocation of municipality zoning.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Scores of Uitzig Secondary pupils, joined by a group of parents and members of COSATU, took a train to the city centre and then marched to the provincial legislature in protest over the poor state of the schools.
The house of a suspected murder was set alight by residents in retaliation in Mabeskraal, outside Rustenburg.

column7: MKVMA: Mkhonto weSizwe Military Veterans Association
column17: uMkhonto We Sizwe Military Veterans Association protested outside the Western Cape High Court over the parole of Chris Hanis killer.

Protest action in Tembisa left two people injured and an Ekurhuleni metro police department (EMPD) vehicle badly damaged. Streets were left blocked with debris, including large rocks, dustbins, bricks and the remains of burnt refuse.
Protest action took place in Villa Liza in Ekurhuleni over the allocation of RDP housing.
Protesters, some of them Freedom Front Plus Members, gathered outside the a hall in Valhalla, Pretoria to protest against the building of a mosque.

Workers, aligned to the Joint Union Task Team (combination of Nehawu, CPUEU and the NTRU members), protested at the Cape Peninsula University of Technology Belville campus to demand that the university revise a 7 percent salary increase.
Protests continued into a second day in Drieziek over service delivery. As protesters threw rocks, the police retaliated with rubber bullets and teargas.

column7: JUTT: Joint Union Task Team; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: Workers, supported by JUTT, protested outside the graduation ceremony at the Cape Peninsula University of Technology Belville campus today.
A Crossroads councillors office was burnt down. As the unidentified attackers burnt down the office, they fired shots at the several workers, damaging a car but injuring nobody.

column7: WCRO: Women and Childrens Rights Organisation; Women (South Africa)
column17: Residents of Enkanini in Khayelitsha, supported by the Women and Childrens Rights organisation, marched to the Site B police station today in protest against the failure of the police to find a missing 21 year old girl.
At the Zimbabwean embassy in Pretoria, protesting members of a new party, Zimbabwe People First demanded the right to vote in the Zimbabwe elections from South Africa.
The Communication Workers Union marched in Johannesburg s to deliver a memorandum of demands that include an end to outsourcing at fully and partially state-owned entities.
Outsourced Shoprite workers, organised under the #OutsourcingMustFall movement, marched to the retailer's largest distribution centre in Centurion, Gauteng.
Teachers at Woodlands Primary School in Pietermaritzburg to find droves of angry parents protesting outside the school in protest over the rebuilding of a school.
Reclaim the City protesters took to the streets in Cape Town over housing in the CBD.
A group of DA supporters protested near the city hall in the Nelson Mandela Bay area over the decision to deny them permission to hold an anti-Zuma mass protest.
DA supporters marched through the streets of Hillbrow in Joburg in protest at what the party described as the trampling of the countries supreme law by Zuma and the ANC.
Three carriages set alight at Cape Town station causing clouds of smoke to rise out of the station.
A train was set alight, while another four carriages were destroyed by a fire in Kraaifonteins staging yard.
A small group of protesters blocked traffic in Bellair, Durban. Protesters dragged tyres and timber into the street and set them on fire, resulting in vehicles being blocked.
An ANC councillor was shot dead at Glebelands Hostel, Umlazi, Durban.
About 1,000 people from over 70 organisations met at the University of Johannesburgs Soweto campus to call for President Zuma to resign.
About 1000 residents marched in Mamelodi, protesting over the lack of service delivery, especially housing, in the district.
Three men have been arrested for the killing of a man in Johannesburg in what is believed to be mob justice. The group allegedly attacked a man, pelting him with stones.
Protesters took to the streets in Grahamstown and went into residences demanding to speak to alleged rapist who were on a published list.
On 17 April 2016, foreigner nationals shops were looted and destroyed in Dunoon, Cape Town (Western Cape). The Police blocked roads. 12 people were arrested. [size=at least 12]
A Malawian man has been killed in a suspected mob justice attack in the Joburg CBD.

In Cathcart, police fought pitched battles with residents opposed to a government plan to close the town's hospital and turn it into clinic. Nineteen residents were treated for broken limbs and rubber bullet wounds as a petrol bomb and stones were thrown as police tried to dismantle the barricade. Two police vehicles were also stoned and badly dented and railway power lines were cut.
Pupils from various schools in Durban were forced to join a protest in Clermont which centred on service delivery.
#OutsourcingMustFall protesters shut down the Tshwane South College's Atteridgeville campus , saying officials have failed to address issues of outsourcing and wage disputes.

About 150 residents of Tsunami informal settlement in Delft marched to the provincial government in the Cape Town CDB to hand over a memorandum demanding electricity and toilets in their community (service delivery).

A protest took place in Copesville over service delivery. The protesters burnt tyres and rubbish and placed guardrails on the road in which the police responded by firing rubber bullets and tear gas. As a result, three people were injured and a councillors office wasset alight.
Protests and looting reportedly continued into a second day in Dunoon, in what is thought protest action following recent housing protests. A MyCiTi bus terminal was also stoned.

Residents woke to protests New Germany where protesters were burning tyres and rubble. One woman has been arrested for public violence while a few were taken for treatment after police resorted to rubber bullets to control the situation.
In ongoing protest action at Rhodes University, students protested and disrupted classes in a bid to get the attention of the management.
A group of supporters of Oscar Pretorius stood outside the Pretoria High School in a show of support.

Violent protests and looting spread to Klipheuwel, where a group of angry residents damaged an ATM and electric cables. Residents were demanding electricity as they burnt tyres, barricaded the road with rubble and pelted passing cars with rocks.
Protesters burned down a park home-type structure at Mason Clinic in Pietermaritzburg. Reasons for the attack are unknown.

Small pockets of protesters, anger about service delivery, continued to take to the street in and around Copesville. Fires burned and anger had simmered as police and protesters clashed with 20 people being arrested.
In ongoing protest action at Rhodes University, students took their protest action further with the #NakedProtests on campus.
The bodies of two men were discovered after they were killed following the murder of another man in Motherwell, in what is suspected of being a vigilante killing.
Zandspruit residents took to the streets in anger over the lack of electricity supply in the area. The protesters blocked roads and disruted traffic with burning tyres.

In ongoing protest action at Rhodes University, chaos between police and students at Rhodes University escalated as rubber bullets, pepper spray and tear gas were used against a group of students protesting against the rape culture and the sexual assault policy at the university. Six Rhodes students were arrested during the chaos.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: The Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) in the Northern Cape marched to Premier Sylvia Lucas office in Kimberley to hand over a memorandum of grievance on Wednesday.

column7: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union
column17: Hundreds of SA Democratic Teachers Union (Sadtu) members in the Free State marched in Bloemfontein to hand over a memorandum of demands expressing there dissatisfaction over the education system.
The community of Ocelwane barricaded their dirt road with burning tyres and rocks to prevent officials of the government's Regional Mining Development Environment Committee from inspecting the land.
About 2 000 residents from Zandspruit, on the West Rand, marched for electricity connections. Residents barricaded the road leading into the West Rand township with burning tyres.

column7: JUTT: Joint Union Task Team; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: Striking employees, under the banner of the JUTT, of the Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT) shut down the Cape Town campus, protesting about the way the management had handled their wage dispute.

Schooling was disrupted and workers left stranded after residents of squatter settlements in Kimberley embarked on a protest action, blockading the main road and reportedly damading property in service delivery protest.
A group of learners went to forcefully remove students out of class and then started throwing stones at classrooms and cars, including the police in Bizana.
Ban Animal Trading SA (Bat) and the Bunny Park Animals 911 Group organised a peaceful protest outside a bunny park in Benoni.
Residents of Copesville in Pietermaritzburg burned the ward councillor's office, setting on fire all the furniture. The residents want the councillor to quit as they are angry about service delivery.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Striking Buffalo City Metro municipal workers, members of SAMWU, blocked roads in the centre of East London and King William's Town with burning tyres and garbage

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Workers, aligned to SAMW, burnt tyres in King Williams town in protest.

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students
column17: More than 1 000 high school pupils, organised by COSAS, marched in KwaMashu, north of Durban, to ""take back"" their schools and community from drug dealers who have infiltrated the township.
Protest action continued on the Bellville campus, lead by the Jutt movement as management failed to concede to a request to meet with them.
850 Equal Education organisation members and pupils from 10 schools in the King Williams Town area marched to the Eastern Cape provincial legislature to hand over a memorandum of demands.
A male was allegedly murdered by community members for the death of his friend in the Magwa falls, in the Eastern Cape.
In another mob justice attack, a suspected criminal was attacked but did not die in Thohoyandou, Limpopo.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; SACP: South African Communist Party; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: About 8 000 members of the SA Communist Party and the Congress of SA Trade Unions (Cosatu) marched through central Durban to hand over a memorandum over a number of labour and education issues
A suspected criminal has died after being set alight by a lynch mob at a Thohoyandou taxi rank in Limpopo.

The residents took to the streets in Spoorview in Ga-Rankuwa Zone burning tyres, city trash bins and even building walls in the middle of the road with the bricks. Residents are angry over empty promises of the building of roads.
Thousands of people from across South Africa walked in the Johannesburg city centre in support of the #IamConstitution campaign.
About 150 people marched through the streets of Bonteheuwel. They demanded that the South African Police Service (Saps) end gang violence in the community.
During the annual Salt March in Durban, people took to the streets in an 18km march to call for peace.

Residents in Orange Farm protested and barricaded roads over lack of service delivery. Residents, led mainly by youth, blockaded the streets with rocks, burning tyres, trees and other objects. Protest action at the time turned violent, with police firing rubber bullets in an effort to disperse the rowdy crowd, who in turn pelted the officers with stones.
Residents in Alldays protested outside the open-pit mine demanding workers be given shares in the company.
A suspected robber was the target of mob justice and sustained a broken leg in the process in Galeshewe.

Pienaarspoort east of Mamelodi was a war zone as the residents threw rocks and petrol bombs at armoured police vehicles while barricading roads with burning tyres and logs, as residents were angry over land evictions.
The anti-rape campaign gained momentum as it spread to Wits campuses in Johannesburg. Wits female students protested against rape in solidarity with their Rhodes counterparts.
About a thousand students and representatives of Equal Education marched in Kuils river to demand safer schools.
Blikkiesdorp residents marched to Mayor Patricia De Lilles office demanding to know when they will be relocated and to where.
Non-profit organisation Right2Know protested against state surveillance outside Parliament in Cape Town.
United Front (UF) and Right 2 Know campaign march on the streets of Durban, under the banner of #ZumaMust Fall.
A DA member was allegedly assaulted and stabbed by ANC members during a door-to-door campaign in Welbedacht, Chatsworth.
Protest action erupted again in Copesville, KZN.Protesters again barricaded the roads and demanded tthe removal of an ANC leader.
In A show of solidarity, hundreds of Lusikisiki villagers marched to the local police station demanding to be arrested for the murder of a man pushed over Magwa Falls last week.
Several hundred Capetonians marched through the streets of Cape Town under the #ZumaMustFall banner on Freedom Day to demonstrate their dissatisfaction with Zumas leadership.
South Durban residents and South Durban Environmental Alliance members gathered and protested at the Durban container terminals to highlight their lack of freedom.

The group of R2K Gauteng members protested outside the Office of the Interception Centres calling for urgent reforms and the end of what they alleged was surveillance abuse. Simultaneously in Johannesburg, hundreds of protesters,under the banner of #ZumaMust Fall, sang liberation songs and waved placards calling on Zuma to resign.
Just hours after Freedom Day celebrations, people in Matsulu went on the rampage, blocking roads with burning tyres to demand electricity and other services.
A group of residents staged a sit-in at the Nyanga police station in Cape Town, demanding justice, police visibility and the establishment of a task team to investigate gang activities.
An impromptu march, lead by MMM supporters was held in Soweto where fans flaunted their wealth gained through the pyramid scheme.
About 100 Motherwell residents decided to boycott Freedom Day celebrations, and stage a housing protest instead
A group of Stellenbosch University (SU) students demonstrated half-naked on the universities Red Square and held discussions on rape culture at campuses in solidarity with Rhodes students.
Protests continued in Matsulu over electricity and other services. There was no report of violence or damage to property.
Metered taxi drivers took to the streets in Durban at what they believe is unfair competition and the lack of regulation of taxi hailing app, Uber.
Waste collecters downed tools and protested in the Nelson Mandela Municipality, outside the city hall over pay and bonuses.

Protest action continued overnight in Copesville, KZN over the removal of an ANC leader. The protesters blocked the road with burning tyres and logs, and allegedly hurled rocks at passing motorists until police intervened, dispersing the crowd with teargas.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: In protests over payments, SA Municipal Workers Union members took to the streets in Jansenville and blocked the roads.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Hundreds of striking SA Municipal Workers Union members marched to East London City Hall in protest over salary disputes. A group of workers trashed parts of East London by spilling rubbish onto the streets. Workers reportedly also set fire to electricity boxes near the municipality's Trust Building
About 100 blind and wheelchair-bound people took to the streets in Cape Town CBD demanding better transport service.

Waste collecters downed tools and protested for the second day in the Nelson Mandela Municipality, outside the city hall over pay and bonuses. A group of workers trashed parts of East London by spilling rubbish onto the streets. Workers reportedly also set fire to electricity boxes near the municipality's Trust Building.
Members from several local ANC branches joined a small group of anti-Zuma marchers in Bloemfontein.
Khayelitsha residents were locked in a stand-off with city authorities at the civic centre after a march with the Social Justice Coalition to hand in 3,000 budget submissions.
Two alleged robbers were beaten and killed by residents in Nyanga in an apparent mob justice attack.

In protest action in Vuwami, a truck and grader were torched in which a tyre of a police trailer that was carrying razor wire was also burned. On the same day, Pupils in the area who watched their schools go up into flames
A man in Dunoon was assaulted by residents and later died in hospital due to his injuries.

Disgruntled Vuwani residents outside Thohoyandou protested again against the decision to incorporate their area into a new municipality. The riots resulting in the burning of several schools an other public property.
Two more schools were burnt in Vuwani in ongoing protest action by residents.

column7: EDSOA: eThekwini Driving School Operator Association
column17: Driving school operators, led by the eThekwini Driving School Operator Association, brought traffic to a standstill as they marched through the Durban CBD, demanding recognition as a sector in the transport industry.
A 700-strong crowd marched from Masiphumelele and spent the day outside the Simons Town court waiting to hear if their leader would return home.

column7: SATAWU: South African Transport and Allied Workers Union
column17: South African Transport and Allied Workers Union (Satawu) says its members who are protesting on the N1 highway in Midrand, Johannesburg are frustrated after going 4 years without salary increases. Eight protesters were arrested as protesters threw rocks and police fired rubber bullets.
Taxi industry people shot at and beat up residents for supporting the lockdown in Masiphumelele. Some residents were injured.
The SRC lead protests at the Vaal University of Technology.

column7: DAWN: Democratic Alliance Womens Network; Women (South Africa)
column17: The DA Womens Network staged a silent picket protest outside the Port Elizabeth court to raise awareness around the impact of gender violence on women and children. At the same time, a group of women gathered to show support for the accuses.
Protesters, upset over the ANC local candidate choice, blockaded roads in Umlazi,, burning tyres, breaking beer bottles and toppling rocks on to the road.
In ongoing protest action in Vuwani, two schools were set alight at Masakona, apparently by the protesters bringing the number of schools that were torched to 17.
Frustrated pupils at the Heritage Academy staged a protest at the school in Pietermaritzberg, demanding the school employ a maths teacher and provide them with library and Internet access.

column7: SATAWU: South African Transport and Allied Workers Union
column17: Protest action by Satawu members in continued in Johannesburg.
Classes at the Western Cape College of Nursing in Athlone were suspended after a student protest over bursaries.
Hundreds of angry residents in Pietermaritzburg took to the streets , blocking Selby Msimang Road with burning tyres. Residents were unhappy over the lack of service delivery
On a train in Eerste River, a robber tried to escape a crowd after committing a crime but was beaten with a rod by passengers on the train.

column7: SATAWU: South African Transport and Allied Workers Union
column17: Protest action by Satawu members in continuing in Johannesburg.

Residents from Ennerdale and Fine Town in the south of Johannesburg took to the streets over service delivery and infighting about candidates being nominated for the local government elections. Roads were blocked with rocks, burning rubbish, tree branches and metal polls.
Failure to pay workers at Mpumalangas collapsed Lily Mine resulted in a massive protest involving local residents and more than 700 disgruntled miners in Louieville, Mpumalanga
Protest action continued for the fourth consecutive day in the Vuwani. Roads were barricaded, while passing cars and riot police were pelted with stones.
In ongoing protest action at the Western Cape College of Nursing in Athlone, a government vehicle was set alight.

A group of mostly old men and women blocked the entrance to Parliament ahead of President Jacob Zumas budget vote reply, demanding they be paid pension money they claimed they were still owed. Meanwhile, in the Cape Town CBD Communication Workers Union members took to the streets.
Residents of Setlopo village, outside Mahikeng, took to the streets demanding better roads.
Municipal workers who were on duty at the Nandoni Dam were forcibly removed, by residents, from their offices and forced to switch off the water supply to villages outside Vuwani.

A protest in Mdantsane, East London was held by parents and students over the failure of a ward councillor to give residents answers about houses she allegedly promised them (housing delivery). Protesters blocked the streets with burning tyres, stones and rubbish.

In a second day of protests outside parliament, a group of younger protesters joined elderly people and demanded access to parliamentary grounds. Police intervened and forcibly removed and arrested protesters who refused to move from the entrance.
Nigerian nationals held a peaceful protest outside the the Nigerian High Commision in Pretoria.

A small group of about 50 striking South African Post Office (SAPO) workers belonging to the Communication Workers Union (CWU) gathered in Johannesburg to protest the lack of government support of the postal entity.
In ongoing violence in Vuwani, a school which had been previously vandalised by protesters was torched on, putting the number of schools set alight at 20.
Thousands of South Africans took to the streets of Cape Town demanding a relaxation of drugs laws to allow medicinal and recreational use of cannabis.

column7: ANCWL: African National Congress Womens League; Women (South Africa)
column17: ANCWL members held a demonstration outside the Union Bildings in a show of support for the ANC.

After residents assaulted a suspected criminals, about 60 foreign nationals from KwaNomzamo in Humansdorp marched to the police station, demanding to know why a burglary suspect had not been arrested.

column9: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: Two senior ANC Youth League (ANCYL) members were shot in Newcastle. One member was killed while the other sustained serious injuries.
Residents assaulted a man they claimed had previously broken into one of their homes in Humansdorp.
Protesters took to the streets on the N2 between Mdantsane and East London as they want their councillor removed over lack of service delivery
Close to 100 community representatives staged a protest outside the casino to demand answers and pressure the casino in Whittlesea.
In Stinkwater, members of the ANC party were assaulted and a bodyguard shot as comrades turned against comrades in the battle for who will occupy the councillor position in the ward.
Suspended students and members of the #FeesMustFall campaign protested at the University of Johannesburg.
A group of 10 people, including prominent business owners, were arrested by police in Dutywa after service delivery protests erupted.
Protest action erupted in Grabow as residents are upset over housing and evictions.
Operations at Richards Bay Minerals (RBM) in northern KwaZulu-Natal have been suspended after community members blockaded roads leading to the mine's entrance.
Taxi Drivers gathered and blocked residents from leaving Masiphumelele.
About 100 students gathered on Rooiplein in Stellenbosh and remained peaceful during their demonstration. They gathered to protest against the dismissal of 150 workers.
An East London high school has been brought to a standstill after pupils locked the gates and staged a protest calling for the removal of their principal.

column7: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union
column17: SADTU members held a demonstration in Durban over the overcrowding at public schools.

A group of about 20 tenants from Naruna Estate, Rugby, Sanddrift and De Waal Drive marched to the provincial legislature on to hand over a memorandum to MEC for Human Settlements Bonginkosi Madikizela.

Residents of Ga-Rankuwa took to the streets to express their dissatisfaction with service delivery. They barricaded roads with burning tyres and rubble as they demanded the City of Tshwane tar roads and install storm water drainage systems.

Thousands of residents in Grabouw set a vehicle alight and burnt down the local traffic department. They were protesting evictions and calling for better housing. Residents blocked the main road forcing traffic officers to close down a section of the N2 highway.

In Pietermaritzburg, residents protested against ward councillor Sindisiwe Gwala and lack of service delivery. Richmond road was barricaded with burning tyres and stones. Stones were thrown at the police. Police dispersed protesters with rubber bullets and teargas. Police dispersed protesters with rubber bullets and teargas.
The SRC lead protests at the Vaal University of Technology.
Disgruntled residents pelted cars with stones, looted stores and burned tyres in ongoing protest action in Idutywa over poor service delivery.
Residents of Bloemhof went on the rampage, blockading the road. They torched three trucks and pelted passing car with stones as they vented their anger over service delivery.

Protesters in Vuwani returned to the streets, after State Security Minister David Mahlobo and his team had cleared the roads. Protesters began throwing stones and burning tyres on the main road. The move prompted police to use rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse protesters.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: Members of the Western Cape ANC Youth League clashed with police during a picket outside the South African Rugby Union Offices in which police used stun grenades to disperse the crowd. The protesters were angry over lack of transformation in sports.
Around 100 people embarked on a service delivery protest in the Melville township, north of Durban. No reports of violence or damage to property were recorded.

A handful of protesters assembled on UCTs Jameson Plaza calling on UCT to ""bring back our cadres"". A large cloth was laid out on the steps proclaiming: ""Death of Dreams"". By noon the protest had grown to dozens of people.
Violence escalated at the Vaal University of Technology to a point where several buildings of the university were burned, placing non-protesting students and staff at great risk.

There were running battles between protesters and the police in Grabouw for a second day. Police used rubber bullets, stun grenades and tear gas to disperse protesters after they were pelted with stones.
Pupils at Orlando High School went on a rampage, vandalising property and looting computers, laptops and tablets. Police had to use rubber bullets to disperse the mob.
At least six taxi and several other vehicles were damaged by protesters as violence continued unabated in Vuwani, Limpopo.
#RhodesMustFall members and students gathered to remember the Shackville protestsand to stand in solidarity with the students indicted in a court judgment at UCT.

Members of the Treatment Action Campaign started their march to the SA Police Service (SAPS) and the Free State Prosecutors Office in Bloemfontein to demand a rapid finalisation of investigations into charges laid against Health MEC Benny Malakoane.

About 200 residents of Siqalo informal settlement, near Philippi, supported by Ses'Khona Peoples Rights Movement, marched to the Cape Town Civic Centre. They want the City to buy the land on which they are living so that it can be adequately serviced.

column7: SATAWU: South African Transport and Allied Workers Union
column17: Employees of Teti Traffic Workers, aligned to SATAWU, picketed outside Sanrals offices in Midrand, and have given the company 48 hours to respond to their demands.
Police used rubber bullets and teargas to disperse the crowd that was protesting near the community hall in Imbali Unit 13, Pietermaritzburg. The protesters were unhappy about the lack of services.

A group of about 50 municipal employees, including traffic officials and other members of the municipalities safety and security directorate, protested in Govan Mbeki Avenue opposite the Vuyisile Mini Square, where the launch took place.

column7: SAFSC: South African Food Sovereignty Campaign
column17: Members of the South African Food Sovereignty Campaign marched through the streets of Johannesburg in protest against the high price of bread in the country.

Hundreds of angry protesters from Reeston pelted stones at vehicles travelling between Mdantsane and East London. They are demanding street lights, low cost houses, as well as tarred roads. No injuries reported
South African environmentalists, 350.org members and Right2Know activists converged in Johannesburg to demonstrate against climate change.

column16: Business Live (South Africa); Daily Vox (South Africa)
column17: Petrol bomb was thrown in the auditorium at University of Johannesburg, destroying computer laboratories - including equipment used for career assessment and guidance. This follows a trend of sorts - two weeks of schools being burnt down in Vuwani, Limpopo, and a building at the Vaal University of Technology being set alight as well.
About 50 students from Sizimisele Technical High School in Khayelitsha marched from Cape Town train station to the offices of the Western Cape Education Department demanding more teachers.
More than 1000 Middledrift community members braved the heat to attend a march against gender-based violence led by social development MEC.

column16: South African Police Service; Mercury (South Africa)
column17: A group of 20 pupils aged between 15 and 17 arrested due to the throw of stones and rocks to pelt other learners. No injuries reported. A police unit was deployed and the pupils were arrested at the scene.
Violent protests erupted in Kokstad over poor service delivery. 37 people were arrested as protested blocked the streets with bricks and stones.
An ANC councillor was shot dead and his wife seriously wounded when a gunman opened fire on their car in the northern KwaZulu-Natal town of Nongoma.

About 200 people gathered during the peak rush hour traffic, causing the closure of two Durbans key highways with burning tyres and rocks. Police dispersed the protesters useing stun grenades and rubber bullets.

About 200 people gathered during the peak rush hour traffic, causing the closure of two Durbans key highways with burning tyres and rocks - the N2 near Lamontville and the M19 near Reservoir hill. Police dispersed the protesters useing stun grenades and rubber bullets. 2 injuries reported in Lamontville.

About 200 people gathered during the peak rush hour traffic, causing the closure of two Durbans key highways with burning tyres and rocks - the N2 near Lamontville and the M19 near Reservoir hill. Police dispersed the protesters useing stun grenades and rubber bullets.
Hundreds of protesters took to the streets demanding the removal of the local mayor and her deputy. Police used teargas against rampaging protesters who trying to damage properties.

In a village near Libode, an elderly woman was killed by members of a soccer club and some of their supporters because the group had accused her of witchcraft following the deaths of two Young Aces Football Club players. The murder occurred in full view of her young grandchildren.
Over two days, residents of Tshepisong on the West Rand blockaded roads with tyres and rocks on in protest against power outages (service delivery).
Colleagues of a slain nurse demonstrated outside the Pietermaritzburg Magistrate's Court against bail for her alleged killer.
Clashes between two group of youngsters killed two people and wounded three.

University of Fort Hare (UFH) East London campus students marched to the East London Magistrates Court to pledge their support for 20 students facing public violence charges. They say they will not be part of the centenary celebrations planned for this weekend in protest for the 20 students arrested in October last year during violent #FeesMustFall protests.

Students at the University of Fort Hare gathered at the Student Centre on Tuesday to hand over a memorandum to the universities management. After the unsuccessful talks with univerity management, on Wednesday nigth, protesters burned the tent in which the centenary celebrations were supposed to occur, as well as tyres near the entrances. Police were deployed to the campus and arrested ten students.

Between 100 and 150 members of the Pakistani community in South Africa protested outside the Indian consulate in Joburg to condemn the involvement of the Indian intelligence agencies Research and Analysis Wing (RAW) in terrorism in Pakistan.
Cleaning workers on strike after hearing that their contracts had been terminated. They collected garbage from nearby houses, roadsides and taxi ranks to throw into the municipal premises.
Several hundred residents of Missionvale in Port Elizabeth took to the streets, blocking the Uitenhage road with burning tyres and attacking a taxi. The demand water, sanitation and jobs.
In a second day of protests, residents of Tshepisong on the West Rand blockaded roads with tyres and rocks on in protest against power outages (service delivery).

column7: SACWU: South African Chemical Workers Union
column17: Striking workers of Aspen Pharmacare and members of the South African Chemical Workers Union picketed outside the company premises on in Port Elizabeth over labour issues.
Villagers in Vuwani continue their protest against the governments plans to demarcate their area into a new municipality, and erect barricades and clash with police.
A 20 year old man wanted by the police was killed by community members in Philippi.

Students protested during the centenary celebration of the South Africa university. Police at the Fort Hare campus used water cannon to force back students who tried to march on the venue where dignitaries including President Jacob Zuma and Mugabe were gathered. The students later staged a protest vigil after their bid to block the main entrance with barricades, thwarted by police. 10 students arrested over the night.

column9: ANC: African National Congress; Women (South Africa)
column17: A female ANC branch leader in Rustenburg was severely assaulted with golf clubs, a sjambok and stones allegedly by two prominent party members.
In a march to the offices of property companies in Pretoria, residents complained over the high prices of rent and the blacklisting of tenants.
About 500 people took to the streets of Langa, participating in the fourth annual Khumbulani Pride march.
Two people have been killed and seven others injured after Basotho nationals clashed with Zimbabweans while playing soccer in Garsfontein.

On 22 May 2016, in Botshabelo outside Bloemfontein, violent demonstrations erupted as people were angry over the appointment of an ANC councillor. A group of people blocked roads with burning tyres and looted one foreign-owned shop as police used tear gas rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. [size=no report]

Umzinto, on the KwaZulu-Natal South Coast, was a no-go area as protests erupted over two days. Protesters were burning tyres and entrances to the town were blocked. The reason for the protest was unknown.
Another school in Vuwani, Limpopo was burnt down in ongoing violent unrest in the region over the merging of municipalities.
Ekurhuleni East College students on the Daveyton campus protested and burnt tyres in front of the institutions gates as they were angry over funding and university jobs.

Two people (reported security guards working for the Red Ants) have reportedly been killed by protesters. The protesters were angry over the removal of shacks, attacked and killed people who were demolishing shacks.
Shakaville residents went on a protest complaining about the candidate to contest this year's local government elections in the area.

Umzinto, on the KwaZulu-Natal South Coast, was a no-go area as protests erupted over two days. Protesters were burning tyres and entrances to the town were blocked. The reason for the protest was unknown.

Several shops were looted and ten people arrested for public violence during a community protest in Wolmaransstad, North West. Residents barricaded the N12 freeway and an unconfirmed number of vehicles were pelted with stones.

column16: ZuluLand Observer (South Africa); African News Agency
column17: Water shortages have sparked riots in the far northern KwaZulu-Natal town of Jozini over two days. Rioters blocked every entry into Jozini with burning tyres, trees, rocks and other debris, completely cutting off the town and forcing a shut down.
About 100 members of the Social Justice Coalition (SJC) marched to the office of the Mayor of Cape Town to deliver a petition demanding lasting sanitation for in informal settlements in Cape Town.
Ekurhuleni East College students on the Daveyton campus continued to protest and and burn tyres in front of the institutions gates as they were angry over funding and university jobs.
Violent protests over evictions entered day two in Hammanskraal as roads were blocked off with burning tyres and debris.

An EFF marshal was shot and injured in the leg when he tried to prevent a man he described as wearing an ANC T-shirt from entering the KaMaqhekeza stadium in KaMaqhekeza (formerly Naas) outside Komatipoort

column16: ZuluLand Observer (South Africa); African News Agency
column17: Water shortages have sparked riots in the far northern KwaZulu-Natal town of Jozini over two days. Rioters blocked every entry into Jozini with burning tyres, trees, rocks and other debris, completely cutting off the town and forcing a shut down.
A suspected house robber was stripped naked and beaten , later taking refuge on a Berea rooftop while waiting for police to come and save him.

About 60 participants from civil society organisations, lead by Amabida Crisis Committee, marched through Cape Town against attempts by Australian company Mineral Commodities (MRC) to mine titanium in Xolobeni on the Wild Coast.
Scores of unhappy Edendale Ward 12 residents visited the ANC offices in Pietermaritzburg, in the hopes of having their cries for a new councillor and pleas for their safety answered
On 26 May 2016, in Botshabelo, outside Bloemfontein, a group of people blocked roads with burning tyres and looted one foreign-owned shop. 16 people were arrested by police. [size=at least 16]

Approximately 200 students from the College of Cape Town marched on the offices of the Western Cape Education Department to hand in a memorandum demanding recognition of the three year Primary Health Care course offered at Crawford campus.

In Zwelithsa, disgruntled workers took to the streets and chased workers away, threatening them if they returned to work. Protesters had kicked over that was being used to mark speed humps and threw away their equipment.
Residents from Ennerdale have barred all entries and exits in the area with large rocks and burning tyres and have demanded to be addressed by the member of the mayoral committee over housing issues.
Three carriages were destroyed in a suspected arson attack at the Muldersvlei station in continued arson action against trains in the Cape region.
An ANC leader has been gunned down just outside his house in Nelspruit, Mpumalanga in what appears to be another political assassination.
During a protest, residents of Ramochana, near Rustenburg in North West, burnt a bus..
ANC members held a picket outside the ANC list conference in Pretoria, disputing the validity of its nomination process.

column7: FAWU: Food and Allied Workers Union
column17: Protesters, aligned to the Food and Allied Workers Union, were beaten by private security guards and workers during strike action in Philippi.
Protesting Jeppe Hostel residents took to the streets, but it was unclear what their grievances were about.
During protest action, residents in Pietermaritzburg blocked a road demanding the return of their water supply. They blocked the road using burning tyres, trees and big stones.
During a EFF rally in Esikhawini (KZN) , ANC members intervened and threw stones at EFF members. No injures were reported but police fired rubber bullets at the ANC members.

At a meeting in Hammanskraal, ""ANC hooligans"" began attacking and beating those attending. Most of the people who were assaulted were women and the elderly, while property was allegedly vandalised.Cars were also allegedly vandalised and some torched.

Residents of two Khayelitsha wards closed Kuyasa Primary School in protest against what they say are unsafe conditions. The residents were also protesting at the ANCs choice of candidate for the two wards in the municipal elections.

Residents from different wards throughout KwaDukuza gathered at Sadtu Park with the intention of marching to the ANC regional offices to lay a complaint about candidate lists in certain branches in the region.
Authorities have closed Baden Powell Drive due to a violent protest. Several motorists have been reporting seeing tyres burning.
EE members picketed outside the Premiers office in Bhisho demanding that the Department of Basic Education meet the November deadline for fixing infrastructure in schools.
In Cape Town, about 60 EE activists picketed in front of parliament. They wanted to hand over a memorandum to the chairperson of the portfolio committee for Basic Education.
Classes came to a halt at a rural school ain Maqomeni s nearly a thousand enraged pupils and their parents protested outside the gates for a proper building.

Residents of France ""location"" in Imbali protested. Richmond Road and other parts of Imbali Unit 14 were blocked with burning tyres, stones and tree branches. Road users were forced to use other routes as protesters did not allow anyone to pass through.

In KwaMpumuza, residents protested over the a road drainage project. Residents blockaded the road saying that they want the project closed. Taxi drivers including taxi owners supported the protest. Police used teargas to disperse the protesters.

column7: FAWU: Food and Allied Workers Union
column17: About 20 supermarket workers, Food and Allied Workers Union, who are on strike for higher wages, protested outside the supermarket in Philippi.

A Mpofana (Mooi River) Municipality's former chief financial officer was ambushed and murdered in front of his young children in Pietermaritzburg, had allegedly received threatening messages for months. Hours later, an ANC member with whom he had led a branch in Edendale was also gunned down.

Around 1 June 2016 (as reported), a Somali shopkeeper was beaten and stabbed to death by a mob in Atteridgeville, Tshwane (Gauteng), during a demonstration against the governing party's mayoral candidate. The group was carrying machetes, bars, knives, sticks and rocks, and they had blocked the roads. [size=no report]

column7: PASMA: Pan Africanist Student Movement of Azania; Students (South Africa)
column17: About 50 supporters of the Pan Africanist Student Movement of occupied Azania (Pasma) gathered outside the administrative offices at the University of Cape Town (UCT) to protest the interdict of five of their members from accessing UCT's campus unless they get written consent from the vice chancellor. Tear gas was used by police to disperse protesters.
The launch of this years National Youth Month in Soweto was overshadowed by a disgruntled organisation demonstrating about the need for santiary provisions for needy schoolgirls.

Residents of Siqalo, near Philippi, blocked the roads around the informal settlement this morning over complaints about the cleaning contractor in the area. During the protest a number of people were arrested and police allegedly ripped the clothes of one of the protesters.
In KwaMpumuza, residents continued to protest over the proposed road drainage project.
Residents in Hogsback, Eastern Cape took to the street to protest over service delivery in the area. Residents burnt tyres and trees to barricade the main road in the village
Members of the African National Congress staged a protest outside Luthuli House in Johannesburg when the party annonced the list of its election candidates.

column7: ANC: African National Congress; SASCO: South Africa Students Congress
column17: SASCO and ANC members hurled stones at and attacked DASO members at the launch of DASO's 'My Safe Campus' initiative at PE College. No injuries reported.
A truck was burnt in Kroondal, near Rustenburg, during a community protest in which residents barricaded the road with burning tyres, logs and rocks, demanding water, electricity and toilets.

Protesters from the ANC were forcefully removed from the ANC provincial offices in Salt River during a similar protest over the list. No reports of violence or injury were reported. Protest actions were reported in other provinces in recent weeks.
Bhongweni residents marched to the Mthatha Magistrates Court demanding protection after recent taxi violence.

During the arrest of a suspected drug dealer, community members pelted police officials with stones. A sergeant was struck on her face with a brick/stone. The crowd followed the police to the Gelvandale police station where they continued with their attack by throwing stones. As a result, police and private vehicles were damaged.
A trio of pickpocketers were nabbed by members of the Old Belhar Patrol and Extension Six neighbourhood watch and given a beating by the community in Belhar.
Civil society group Public Transport Voice held a picket outside Prasa offices in Cape Town in protest of a looming train ticket price hike.
Examinations have been disrupted at two school in Motlhabeng near Mahikeng in which a mob walked inside the school premises to disrupt the writing of the examinations.
Meter taxi drivers protested and closed the road to Cape Town International Airport and forced passengers out of Uber cars. An Uber driver was severely assaulted and his licence disk was stolen.

About 100 ANC members protesting against alleged fiddling with party candidate lists for the local government elections kept up the pressure on party regional leaders, burning newspapers and T-shirts outside the ANCs Sahara House headquarters in central Cape Town.
Rhodes Must Fall members disrupted a celebration at the University of Cape Town (UCT) marking the 50th anniversary of the late US senator Robert Kennedys ""Ripples of Hope"" speech.
A National Union of Mineworkers member was shot in the head at a four-way stop in Northam. The unidentified killer ran away.

During protest action Brairdene, Durban protesters blocked roads with burning barricades and hurled stones at passing cars. Officers used stun grenades and rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. A man in his thirties is in a serious condition after he was shot in the stomach during violent incidents.

The small community of Hambanathi protests swept through the streets of the township. Protestors barricaded roads with heavy metal containers and large cement pipes at various points in the township, where angry protestors amassed in a group of about 50, some armed with sticks and knobkerries.
In Krugersdorp, protesters burned tyres and stoned vehicles. Residents were apparently unhappy with the list of candidates for the area who would contest the August 3 local government election.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Mandeni Municipality workers, supported by SAMWU embarked on a violent protest on over extended working hours. the protesting workers set alight the municipality's technical department offices but no injuries were reported.

column9: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union
column17: During violence clashes between the NUM and AMC, police intervened and dispersed the violent crowds with rubber bullets and tear gas.

column9: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union
column17: NUM and Amcu clashed on the R510 between Northam and Thabazimbi. Public order police fired rubber bullets to disperse the groups. An Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union member was stabbed with an assegai.
The Zululand town of iSithebe was marred by protests. Protesters stormed the waterworks and barricaded themselves in and barred access to the site.
Examinations have been disrupted at two school in Motlhabeng near Mahikeng in which a mob walked inside the school premises to disrupt the writing of the examinations.

column9: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Women (South Africa)
column17: A female EFF member who was distributing campaign materials at a taxi rank in the city centre was shot and wounded
A service delivery protest played out when residents of Refilwe informal settlement near Cullinan barricaded the main road with burning tyres, bricks and stones.
A truck transporting timber as well as two other trucks were stopped during the course ofprotests and set alight by local people.
Police fired rubber bullets and teargas to disperse angry Diepkloof hostel residents in Soweto who were protesting against poor living conditions.

Traffic in Durban's Sea Cow Lake area in Brairdene was disrupted on as protests continued for the second consecutive day. There was an unconfirmed report of a minibus being stoned by protesters while old vehicles and tyres were burnt and placed as barricades on Sea Cow Lake Road.

column9: ANC: African National Congress; Women (South Africa)
column17: In what appears to be politically-motivated killings, an elderly woman was shot dead and another was injured while they were returning home from an ANC branch meeting in Imbali, Pietermaritzburg.

The KwaZulu-Natal Department of Education accused the community of Inanda of 'treason' after they allegedly tried to burn down Mvaba High School on Wednesday. The office of the school principal and the staff room were set alight, but no extensive damage was done.
In Krugersdorp, about 500 residents barricaded roads. Residents were apparently unhappy with the list of candidates for the area who would contest the August 3 local government election.
When a student at Sefako Makgatho Health Science University was hit by a car on Molotlegi Street , other students took action and protested.

column7: ANC: African National Congress; DA: Democratic Alliance
column16: Democratic Alliance (South Africa); News24 (South Africa); Times (South Africa)
column17: About 70 relatives and DA members marched to the Gauteng health departments head office. Meanwhile, ANC members from Ward 24 in Tshwane descended on Luthuli House in Johannesburg to protest over candidate lists.
Reclaim the City and about 100 of its supporters marched to the Tafelberg property in Sea Point on in opposition to the sale of the site.
A man suspected by angry community members of murder was stoned to death in Muden near Greytown.
In a taxi strike, roads in Port Elizabeth were blocked with taxis and burning tyres.
In East London a taxi strike took place. Roads inside the CBD were blocked with burning tyres and drivers prevented any car from entering. The N2 between East London and Butterworth was also blocked.
Hundreds of taxi operators arrive at Bhisho State House to protest during widespread taxi strikes in the Eastern Cape.
During widespread taxi strikes, Duncan Village roads blockaded, tyres burning near the community centre there.
In taxi strikes in the Eastern Cape, protesters set tyres alight and blocked roads in Kamesh, Uitenhage.

column7: POPCRU: Police, Prisons and Civil Rights Union
column17: Popcru members took to the street next to Kgosi Mampuru II Prison in Pretoria insisting that their demands be agreed to to prevent further marches. They believe the Department of Correctional Services has swept their grievances under the carpet.

In recurring protests in Khayelitsha by residents and ANC members, over the ward councillor candidate list for the upcoming August local elections, protesters used burning tyres to blocked off Jeff Masemola Road.

In a taxi strike, power to the railway lines at Fort Jackson near Mdantsane were cut. Cars were not allowed to leave Mdantsane. When cars tried to force their way, taxi drivers threatened to beat up the drivers.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) members in Mpumalanga have marched to the Lily Mine offices demanding that the company prioritise finding the three miners who have been trapped underground.

column7: SAPUPP: South African Prisoners Unemployed Political Party
column17: A small group of Oscar Pistorius supporters, joined by the South African Prisoners Unemployed Political Party, is singing and dancing outside the High Court in Pretoria ahead of sentencing proceedings for the former paralympian and convicted murderer.
Residents of Vlakfontein protested over electricity blackouts. A police vehicle was pelted with stones as officers patrolled the area.

Hundreds of residents blockaded the N2 in Cambridge as the ANC replaces their ward candidate for the August 3 local government election. Protesters were burning tyres and trees in the road while police fired stun grenades and rubber bullets in an attempt to disperse the protesters.
Klipspruit residents started a protest against the power cuts that have affected many parts of Soweto.
About 400 backyarders from Mfuleni marched to the Civic Centre to hand over a memorandum demanding housing.
Hundreds of DA members braved the rain and marched to the Port Elizabeth City Hall demanding jobs as the party stepped up its campaign to win the hearts and minds of unemployed young people.

About 150 people surrounded a police station, shouting that they wanted a woman who was accsed of kidnapping children. The gates of the station were locked and residents started to throw stones. Police fired back, apparently using live ammunition and dispersed the crowd.
About 300 residents of Masiphumelele marched to Simon's Town Magistrates Court in support of 43 community members arrested last year for public violence

Residents of Thembelihle and Vlakfontein blocked the Golden Highway after having no electricity. Rocks and tree branches were thrown into the road as burning tyres sent plumes of black smoke into the cloudy sky. A police Nyala was also pelted with stones when it passed near where the crowd had gathered.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; SASSU: South African Social Services Union
column17: About 40 members of the South African Social Services Union (SASSU) and the National Education Health and Allied Workers Union (NEHAWU) picketed the Western Cape Department of Social Development, complaining of unfair treatment, improper labour practices, ethical violations, and mismanagement on the part of MEC for Social Development Albert Fritz.
About 350 protesters burnt tyres and stoned vehicles on the R33 to show their anger in New Hanover ove the choice of ANC councillor for the upcoming elections.

Seven schools and a clinic have been shut down by ward 28 African National Congress (ANC) members who are protesting against alleged imposition of a candidate in KwaMadiba in Bizana in the Eastern Cape.

In recurring protests in Khayelitsha by residents over the ANC ward councillor candidate list for the upcoming August local elections, the police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse protesters in which 4 were arrested.

column7: SAPS: South African Public Service Union
column17: The South African Public Service Union marched to city hall to hand over a memorandum to KwaZulu-Natal Premier Willies Mchunu.
A drug awareness march and community programme was held on 16 June in Isipingo, which saw many young people and community stakeholders converge to make the event successful.
The DA led a March in Soweto, saying a DA government would honour the youth of 1976 through actions and not just words.
Protests erupted in the Springfield area of Durban as informal settlement dwellers took to the streets burning at least one truck and stoning passing motorists

column7: MLDAC: Mamelodi Local Drug Action Committee
column17: Young people from Mamelodi commemorated Youth Day and the 1976 Soweto Uprising by marching again drugs. Under the banner of the Mamelodi Local Drug Action Committee, they took to the streets to call for an end to drug abuse
Motorists in Mamelodi drove over burning rubbish and tyres as ANC supporters went on the rampage, blocking major roads.
The Inkatha Freedom Party is calling on the KwaZulu-Natal multi-party task team to investigate the killing of a candidate in Ward 3 in Abaqulusi.

A Khayelitsha ward councillor fearing for his life after his home was torched in Khayelitsha. Only mininmum damage was done to the house as ANC members are believed to have carried out the arson attack over a dispute within the ANC ahead of the local elections.
The provincial ANC's door-to-door election campaigning was stopped short in Elsies River when the teenage son of one of its members was fatally shot.
The Inkatha Freedom Party has condemned the recent attack on the home of an IFP candidate in Nongoma that left one person dead.
No arrests have been made in connection with the death of an ANC activist and South African National Civic Organisation (Sanco) branch secretary in Maboloka near Brits.
A gun was fired during a protest outside a Khayelitsha ward councillor's home after a group of residents marched there to demand that she does not stand as their representative.

Protest action over the nomination of an ANC councillor in New Hanover has resulted in passing vehicles being stoned, tyres being burned and roads being blockaded. New Hanover erupted in protests after complaints from the residents of Ward 2 in Umshwathi Municipality about the ANC ward councillor candidate went unheard.
Violence broke out near the Tshwane Showground when an ANC member was shot dead. During the violence and comotion, a few properties damaged in the process.

Residents of Colchester in the Eastern Cape protested demanding that South African National Parks return a large piece of land from the a park. Protesters blocked the entrance to the Addo Elephant National Park, near the N2
On 20 June 2016, asylum-seekers, some of whom are battling to have their refugee application processed, held a protest march to the Parliament in Cape Town to mark World Refugee Day.

A group of Right2Know protesters sang songs and waved flags outside the SABC offices in Auckland Park, Johannesburg. The Right2Know Campaign on Monday demanded the removal of SABC COO , saying he is unfit for the job.

On 20 June 2016, residents set vehicles on fire in different parts of Pretoria (Gauteng) in demonstration against the ruling party's choice of a mayoral candidate for local polls. Foreign owned shops and micro enterprises were looted. The attacks lasted 3 days. 5 people died. Fatalities split between 3 events. [size=no report]
A Limpopo man suspected to be part of gang robbing and terrorising the community was burnt to death by outraged members of the community in Madombidzha near Louis Trichardt.
Angry educators and parents marched in New Brighton to force the Department of Social Development to pay subsidy money to feed children at daycare centres in Nelson Mandela Bay.

Police are investigating a case of arson after disgruntled nursing students at the College of Cape Towns campus in Crawford set parts of the institutions building on fire in protest. A group of PHC students threw stones, vandalised windows, burnt dustbins and set some parts of nursing building on fire.

At least 20 buses were reportedly burnt and cars damaged as angry ANC protesters took to the streets in Mamelodi East, unhappy with the ANCs decision to impose MP Thoko Didiza as mayoral candidate for the city. Three metro police officers had to run for their lives after protesters attacked their marked service vehicle in Pretoria.
ANC members in Rustenburg barricaded the roads in protest saying they did not want the Rustenburg mayoral candidate Mpho Khonou.
Residents of Mzombane village in Mokopane protested outside the Mokopane courthouse as the bail application of a accused murder was heard.

On 21 June 2016, residents set vehicles on fire in different parts of Pretoria (Gauteng) in demonstration against the ruling party's choice of a mayoral candidate for local polls. Foreign owned shops and micro enterprises were looted. The attacks lasted 3 days. 5 people died. Fatalities split between 3 events. [size=no report]
A man who allegedly tried to rob a school pupil with a toy gun was killed in a mob justice attack in Kagiso, on the West Rand.

column16: AFP; News24 (South Africa); African News Agency
column17: Protests by angry ANC members continued in the Pretoria area (Atteridgeville) as roads were blocked with burning tyres and debris. There were at least three vehicles a bus and two trucks that were on fire in Atteridgeville.

column16: African News Agency; News24 (South Africa); AFP
column17: Protests by angry ANC members continued in the Pretoria area (Mamelodi) as roads were blocked with burning tyres and debris. 2 people were killed in the violence but authorities are unsure how they died.

column9: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Journalists (South Africa)
column16: African News Agency; AFP; News24 (South Africa)
column17: A group of men armed with sjamboks, knobkerries, pointed sticks and golf clubs and believed to be ANC members have attacked EFF members and the media during a visit to Sethokga Hostel in Tembisa, on the East Rand.
In ongoing violence protests around Tshwane, at least 21 Zimbabweans on a bus were attacked and robbed of their valuables by violent protesters near Hammanskraal.
In ongoing violent protests, sources in Pretoria said haulage trucks and other vehicles were burnt near Zebediela.

On 22 June 2016, residents set vehicles on fire in different parts of Pretoria (Gauteng) in demonstration against the ruling party's choice of a mayoral candidate for local polls. Foreign owned shops and micro enterprises were looted. The attacks lasted 3 days. 5 people died. Fatalities split between 3 events. [size=no report]
Looters targeted shops in the Ga-Rankuwa neighborhood belonging to immigrants.
Protest action took place at Sir Lowrys Pass Village at the foot of the pass. Protesters reportedly started throwing stones at passing vehicles.
Residents of Mabopane joined the protests and looted stores as two people were killed by police as violent protests and looting erupted overnight.
The community of ward 15, Pietermaritzburg waved placards the magistrates outside court, sang and chanted struggle songs; most were wearing ANC T-shirts, hats and jackets.
A clinic and a community hall were partly burnt in Oukasie near Brits in an unknown attack.

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Journalists (South Africa)
column17: People were prevented from entering the SABC building in Durban while a small group of EFF members staged a protest in an attempt to force the broadcaster to fire an Ukhozi FM presenter.

Townships in Tshwane have been plunged into chaos, with police battling to combat widespread looting. In Ga-Rankuwa, mos ran amok and looted several stores. Police reportedly opened fire with rubber bullets at crowds who had gathered.
In ongoing protests and looting, police engaged in running battles with looters in Mabopane. Officers encircled the Central City Mall and fired rubber bullets to repel advancing looters.
