Protesting residents of Malusi informal settlement in Pretoria West took to the streets to demand that the promises made by current Tshwane Mayor Kgosientso Ramokgopa be fulfilled.
In Giyani, smoke was billowing from a shopping complex after angry residents went on a looting spree and burning shops during the early hours of the morning.
In Pietermartizburg, the community blocked roads in Snathing and stopped buses, taxis and cars leaving. People were forced to walk to work or catch public transport five kilometres away in Dambuza.
Four KwaDabeka residents in Durban were injured after ANC members attacked other ANC members who are supporting a different candidate in the upcoming general elections.
About 500 people marched through the streets of Wentworth, Durban, singing and chanting against gang violence in the area.

In a peaceful protest action that took place at the Pick n Pay head office in Cape Town, Greenpeace activists delivered a three meter high solar PV 'engagement ring' to Pick n Pay's CEO Richard Brasher, and two climbers unfurled a banner above the entrance to the headquarters with the message 'Pick n Pay: say yes to the sun'.
Protesters looted the Diepsloot mall, burnt tyres and threw stones at vehicles on the R511, near Diepsloot. An ambulance was damaged during the violent protest.
Residents and colleagues of a man who was beaten up, protested outside the alleged attackers' business in Groblersdal.
A man accused of stealing 11 goats was beaten to death and a car set alight at Moretele village near Taung.
Two people were doused in petrol and set alight for apparently stealing a laptop in George during the week. No deaths were reported.
A 500-strong crowd in Ilitha township near Berlin protested against the nomination of Gideon Norexe as their ward candidate for the August 3 elections.

As the Democratic Alliance leader was in KwaDwesi township, residents were protesting and the car announcing his arrival on a loudhailer was stoned. Residents were angry oer the candidate list for the upcoming elections.

Two Golden Arrow buses were torched and several cars stoned in Barcelona, Ward 40. The culprits said they were ANC members disgruntled with the party's councillor list for the local government elections. Police fired rubber bullets and lobbed stun grenades to disperse the 200 protesters.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Protesters (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Workers from NEHAWU gathered outside Parliament in Cape Town and sang and danced over the suspension of two comrades. At the same time, 300 Congolese nationals marched to Parliament to plead with the government to mediate in a political crisis in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC).

As many as 3 000 people protested outside a guest house in Sodwana Bay (Shazibe) in northern KwaZulu-Natal, where the owner allegedly refuses to take bookings from black people and government employees.
Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) regional leadership joined disgruntled workers who took to the streets of the city and closed down the entrance at Isivuno House on Lillian Ngoyi Street in the CBD.
Residents marched to the Bhisho legislature and handed over their list of demands, saying they had been given empty promises for several decades and were now demanding action.

column7: POPCRU: Police, Prisons and Civil Rights Union
column17: The Police and Prisons Civil Rights Union (Popcru) gathered at the Jan Smuts stadium before marching to the correctional services offices in East London.
An ANC Youth League chairperson in Msunduzi and a branch coordinator were physically attacked during a meeting to introduce electoral candidates in KwaMncane (KZN).
About 80 pupils and activists from Equal Education protested outside the home of the Western Cape Education MECs home in Bergvliet.

column7: SANEF: South African National Editors Forum; Journalists (South Africa)
column17: Scores of journalists and social activists gathered outside the South African Broadcasting Corporation headquarters in Auckland Park to heed the #BlackFriday rallying call to protest against the censorship of news content.
Protesters blockading the N2 near the Borcherds Quarry Road (Cape Town Airport) turn-off caused a six car pile-up.
Protests have broken out on the Beitbridge border post between South Africa and Zimbabwe over new restrictions imposed on imports.

column7: SANEF: South African National Editors Forum; Journalists (South Africa)
column17: Journalists and memebr of the South African National Editors' Forum have picketed outside the SABC's offices in Seapoint, Cape Town, in solidarity with the public broadcaster's staff who were dismissed from the SABC.
Ehlanzeni Technical Vocational Education and Training (TVET) College students staged a sit-in and afterwards burnt part of the institutions offices in Mbombela.
Hundreds of community health workers who claimed not to have been paid for two months took their frustrations to the national Department of Health offices in Pretorias city centre.

column7: SANEF: South African National Editors Forum; Journalists (South Africa)
column17: Scores of journalists and social activists gathered outside the South African Broadcasting Corporation's studios in Durban to heed the #BlackFriday rallying call to protest against the censorship of news content.

column9: ANC: African National Congress; Women (South Africa)
column17: An ANC candidate for ward six outside Osizweni in Newcastle, was shot dead in her home.

Residents of Mataffin, outside Mbombela, marched to the Mbombela Municipality demanding that the municipality evict those occupying the land illegally and protested by blockading access roads into the settlement in protest over the selling of land.
Icasa workers downed tools and picketed outside the Johannesburg offices (Sandton) over payments.
Icasa workers continued their strike and picketed outside the Sandton, Johannesburg offices over payments.

Protest started in Leaches Beach as residents closing off the R72 near the East London Airport. There was no damage done or reported, some motorists travelling in and out of the airport were affected by the blockade. Some demonstrators are arrested at the scene.

Twenty-eight supporters of the National Freedom Party were arrested after they blockaded a busy road on the turn-off to Ulundi near Melmoth. Police had used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd as hundreds of people and barricaded the road with burning tyres and huge logs.
A protest outside the Department of Health's offices in Pretoria took place , with community health workers demanding to be absorbed into the health system.

Rubber bullets and stun grenades were used in Sydenham after a private security company was sent in to evict 31 families from their homes. Community members gathered at the entrance of Howell Road, burning tyres and blocking off the area.
A main road was barricaded by protesters with debris and burning tyres placed along the Rand-Vaal interchange in Randvaal in protests over housing.
Former DA leader Tony Leon and DA members took part in a march against drugs and crime in Chatsworth, Durban.

The South African Communist Party held a picket outside the broadcasters Johannesburg offices opposing the ANCs decision to stand against censorship and the reviewed editorial policy at the public broadcaster was welcomed.

Angry Leaches Bay residents continued to protest over a lack of electricity in their homes. The crowd burned tyres in one of the township's main roads. A few members of the community held Councillor Ntsiki Peter hostage demanding that electricity be restored in their area.
A protest outside the Department of Health's offices in Pretoria continued for second day , with community health workers demanding to be absorbed into the health system.

An angry Limpopo community in Mecklenburg has vandalised a police station after a suspected fraudster who allegedly took their money in exchange for the promise of jobs, was set free. A total of 23 people, 18 women and five men, were arrested for public violence and malicious damage to property.
Icasa workers continued their strike and picketed outside the Sandton, Johannesburg offices over payments.
Armed guards are manning the entrances at Sydenham hospital where a worker was attacked by striking workers demanding to be in-sourced.
Protesting members of the National Freedom Party (NFP) were arrested in Bergville after streets had been turned into waste dumps as members destroyed trash bins and burned tyres.
Supporters of Scalabrini Centre's 'Let's Face It' campaign demonstrated outside the Cape Town Houses of Parliament.
Protesters are burning tyres and blocking roads with rocks in Finetown, south of Johannesburg, complaining about a lack of electricity.
A protest outside the Department of Health's offices in Pretoria continued for third day, with community health workers demanding to be absorbed into the health system.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; Right2Know
column17: Icasa workers continued their strike and picketed outside the Sandton, Johannesburg offices over payments. There was also a piket by the Congress of South African Trade Unions and the Right2know campaign.

ANC members protested in Port Elizabeths Kwazakhele township, throwing stones and damaging property in the area where national executive committee member Bheki Cele was to go on a door-to-door campaign.
Icasa workers continued their strike and picketed outside the Sandton, Johannesburg offices over payments.
More than 50 ANC supporters protested at the ANC constituency office in Philippi over the candidate standing in the 3 August election for ward 80.
Members of the Johannesburg Kashmiri solidarity group of South Africa protested against the visit of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi who visited the Constitution Hill in Braamfontein.
A group of protesters from the Kennedy Road informal settlement petrol bombed an eThekwini Municipality bus and truck.
Local residents in Mapela, Limpopo, have beaten an alleged Bangladeshi kidnapper to death after 4 men held a local resident hostage.
A Limpopo man who allegedly took part in the murder of an 82-year-old woman was killed in a mob justice attack.

Protest action took place in Woodlands, Pietermaritzburg over unhappiness about the performance of a councillor. There was the burning of tyres on the road and toyi-toying in which protesters also threw stones from the Ottos Bluff Road bridge at passing vehicles.
In Port Elizabeth, Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University students and SASCO members protested against the withholding of results and some being prevented from starting their second semester.

Residents in Mamelodi were embroiled in a violent fight with the metro police and Red Ants after a few of their shacks were demolished. Residents threw stones and empty bottles at the police and the Red Ants. Some formal houses were damaged by the demonstrators who smashed their windows.
Residents of Sendedza village outside of Thohoyandou dragged a man accused of murder to a local sports ground and assaulted him.

While resident were assaulting a suspected murderer, they turned on police and through rocks at them. Roads were barricaded with big rocks and trees, police continued to deal with that situation until one of their vehicle was burnt to ashes and another pelted with stones, leading to serious damages on the vehicle windscreen.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; Taxi Drivers (South Africa)
column17: The Congress of South African Trade Unions in the Western Cape protested the state of public transport in Cape Town, a move which the City labelled an election stunt. At the same time, about 60 Uber drivers protested outside the offices of the Western Cape government Offices in Wale Street, asking Premier Helen Zille's help in their dispute with their employer.
Violent protest action has closed the N2 and other arterial roads that surround the informal settlement of Shakas Head near Ballito. Protesters stoned passing cars and had erected burning blockades.
Residents of an informal camp in Port Elizabeth protested on the streets demanding security, electricity and toilets (service delivery).
A EFF branch commander has been shot and injured, along with his brother in Vrygrond. The suspects are unknown.
During a confrontation between strikers and security guards at King Edward VIII hospital in Durban, two people were shot dead.

Violence has erupted again in Vuwani in Limpopo, with protesters targeted passing vehicles, including a police van. Renewed violence broke out as residents took to the streets, pelting passing motorists with stones.

Five vehicles including an ambulance were burnt down in Sunrise Park near Rustenburg. The torched cars include a bakkie belonging to the Rustenburg municipality, a mine ambulance, two bakkies and a Toyota Quantum minibus owned by security companies.

column7: SAITA: South African Informal Traders Alliance
column17: Western Cape informal traders (South African Informal Traders Alliance) marched to the office of the Western Cape Premier, demanding better treatment from provincial and national government. They want to be treated the same as other businesses.
About 50 members of a group called Black Solidarity Action, led by Khayelitsha pastor Xola Skosana, marched on the US embassy in Tokai to protest police killings of black people in the United States.
Protesters at Eskom subsidiary Rotek sang loudly outside the gates of the companies Rosherville operations (Germiston) as a strike over performance bonuses continued.
Dozens of meter taxi drivers clashed with police in Cape Town, in a protest that ended in at least 15 arrests and threats to burn any Uber that entered the city centre

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Protest action broke out in Meyerton as municipal employees at the Midvaal Municipality barricaded roads with rocks and burning tyres. SAMWU member were taking part in the protest and a member was shot in the leg with a rubber bullet while two other members have been arrested.
Zimbabwean immigrants in Cape Town demonstrated and called for the removal of disgraced President Robert Mugabe after almost three decades of rule.
Hundreds of Zimbabwean protesters gathered outside the Zimbabwean Embassy in Pretoria to demand that President Robert Mugabe step down.
Protesters and R2K members protested outlisde Luthuli House in Johannesburg over demands for the SABC to change its policy.

The South African Communist Party (SACP) demonstrated outside the ANN7 news channel offices in Midrand over the suspension of staff who had objected to a visit by the ANC Youth League president earlier this year.
Members of the Right2Know campaign picketed outside the Umlazi police station in Durban in an effort to draw attention to the spate of killings at Glebelands Hostel.

About 1500 grandmothers marched on Durbans International Convention Centre, where the 2016 World Aids Conference is set to begin, to demand greater recognition for the plight they face and the role they face in fighting the deadly HIV/Aids epidemic that is ravaging the continent.
About 5,000 people, including TAC members, have marched to the International Convention Centre in Durban, venue of the 21st International Aids Conference.
Another KwaZulu-Natal ANC member and candidate councillor was shot dead while dropping his children at school.

column9: ANC: African National Congress; Women (South Africa)
column17: An KwaZulu-Natal ANC member and candidate councillor was shot dead on her way to a Mandela Day event in Ladysmith.

A group of Black First, Land First protesters forced their way into Public Protector Thuli Madonsela's Pretoria offices and allegedly held some staff hostage. No violence or damage to property was recorded.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: Numsa workers arranged a picket outside Eskom head office at Megawatt Park.

Several creche-going children from the Tshepong Day Care in Mamelodi east in Pretoria, accompanied by adult well-wishers doing their Mandela Day duty took to the streets to condemn rampant drug abuse.
Around 200 people, including DA members, protested outside Parliament to deliver a list of demands to ANC Chief Whip Jackson Mthembu over the recent happenings at the SABC.
Astra Primary School in Bethelsdorp near Port Elizabeth was closed by angry parents who shut the school gates, picketed and burned tyres. They are demanding the provision of ten more teachers.

column7: DENOSA: Democratic Nursing Organisation of South Africa; Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Doctors and nurses, with the support of DENOSA, brought Prince Mshiyeni Hospital to a standstill with a lunch-hour protest. Police used tear gas to disperse protesters outside the hospital gates after numerous warnings that they were contravening a court order which prohibited them from picketing within 500m of the gates.
At the exhibition hall at the 21st International AIDS Conference in Durban as activists from Section27 and the TAC protested against the price of Gilead Sciences' HIV and hepatitis drugs.
Residents of Zamimpilo informal settlement near Riverlea, south of Johannesburg blocked roads and burnt tyres demanding houses.

The South African Communist Party (SACP) in the Western Cape held a protest in Sea Point and demanded the immediate dismissal of the South African Broadcasting Corporation (SABC) chief operations officer (COO) Hlaudi Motsoeneng.

Five well-known ANC members in the ward, protested outside the home of a rival ANC candidate on his return from an interview at a local radio station. The protesters reportedly started throwing stones at his car.
A crowd of around 150 people gathered and forced Madibeng FM, a community radio station in Brits, to cancel a live interview with critics of the community's leadership.
Local and international activists marched to the Indian consulate in Durban to deliver a message to the Indian ambassador to take to their government.

There was chaos on the R59 in Meyerton with police officers firing rubber bullets and teargas as residents from the nearby Sicelo informal settlement went on the rampage, blocking the R59 with burning tyres and large rocks.
A mobile classroom was partly burnt down by a mob at Piet Plessis, near Stella, in North West.

Two Inkatha Freedom Party members have been shot dead in the uMtshezi area near Estcourt in KwaZulu-Natal. The suspects were reportedly confronted by people allegedly wearing African National Congress T-shirts.

column7: PAGAD: People Against Gangsterism and Drugs
column17: PAGAD members demonstrated outside the Bellville Magistrates Court where Cape Town businessman Irshaad Laher and Vereeniging arms dealer Alan Raves appeared.
Disabled activists protested at the ICC in Durban during th HIV coference complaining about the lack of disabled issues at the conference.
An eNCA journalist has been attacked by protesters during a service delivery protest in Meyerton.
A silent protest by SABC television news staff, who all dressed in black when they were on camera reportedly took place in Auckland Park.

A group of angry protesteras in Mbekweni, unhappy over housing, protested on land belonging to the municipality. Sporadic flare-ups ensued over the weekend, in which one municipal firefighter was stoned and injured and a centre was damaged.

On 25 June 2016, ongoing violence continued in the Mbekweni area, with irate residents setting Drakenstein Municipality vehicles and foreign-owned spaza shops alight in a demonstration over housing. [size=no report]
Homeless people in Cape Town marched to the civic centre to protest against treatment they believed rendered them undesirables.

The KwaZulu-Natal Zimbabwe Solidarity movement marched through the streets of Durban to hand a petition to city officials calling for an end to police brutality, arrests and the disappearance of peaceful activists in Zimbabwe.
About 100 people from the Kusile area protested, demanding jobs at the Kusile Power Station in Mpumalanga. Protesters allegedly throwing rocks at passing vehicles.
ANC ward candidate Nceba Dywili was gunned down in the Zwide township of Port Elizabeth in Nelson Mandela Bay.

The Johannesburg Metro Police Department urged motorists to avoid Boundary and Union roads in Kliptown due to protest action. Protesters were throwing rocks at passing vehicles while police arrested 6 people.
Classrooms were burnt down at Setilo Secondary school at Mareetsane Village near Mafikeng in the North West due to alleged political violence.
Two students who were part of a group protesting against accommodation fees in Braamfontein sustained injuries to their heads after being hit by rubber bullets.

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: Chaos erupted in Johannesburg when a group of EFF supporters and EFF student command protested at the Nelson Mandela Bridge. Protesters also stoned a vehicle, shattering its windows and one person was shot in the eye, as police fired rubber bullets in a bid to disperse the crowd.

column7: CEPPWAWU: Chemical Energy Paper Printing Wood and Allied Workers Union
column17: Striking members of the Chemical, Energy, Printing, Paper, Wood and Allied Workers Union (CEPPWAWU) picketed outside Chevron Refinery in Cape Town.

column6: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column9: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: A Pikitup staff member was killed in Johannesburg and another one critically injured after South African Municipal Workers Union (Samwu) members were shot at by union officials' private bodyguards.

In Elsies River, a man was allegedly attacked by Kirk Walker, husband of DA ward 26 candidate Franchesca Walker, after hequestioned why the DA was fielding 'fraudsters and thieves' in Wednesday's local elections.
A protest prevented Independent Electoral Commission of South Africa (IEC) officials from working in Ward 1 at the Umzimkhulu Municipality near Kokstad.
Rocks and stones were thrown at DA ward candidate by angry residents while he was campaigning in Bonteheuwel.
Elections were disrupted in protests included some voting districts in Ward 8 in Amathole.

In Cambridge in East London, police fired rubber bullets and had to use teargas to disperse residents who burnt tyres and threw stones, demanding that ANC member Mbulelo Vula be the candidate for their ward and not the person listed on their ballot papers.

In Chatsworth, a group of residents from the Bottlebrush informal settlement near Croftdene had stoned vehicles passing on the link road from the Higginson Highway in an apparent protest over piped water.
In Mzinyonke in Ezakheni near Ladysmith, voting was interrupted when residents blockaded the road. Riot police were deployed to manage the situation.

Police, responding to an incident at at voting station, attempted to disperse a group of people. The group started to attack the police with stones and managed to grab the service pistol from one of the members and assaulted another officer,"" said Otto.
An African National Congress supporter was dragged out of a voting queue and struck several times with a panga (larfe knife ir Machete) in the Pongolo municipality.
Elections were disrupted as protests took place in Ward 16 in Ntabankulu.
Order has been restored to the IECs Gauteng results centre in Pretoria after protest action by presiding officers threatened the counting process.
A mob of young men believed to belong to a gang called Ruff 3, armed with pangas, knives and guns, attacked and looted three houses in Extension 13 in Tsakane.

EFF supporters stood holding placards referring to President Jacob Zuma's rape accuser, known as Khwezi, who went into exile following his acquittal, as he rose to deliver the closing address at the IEC announcements ceremony in Pretoria.

The demolition of shacks illegally built on municipal land in Mayville sparked a violent protest on the N2 highway heading south just after Spaghetti Junction which caused a major traffic jam. Protesters blocked the freeway with debris and burning tyres, threatening motorists who forced their way through the crowd.
At Rhodes University in Grahamstown, a group of student activists protest the arrival of Higher Education and Training Deputy Minister Mduduzi Manana and barred him from the institution.
The police again dispersed protesters from Mayville who blockaded the N2. No arrests or violence was reported by police as protesters burnt tyres and blockaded the road.

column7: SACBTA: Southern Africa Cross-Border Traders Association
column17: Police broke up a protest, led by the Cross-Border Traders Association, at the Beitbridge border (Musina) post. People are protesting against Zimbabwe limiting imports from South Africa.
About 40 female students marched from Fort Hare campus down Oxford Street to challenge attitudes to rape, and to encourage survivors to report the rapes committed against them.

column7: UJW: Union of Jewish Women; WCRLF: Western Cape Religious Leaders Forum; IWPG: International Women's Peace Group; Women (South Africa)
column17: A group of women gathered in Cape Town and marched for women's right. The march featured members from Western Cape Religious Leaders Forum, Union of Jewish Women and the International Women's Peace Group.
A block of four classrooms was destroyed in a fire in Vuwani, Limpopo in apparent violent protest.
Police fired at striking workers who were protesting peacefully outside Hendrina Power station in South Africas eastern Mpumalanga Provine, injuring several of them.
In Hout Bay, Wynberg taxi drivers went on strike and blocked the road in protest, causing heavy traffic, road closures and inconvenience to commuters.

About 50 residents of informal settlements in Mfuleni protested, blocking streets with burning tyres and garbage. They are furious that their ward councillor, Themba Honono (ANC), has not helped them get an electricity connection.

column7: CEPPWAWU: Chemical Energy Paper Printing Wood and Allied Workers Union
column17: A handful of Ceppwawu workers picketed outside the Sasol refinery in Alberton.
A group of residents representing the independents and the IFP protested in the main road through Inanda, wit the aim of having the electoral results scrapped.

Protesters, unhappy over service delivery, were trying to burn down the municipality's building in Refilwe, Cullinan. Angry locals had tried to torch police Nyala vehicles with petrol bombs and thre rocks.
A couple, including a prospective ANC councillor, was killed in their home in Mayamuleni, Tsolo.

Approximately 100 Telkom workers with the Communications Workers Union (CWU) marched from Keizersgracht Street to the telephone company's Cape Town offices today to hand over a memorandum demanding a wage increase

Students in Libode near Port St Johns burnt down classrooms and two storerooms, and removed taps from water tanks at Mhlanganisweni Technical & Commercial High School yesterday. They were protesting against the Eastern Cape Department of Education.

The shooting of a suspected poacher by rangers in South Africas biggest wildlife park set off protests by villagers living nearby. residents of the village of the suspected poacher had used stones, branches and burning tires to block a road 12 miles.
A man was assaulted in Imbali in an apparent mob justice attack.
Student protest erupted at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Pietermaritzburg campus over fee increases.
Angry residents of Asanda Village in Strand have vandalised and looted at least eight spaza shops owned by Somalis after a resident was shot dead, allegedly during a dispute with a shopkeeper.
Angry villagers closed down several schools in villages near Libode. They are demanding the immediate removal of an ANC ward councillor candidate elected during the recent local government elections.
Angry citizens at the Department of Labour in the Durban CBD stoned staff cars after they were turned away from its offices.

Nineteen people arrested following a violent protest in Inanda on Monday. The road blockaded with burning rubble and tyres. A bus was set alight while a metro police officer was shot in the mouth and arm during the protest

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students; Students (South Africa)
column17: Chaos erupted outside the University Johannesburgs Doornfontein campus on Monday when protesting Congress of South African Students (Cosas) attempted to block roads. They held placards a few hundred meters from the university entrance that read ""fees must fall"" and ""free education"" and set alight bins in the vicinity
Mangosuthu University of Technology in Durban after sporadic student protests against the increase in fees.
A municipal worker was gunned down and killed in the car park outside the municipal offices in Nongoma.

In a second day of protests, the Pietermaritzburg UKZN campus was closed on Monday and will remain closed on Tuesday in the wake of student protests over possible fee increases. A student was reportedly assaulted during the protests.
Disgruntled residents of an informal settlement in the area took to the N2, burning tyres and bringing north-bound traffic to a standstill in Blackburn.
Dr Nomafrench Mbombo led a march at Tygerberg Hospital to endorse a #Khuseleka campaign, which promotes a safe working environment for all health-care professionals.

column7: LSF: Left Students Forum; Students (South Africa)
column17: Workers, joined by about 100 students and members of the Left Students Forum, staged a protest at UCT over outsourcing.
Student protest entered their third day at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Pietermaritzburg campus.
In a reported mob justice attack, a man was found dead in Mfuleni.
Angry villagers closed down several schools in villages near Libode. They are demanding the immediate removal of an ANC ward councillor candidate elected during the recent local government elections.
Protests continued as disgruntled residents of an informal settlement in the area took to the N2, burning tyres and bringing north-bound traffic to a standstill in Blackburn.
Striking workers at pharmaceutical company Aspen Pharmacare in Port Elizabeth picketed over the management of breaking the rules by removing a water tap. The workers were joined by EFF members.
In Cape Town, protestors from the social justice organisation Right2Know gathered outside the SABCs Sea Point offices and held a candlelight vigil for the slain miners
In a protest in Keats Drift, near Msinga, about 150 protesters barricaded a road with burning tyres and rocks.
The owners of shacks demolished on a private property in Sydenham have demonstrated their anger by burning down two municipal trucks in the past two days.
Hundreds of Wonderkop residents in Marikana gathered to honour miners killed by police on August 16 2012.

A large crowd of Wits University students marched silently through the institutions grounds in solidarity with victims of gender violence on campus and beyond. The event marked the 10th anniversary of the Silent Protest March which was started at Rhodes University.
Students shut Walter Sisulu Universitys Nelson Mandela Drive campus in Mthatha in protest.
In Mbhashe municipality, members of the community burst into the council chamber trying to prevent the swearing-in ceremony from taking place.

Members of the public disrupted the swearing-in ceremonies of councillors and the election of mayors, council speakers and chief whips in the Mnguma municipality. Police fired rubber bullets at the crowd as protesters destroyed property.
In a fourth day of protest action, police and security guards fired paintball and rubber bullets at protesting students at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Pietermaritzburg campus.
The owners of shacks demolished on a private property in Sydenham have demonstrated their anger by burning down two municipal trucks in the past two days.
Hundreds of Ethiopian refugees, and members of the oromo Peoples Association, living in South Africa protested in Johannesburg condemning the recent killing of 97 protesters in Ethiopia.
Lectures were also suspended after protests at the UKZNs Westville campuses in ongoing student protests over fees.

Hundreds of Walter Sisulu University students in Mthatha, blocked the N2. Some threw stones at passing cars. The students were demanding answers to concerns they have about their university fees. Police fired teargas to disperse them.
A Democratic Alliance councillor has been shot dead in Danielkuil in the Northern Cape.
Police presence was ramped up in Westbury and Newclare' west of Johannesburg' as the community protested against crime in the area.
Two students were arrested as protests continued on UKZNs Pietermaritzburg campus.
Protesters held placards with the names of ward councillors they want removed at the inauguration of the new councillors at Pietermaritzburg City Hall.
Protests started at the Buffalo City campus in East London with students protesting over fees.
Lectures were suspended after protests at the UKZNs Westville campuses in ongoing student protests over fees.
Police are investigating a case of arson after six Mangosuthu University of Technology (MUT) buses were burned at the university in Umlazi, Durban.
Students at Walter Sisulu Universitys Bika campus participated in a blockade of the N2 during which motor vehicles were pelted with stones. Ten students were arrested during a protest.

column7: Black Sash; SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union; KZNCSOC: KwaZulu-Natal Civil Society Coalition
column17: Non-profit civil society organisations came out in force to protest outside the department of social development (DSD) offices in Phoenix, near Durban. Organisations such as the Black Sash, the SA Democratic Teachers Union and the KZN Civil Society Coalition
After an ANC member was assautled, ANC supporters dressed in party T-shirts, tried to force their way into a meeting in Rustenburg.
An ANC supporter was assaulted by EFF supporters who were trying to bar the ANC from entering a hall in Rustenburg.

After three people were arrested following an assault, community members threw stones at the police vehicles and police fired warning shots to disperse them. One community member was allegedly hit by a bullet and died

One man was arrested after several skirmishes between police and protesters in Chesterville, Durban. Riot police faced-off with the stone-wielding protesters and fired rubber bullets to disperse them. One person was arrested.

Zimbabwean nationals living in the Eastern Cape marched in Port Elizabeth to express their anger at their government. The marchers demanded the immediate resignation of president Robert Mugabe blaming him for causing starvation and creating record unemployment.
A 35-year-old man was allegedly assaulted (killed) by community members, as he was allegedly involved in housebreakings and robberies in Masingatha near King Williams Town.
A 40-year-old SACP supporter was shot and killed by unknown suspects in the Fredville area, Inchanga.
After the killing of two people, residents blocked the roads with burning tyres and stones in Inchanga. Five houses were torched during the violent protest action.
An African National Congress (ANC) member was shot in a suspected revenge attack in Inchanga.

After hearing that the SAPS, Tshwane Metro and the Red Ants were on the way to demolish houses in Memelodi East, occupiers gathered on the roadside, blocking it with bricks and burning rubble. Police fired rubber bullets to disperse the group.

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students; Students (South Africa)
column17: In Buffalo City, SRC members led a group of 400 students. They forced their way into residences kicking doors, and threw water at students who refused to join the protest.
About 50 supporters of Right2Know protested outside Parliament in Cape Town, demanding that steps be taken to resolve the SABC crisis.

column7: DENOSA: Democratic Nursing Organisation of South Africa; Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Nurses, aligned to DENOSA, at the KwaMashu Community Health Centre embarked on a wildcat protest outside the polyclinic over what they allege is poor management of the facility.
In the unstable region of Inchanga, plumes of smoke from burning tyres filled the air, with hundreds of residents in different sections of Ward 4 stoking the fires and chanting slogans.
Around 200 employees from Telkom, affiliated to the Communication Workers Union (CWU), protested outside Luthuli House in the Joburg CBD.

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students; Students (South Africa)
column17: The Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University (NMMU) was affected by student protests' with lectures and tests postponed in response to protest action that saw about 300 students' many affiliated to the South African Students Congress' blocking an entrance to the south campus.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Protest action took place as members of the National Health and Allied Workers Union (Nehawu) took to action in the Nelson Mandela Bay Metro. Nehawu museum shop steward Ncediwe Ndima said the protest was peaceful and visitors were not being intimidated.

column7: CSAAWU: Commercial, Stevedoring and Allied Workers Union
column17: Workers at Robertson Winery went on strike and protested outside the winery over wages. The workers were supported by the Commercial, Stevedoring and Allied Workers Union (CSAAWU).
There was violence between police and residents of Elsie's River on the Cape Flats. After 3 houses were demolished eesidents burnt barricades blocking on 9th Avenue and Police fired rubber bullets.
Villagers pelted police with stones and damaged police vehicles while police responded with rubber bullets. 16 were arrested while 1 students was killed in Mount Ayliff.
While normality returned to Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University (NMMU) campuses in Port Elizabeth, its George campus was hit by an unexpected protest.

Th Social Justice Coalition and Equal Education led residents in a protest march to Premier Helen Zille's office (Cape Town) demanding authorities implement recommendations of the Khayelitsha Commission of Inquiry.
A group of Pretoria students decided to make a stand against the discriminatory rules on hair at their assembly meeting (Pretoria Girls High School) by dressing all in black and wearing headwraps.

column7: WAVA: Women Against Violence and Abuse; Women (South Africa)
column17: Residents of Shaudeville, Port Elizabeth marched to highlight the problems of drug abuse and gangsterism in their neighbourhood. The protesters were led by a group called Women Against Violence and Abuse
Bromwell Street tenants supported by activist group Reclaim the City marched through Woodstock to oppose their imminent evictions from their homes.
About 30 volunteers made a united stand when they formed a human chain around the Sardinia Bay Surf Lifesaving Club in a last-ditch attempt to stop it from being demolished.

column7: CSAAWU: Commercial, Stevedoring and Allied Workers Union
column17: Robertson Winery workers continued with their protest outside the the offices in Robertson, with the help of the CSAAWU. The union alleges employers were using their wealth, power and status to fight them.
A fire was put out at a University of KwaZulu-Natal campus in Durban after it was burnt in an arson attack during student protests. Those responsible are unknown.
Telkom workers with the help of the CWU picketed outside the company offices in Port Elizabeth, demanding a 9% salary increase.
Pupils at Pretoria High School for Girls claim they have been subjected to racism and that their blackness has been discouraged. They protested outside the school.

column7: Students (South Africa); EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters
column17: Students, joined by Economic Freedom Fighters supporters, protested in the street in front of a PE school in protest before moving to the school hall.
At UKZN Pietermaritzburg campus, a fire caused damaged to an exam venue. Arson is suspected given the recent student protests.
Angry Grade 12 pupils from Nogemane Senior Secondary School in Ntibane Village, Ngqeleni, set a block of classrooms alight demanding that the school fund a farewell ceremony for them.

At Sandi Senior Secondary School in Ntsundwana Village, pupils could not write their trial exams as a strike continued. Pupils there also went on a rampage and burnt some classrooms, while others were chased away by locals who had accused them of instigating the strike.
At Howard College campus in Durban, student protests continued over fee increases.
Residents of Sydenham Manor, formerly Sydenham Heights, protested against a court summons issued to many over unpaid levies. More than 100 families have fallen behind on their levies
Residents along with the lobby group Parkscape in Tokai protested and held placards/displayed banners to highlight their concerns over the felling of trees in the area.

A school in the OR Tambo district has been torched - this time the Chief Henry Bokleni (CHB) High School near Libode was set alight. It is not clear who set fire to the school this time around, community members suspected it was some pupils because the fire had started shortly after they had staged a protest.

Chaos erupted at Lovedale TVET College as angry students at the Alice campus damaged property, blocked the road for passing cars and attempted to burn their campus. Police fired rubber bullets to disperse the protesters.
The Social Justice Coalition (SJC) marched with family and neighbours of slain Nomanesi Klawushe, demanding the end of gender-based violence.
A group of students at the University of Free State (Bloemfontein) protested and voiced their frustrations with the SRC for prioritising race over women's issues.
A Fort Beaufort contractor and his workers chained to a fence in a remote corner of little Kwandulwazi Primary in Ncera village in protest.
Protesters, believed to be University of KwaZulu-Natal students, stoned cars and barricaded a major thoroughfare in Clare Estate, Durban.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Disgruntled NMMU staff members with NEHAWU staged a peaceful march in Port Elizabeth to highlight their dissatisfaction with their working conditions.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Protesters (Gabon); Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: About 150 people protested in the parliamentary precinct, led by the National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union (Nehawu) over the suspension of their branch chairperson. At the same time, at least 400 Gabonese nationals living in South Africa staged a demonstration at the French Consulate in Cape Town over the disputed election results back home.

Dozens of learners at Sans Souci High School in Cape Towns southern suburbs (Newlands) protested in the school grounds against what a student described as the racist tendencies of the school authorities.
The Fees Commission hearing held at East London City Hall had to be suspended after angry students who stormed the venue in protest.
More than 100 pupils from various high schools in Cape Town protested at Sans Souci Girls High School after first joining countrywide protests against discriminatory school policies on Thursday.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: The #OccupyLuthuliHouse movement - an anti-Zuma grouping - was given an opportunity by the National Press Club to brief members. During the briefing, leaders of the Tshwane ANC Youth League stormed in and brought proceedings to a halt in protest.
East London residents took part in a protest march against Buffalo City Metros ""high"" water and electricity tariffs.

An Ekurhuleni disaster and emergency management services (DEMS) fire engine was set alight by community members in Moleleki section Katlehong. Members of the public confronted them with stones and rocks, breaking all the windows and forcing the crew to abandon the vehicle.

Ward 17 residents in Pietermaritzburg took to the streets over two days to demand that the Msunduzi Municipality resolve the water problems the community has faced. Roads leading to Imbali Unit BB and surrounding areas were blocked with stones, dried tree branches and burning tyres.

column9: Government of South Africa (1994-); Women (South Africa)
column17: The mayor of Enoch Mgijima municipality escaped serious injury, when her house was engulfed in flames.
Residents of Gxididi village outside Mthatha burnt tyres and blockaded the main gravel roadwhile chanting derogatory songs. The residents were angry over the location of a R2-million community hall.
There were protests at the universities Howard College campus in Durban in ongoing protests. At the protests police arrested 13 students.
There were protests at the universities Pietermaritzburg campus, as well as protests at the universities Howard College campus in Durban in ongoing protests.
Between 150 and 200 pupils gathered outside the Sastri College in Greyville, Durban to express their unhappiness with the schools rules pertaining to hair.
#OccupyLuthuliHouse protesters (ANC supporters) gathered outside Luthuli house in Johannesburg in protest over the ANC.

Six vehicles were torched and a building gutted by fire on UKZNs Westville campus in ongoing protest action in KZN. Protesters also threw stones at the police, vandalised the centre management office using stones and blocked the road

Protesters in the Mshwathi Municipality (Wartburg), near New Hanover, caused damage estimated at R10 million when they torched government property, demanding a library and that their ward councillor step down.

Ward 17 residents in Pietermaritzburg took to the streets over two days to demand that the Msunduzi Municipality resolve the water problems the community has faced. Roads leading to Imbali Unit BB and surrounding areas were blocked with stones, dried tree branches and burning tyres.

Roads were closed off in Pietermaritzburg when about 70 students protested while about 200 students set alight six vehicles and burnt the building's senate chambers. police had to use rubber bullets to disperse the protesters in Pietermaritzburg.

About 250 students participated in the protests at Howard College. A group of students protested inside the campus throwing stones at the police. They also burnt campus property including a Law Library. They threw stones at the police. Police had to use rubber bullets to disperse them
About 50 participated in the protests at the Westville campus. Students, university security and police engaged in running battles at the Howard College, Pietermaritzburg and Westville campuses.
Student protesters brought an early end to the hearings of the Fees Commission as students occupied the Cape Town Centre for the Book during a university fees meeting.
Storerooms and classrooms were torched during two days of protests at Joe Slovo High School in Khayelitsha. Police were called in and fired rubber bullets.
A group of Mamelodi East residents began protesting after their shacks were demolished. They barricaded Tsamaya Road with burning tyres and stones
After police arrested a rape suspect, angry residents marched to the station demanding the man be handed over to them.
Police spokesperson Andre Beetge said the woman who allegedly abducted some children was assaulted by a large group of residents in Kwazakhele.

Zimbane campus and Cicirha main campus, both in Mthatha, joined the protest. Groups from different campuses gathered outside the main campus throwing stones and demanding those inside the campus leave. Police also used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.
About 200 residents attacked a rape suspect in New Brighton. In the vigilante attack a 30-year-old man sustained serious injuries.

In protests, high school pupils travelled from Khayelitsha to the Cape Town CBD in a bid to engage the Western Cape education department about a R5 penalty pupils are charged for late-coming, which resulted in a riot at Joe Slovo High School on Tuesday.
Storerooms and classrooms were torched during two days of protests at Joe Slovo High School in Khayelitsha. Police were called in and fired rubber bullets.
A group made up mostly of female students gathered at the main campus in Pietermaritzburg to protest against the alleged rape of a female student by a police officer.
About 40 disgruntled parents picketed outside Settlers Park Primary School in Walmer, calling for the immediate removal of principal Andre Schlemmer and four teachers.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: The striking NEHAWU workers gathered and sang outside the Parliament, calling for their leaders's suspension to be lifted.

Student residences were set alight at two King Sabatha Dalindyebo Technical and Vocational Training campuses. Police used rubber bullets to disperse a group of over 100 students at KSD college, Zimbane campus in Mthatha
A similar incident of violence at Ntabozuko Campus in Elliotdale, students set alight two residences forcing students to evacuate.
Firefighters were pelted with stones by angry protesters when they arrived to put out a fire at the Durban University of Technology's Steve Biko campus.
Over a hundred students from Bulumko and Joe Slovo Secondary schools protested outside the Western Cape Department of Education (WCED) offices.
A school boy was shot in the mouth in Pietermaritzburg with a rubber bullet, after police fired rubber bullets at angry residents protesting over water shortages.

Two student managed to blockade the University of Cape Town (UCT) and stop the Jammie Shuttle service from running. The mini-protest called for the university to listen to complaints by students and insourced workers.
Protesters stripped while objecting to allegedly not having been paid their wages in five months in Centurion.
Pupils at Qunu Junior Secondary School broke windows and burned down a storeroom and kitchen on the weekend.
Four people were allegedly attacked by a mob in Libode at the weekend over the election of a ward councillor for Nyandeni municipalities ward 15.
Residents began protesting over their water problems in eMalahleni.
Students at Stellenbosch University (SU) have staged a sit-in at the JS Gericke Library. The sit-in began on Monday and was still ongoing late on Wednesday evening.
Two men's alleged attempt to hijack an elderly Muslim man in Pine Street, Durban were attacked by a crowd. One man was beaten.
Cops were called out to a high school (Woodstock) after about 200 learners protested against alleged racism and favouritism over drug tests at their school.
About 70 students from iQhayiya High School in Khayelitsha learners protested outside the Western Cape Department of Education demanding the right to wear their hair as they liked.
Thousands of Birch Acres residents took to the streets of Ekurhuleni as they embarked in a service delivery protest over lack of schools, clinics and a library in the area.

Around two hundreds residents protested on the R28 between Randfontein and Westonaria on over issues of service delivery. The remnants of heavy protesting could be seen along the R28 with scorch marks on the road, wire, burned out tires and rocks moved to the side of the road.

column7: SANCO: South African National Civics Organization; Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Around 300 provincial emergency medical services workers, police officers, private paramedics, nurses and residents and SANCO members marched past homes, dogs and street vendors to a sports field in Phillipi.
Dozens of students from Thandokhulu High School in Observatory protested in front of the school gate, demanding a change in the school rules on hair.

Protests in Ekurhuleni began in the early hours of Thursday morning with some residents burning tires and blocking roads with rocks and refuse. The protest began in the early hours of Thursday morning with some residents burning tires and blocking roads with rocks and refuse.The protest began in the early hours of Thursday morning with some residents burning tires and blocking roads with rocks and refuse.The protest began in the early hours of Thursday morning with some residents burning tires and blocking roads with rocks and refuse.
A police officer was injured when learners went into a rampage damaging property in Tlakgameng near Ganyesa.

More than 150 students and workers marched from the Belmont Square Conference Centre to University of Cape Town (UCT) Upper Campus, singing and interrupting traffic, to protest against outsourcing, low wages for workers, and suspensions and expulsions of student activists.
The University of Cape Town has closed its libraries and 24/7 study area during ongoing protests by hundreds of student.
Protest action by students took place in the library at the University of Stellenbosch.
More than 200 community members burnt a tuck shop in Koster outside Rustenburg.
Three classrooms and a staff room of Humula Secondary School were destroyed by the fire at Mukhomi village near Malamulele.
Students of the University of the Free State protested on campus over fee hikes.
Isipingo Primary School pupils boycotted class and disrupted teaching, demanding a refund for their cancelled sports day and calling for the principal to vacate his post.
Students blocked both the south and north entrances at UCT's upper campus and all Jammie Shuttle routes were suspended.
University of Stellenbosch students damaged property and assaulted fellow students and members of staff on Monday and Tuesday.
Pretorias streets were white with thousands of social workers from various parts of the country who gathered to hand over a memorandum at the Union Buildings.
Lectures at Witwatersrand University would continue despite students protesting against the looming tuition fee hike.
The University of the Free State suspended all academic activities due to ongoing protests.

Metrorail in Cape Town suspended trains in the central service corridor following a service delivery protest in Langa. Police used rubber bullets to disperse the crowds, and by 10:00 on Tuesday morning, 18 people had been arrested.
The North West University (NWU) has shut down its Mahikeng campus indefinitely Tuesday.
University of Stellenbosch students damaged property and assaulted fellow students and members of staff on Monday and Tuesday.

column7: SJC: Social Justice Coalition; EE: Equal Education
column17: A group of protesters, lead by Equal Education and the Social Justice Coalition organised outside the Western Cape High Court during proceedings on police allocation of resources.
A group of parents from GaSekgopo village, near Modjadjiskloof, blocked the entrance to the Munnik Primary School with burning tyres and tree branches.

column16: Star (South Africa); Cape Argus; Mercury (South Africa)
column17: Stellenbosch University's Tygerberg campus was also blockaded, causing the suspension of classes

column16: Star (South Africa); Mercury (South Africa); Cape Argus
column17: A large group of UCT students disrupted lectures, effectively preventing any access to campus. Students used boulders, tree stumps, rubble and canoes to barricade the access routes.

column7: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union
column17: Operations at some schools in KwaMhlanga in Mpumalanga have been disrupted as hundreds of members of the South African Democratic Teachers Union (Sadtu) have taken to picketing in protest against what it called government job cuts.

column16: Star (South Africa); Mercury (South Africa); Cape Argus
column17: Students at the TUT Arcadia and Arts campuses shut down both campuses as they were against the possible fee increment

column16: Cape Argus; Mercury (South Africa); Star (South Africa)
column17: Wits University has shut down its campuses following violence and unrest: Students, police and private security guards at Wits clashed several times.

column7: #FeesMustFall; Students (South Africa); EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column16: Mercury (South Africa); Cape Argus; Star (South Africa)
column17: Hundreds of students with the EFF student command from the Pietermaritzburg campus marched to the legislature, demanding free higher education.

column16: Star (South Africa); Mercury (South Africa); Cape Argus
column17: The management at the Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University in Port Elizabeth urged its staff and students to stay off campus as protests continued.

column16: Cape Argus; Star (South Africa); Mercury (South Africa)
column17: Students at the Pretoria West Campus shut down both campuses as they were against the possible fee increment

column7: #FeesMustFall; Students (South Africa); EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: The University of Pretoria shut down its Hatfield campus indefinitely as protests took place. The EFF Student Command protested in the amphitheatre at the university, calling on management to respond to the fee increment.

Students at Fort Hare's Alice campus set a building alight last night, containing much of the university's equipment. This followed a mass meeting in which students did not agree with some of the resolutions presented by the university's management.
800 students were active as lectures were disrupted by protesters at Rhodes University.
A group of University of the Free State students marched to Motheo FET College in Bloemfontein to ask students there to join their fees protest.
The North West University (NWU) has shut down its Mahikeng campus indefinitely Tuesday.
Multiple fires, including one at a substation at the University of Zululand, are suspected to have been started intentionally.

A peaceful student march quickly turned into a confrontation with police at Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University. Students pushed back and a group at the back began hurling water bottles at police. Students blocked the road while 11 were arrested.
Student activists from UCT continued with the #FeesMustFall national shutdown yesterday by disrupting the universities Hiddingh campus.
Students at the University of Cape Town continued to protest, while the institution's heath faculty made plans to hold a picket outside Parliament this afternoon.

A group of protesters from former president Nelson Mandelas home village of Qunu protested.Traffic was affected on the N2 near Qunu when the angry protesters blocked the road with burning rubble and rocks.
Chaos reigned at Wits University as rocks and rubber bullets were exchanged between students and the police, who used stun grenades and tear gas in a bid to quell the protests

Minor protests were also reported at the Tshwane University of Technology's Arcadia campus. About 50 students at Tshwane University of Technology gathered at the Arcadia campus and burnt tyres at the main entrance.
The North West University (NWU) has shut down its Mahikeng campus indefinitely Tuesday.

More than 500 protesting students clashed with riot police, and threw stones at a test venue at the campus. Police shot rubber bullets and released teargas on protesting students at the Malherbe residence on campus.
A divided group of a few hundred protesters, some picketing against fees for higher education and some protesting the picket, gathered outside Parliament in Cape Town.

Students from the Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University vowed to continue with the Fees Must Fall protest. They gathered at the Port Elizabeth Magistrates Court where nine students appeared in court.
Rhodes student protested at the university over fee increases.Tyres were burnt

Residents of Ward 19 in Stinkwater protested and brought a training course for Tshwane councillors to a halt when they stormed into the chamber to demand an end to a series of evictions in the township.

The Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University has again been forced to close its doors as protests took place. A small group of students once again barricaded the entrance to the main campus with upturned benches, pallets and burning tyres
Over 1000 students marched around the University of Stellenbosch in good spirits on to drum up support for a campaign to scrap university fees and decolonise education.
The protesting students also barricaded other TUT entrances at campuses including Arcadia, Soshanguve and GaRankuwa.
Students marched on the streets of Pretoria as they demanded the shutdown of universities until the government declares higher education free.
At the University of Johannesburg, all entrances to the university's main campus in Auckland Park were closed as students joined the protests.
A handful of students protested on UFS campus in Bloemfontein while campus security monitored them.
Wits students have marched toward Adam Habibs home as the protest against university fees escalates.
A fire tore through a residence at the University of KwaZulu-Natal's Pietermaritzburg campus. Later on, students barricaded the entrances to residences threw faeces at a test venue.
Fees Must Fall protests spread to the University of Johannesburg's Kingsway (Auckland Park) and Soweto campuses.
A man was beaten and killed allegedly by an angry mob in section V, Botshabelo, Free State

Tshwane University of Technology (TUT) students shut down their campuses on Monday, joining their colleagues in other parts of South Africa demanding free higher education. tyres were burning at the main campus of the TUT.
Students at the Durban University of Technology's campuses (Durban) engaged in marches on to call for the removal of fees.
The protesting students also barricaded other TUT entrances at campuses including Arcadia, Soshanguve and GaRankuwa.
Nine vehicls were set alight at the University of Zululands main campus in Kwa-Dlangezwa, near Richards Bay
The protesting students also barricaded other TUT entrances at campuses including Arcadia, Soshanguve and GaRankuwa.
Students at the Durban University of Technology's campuses (Pietermaritzburg - Imbali) engaged in marches on to call for the removal of fees.

University of Technology students were arrested during a protest in which a group of about 300 students marched on Markgraff Street in Bloemfontein and vandalised road signs and municipal bins, said Marope.

Violence erupted outside the Tshwane council chambers where a council meeting took place on as a group protested and tried to gain entry. The group of protesters broke the glass door, and several metro police officers were injured in the process.
A group of protesters gathered at UCTs main campus.
Police and journalists came under attack from a group of students who threw stones at the Durban University of Technology. Police fired rubber bullets and stun grenades at protesters.
Running battles between students at the University of Limpopo's Mankweng campus (Polokwane) and the police have forced the university management to suspend lectures.
Students from the Durban University of Technology clashed with police for a second day in a row. Police had to use teargas and rubber bullets to disperse stone-throwing students.
A large group of students gathered outside the main gate at the Auckland Park campus (UJ) but were barred from entering as security locked the gates.

It was a chaotic day at the University of Johannesburg (UJ) (Doornsfontein) as students and private security clashed sporadically. Several students were pepper-sprayed and others were seen with cuts and bruises.
70 Right2know protesters marched through the streets of Johannesburg against companies advertising with the SABC.
The University of Cape Town closed its campuses on Wednesday after a group of protesters allegedly ""intimidated and traumatised"" university staff.
A section of the Dora Nginza Hospital in Zwide, Eastern Cape, was severely damaged by fire late when protesting residents torched it.
Student protesters from Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University (NMMU) walked through the streets of Port Elizabeth canvassing for moral support from residents
Students at Rhodes University protested. Following their arrival on campus, police officers pepper-sprayed students in response to the disruption of a lecture
A lecture hall caught fire at the University of Johannesburg. Reasons for the fire are unknown.
A security guard has been left critically injured after being severely assaulted by students at the University of Zululand (UniZulu).
About 100 students from the Durban University of Technology (DUT) staged a protest outside the Durban Magistrates Court on Thursday
3 people were arrested at UKZNs Pietermaritzburg campus arrests after the computer room was burnt down.

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students
column17: A Congress of the South African Students (Cosas) march at which the organisation handed over a memorandum to the JSE to place in Sandton, JHB. A teenager died after he was pinned between two buses during the march.
Protesting students at the Indumiso campus of the Durban University of Technology (DUT) in Pietermaritzburg blocked roads with stones and burning tyres.
About 50 Congolese living in Cape Town marched from Keizersgracht Street to parliament on Friday, protesting against violence against demonstrators in Kinshasa on 19 and 20 September 2016.
Police and students clashed at the Westville campus of the University of KwaZulu-Natal in protests that led to between four and six arrests, including that of one reporter.

Thousands of students and staff heeded a call to sit down for an hour and read in silence on the steps of the University of Cape Town (UCT) upper campus. A few minutes after the silent protest started, a group of about 100 #FeesMustFall protesters marched up the steps and stood in front of the bulk of the silent protesters.
A Joburg community who were fed up with criminals in their area allegedly took the law into their own hands, killing two suspected thieves and leaving three others injured in Fleurhof (jhb).
Four students were arrested for contravening court orders by inciting violence when throwing stones at security guards
Student at WITS in Johannesburg continued to protest over fee increaese.
Classes and tests were disrupted at the Durban University of Technology (DUT) as a small group of protesters forced students out of class.
At the University of KwaZulu-Natal (UKZN), students gathered at the Westville and Howard College campuses before they were asked by the police to disperse.

At the University of Johannesburgs Soweto campus, several students were arrested when they attempted to block entrances. They are being held at the Kliptown police station awaiting their appearance in court.
At the University of KwaZulu-Natal (UKZN), students gathered at the Westville and Howard College campuses before they were asked by the police to disperse.
DA supporters gathered outside the SABCs Auckland Park headquarters for a protest calling for the public broadcasters board to be dissolved and for Hlaudi Motsoeneng to be axed.

Protesters blocked the main entrances to the University of Cape Town (UCT). two students were arrested for blocking entrances to the university; intimidation and breach of an interdict that prohibits one of them from being on campus.
Universities in the Western Caperemain are on alert after protest action brought some campuses to a halt. Protesters shut down UWC and CPUTs Bellville, Mowbray campuses.
A man was killed in what is believed to be a case of mob justice north of Durban (near Inanda).

At CPUT a group of angry student protesters marched to the different faculties at the institution disrupting lectures.They forced their way into the business and mechanical engineering faculty, setting off the fire extinguishers inside the classes for students to vacate the lecture rooms.
Universities in the Western Caperemain are on alert after protest action brought some campuses to a halt. Protesters shut down UWC and CPUTs Bellville, Mowbray campuses.
Police fired stun grenades to disperse protesting Wits University students near the institutions Solomon Mahlangu House
In ongoing protests at UCT, stun grenades and teargas were fired by police at UCT students set fires and tried to reoccupy the Steve Biko Students' Union building.

column7: STTOP: Sector Task Team for Older Persons
column17: Members and allies of the Sector Task Team for Older Persons (STTOP) held a demonstration yesterday outside Parliament to raise awareness of elder abuse in Cape Town
Police are investigating a case of arson after an office and a car were torched at the Durban University of Technology (DUT).
Two groups of students clashed at the University of Witwatersrandover whether or not to continue the academic year.

Calm was restored at the Marabastad Refugee Reception Office (pretoria) after protests at the facility. A group of asylum seekers had damaged the property by breaking windows in protest against the new application system.

A group of over 200 students blocked off all entrances to Rhodes campus and scattered medical syringes at the entrance at the corner of Prince Alfred and Somerset Streets. The group removed a trailer from the premises, overturned it at the Artillery Road entrance and set it alight.
At the Cape Peninsula University of Cape Town (CPUT), students dumped human waste at the security office at the Bellville campus in ongoing protests.

About 30 students from the #FeesMustFall movement were singing and dancing at the main entrance toNMMU university (Port Elizabeth) while a few metres away was a group of about 80 people from #OpenNMMU, including students and parents of students. Manwhile, security guards and cleaners marched to the Port Elizabeth City Hall, demanding higher salaries, better working conditions and the end of outsourcing.The marchers work for various companies in the city but declined to name them.
Six more students from the Durban University of Technology have been arrested. This after a group of approximately 30 students tried to disrupt classes at the ML Sultan campus.
About 30 University of Zululand workers staged a peaceful protest at the World Trade Union Conference in Durban.
Protest action continued at Cape Town universities with petrol bombs thrown, faeces flung around, lecture halls invaded and students who want to keep studying facing off with protesters.

A meeting at the Cape Peninsula of University of Technology's Bellville campus was disrupted when protesting students threw human faeces. Protesting students threw stones at police. Officers used stun grenades to disperse the crowd. No injuries were reported.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: A handful of ANC youht league members marched to their regional office on asking for the ANC in Ekurhuleni to oversee processes leading to branch general meetings.
Sporadic skirmishes between protesting students and police were reported at the University of KwaZulu-Natal's Pietermaritzburg campus.
Students at UCT protests at the Wynberg Magitrates court as students were in court.
Unconfirmed reports of running battles between police and students on Howard College Campus took place in ongoing protest action.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Close to 200 workers affiliated to COSATU took to the streetsin Johannesburg o march for decent jobs in line with Cosatu's mass action campaign for decent work
According to a student leader of the Westville campuss Students Representative Council, Ncebo Mazibuko was arrested after a skirmish during which the police fired rubber bullets.

A group of less than 100 students protested at the entrance of Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University's North Campus. As the protest continued and students burnt tyres police and private security guards kept a watchful eye.
Police officers used plastic shields and launched tear gas to hold back protesting CPUT students who were throwing rocks and faeces at the Bellville Campus.
At UKZN Westville campus, student protesters hurled bottles and bricks at police, who responded by firing tear gas.
UWC said it had suspended on-campus operations for the rest of the week because of ongoing disruptions and protests.
Learning was interreupted at UKZNs Howard cakpus in Durban as student protests continued.

Police and protesting students continue to face off at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Pietermaritzburg campus. Police officers were firing teargas and students responding with bottles, stones and marbles fired from slingshots.

Police are investigating a case of public violence after a group of 30 protesters in Driftsands, near Blue Downs burned tyres and mobile toilets while demanding access to electricity and other services.
Teachers were yesterday prevented from entering a Soweto (Zola North) school by angry parents who are demanding a new principal.
There were disruptions at the Mafikeng campus as students protested. University management said disruptions were perpetrated by non-students.

Hundreds of students demanding free education have clashed with police in renewed violence at Wits University in Johannesburg. Police used tear gas, rubber bullets, stun grenades and water cannon on Monday to disperse stone-throwing protesters at Witwatersrand University.
The University of the Free State remained open despite protests by some students. Security used paintball guns to disperse the protesting group outside computer labs at the universities main campus.
There were also student protests at the University of Pretoria and Stellenbosch University.

In Grahamstown, Rhodes University remained closed. Five students were arrested after violent protests ensued. The five were arrested hours after university toilets were vandalised and aerosol cans were thrown into lecture rooms, so preventing staff and students from attending class.

There were also student protests at the University of Pretoria and Stellenbosch University. Student protesters of the Fees Must Fall movement at Stellenbosch University clashed with police and private security. A protester argues with police after pepper spray had been used on protesters.

Skirmishes between police and students continued throughout the day at Wits University. Police fired stun grenades and rubber bullets at students after protesters pelted stones at campus security guards stationed outside the Great Hall.At Wits University, the John Moffet Architecture Building was targeted in an arson attack.
More than 1 000 university students from across KwaZulu-Natal joined a #FeesMustFall march to Durbans City Hall.
Tyres were also burnt at the gate of the Tshwane University of Pretorias west campus.

Tensions at the Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT) campuses reached boiling point, with police firing stun grenades, tear-gas and rubber bullets at stone-throwing protesters. Twelve arrests were made at the Bellville campus, three at the Cape Town campus and another four at the Mowbray campus.

At least three universities across the country were targets of arson: At the University of KwaZulu-Natal's Pietermaritzburg campus, students had to be evacuated from the Malherbe Residence after a fire broke out in a common room.
Students at the University of Fort Hare University disrupted a meeting between parents and management.

Tensions at the Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT) campuses reached boiling point, with police firing stun grenades, tear-gas and rubber bullets at stone-throwing protesters. Twelve arrests were made at the Bellville campus, three at the Cape Town campus and another four at the Mowbray campus.

Tensions at the Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT) campuses reached boiling point, with police firing stun grenades, tear-gas and rubber bullets at stone-throwing protesters. Twelve arrests were made at the Bellville campus, three at the Cape Town campus and another four at the Mowbray campus.
Students blocked off the TUT main campus in Pretoria west, setting alight several tyres and using rocks to block the roads.
At least three universities across the country were targets of arson: Two separate incidents were also reported at the Cape Peninsula University of Technology as buildings were set alight.

Violence at the Vaal University of Technology escalated, with buildings being set alight. Part of the VUT in Vanderbijlpark was set alight. Large groups of students were pictured and a structure was in flames.
Protesters in Pretoria tok place, causing major chaos and traffic delays on the on- and off-ramps as well as the N1.
Traders on Cape Town station deck marched to Passenger Rail Agency of South Africa (Prasa) office demanding a drop in rent from R1,400 to R500 a month.
Classes at the Shauderville school in Port Elizabeth started late after students and teachers held a protest outside the school against their School Governing Body.

Lectures were suspended at the Tshwane University of Technology (TUT) Pretoria campus after protesting students burned tyres and barricaded the entrances to two campuses of the Pretoria institution. Rubber bullets were fired several times in the city centre as some students retaliated by throwing rocks and rubble towards police lines.

Lectures were suspended at the Tshwane University of Technology (TUT) Pretoria campus after protesting students burned tyres and barricaded the entrances to two campuses of the Pretoria institution. Rubber bullets were fired several times in the city centre as some students retaliated by throwing rocks and rubble towards police lines.

A private security guard at Tshwane University of Technology has allegedly shot at a student with live ammunition during protest action. The protest descended into violence as police dispersed students with rubber bullets. The students retaliated by throwing stones and burning tires. A building was also burned.

column7: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union; Students (South Africa)
column17: A group of learners from Bulumko and Joe Slovo Senior Secondary Schools in Khayelitsha, and members of the South African Democratic Teachers Union (Sadtu), entered Injongo Primary School to stop the systemic tests which learners were writing.
Lavender Hill teachers joined forces with religious leaders and community members in a picket against gang violence in the area.

protesters had used 'fire crackers to alarm and disperse students in the Matrix Student Centre'' and there were 'reports of stink bombs being used to disrupt lectures in some classes' on the Braamfontein campus.
Clashes between students and police at the Vaal University of Technology took place. Students are throwing stones and petrol bombs at the police and they are retaliating with rubber bullets.
Violence broke out between police and students at UKZN's Westville campus. Police clashed with students armed with stones, and using ironing boards as shields.

column16: East Coast Radio (South Africa); Times (South Africa)
column17: There were protest disruptions at the Soshanguve campus of Tuts in Pretoria. With heavy police presence, protest action by students has continued at the Tshwane University of Technology (TUT) with police firing rubber bullets at the Soshanguve campus to disperse crowds
A schoolin Qunu, was nearly burnt to the ground by a mob.
Hundreds of Athlone students, teachers and activists marched the same road where three youngsters were shot dead by police in 1985.

column7: SAUS: South African Union of Students
