column17: The South African Union of Students (SAUS) and other youth formations marched to the the Chamber of Mines to press for education funding.
Police warned people to avoid Braamfontein near Wits after cars were set alight or stoned by protesting students. Businesses were also damaged.
Part of an HIV/Aids clinic was torched at the University of KwaZulu-Natals Howard College campus as protesters change tactics to night battles.
UCT says its vice-chancellor was assaulted by protesters after he met with them to discuss their demands for free university education.
A car which was used by students and researchers was destroyed by fire outside the University of Cape Town's (UCT) Geological Sciences Department
Separately, police fired rubber bullets to disperse protesters at the Vanderbijlpark campus of the Vaal University of Technology
Hundreds of Walter Sisulu University students from the Buffalo City campus blocked Oxford Street today after a mass meeting.

About 30 student protesters blocked Baxter Road outside the University of Cape Towns Tugwell and Leo Marquard residences. police then arrived and with private security blocked the entrance to the RW James building. Stun grenades and pepper spray were used to disperse the students by police.

Social grant recipients protested yesterday outside Grindrod Mews in Durban against unlawful and unauthorised deductions from their grants. The protest formed part of the Black Sash-led ""Hands Off Our Grants"" campaign
There were two days of running battles where police used rubber bullets, teargas and stun grenades as they clashed with students at Westville campus of UKZN.
Walter Sisulu University students were in the street again in which they blocked the road and set tyres alight. Stones and bottles were also thrown at the police.
Running battles between protesters and police began at Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University (NMMU).
Violent clashes erupted between student protesters and private security at the University of Cape Town (UCT), leaving a number of protesters injured and four arrested.
There were two days of running battles where police used rubber bullets, teargas and stun grenades as they clashed with students at Westville campus of UKZN.
About 50 to 60 academic and administrative staff protested outside Wits University's Great Hall to raise concerns about the heavy police presence on campus
At UWC, windows were broken and furniture from one of the residences set alight as police opened fire on students.

Pupils were allegedly prevented from writing the tests at Injongo Primary School in Khayelitsha as teachers protested outside the entrances of Uxolo High and Sivuyiseni Primary in Khayelitsha yesterday
Running battles between protesters and police entered a second day at Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University (NMMU).

Calm has been restored at the Union Buildings in Pretoria after a tense stand-off between police and Fees Must Fall protesters. Earlier police and students clashed violently. During the protest, one student was killed in a car accident.
Details emerged of the killing of two alleged house robbers in Erasmia, allegedly by residents.
Students at Walter Sisulu University (WSU) Nelson Mandela Drive Campus killed two thieves and left one badly injured.

Students clashed with security and police at the UKZN Pietermaritzburg campus. Sudents began hurling stones and petrol bombs directly at security and police while the police responded with tear gas, rubber bullets and stun grenades.
A peaceful march hosted by the Right2Know (R2K) campaign which had hoped to attract students in their numbers in Durban, attracted a crowd of less than 40.
Running battles between protesters and police entered a third day at Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University (NMMU).

A group of protesters at the TUTs Soshuguve campus demanded to be transported to the #FeesMustFall march to the Union Buildings. When this was denied, clashes with security guards ensued and the SAPS had no option but to intervene to disperse the protesters.

Several lectures and two tests were disrupted at Wits University when fireworks and stink bombs were set off in lecture rooms. Four students were arrested on Friday for allegedly contravening a court order
Pupils from around 30 Western Cape schools protested in Somerset West and Observatory (Mowbray) for premier Helen Zille to take their demands for safe schools seriously
Pupils from around 30 Western Cape schools protested in Somerset West and Observatory for premier Helen Zille to take their demands for safe schools seriously
Mamelodi community members took to the streets to demonstrate against the torching of buses whenever violence erupted.
The north campus of Tuts was closed after a group of students drove security personnel and staff off campus. Students blocked the entrance with rocks, burning tyres and dustbins.
Tshwane University of Technology was yet again hit by #FeesMustFall protests, with students barricading the main gates at both the Soshanguve South and North campuses.
A number of vehicles were set alight at the Cape Peninsula University of Technology campus in Bellville
Four vehicles were set alight on the University of Cape Towns lower campus.
A civil society leader was shot in the mouth during an argument with police at the University of KwaZulu-Natal campus in Pietermaritzburg

Villagers blockaded the main road from Mahikeng leading into Disaneng village with stones and other objects, demanding the intervention of Ratlou local municipality mayor Tebogo Modise in the removal of the local chief.
Wits University students with disabilities participated in a protest march from the David Webster residency to the Great Hall
Phillipi residents took to the streets over the escalation in crime directed at women in the area, where police say more than 60 cases of rape get reported every month.
There was drama in the Durban City Hall when disgruntled former military combatants of the Azanian People's Liberation Army stormed an executive committee meeting demanding employment from the city.
Teachers at Luleka Primary School in Khayelitsha say a group of protesters claiming to be parents beat them in front of learners and forced them to leave the school premises.
A police van and a bus was set alight by protesters who blocked roads using rocks and concrete rubbish bins in Braamfontein.

column7: AFASA: African Farmers Association of South Africa
column17: Black farmers who have embarked on a #LandMustFall campaign marched to the Union Buildings to hand over a memorandum expressing their dissatisfaction with the slow pace of land reform. About 300 members of the African Farmers Association of South Africa took part in the march.

Five trucks were set alight and two police vehicles were damaged in Majakaneng, south of Brits. some members of Majakaneng community barricaded N4 road with burning tyres and stones near Sun City off-ramp. 4 people were arrested

Arsonists set fire to two Rhodes University exam venues and burnt to the ground the tennis clubhouse in which protesting students and police clashed repeatedly. Six students had been arrested and the sound of gunfire and stun grenades was coming from all corners of the campus.
The Orlando Pirates Gauteng supporters branch - accompanied by community members - handed in a memorandum to the police after marching in the streets of Vosloorus.

Learners from several schools in the King William's Town area tried to stop matric exam papers being distributed in a bid to force the Eastern Cape Department of Education to fix their schools. Hundreds of learners blocked roads in King William's Town then moved to De Vos Malan High School, where matric exam papers are kept
Protesters from the Pakistani community in South Africa converged outside the UN headquarters in Pretoria to demand the UN implement its resolution for a plebiscite on Kashmir.

Dozens of police launched stun grenades at a group of students who had gathered outside Parliament, while some protesters climbed on police vehicles, smashed vehicle and business windows and stoned buses in different parts of the city.
Today, dozens of angry family members demonstrated outside the Gauteng Department of Health head office in Johannesburg

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Hundreds of Tshwane municipal workers (SAMWU Union) took to the streets of Pretoria over employment contracts.
CITY health workers picketed outside the Gauteng Department of Health in Johannesburg demanding reasons for salary delays.
About 50 older people gathered outside Parliament today, carrying posters and singing to demand reparations for damages suffered under apartheid.
Clashes between students and police and private security erupted at the University of Pretoria. Police reportedly threw stun grenades at protesters.
About 30 UCT staff picketed outside the UCTs administrative offices, Bremner building, protesting against the militarisation of the campus.

column7: SJC: Social Justice Coalition; Equal Education; NU: Ndifuna Ukwazi
column17: Civil society organisations, including the Social Justice Coalition (SJC) and supported by Ndifuna Ukwazi (NU), Equal Education (EE), marched in Cape Towns CBD to oppose President Zuma.
Dozens of people protested outside the St George's Cathedral in the Cape Town CBD against state capture and corruption. The protest was organised by civil society group, South Africa First Forum.
About 200 people stood in solidarity with the national #Save SA campaign in Durban and Pietermaritzburg with a fierce message that President Jacob Zuma must fall.
Pupils from schools in and around King Williams Town disrupted exams at the De Vos High School. No reports of violence were reported.
About 200 people stood in solidarity with the national #Save SA campaign in Durban and Pietermaritzburg with a fierce message that President Jacob Zuma must fall.
Hundreds of DA supporters gathered in Pretoria to march to the magistrates court, calling for the Constitution to be protected.

During protest action in Pretoria, EFF supporters clashed with police officers. 2 officers were injured in the violence as stones were thrown at windows, while a hotel was looted, roads were barricaded and traffic disrupted.
About 100 #feesmustfall protesters attempted to disrupt exams at the University of Stellenbosch. No violence was reported.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Workers aligned to SAMWU took to the streets, some emptying bins and disrupting traffic in the city.
Active Citizen Movement members stood in solidarity with the nation-wide protest to Save South Africa against state capture and corruption in Pietermaritzburg.
A group of about 14 people accused a boy of being a member of a gang that was allegedly terrorising the community of Etwatwa. The community assaulted him and tried to set him alight.
A Gauteng resident suspected of killing a man was assaulted by community members in the Itireleng informal settlement in Laudium.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: Disgruntled workers of the CSIR picketed at the entrance of the convention centre in Pretoria during the CSIR excellence award ceremony to honour employees for their outstanding performance. The protest was supported by the ANC Youth League .
Two floors in the Reslife building had been damaged in an arson attack at the University of the Western Cape.
On 6 November 2016, two Ethiopians working as shopkeepers were tied up, burnt, and killed inside their shop by seven men in King Williams Town (Eastern Cape). Five suspects were arrested.

A house belonging to tavern owners and their three cars were burnt to ashes in Westernburg in Polokwane when residents and patrons gathered and attacked the family after one of the alleged armed robbers was shot dead by the wife of the tavern owner.
There was an arson attack at the education faculty at the University of the Western Cape.
Young people in Hammanskraal took to the streets demanding answers to questions about an uncertain future and the inability to find secure jobs.

Exams began at the UWC campus but protesting students unhappy with management's decision to go ahead without first meeting their demands led to unrest at the University in Bellville. Protesters clashed with police after they tried to stop students from boarding buses to take them to off-campus exam centres.
A member of the Glebelands hostel peace committee was gunned down in a drive-by shooting in Umlazi's V-Section in Durban
Workers at a Spar supermarket in Kwazakhele, Port Elizabeth, picketed, demanding better working conditions, overtime compensation, payment from a share scheme, and the abolition of labour brokers.
Police have detained a man on Tuesday, in connection with an arson attack at the University of KwaZulu-Natal's Pietermaritzburg campus.
A wave of protesters descended on the Gauteng Department of Healths offices in the Joburg CBD

On 9 November 2016, three foreign nationals were injured in clashes between their group and security personnel at the Home Affairs refugee centre in Marabastad in Pretoria. Foreign nationals started throwing stones at security personnel. The riot escalated when metro police fired rubber bullets at the foreign nationals. [size=no report]
Fishermen protested at parliament in Cape Town, waving placards and chanting. The small group included fishermen and women from Hout Bay, Langa, Masiphumelele, Nyanga Strandfontein and Vrygrond.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Hundreds of Expanded Public Works Programme (EPWP) workers under Msunduzi Municipality in Pietermaritzburg and aligned to SAMWU gathered at Alexandra Park, saying they are prepared to fight the termination of their contracts.
Around 50 UJ students gathered at The Yard in Johannesburg with the intention to march after the death of a student over the weekend.
At a protest joined by members of the community, workers dumped several plastic bags of human waste at the entrance to the town hall of Uitenhage.
A handful of University of Johannesburg students marched in Auckland Park to demand that the university removes ""hired bouncers"".
Dozens of supporters have gathered outside Parliament in support of President Jacob Zuma at the time of a no confidence vote.
One person was shot and killed when a mob turned on police officers following up on a cellphone robbery in the Durban CBD.

column7: #FeesMustFall; Students (South Africa); EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: A handful of #Feesmust fall protesters and Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command members gathered and marched through the Durban central business district to the City Hall.
Police are investigating the death of Thembinkosi Zoleka, an African National Congress PR councillor who was shot in Margate.

column7: #FeesMustFall; Students (South Africa); EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: Exams were set to go ahead at the Tshwane University of Technology despite ongoing disruptions by 'FeesMustFall' protesters at its campuses (Soshanguve campus) .
Home Affairs centres were closed due to a march by workers to the departments head office in Pretoria regarding the protracted dispute over working hours.
Two homes were petrol-bombed as part of a long-running battle between Shack dwellers and the municiplaity in Puntans Hill, Morningside in Durban.
Police confirmed a petrol bomb was thrown at a mail room adjacent to Keizersgracht Street at the Cape Town campus in ongoing student protests.
Farm dwellers used burning logs and tyres to blockade the road to the farm, in the Ntokozweni area, north of Durban (Verulum). Police later dispersed the protesters.
Taxi-rank toilet cleaners who lost their jobs protested with about 90 residents at the Uitenhage Town Hall.
Parents protested outside Ilitha Primary School in Mount Frere demanding a Grade R teacher be suspended
Farm dwellers are alleged to have attacked farm workers, injuring five in areas around Verulum. They also cut fences to the property and were seen carrying bottles of petrol.

column7: NU: Ndifuna Ukwazi; RTC: Reclaim The City
column17: Several activists from Ndifuna Ukwazi and Reclaim the City protested by sitting in at the Department of Transport and Public Works building in Cape Town, blocking access to the building for about two hours.

column7: ANC: African National Congress; DA: Democratic Alliance; EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters
column17: Demonstrators have protested against racism outside a South African court in Middelburg where two white men face assault charges for allegedly forcing a black man into a coffin and threatening to set him on fire. The EFF, ANC and DA held protests outside the court house.

Students staged a protest at the University of Wits night to have the alleged perpetrator evicted from the premises after students protested that it was not conducive for the victim to live in the same building as the perpetrator.
In protest, small-scale fishermen - who are angry and demand more fishing rights - decided to sleep in the boardroom of the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries in Richmond Hill.
In protest, small-scale fishermen - who are angry and demand more fishing rights - fishermen protested in Port Elizabeth.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Pietermaritzburg municipal workers with SAMWU members staged a protest march to the offices of Msunduzi Municipality. workers emptied rubbish bins on the busy city centre streets forcing traffic to slow down during the rush hour traffic.

column7: NU: Ndifuna Ukwazi; RTC: Reclaim The City
column17: About 20 activists from Reclaim the City and and Ndifuna Ukwazi gathered outside the department's building in Dorp Street (Cape Town).
Dozens of members of the Treatment Action Campaign (TAC) picketed outside the Michael Maphongwana Clinic in Khayelitsha.
Hundreds of people marched through the Johannesburg CBD today against the government's proposed nuclear deal. Earthlife had organised the protests.
A group of 30 people marched on Netcare Greenacres Hospital in Port Elizabeth to demand compensation for a person who fell from his hospital bed in December last year.
#FeesMustFall students burned a university bus outside the Soshanguve campus.
In Reservoir Hills, two busloads of voters blocked Mountbatten Drive with bricks and burning tyres after the election was postponed at the Siripat Road grounds.
At the Bayview Community Hall, the station commander and two other police officials were allegedly attacked by an angry mob from ward 69. One of the officers was hit with a chair.
Furious investors in an alleged Ponzi scheme marched on two police stations in Touws River and De Doorns to demand the companies bank accounts be unfrozen.
Furious investors in an alleged Ponzi scheme marched on two police stations in Touws River and De Doorns to demand the companies bank accounts be unfrozen.

Members of a community protesting against a lack of service delivery have disrupted and delayed exams at a school in Ga-Mphahlele in Limpopo. They destroyed examination question papers for Grades 10 and 11 pupils.
16 people at its Soshanguve campus of UT were arrested for allegedly contravening the institution's court order in what appears to be protest action.
A gorup of about 50 residents from Chatty 1060 staged a sit-in protest at the offices of the Housing Development Agency (HDA) in Port Elizabeth.

The plush Sheraton Hotel on the eastern side of Pretoria CBD has been hit by a wage dispute, with workers picketing outside the grand facility, demanding pay increases. Members of the Workers and Socialist Party were present.
A fire broke out in the multi-purpose hall at the Cape Town campus shortly after midnight on Monday, resulting in limited damage
The community of Entsikeni village outside Umzimkhulu handed over a list of grievances at a community march to Entsikeni Police Station.

column7: CWU: Communication Workers Union; PA: Patriotic Alliance; BLF: Black First, Land First; COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; Journalists (South Africa)
column17: A handful of people representing the Communication Workers' Union, Patriotic Alliance, Black First Land First, Cosatu and other unions protested at the Citizen newspaper in support of the papers suspended editor Steve Motale in Johannesburg.

Thousands of ANC members gathered outside the Pietermaritzburg High Court yesterday as they made it clear they want nothing less than the dissolution of the ANC conference that elected the current provincial leadership of the party.
A crowd gathered outside the high court in Cape Town in support of the South African Broadcasting Corporation corporate affairs executive Hlaudi Motsoeneng.

column7: FAWU: Food and Allied Workers Union
column17: About 1 100 members of the Food and Allied Workers Union (FAWU), coming from the Poultry Industry, staged a protest march to the offices of the European Union (EU) Commission embassy in Pretoria.
Six hundred people took to the streets of Kraaifontein in support of the 16 Days of Activism Against Violence Against Women and Children. The march was organised by the police.

The hostel superintendent at the centre of allegations of racial abuse at Wynberg Girls' High School has been put on special leave as pupils staged a protest at the school's Waterloo boarding house. The protest was attended by members of #FeesMustFall
About 100 people picketed outside the Braamfontein metro centre over labour issues.
About 50 fishers protested outside Parliament demanding that the Policy for the Small Scale Fisheries Sector (Policy) be implemented
About 500 men took part in a march in East London against crime and the abuse of women and children.
People with disabilities marched through the streets of Gugulethu to raise awareness of their plight before handing memorandums at the townships hospital and Gugulethu Mall.
African National Congress Yeoville residents protesting against the selection of Martha Mazibuko as ward councillor.
Security guards held a protest outside a hospital in Port Elizabeth.

column7: FAWU: Food and Allied Workers Union
column17: The Food and Allied Workers Union (Fawu) has given the National Treasury until early next month to respond to a memorandum against a proposed sugar tax as they demonstrated in Pretoria.
Shack dwellers in Springfield, Durban barricaded Umgeni Road with burning tyres and rubbish after, they claimed, the city tore down several of their homes earlier in the day.
A group of Kuils River residents want the City of Cape Town to give them land for a housing project they say they have designed for themselves. They protested outside the Civic Centre in the CBD.
Attempts to disconnect illegal users resulted in protest action in Schaapkraal and the Philippi horticultural area - home to the Egoli and Jim se Bos informal settlements.
The house of an accused linked to the kidnapping a person, was torched by angry community members in Phuthanang, just outside Kimberley.
Protestors blocked the road and set up barricades in Springfield after shacks were demolished in the informal settlement.

column7: NU: Ndifuna Ukwazi; RTC: Reclaim The City
column17: A group of about 25 Reclaim the City and Ndijuna Ukwazi supporters marched through Sea Point to the suburb's Pavilion landmark.

column7: ANC: African National Congress; EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; UDM: United Democratic Movement; COPE: Congress of the People
column17: Nearly 1,500 Port Elizabeth residents marched to City Hall to hand over a petition to recently elected mayor Athol Trollip (DA).ANC and UDM members took part in the protest. There were also EFF and Cope representatives
An ANC Ward 3 councillor was shot dead while addressing a community meeting on housing-related matters in Umuziwabantu municipality.
Just over 100 people have embarked on a march to the Johannesburg Zoo (Parkview) to publicly denounce the abuse of women and children.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Senior officials of trade union Nehawu handed a memorandum of demands to officials of the United States of America embassy in Pretoria, after picketing outside the diplomatic post in Pretoria.

A riotous mob beat a man until he fell to the ground and then trampled on him and continued beating him with their fists. This occurred outside the middelburg court while two men were were standing trial.

On 3 December 2016, about 40 foreign nationals took to the streets in Newcastle (KwaZulu-Natal) to demand the arrest of the perpetrators of a robbery followed by death of a foreign national. [size=about 40]

Activists from Sonke Gender Justice stood dressed in orange outfits reminiscent of prison garb, holding posters depicting the conditions in the prison as they protested outside the Western Cape High Court.
Western Cape police are investigating the origin of a hand grenade that exploded in Manenberg, Cape Town , seriously injuring six youths.

Protestors in Springtown erected burning barricades and hurled stones at cars on Umgeni Road. On Monday residents set fire to tires and refuse in the roadway before stoning cars, prompting metro police to intervene.
A KwaZulu-Natal chief has been shot and killed in front of his daughter during a drive-by shooting in the chappies area.

A truck driver lost control of his vehicle after protesters pelted it with stones and other objects. The truck hit a pedestrian who was walking nearby and was not even part of the protest. He died instantly.

column7: FAWU: Food and Allied Workers Union
column17: FAWU members staged a third mass protest action in the KwaZulu-Natal provincial legislature (Pietermaritzburg) against the dumping of poultry products from the EU.
Numerous police officers marched to Pretoria central, raising awareness of the dangers of women and child abuse, as part of the annual 16 Days of Activism for No Violence Against Women and Children
Just over 50 contractors gathered outside the City of Joburgs head office in Braamfontein, calling on mayor Herman Mashaba to come out and listen to their concerns.

PETROSA workers have taken to protest in Parow after reports emerged at the weekend that the state oil company paid 11 senior executives millions of rands in bonuses despite a loss of more than R14 billion in the past financial year.

column7: ANC: African National Congress; ANCWL: African National Congress Womens League; SACP: South African Communist Party; Women (South Africa)
column17: A group comprising of members of the African National Congress (ANC), ANC Womens League (ANCWL) and the South African Communist Party (SACP) sang and danced in protest outside the Middelburg court.
A group of residents took part in a protest in front of the Red Location Museum in Port Elizabeth.
A group of Pakistani nationals outside a Wynberg court where two Pakistanis and a South African woman, arrested in connection with the kidnapping of a businessman, appeared
Residents in France, ward 18 in Pietermaritzburg, supported by the Treatment Action Campaign (TAC) and the local leadership, marched to demand a clinic.
1 person was killed in Inchanga in suspected political violence concerning the nomination of coucillors for the local government elections.
In what is believed to be political killings, family members of the ANC proportional representation councillor Boy Shozi, were gunned down in Inchanga. 2 members died and other injured.
Women protest outside the Pretoria Magistrate's Court at the appearance of a Nigerian man, who allegedly held a 12-year-old girl as a sex slave for two months.
After the murder of a Somali trader during a robbery, members of the community hunted down the four suspects and killed two of them in Gomora informal settlement, west of Tshwane (Daspoort).
The South Durban Community Environmental Alliance (SDCEA) held a protest at the Department of Mineral Resources in Durban, opposing South Africa's nuclear deal with Russia.
About 30 protesters held a picket in Sea Point in the hopes of halting an eviction order against Thandeka Sisusa, a resident of Sea Point for 23 years

Bushbuckridge Residents Association (BRA) members marched on the Acornhoek station on to hand over a memorandum calling for him to be removed from his post. Captain Lindiwe Ngozelweni received the document
An ANC councillor in ward seven of the uPhongolo municipality in northern KwaZulu-Natal, was shot dead at his homestead at Kwalubisi village by an unknown assailant who knocked at his house

1 person was killed in Inchanga in suspected political violence arising from tensions between the ANC and SACP and the nomination of coucillors for the local government elections. SACP Mzamo Mzimela is killed by gunmen.

1 person was killed in Inchanga in suspected political violence arising from tensions between the ANC and SACP and the nomination of coucillors for the local government elections. SACP Lungisani Mchunu was killed by people allegedly looking for his brother, Siphesihle Nyandu, an SACP leader in the area.
Two opposing groups of villagers and livestock owners clashed near Mthatha resulting in the deaths of 2 people.
In the Cape Town CBD, stun grenades were fired by police at a group of about 200 protesters gathered at Thibault Square.
The African Diaspora Forum held a march in Johannesburg to protest xenophobic comments by the mayor.
South African women protested outside the Syrian embassy in Pretoria in support against the war in Syria.

Several Congolese nationals have been arrested after an anti-government protest in front of the Democratic Republic of the Congo embassy in Pretoria turned violent. Police fired several rounds of rubber bullets and stun grenades after protesters started pelting the embassy with large stones and plastic yellow and black parking barriers and shouting ""Kabila must go!"".
A man was burnt to death by a mob after he allegedly killed his girlfriend and hid her body in his house in Ngwaritsi village

column8: Police Forces of South Africa (1994-) Prison Guards
column17: Three people were killed and a further 26 injured in a clash between prisoners and prison wardens at the St Albans Prison in Nelson Mandela Bay.
On 28 December 2016, police assaulted a man in Hopefield (West Coast, Western Cape), seriously injuring him.
A Nigerian citizen was suffocated to death by the Metropolitan Police in Cape Town.
A suspected thief was subjected to the as the victim of a mob attack in Kanana informal settlement in Gugulethu. He was killed in the attack.
Residents of Schornville outside King William's Town marched to the town's magistrate's court to oppose bail in a rape case.
Community member allegedly assautled a man in Seweding near Mahikeng. The man died of his injuries.
Paramedics protested outside the Khayelitsha Magistrates's court over the string of attacks they have been the target of.
Police arrested a Congolese man on his way home from a party. He was beaten to death in police custody.
A mob killed a suspected criminal in Wesernburg outside Polokwane.
On 7 January 2017, a mob went on the rampage attacking and looting tuckshops owned by foreigners in Kuruman. [size=no report]
More than 100 parents from Mamelodi in Pretoria East burned tyres on Tsamaya road to display their frustrations over the new online registration system.
Residents protested and blocked the R536 in Bushbuckridge with boulders and branches, saying promises of jobs have gone unfulfilled.
Mine workers staged a sit-in protest inside a mine at the Kusasalethu mine in the West Rand.

Shots were fired, people injured and insults hurled as Mnquma municipality's power struggle turned violent as ANC factions clashing over a council decision to end with immediate effect Sindile Tantsi's municipal manager contract. A brawl broke out and the groups pelted one another with stones until shots were fired from the municipal buildings.

Anti-Riot police fought sporadic battles with protesters who threw rocks at passing cars and burned barricades on the busy R72 coastal road between Nelson Mandela Bay and Buffalo City metros at Kenton-on-Sea.
ANC supporters protested outside the Roodepoort Magistrate's Court urging the court not to grant a suspected murderer bail.

Schooling has been disrupted by protesting residents, unhappy with the state of roads in the Tshitale area in Makhado, Limpopo. Three government vehicles and a building were torched during the protest.
A group of about 200 people camped outside the municipal offices in Butterworth demanding the removal of municipal manager Sandile Tantsi.
Protesting residents continued to protest over the completion of road in the Tshitale area. There was no reports of violence on the second day of the protest.
At least 60 people wearing T-shirts with images of a baby, who was killed, protested against bail for two murder accused at Simon's Town Magistrate's court.
A man was burnt to death by a mob after he was accused of raping two girls in Moeka, north of Pretoria.
ANC members assaulted the DA Candidate for ward 25, Marchell Kleynhans in Uniondale, Western Cape.
A school and post office were set alight during violent protest action in Tshitale, Limpopo over education.
Residents in Ga-Rankuwa took to the streets in protest. Several roads were barricaded with burning tyres and large boulders. School children in the area could not attend classes.

Over a two day period, parents, who support the newly appointed principal atg a school in Kimberly, Northern Cape, gathered in front the school in protest over a court interdict has halted the appointment of a school principal.

column7: Students (South Africa); NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers' Union; SASSU: South African Social Services Union
column17: Central Johannesburg TVET College students and members of trade union Nehawu protested in Alexandra. Students had barricaded London Road and 13th Avenue with burning tyres and garbage.
Police arrested 19 people in Mphephu for public violence, after protesters barricaded the R523 road.
Frustrated community members of Freedom Park stormed the premises of town planners in protest in Milpark, decrying the lack of community beneficiation for the mainly informal settlement.
Another school was set alight in ongoing violent protest action in Tshitale, Limpopo.
Protesters gathered outside the Bafokeng Magistrate's Court during the appearance of community activist Napoleon Webster.
Blind employees of Are-Itireleng Trust in Ga-Rankuwa took to the streets, accusing their managers of denying them access to money, company cars and office space.

Over a two day period, parents, who support the newly appointed principal atg a school in Kimberly, Northern Cape, gathered in front the school in protest over a court interdict has halted the appointment of a school principal.
Students protested, burnt tyres and carried placards outside the Thuto Bophelo Nursing Academy in Pretoria.
There was a small contingent of supporters for Fees Must Fall student Bonginkosi Khanyile ahead of his pre-trial conference at Durban Magistrate's Court.
Family members of a murderedwomen staged a picket outside the Durban Magistrate's Court.
Lectures were brought to a halt at Buffalo City Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) College in East London when students joined a nationwide shutdown at colleges yesterday
Commissioner Road in Boksburg has been re-opened following a protest. Rubble, stones and burning tyres were used during the demonstration by a group of people claiming to be living nearby.

Women gathered at Cape Town's Company's Gardens for a ""Sister March"" in solidarity with those marching in Washington and cities around the world in protest of newly-elected US President Donald Trump.
A group of concerned Durban women marched to the US Consulate in solidarity with the Women's March on Washington.
There was a solidarity march against Donald Trump in Johannesburg, South Africa, where marchers held up banners reading 'Black lives matter' and 'Love trumps hate'.

A crowd of about 100 people opposed to an upcoming by-election disrupted Electoral Commission of South Africa (IEC) officials from registering voters and damaged an IEC bakkie in a rural Mpumalanga village
On 23 January 2017, 7 Zimbabweans were shot and killed by a group who called themselves The Community in Pretoria, Tshwane (Gauteng). The crime was linked to a xenophobia outbreak in the region.
SJC members held a picket outside the SAPS provincial head office in Cape Town.

Residents of Delmore Gardens in Boksburg took to the streets to protest against the government's move to erect an informal settlement close to their established residential area. They blockaded the road with burning tyres, stones, tree branches and other objects, demanding that the municipality call a halt to the construction.
A community worker was joined by Uitsig High School pupils, as they hand over a memorandum in protest to the Western Cape Provincial Legislature to keep their school open.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: About 50 employees of a Volkswagen SA logistics service provider have declared a strike over staff benefits and alleged nepotism and protested in Uitenhage. The workers were aligned to NUMSA trade union.
A protest in Booysens, Gauteng took place and left one person injured. Makhubela said several roads in the area have been barricaded with burning tyres and stones.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: Protesting ANC Youth League supporters pushed their way into an Absa bank branch in the Durban central business district.

column7: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union; COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: A protest march, led by the South African Democratic Teachers Union (Sadtu) and Cosatu and its affiliates in the education sector, took place in Polokwane.
A group of women have gathered outside the Wynberg Magistrate's Court to protest against the bail application of a Westlake man accused of stabbing his wife to death.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Close to 4 000 SA Municipal Workers' Union (Samwu) members took to the streets in the Pretoria city centre to protest, demanding that they be employed permanently.
A group of ANC supporters gathered outside a court building in Port Elizabeth singing songs and holding up placards with the words ""hands off our councillor"".

Business ground to a halt in Butterworth as an ANC faction protested against Mnquma municipal manager Sindile Tantsi. At one stage police fired rubber bullets at them as they marched towards the municipality's offices.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Thousands of Unisa workers and NEHAWU members braved the pouring rain outside the Sunnyside campus in Pretoria to protest against the 6% salary increase offered by the institution.
Students trying to register at Unisa in central Durban protested after they were turned away by Unisa staff, who brought registration to a halt.
Protests in Ivory Park took place regarding dangerous road conditions. Residents blockaded Republic Road and Angel Fish Drive to highlight the dangerous road conditions.
Protests continued in Booysens in Gauteng . Several roads in the area have been barricaded with burning tyres and stones.
A handful of Black-First-Land-First protesters turned out at Absa branches across Johannesburg .
Black First Land First movement held demonstrations out the ABSA banks in Pretoria.
Black First Land First movement held demonstrations out the ABSA banks in Polokwane.

A protest for clean drinking water turned violent North West's Moeka village, leaving a young man dead and several homes in flames. A young protester was fatally shot through the head by unknown men as he barricaded the road.

Armed with placards that made use of existing biblical scriptures that preach unconditional love, a group of men and women held a picket outside Grace Bible Church in Pimville, Soweto to ask the church to promote unconditional love instead of homophobia.
Nearly 200 supporters joined members of Reclaim the City in Sea Point park to raise awareness about the ongoing struggle to secure affordable housing in the city

The police in Galeshewe have arrested seven protesters as enraged residents in Galeshewe by barricaded a road with burning tyres and refuse material. Residents are protesting about poor service delivery at their settlement.
A power box was set alight on the R102 during a protest against an electricity blackout in the Fairbreeze area, Tongaat, north of Durban.

Traffic came to a standstill in parts of Potsdam as residents barricaded the road in a protest to get electricity installed in various parts of the area. The disgruntled residents also burnt tyres, barricading traffic.
Teachers picketed outside the homes of the two mothers in Manenberg, blaming them for the shutdown of a creche facility, which has been operating for 25 years.
There were violent clashes between the residents of the Khayelitsha tract of land and law enforcement officers. Residents burnt debris in the road and stoned a law enforcement vehicle.
Protesters in support of the Bromwell Street residents who are fighting an eviction order picketed outside the Cape High Court in Cape Town.

Police and the City's anti-land invasion unit faced-off against about 200 residents in Khayelitsha, resulting in rubber bullets, tear gas and stun grenades being used to disperse the backyarders in a second day of violence.
Ten people were arrested after at least six shops were looted in Itsoseng near Lichtenburg following violent protest in Itsoseng.

column7: UFAWU: United Food and Allied Workers Union
column17: About 500 FAWU-aligned workers, former workers and company managers from the South African poultry sector marched on the EU headquarters in Pretoria, furious over cheap imports and mounting job losses.
On 1 February 2017, a Zimbabwean man was set on fire and killed by a group after they accused him of rape in Mpheni (Limpopo). [size=no report]
A small number of KwaZulu-Natal ANC Youth League members have gathered outside an Absa bank in Ballito demanding that the bank pay back money.
Protest action started in Barbarton over unpaid salaries and the abandoned rescue of three bodies trapped underground at Lily Mine.

Angry residents blockade a road in anger over the demolition of shacks in illegally occupied a piece of land in Wells Estate.Police had to fire rubber bullets when residents took out their anger by throwing stones at passing motorists.

A small group of mineworkers and residents blocked off a main road in Barbarton and burnt tyres in protest over unpaid salaries and the abandoned rescue of three bodies trapped underground at Lily Mine.
Glebelands Hostel residents are living in fear and some whistle-blowers have threatened to stop co-operating with the police after the killing of a murder witness.
Members of the Upper Highway Air non-profit organisation lead a protest march in Hillcrest calling for the closure and rehabilitation of Evniroserv's Shongweni landfill site.
A man identified as a suspect in a weekend shooting spree in Oliventhoutbosch in Centurion was killed in an apparent mob justice incident

On 5 February 2017, residents took to the streets and forced their way into foreign nationals homes they believed to be used for drug dealing and prostitution in Rosettenville, Johannesburg (Gauteng). Nine people were arrested. No reports on injuries. [size=at least 9]
Police are monitoring Vuwani in Limpopo, after protesters forced a satellite municipal office to close and brought schooling to a halt.
During a murder trial at the Rustenburg Magistrate's Court, people gathered and protested outside.

column7: WAMUA: Women from Mining Affected Communities United in Action
column17: About 50 supporters of Women from Mining Affected Communities United in Action (WAMUA) from across the country chanted at the busy intersection of Lower Long and Walter Sisulu roads outside the Cape Town Convention Centre.
Several protests at Walter Sisulu Campuses in East London forced. campuses to shut down: Chiselhurst Campus
A small group of Durban University of Technology (DUT) students embarked on a peaceful march to the vice chancellor's office .
Hundreds of protesters gathered outside the Johannesburg office of pharmaceutical company Roche over cancer deaths.
Several protests at Walter Sisulu Campuses in East London forced campuses to shut down: Potsdam Campus
Service providers to the city of Pretoria have protested outside the office of the Speaker of Council, vowing not to leave until payments they say are due to them have been made.

Motorists travelling between Berlin and Potsdam were delayed for hours after residents of Baghdad and Kanana near Walter Sisulu University's Potsdam campus blockaded the road with burning tyres in protest against lack of service delivery.
Ten people have been arrested after Bela-Bela residents petrol-bombed the mayor's private car and torched a building in the area. 1 person was shot and killed during the protest action.

The Rhodes statue in the Company's Garden (Cape Town) was covered with posters during a protest by Sonke Gender Justice against the gold mines. At the same time, Residents of Marikana and their supporters outside the Western Cape High Court.

A small group of protesters under the leadership of the South Durban Community Environmental Alliance marched to the Durban City Hall to voice their concerns about Eskom's controversial proposed new nuclear procurement programme for the country.
A man who allegedly stabbed his ex-girlfriend repeatedly in full view of commuters at a KwaZulu-Natal taxi rank in Richard's Bay has died after witnesses attacked him.

column7: Taxi Drivers (South Africa); EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; BLF: Black First, Land First
column17: A metered taxi operator hoisted a placard at a march against Uber in Pretoria. Members of the EFF and Black First Land First joined the march in solidarity with the metered taxi operators

As part of the national #UberMustFall campaign, cab operators marched from Joburg to Pretoria in protest to the department's offices in Pretoria. The march was marked by chaos as protesters, some allegedly armed with knobkerries threatened their counterparts who refused to participate. The windows and windscreens of some Uber cars were smashed in and the keys of others snatched by meter taxi operators.
Residents of Cuba and Eluxolweni in MDantsane blocked Qumza Highway over lack of electricity in their area.

column7: Students (South Africa); ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: Walter Sisulu University students at the Nelson Mandela Drive campus (Mthatha) were chased off campus after they set alight a building and blocked the fire brigade from entering the premises. Earlier that morning, the ANC Youth League on the campus blocked access to the university
Several Despatch residents took to the streets blocking Old Uitenhage Road with burning tyres.

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; ANC: African National Congress
column17: ANC and EFF supporters held separate protests in the Cape Town CBD before the President gave the State of the National Address.

Economic Freedom Fighters members and security dressed in white shirts clashed during the State of the Nation Address in Parliament ahead of President Jacob Zuma's State of the Nation Address (SONA). Tear gas, or pepper spray, was also apparently used in the public gallery.

column7: ANCWL: African National Congress Womens League; Women (South Africa)
column17: A group of members of the ANC Women's League protested outside the Moretele Magistrate's Court during a murder trial.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: South Africa's National Education Health and Allied Worker Union (Nehawu) protested in various parts of the country: Kwa-Zulu Natal (Pietermaritzburg)

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League; BLF: Black First, Land First
column17: More than 300 members of the African National Congress Youth League and the Black First Land First (BLF) movement brought the streets of Johannesburg banking district to a standstill during a march to Absa's headquarters, following the release of the Public Protector's report.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: South Africa's National Education Health and Allied Worker Union (Nehawu) protested in various parts of the country: Eastern Cape (Port Elizabeth)

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: South Africa's National Education Health and Allied Worker Union (Nehawu) protested in various parts of the country: Cape Town

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: South Africa's National Education Health and Allied Worker Union (Nehawu) protested in various parts of the country: Pretoria

About 200 former residents carried placards with the names of their streets, long since bulldozed into the annals of history. They wound their way from the District Six Homecoming Centre to the suburb on the slopes of Devil's Peak (Cape Town).

On 11 February 2017, police fired rubber bullets to disperse about 300 South African nationals during a demonstration in Rosettenville, Johannesburg (Gauteng). At least 10 houses suspected to belong to drug lords and brothel owners were set on fire. The group also tried to plunder a home belonging to a Congolese national. No reports on injuries. [size=about 300]
Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University (NMMU) has clamped down on security after a building on the south campus was petrol- bombed

column7: ANC: African National Congress; Women (South Africa)
column17: A Women's' League leader confronted a group of ANC members wearing CR17 T-shirts when she attended an event in Ekangala, Mpumalanga.
An alleged rapist died after being assaulted and set on fire in a mob justice incident in Mpheni Village

Around 12 February 2017 (as reported), at least 22 houses belonging to foreign nationals, mostly Nigerians, were set on fire by residents of Rosettenville, Johannesburg (Gauteng). The group was accusing foreigners of transforming the neighborhood into a 'drug heaven'. No reports on injuries. [size=no report]
50 workers protested at the Blue Ribbon depot in Port Elizabeth due to retrenchment packages offered by Blue Ribbon.

A Cape Town school in Crossroads, where staff members are forced to use buckets to flush the toilets and where lights remain turned off due to fears of electrocution, has been shut down by angry parents who say their children are being taught in a death trap.

column7: NANDUWE: Nancefield Dube West Taxi Association
column17: Members of the Nancefield Dube West Taxi Association (Nanduwe) peacefully blocked off parts of Johannesburg to get the department to intervene in a turf war that has been going on since 2014.
Roads were blocked off with burning tyres between Rabie Ridge and Mayibuye along Modderfontein Road in Johannesburg by community members.
Residents of Schweizer-Reneke that are facing a water shortage went took to the streets, burning water tanks that were meant to alleviate the problem.
A group of residents from Helenvale in Port Elizabeth protested outside the offices of a councillor who they claim does ""not deliver services"" to the people.
Protesters demonstrated outside the Wynberg Magistrate's court over the bail hearing of a criminal.

About 100 residents and neighbours of Masiphumelele marched to Fish Hoek Civic Centre, where a sub-council meeting was being held, to hand over a memorandum on unhealthy living conditions. The march was supported by members of the Social Justice Coalition (SJC) and Right2Know.
Students at Walter Sisulu University's Ibika campus in Butterworth protested and halted the registration process after they forcibly removed staff from the premises.

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students
column17: A peaeful protest lead in COSAS in Proteria decended into chaos as protesters looted and stole goods from shops. Police responded with stun grendaes.

A shortage of accommodation, which has forced some students to sleep on benches or squat in packed residences, sparked a protest at the Tshwane University of Technology (TUT). Management closed the main campus in Pretoria West, after students blocked the entrance with burning tyres.
About 70 Fisantekraal residents marched to Parliament in Cape Town protesting for the implementation of the Enhanced People's Housing
Pupils blocked the road between Alice (near Alice) and King William's Town after a wall at their school collapsed.
A closed Blue Ribbon bakery in Walmer (Port Elizabeth) was petrol-bombed, with shots fired at a security guard.

Protesters from the Philippi Horticulture Area Food and Farming Campaign picketed in Cape Town ahead of Environmental Affairs MEC briefing on the province's water situation at the Cape Town Press Club on Thursday.
Nearly 100 Durban University of Technology students slept on the steps of the Vice Chancellor's office as a housing crisis enters its
Police used teargas and rubber bullets to disperse a protest against a suupermarket that had blocked off a public thoroughfare.

On 18 February 2017, residents set at least 3 houses on fire and looted several residences of foreign nationals in Pretoria West, Tshwane (Gauteng). The group were accusing the foreign nationals of drug and human trafficking. No reports on injuries. [size=no report]
Rioters in Duduza blockaded a road with burning tires and vandalised shops to protest against a company that has been hiring foreign nationals. The police arrested 10 people.
Shops belonging to immigrants were looted.
MK veterans marched from Kwazakhele to New Brighton to protest crime.
A group of people stormed and looted 3 Somali-run tuckshops in Mamelodi.
Students at the Durban University of Technology barricaded the road with burning tires to protest funding problems. The police used teargas to disperse them.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Nurses marched to demand protection from violent patients in KZN. No more information provided

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Nurses marched to demand protection from violent patients in Eastern Cape. No more information provided

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Nurses marched to demand protection from violent patients in Northern Cape. No more information provided
In Gugulethu, classes were disrupted at the school when parents, members of the school governing body (SGB) and some teachers protested against alleged overcrowding and non-payment of teachers.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Nurses marched to demand protection from violent patients.
Shops belonging to immigrants were looted.
Students marched to protest for the #feesmustfall leader who has been in prison for 150 days.
Police attempted to disperse an anti-immigrant march from Mamelodi.
A group of demonstrators from Atteridgeville clashed with panga-wielding immigrants from Somalia. Police broke up the clash using rubber bullets and water cannons.
A shop belonging to a member of the Nigerian community was looted in the latest xenophobic attack at Jeppestown, Johannesburg.

The usually quiet and peaceful town of Greyton has been rocked by violence. Residents broke down the existing and newly-built dwellings that had been established in the development. Several people were assaulted in altercations

On 27 February 2017, a foreign national and his family were beaten by unidentified individuals inside their house in Pretoria, Tshwane (Gauteng). The group looted several items. The victim filed a xenophobic complaint with the Police.
Residents of Rosedale in Uitenhage shut down a clinic, citing a string of issues, including a shortage of staff and medicines and lack of security.
Three firefighting vehicles responding to a fire in Grassy Park, withdrew from the scene after they were stoned by angry residents.
Residents of informal homes in Greyton showed their dissatisfaction with the local government by holding a protest.
Hundreds of PAC members marched to the University of Fort Hare (Alice), demanding that the university management rename the institution after its founding president Robert Mangaliso Sobukwe.

Protests in Alexandra township forced the official opening of the River Park Clinic to be cancelled. Several hundred residents burnt tyres, City of Joburg flags and refuse while blocking roads with tree trunks, rocks and debris.
DA leader Mmusi Maimane led a protest march in Johannesburg over the Life Esidimeni tragedy to Gauteng Premier David Makhura's doorstep
Teaching stopped when parents, teachers and pupils marched to the Gugulethu police station to try and obtain a permit to march to the department
The ANC's battling Dr WB Rubusana factions disrupted a tense Buffalo City Metro council meeting at the City Hall (East London) with protests erupting in the public gallery.

Over two days, residents in Gugulethu Section Four protested against the City of Cape Town's plans for a piece of land in Tambo Square. Sections of the township were blocked with burning tyres, rubbish, and rubble.
Residents in Umlazi protested outside the Durban high court, saying they would not move accommodation unless alternative accommodation was provided.
A group of about 200 Jozi@Work protesters took to the streets in central Johannesburg late on as they continued to express objection against the canning of the programme.
Hundreds of EFF supporters gathered outside the Constitutional Court (Johannesburg) in support of Fees Must Fall activist Bonginkosi Khanyile.
A group of about 200 Rastafarians - aligned to the Rastafari United Front - marched through Keizersgracht, Constitution and Roeland streets in Cape Town.
Tshwane Metro Police have deployed officers in a bid to re-open the major routes ""illegally"" blockaded by protesting truckers in Pretoria.

Over two days, residents in Gugulethu Section Four protested against the City of Cape Town's plans for a piece of land in Tambo Square. Sections of the township were blocked with burning tyres, rubbish, and rubble.
Student protests started at iQhayiya High School in Khayelitsha. Stun grenades were fired when the protesting students attempted to enter the school grounds.
Dozens of Black Sash and Right2Know members held pickets at several South African Social Security Agency (SASSA) offices across Cape Town: Delft.
Dozens of Black Sash and Right2Know members held pickets at several South African Social Security Agency (SASSA) offices across Cape Town: Eastridge.
Dozens of Black Sash and Right2Know members held pickets at several South African Social Security Agency (SASSA) offices across Cape Town: Khayelitsha.
Members of Earthlife Africa demonstrated outside the North Gauteng court in Pretoria over the new coal-fored powerplant.
Dozens of Black Sash and Right2Know members held pickets at several South African Social Security Agency (SASSA) offices across Cape Town: Tafelsig.
A man died on his way to hospital after he was allegedly assaulted and set alight by members of the Soul City community in Kagiso, Soweto in a mob justice attack.

Just over 100 people joined a march through the Cape Town city centre, carrying placards that read: 'We stand united against xenophobia' and 'Refugees and immigrants need to be protected'. The march was organised by the Workers International Vanguard League.
14 miners were killed as groups of Zama Zama miners clashed in Benoni over the weekend.
14 miners were killed as groups of Zama Zama miners clashed in Benoni over the weekend.
About 150 students from Philippi High School marched to the Metro South Education District Office demanding that a new school they say was promised to them be built.
A special task team has been established to investigate the murder of Richmond municipal manager Sibusiso Sithole, who was shot and killed.

On 6 March 2017, police used rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse a group that blocked roads with rocks and burning tires on roads in Olievenhoutbosch, Tshwane (Gauteng). The group was demonstration against violence in the city; at least 5 foreign owned shops were looted. [size=no report]
A group of New Crossroads residents protested and barricaded streets with burning tyres, large rocks and rubble.
Mpumalanga's department of education has condemned the actions of protesters in Barberton who reportedly forced pupils at six schools in Emjindini to join them.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Hundreds of Kouga Municipality workers affiliated to SAMWU (South African Municipal Workers' Union) went on strike after talks with the employer reached a deadlock. Workers gathered at the municipal offices in Da Gama Street, Jeffreys Bay, holding placards and singing
Members of Earthlife Africa sing and chant outside the high court in Pretoria

Residents of Golden Drive informal settlement in Benoni had to run for their lives when gas exploded and shots were fired in a clash between police and illegal miners. The police and miners also exchanged gunfire.
People were shot with rubber bullets during a protest over the allocation of RDP houses in Princess informal settlement, west of Johannesburg (Roodepoort).
A incident of mob justice took pace in the princess informal settlement in Roodepoort when a suspected thief was killed by an angry mob.
Parents disrupted the start of the school day at Manenberg Primary,protesting over unconfirmed reports that the school might be shut.
Hundreds of students demonstrated outside their East London campus over student issues.
The Right to Know Campaign (R2K) gathered outside Sassa's offices in Umlazi, demanding answers from Social Development Minister Bathabile Dlamini on the future of grant payments.
A large group of Reiger Park residents gathered in front of the Ekurhuleni municipality's offices in Benoni.
Community groups intend staging a march against crime, poverty, and xenophobia to the Union Buildings. The Coalition of Civics Against Xenophobia organised the protest.
Five people were injured in Reiger Park when police used rubber bullets to disperse a crowd which had turned violent. Protesters had tried to set a councillor's house alight.
Taxi drivers, angry about the rise of Uber, protested and blocked roads around OR TAMBO Airport in Kempton Park, Johannesburg.
Democratic Alliance (DA) leader Mmusi Maimane led a march to the Department of Social Development in Pretoria.

Around 50 staff, who are members of the Academics Union and the Employees Union at the University of Cape Town (UCT), demonstrated outside UCT's Bremner building, calling for an amicable resolution to salary negotiations.
In Hlanganani outside Giyani, a man was killed with a sjambok during a mob attack.
Limpopo police have launched a manhunt for a group of people who killed a man in Mvelaphanda in mob violence.
Protest by residents of Masiphumelele to draw attention to land issues in the community cut the Cape Town Cycle Tour short.

Students at the University of KwaZulu-Natal's Edgewood campus in Pinetown brought lectures to a halt in protest, demanding funding from the National Student Financial Aid Scheme (NSFAS) for those who qualified.
A small group of Right2Know supporters picketed outside Sassa's head offices in Pretoria
Protesters barricaded roads in Riverlea, Johannesburg, with burning tyres and rocks.
On 14 March 2017, five Nigerian nationals were attacked by unidentified individuals in Ivy Park, Polokwane (Limpopo). The house of one of them was set on fire. [size=no report]

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Social workers, supported by Nehawu, picketed outside the South African Social Security Agency (Sassa) offices in Mitchells Plain after talks between their union Nehawu and the Department of Social Development broke down over working conditions.

A brand new city development was hit by a massive labour protest, when 500 job seekers from the surrounding area stormed the basement parking demanding jobs be given to residents of Pretoria. After the protestesr became violent police had to intervene resulting in the injury of one police officer.
Dismissed security guards from the University of the Western Cape (UWC) demonstrated outside the university on Tuesday, calling for their employer, Securitas to reinstate them.
Parents, teachers and pupils marched outside a school in Strand against alleged overcrowding, no proper school structure, no sport grounds and no proper school ground.

On 15 March 2017, police used rubber bullets to disperse rival groups of South African and foreign nationals during a standoff in Turffontein, Johannesburg (Gauteng). South African nationals were accusing foreigner nationals of operating drug dens and brothels. No reports on injuries. [size=no report]
Students at the historic Healdtown Comprehensive High School in Fort Beaufort blockaded the road and burnt tyres in front of the education district office in protest over the shortage of teachers.

On 15 March 2017, villages in the North West experienced demonstration action over poor service delivery. In Blydeville township in Lichtenburg, several foreigner-owned shops were looted during this week's violent demonstrations. [size=no report]
About 40 Braaf family members picketed along Borcherds Quarry Road outside the Cape Town airport (Matroosfontein in Cape Town) over land claims.
The Bakutsoe High School in Nelspruit was set alight on March 15 during a service delivery protest by residents.
High school students looted shops in Fordsburg, Johannesburg.

Villages in the North West experienced protest action over poor service delivery: In Makgobistad village, the road leading to Bray from Mahikeng and a border post into Botswana were also blocked by angry residents demanding road upgrades and maintenance, among other things. Several police and private vehicles were pelted with stones and damaged.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: As part of its ongoing efforts to put pressure on Absa bank to repay a SA Reserve Bank loan, the ANC Youth League brought a branch in the Pietermaritzburg CBD to a standstill on Wednesday.
About 1500 former residents with Right2Know of the iconic Schubart Park took to the streets of the city demanding the speedy refurbishments of the flats.
Students at the University of Fort Hare in East London brought traffic to a standstill when they marched to the institution demanding to meet the vice-chancellor, Sakhela Buhlungu.
Residents staged a protest outside the Garsfontein police station when the man was apprehended in March.

column7: SWEAT: Sex Workers Education and Advocacy Taskforce
column17: Activists demonstrate outside the Western Cape High Court today where artist Zwelethu Mthethwa was found guilty of the murder of sex worker Nokuphila Kumalo
Hawkers burned tyres in Mthatha in protest against the confiscation of their stalls by the municipality.
Parents of pupils at Kwa-Phalo Primary School in Meadowlands, Soweto, blocked the entrance to the school, preventing staff and pupils from entering.
Calm has been restored to Avian Park in Worcester after residents turned on police, pelting them with stones. About 600 residents gathered at the scene and started throwing stones at police

A group of residents from Asanda Village in Lwandle, Strand, blocked traffic on the N2 when they marched to the Asla construction company's offices to protest against the state of their RDP houses that the company built.

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students; Students (South Africa)
column17: Thousands of school students with the help of COSAS held protests in Baamfontein in Johannesburg.
One man died after residents of Extension One chased him and beat him to death in a suspected mob killing.
The arrests of two men for allegedly burning a shack owned by a man they suspected of murder sparked a fiery protest. They burnt tyres and blocked roads.
Workers gathered from across Gauteng and protested outside the Menlyn offices, marching to the Department of Transport to submit a memorandum of grievances to the minister.

On 18 March 2017, police used stunt grenades and rubber bullets to disperse a crowd in Rosettenville, Johannesburg (Gauteng) after some residents started to march against drugs, prostitution, property theft and brothels. [size=no report]
Young children joined their parents, other locals, civic leaders and political parties during a mass protest against a planned tavern in Woodview, Phoenix.
Police have fired rubber bullets at protesting residents from the Masiphumelele township in Cape Town. The violence ensued after protesters barricaded roads with burning tyres near Kommetjie.
Dozens of women who lined up outside the Western Cape High Court, calling for nikahs to be declared legally valid.
Villagers of Mutele and surrounding areas began protesting at the gates to the national park to demand that SANParks include them in its social and labour programmes.
Eight people were arrested for public violence during a protest in Mzimhlophe, Soweto. Protesters had barricaded the Soweto Highway in a protest against evictions in the area.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Workers and members of the National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa's (Numsa) marched to the RAF head offices in Centurion to submit a memorandum to chief executive Eugene Watson.
Freedom Park residents marched to Luthuli House in Johannesburg, where they called on the African National Congress (ANC) to provide them with land.
Residents of Mbekweni near Paarl marked Human Rights Day on Tuesday with a march against drugs and crime.
Protest action in Marite, Bushbuckridge resulted in the torching of Lamulelani and Bakhutshwe high schools.

While president Jacob Zuma was giving a keynote address at the Human Rights Day national celebrations in King William's Town, residents were protesting against lack of service delivery. They blockaded the R63 road with burning tyres and stones saying their human right to electricity was being violated after weeks of no power.
More than 100 people took to the streets to protest against a gross violation of human rights human trafficking.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Members of the National Education Health and Allied Workers Union picketed in front of the Western Cape Department of Social Development offices.
About 1 000 residents who were protesting attempted to attack a murder suspect, during which a police officer was injured and four vehicles damaged.
Residents from Ward 13 (East London) marched in protest with the SACP against corruption.
Workers picketed outside their Menlyn branch offices and attracted support from the EFF for the strike action.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: ANC Youth League (ANCYL) demonstrators were slowly gathering on Thursday morning in Shakas Head in preparation for their march to the Ballito Junction Mall ahead of its grand opening.

column7: NU: Ndifuna Ukwazi; RTC: Reclaim The City
column17: Activists from Reclaim the City and Ndifuna Ukwazi have occupied two provincial government buildings protest and in the hope of pressuring authorities to develop affordable inner city accommodation in Cape Town: Woodstock
The Barcelona informal settlement in Gugulethu is strewn with reeking portable chemical toilets after residents stopped cleaners from working in a protest against recruitment policies.

column7: Students (South Africa); RTC: Reclaim The City; NU: Ndifuna Ukwazi
column17: About 60 students from Philippi High School marched from Cape Town train station through the city centre to the Western Cape provincial legislature in a protest over conditions at their school. At the same time, activists from Reclaim the City and Ndifuna Ukwazi have occupied two provincial government buildings in protest and in the hope of pressuring authorities to develop affordable inner city accommodation in Cape Town: V & A Waterfront in Cape Town
At Rhodes University, protest flared up in the form of a spontaneous march around campus, trailed by police cars
Steenberg residents returned to continue their protest held outside a church in Galilee Street against a proposed erection of a cellphone mast there.

Over three days, Komga has been host to service delivery protests. About 300 protesters gathered in a field close to Happy Valley township after burning tyres and blocking the road with tree stumps to restrict entry to the town.
On 27 March 2017, a group took to the streets of Polokwane (Limpopo) chanting anti-drugs songs. [size=no report]
Residents of Eshowe, northern KwaZulu-Natal, went on a service delivery protest. They blockaded the town's busiest street with burning tyres and concrete rubbish bins.

A protest took place in Pimville, Soweto, against the installation of prepaid electricity meters under control. About 50 Pimville residents had blocked Modjadji Road with burning tyres, forcing Eskom employees to abandon their meter installations for the day.
Students have been blocking entrances, damaging University of Venda property and clashing with police in a renewal of student protests.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Officials in the department's health facilities started picketing outside the Polokwane Hospital's entrance, demanding to be paid their bonuses. Trade union Nehawu said the strike would continue until their demands were met.
Bhisho Park ratepayers have called on the Buffalo City Metro to pay R2500 in compensation to each household affected by a power outage of eight days. They marched to the metro's offices in Bhisho.
Over three days, Komga has been host to service delivery protests. One protester was taken to Frere Hospital after being hit by rubber bullets by police while 8 were arrested.
Three schools were set alight in Marite in Bushbuckridge, Mpumalanga, as the community demanded the tarring of a road in the area.
Eshowe community members held a destructive protest at the Eshowe constituency offices. The community allegedly burnt tyres near the offices and damaged the windows
An anti-xenophobia march, lead by the African Diaspora Forum (ADF) and consisting of 200 supporters took to the streets of Johannesburg.

Students have been blocking entrances and damaging University of Venda property and clashing with police. Four student protesters were arrested on charges of public violence and will appear in the Thoyohandou magistrates court.

column9: Labour Group (International); Migrants (International); Civilians (Somalia); Labour Group (Somalia)
column17: On 28 March 2017, four cars were burnt in downtown Polokwane (Limpopo) during an apparent demonstration against drugs. Foreign owned shops were looted. Taxi drivers attacked Somali shop owners, looting a shop and destroying properties in Polokwane. No reported injuries. [size=no report]
Police are monitoring the situation in Olievenhoutbosch, Centurion where the R55 has been blocked with rocks and tyres.
Police kept a close watch as the protests continued in Eshowe over service delivery.
Activities at the University of Venda were shut down on as a result of student protests.
Government has appealed for calm in Vuwani after fresh violence erupted following the Municipal Demarcation Board's announcement that it would not review its decision to shift boundaries in the area.

column7: PSG: Palestine Solidarity Group; #FeesMustFall; Students (South Africa)
column17: A protest was staged on the Jammie Plaza at the University of Cape Town, with students from the Palestine Solidarity Forum (PSF) joining forces with students protesting for the Fees Must Fall (FMF) movement to defend the space together.
In Elsies River, protesters blocked the surrounding streets with burning tyres, furniture and mattresses. Police used rubber bullets, tear gas and stun grenades. Protesters threw rocks.

Over three days, Komga has been host to service delivery protests. About 300 protesters gathered in a field close to Happy Valley township after burning tyres and blocking the road with tree stumps to restrict entry to the town.
A march started at National Treasury offices in Pretoria before heading to the Union Buildings over the recent cabinet reshuffle.
Members of the taxi fraternity, the community policing forum and thousands of other marchers as they moved through the streets of Naturena with placards calling for rapists to be brought to book.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Protesters, supported by NEHAWU, have set tyres alight in the hope of getting their demands met in Newcastle.

An angry mob tried to burn the structure down in Mitchells Plain. Police opened fire with rubber bullets in a bid to disperse the 300-strong mob outside the suspect's home in Matroosberg Street, Tafelsig
Over 200 people protested outside Parliament calling for the immediate resignation of President Jacob Zuma.
Outsourced workers at the embattled Passenger Rail Agency of South Africa (Prasa) staged a protest outside the entity's offices in Hatfield demanding to be hired permanently by the parastatal.
Hundreds of people have gathered in Church Square in Pretoria to protest against President Jacob Zuma's Cabinet reshuffle.
Amid the spreading protests against President Jacob Zuma's reshuffling of the cabinet, a handful of Johannesburg residents picketed outside the Gupta family compound in Saxonwold Johannesburg.
Hundreds of residents from the Tafelsig area of Mitchells Plain turned up at the local magistrate's court to protest, and demand justice following the murder of 11-year-old Stacha Arendz.
Two suspected robbers were burnt to death and two others were injured in Ga-Kgwete near Mecklenburg in Limpopo.
On 5 April 2017, a gunman, who hid away at a local spaza shop after allegedly shooting and killing a 16-year-old boy in Kraaifontein, was caught and killed by an angry mob.
Save South Africa supporters camped out at Church Square in Pretoria in protests.
Thousands of protesters have gathered for the anti-Zuma march in Cape Town, stretching from St. George's Cathedral to the train station.
About 400 community members clashed with police outside the Richmond Magistrate's Court. Police retaliated with stun grenades and rubber bullets to disperse the unruly crowd
A school administration block has been burnt just four days after fresh violence erupted in Vuwani over the municipal boundary line.

On 6 April 2017, a person was killed, and five others were injured during attacks against Nigerian nationals in Polokwane (Limpopo). The victims were accused of being involved with drug dealing. [size=no report]
