Thousands of Garden Route residents stood in solidarity with the rest of the country, calling for President Jacob Zuma to step down: Knysna
The Democratic Alliance held pickets at major intersection in Rustenburg, as part of the call for President Jacob Zuma to resign as head of the country.
Thousands of Garden Route residents stood in solidarity with the rest of the country, calling for President Jacob Zuma to step down: George
Thousands of Garden Route residents stood in solidarity with the rest of the country, calling for President Jacob Zuma to step down: Plettenberg Bay
Thousands of Garden Route residents stood in solidarity with the rest of the country, calling for President Jacob Zuma to step down: Mossel Bay

On 07 April 2017, ANC members who demonstrated outside the Luthuli House in Johannesburg grabbed and attacked three people, believed to be DA supporters, who ran into their march with a banner. Police fired rubber bullets and tear gas. [size=no report].
About 150 people from the Little Karoo town of Barrydale participated in a peaceful anti-Zuma protest on Route 62.
A protest against crime in Ocean View turned violent when youths attempted to block roads by burning tyres and throwing stones. Police used teargas and rubber bullets to disperse them.

As South Africans came together in a series of protests across the country calling for President Jacob Zuma to step down, the youth in Port Elizabeth made their dissatisfaction with Zuma heard at a peaceful protest rally attended by thousands of residents.
Thousands of Save South Africa supporters have descended on Church Square in Cape Town to call for President Jacob Zuma to step down.
Thousands have gathered near the Old Durban Drive-in to protest President Jacob Zuma's recent Cabinet reshuffle.
Archbishop Emeritus Desmond Tutu and his wife Leah joined protesters outside the retirement home they are staying at in Hermanus, to add their support to nationwide anti-Zuma marches.
The Democratic Alliance held pickets in Pietermaritzburg.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: After the ANCYL interruted a peaceful march with violence, police intervened, hurling stun grenades at youth league members who went on the rampage, destroying the DA's gazebo and tables before throwing eggs at the demonstrators.

Police used rubber bullets and teargas to disperse disgruntled Polokwane residents who blocked roads. Residents had burned tyres and blocked roads, as they joined nationwide action against President Jacob Zuma.

The crowd of an estimated 40 000 people from different political organisations, civil organisations, unions and the general public gathered at the Union Buildings in Pretoria in the first mass protest against a sitting government since the dawn of democracy.
Protest action at the intersection near Somerset West in Cape Town took place with burning tyres and stone throwing by protesters

column7: SATAWU: South African Transport and Allied Workers Union; NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: Over 150 striking workers march down Klipfontein Road in Rondebosch, Cape Town to demand better wages and working conditions. Unions were represented included SATAWU and NUMSA.
About 300 residents of Mbekweni informal settlement marched to the Paarl Magistrates Court.
Community members caught a man who had killed a child in Soweto and assaulted him but did not kill him.

On 12 April 2017, a foreign national was killed and his house set on fire by a group in Kwelera village (Eastern Cape). According to information, the group was unhappy about the presence of foreign nationals in the area. [size=no report]

column7: HOSPERSA: Health and Other Service Personnel Trade Union of South Africa; Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: The Health and Other Service Personnel Trade Union of South Africa (Hospersa) marched to Northdale Hospital, protesting against a nursing operations manager allegedly being ""subjected to religious discrimination"".

Thousands of marchers led by the EFF have gathered in Pretoria's Church Square, singing and dancing to shake off the grey clouds above them, as various political parties prepare to march to the Union Buildings to call for President Jacob Zuma to step down.

Four people have been arrested for public violence in Stutterheim following a violent protest allegedly by Amahlathi Local Municipality workers. A municipal building was damaged and roads were blocked with burning tyres
A group of women gathered outside the Hawks offices in Port Elizabeth in support of victims they say had been roped in by ""pimps"" belonging to the pastors church.

At least 15 people were injured and three houses vandalised in a dispute between members of a local church and residents in Mokhurumela, outside Senwabarana in Limpopo. Church members started hurling stones at the tavern and tavern owner's house.
A group of ten people from Johannesburg Against Injustices (JAI) conducted a protest"" outside the Military Museum in Saxonwold, Johannesburg where the Gupta-organised event was being held.
Police are investigating a case of assault after a Democratic Alliance member was attacked, allegedly by ANC members, during an election campaign in Nquthu on Monday.
The Democratic Alliance took to the streets in Polokwane, Limpopo in a march against President Jacob Zuma.

Six cars were damaged by people throwing stones in Vuwani during protest action. Two people were killed in Vuwani in Limpopo on when the car they were travelling in crashed into a pipe that was being used to barricade a road (during a protest), and burst into flames.
Pensioners and supporters with the help of Right2Know picketed at Parliament to protest against deductions from their social grants.
Police officers arresting a teenager caught with drugs in Manenberg came under attack from angry residents, who pelted their vehicles with stones, demanding that the man be released.
Student protesters handed over a memorandum to the University of the Witwatersrand, in which they demanded the removal of the Respublica facilities manager.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Hundreds of Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) members marched to Absa head office in Johannesburg to hand over a memorandum of demands, calling for the bank to repay bailout money paid to Bankorp by the Reserve Bank during apartheid.
An ANC regional deputy decretary was shot several times and died as he arrived at his home in Emfundweni, ward 13 in Umzimkhulu.
At TUT, security workers embarked on a peaceful protest at the main campus in Pretoria West demanding that management honoured agreements made during previous protests.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; NTEU: National Tertiary Education Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Both the National Education, Health and Allied Workers' Union (Nehawu) and the National Tertiary Education Union (NTEU) joined protests at the Rhodes University in Grahamstown.
In Coligny, protesters looted a liquor store and stole cool drinks in service delivery protests.
Members of the South African Communist Party (SACP) picketed outside the Treasury in Pretoria, calling for an end to the capture of the financial sector.
Klipspruit residents have blocked the renovation of one of the schools in protest, claiming that they were not informed about the project.
A truck was set alight during a service delivery protest in Lichtenburg.
Nearly 200 scientists and science lovers took to the streets of Durban in support of science.
About 100 Hangberg residents including school children marched in Hangberg, Hout Bay, demanding better policing and tougher measures against crime and drug-dealing.
A bottle store was looted and pupils removed from schools in Coligny during a protest. Public order police are managing the situation. No reports of injuries have been received
Amalinda Forest shack dwellers (in East London) took to the streets in a cry for attention to their housing and electricity needs in their 30-year-old settlement.
In Lichtenburg, several shops were looted. Three trucks are believed to have been set alight by protesters in ongoing protest violence after the death of a child.
The man accused of killing 13-year-old Rene-Tracy Roman from Lavender Hill abandoned his bid for bail after residents protested inside and outside the court (Mitchells Plain).
Police were forced to fire rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse angry crowds in Coligny.
Police fired rubber bullets as residents in Lenasia South barricaded roads, burnt tyres and threw rocks, in protest against what they called an illegal land invasion.
Police were forced to fire rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse angry crowds in Lichtenburg.
Hundreds of CPUT students living at New Market Junction residence in Woodstock were protesting over a lack of proper facilities, and alleged unlawful evictions.
200 students marched to the Mankweng (Turfloop) police station demanding to be protected from criminals who are terrorising them.
Residents of Fine Town informal settlement in Johannesburg took to the streets demanding they be allocated stands in the nearby Moriting informal settlement. They blocked roads with burning tyres.

There was singing and dancing outside the Durban High Court during a protest as the Judge granted an interim order compelling waste management giant EnviroServ to cease all acceptance, treatment and disposal of waste at its Shongweni landfill.

A Limpopo chief fled his home in Diphale village near Burgersfort after community torched his house and the traditional authority offices. Roads leading to the village were still barricaded with stones and tree trunks.

Residents from King Senare Forestview near Soul City (Kimberley) have laid charges of inciting violence against Sol Plaatje executive mayor Mangaliso Matika, following a protest where stun grenades were fired and a number of residents were hit by rubber bullets. during the protest tyres were set alight and buckets of raw sewage were emptied onto the streets.
About 50 members of Afriforum picketed at the Union Buildings in Pretoria.

column7: SACCA: South African Cabin Crew Association
column17: South African Cabin Crew Association members picketed outside the offices of South African Airways (kempton Park) over meal allowances.
A small group of protesters blocked the roads into the Ndaleni area just outside the Richmond CBD with concrete slabs, burning tyres and rocks.

column7: PAGAD: People Against Gangsterism and Drugs
column17: About 70 Bokmakierie residents (Athlone) and PAGAD members held an unplanned march and picket to protest against gang shootings, drugs and crime in their area.
About 500 people gathered at a stadium following a march from Njoli Square in Port Elizabeth. The marchers were made up of various Civil Society organisations under the campaign of SaveSA.
Nearly 2,000 learners from schools in the Eastern Cape marched to the provincial education department in Zwelitsha, King William's Town on Freedom Day. The march was supported by Equal Education.

The community of Fleurhof on the West Rand took to the streets in protest against lack of electricity. They blocked Main Reef Road with burning tyres and stones, demanding that the electricity be restored.
Outside the Coligny court house, residents of Tlhabologang sang liberation songs and waved placards calling for an accused murderer not to be granted bail.
Hundreds of people participated in a march in the city centre of Durban during Works Day celebrations.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Hundreds of Cosatu members marched for Workers Day to the Johannesburg Stock Exchange in Sandton to demand an end to 'white monopoly capital'.

On 2 May 2017, the police fired rubber bullets to disperse a crowd in Kliptown, Johannesburg (Gauteng), during a demonstration over housing. Community members barricaded roads with rocks and tires. [size=no report]
Students embarked on a protest at the Walter Sisulu University in Mthatha, demanding that the university reopen registration for education programmes for prospective students.
Over 1,500 students shut down their high school in Zwide Port Elizabeth in protest. They were demanding more teachers, additional and clean toilets, and enough nutritional food for everybody.
Service providers protested outside the office of the Tshwane City Council over money owed to them by the city.
A truck was set alight by protesters in Bapong near Brits the road linking Sun City and Pretoria was barricaded with burning tyres.
Some protesters were seen outside the Coligny Magistrate's Court chanting liberation songs while the matter of the two accused was still being heard in court.
Three shacks belonging to the people arrested for the murder of little Iyapha Yamile in Khayelitsha were burnt down by people enraged by her death.

Protesters gathered outside the entrance to the West Rand campus in Johannesburg, singing and burning tyres in defiance of campus administration. Organisers said they estimated more than 2 000 students had filtered joined the protest.
About 20 employees of the Perishable Products Export Control Board (PPECB) picketed outside the head office in Plattekloof (Cape Town) as part of a national strike over wages.
Over 1,500 students shut down their high school in Zwide Port Elizabeth in protest. They were demanding more teachers, additional and clean toilets, and enough nutritional food for everybody.

Protesters gathered at the Mitchells Plain Courthouse at the hearing of a murder accused. The demonstrations outside court included members of the Mitchells Plain community as well as community members from Lavender Hill.
Crowds gathered outside the Port Elizabeth Magistrate's court building to support a pastor , charged with human trafficking and sexual assault.
Protesters took to the streets of Durban on the opening day of the World Economic Forum on Africa to protest against the exclusivity of WEF Africa which is currently taking place in the city.
Protesters burned tyres and rubbish, blocking traffic on Freedom Way in Joe Slovo near Milnerton
At least 400 people barricaded roads during a protest in Irene, south of Pretoria
A group of about 150 Wits University students blocked the entrance to the education campus in Parktown .
High school students from across Gauteng affiliated with Equal Education picketed outside the offices of the Gauteng Department of Education in the Johannesburg CBD on Thursday.
Reclaim the City protesters stood defiantly and vowed to continue to fight for a disputed piece of land in Tafelberg as a case was heard at the Western Cape High Court.

column7: SAMA: South African Medical Association; Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: On May 5, over a thousand health workers with the support of South African Medical Association (SAMA) marched in Durban to highlight the health crisis.
At least 500 supporters of the decriminalisation of cannabis marched through Cape Town city centre.
Protests began as people threw stones at passing vehicles in Reservoir Hills.

On 8 May 2017, a pregnant woman was shot in the stomach with rubber bullets by the police after a violent demonstration erupted in Eldorado Park, Johannesburg (Gauteng) against evictions in the area. Roads were blocked with burning tires and several vehicles were pelted with rocks and a truck was set on fire. At least 15 people were arrested. [size=at least 15]
EFF members picketed outside the Wierdabrug police station (Centurion) to seek answers regarding a domestic violence case that was withdrawn without a fair trial.

In Coligny, three houses were set alight and property damaged after residents continued to protest following the death of a teenage boy. A Photographer was manhandled by the owner of one of the houses that was set alight.

column7: PRISAWU: Private Schools and Allied Workers Union
column17: Workers had gathered on the campus at the corner of Harrison and Commissioner streets in the Joburg CBD to make their voices heard.
Two classrooms at the Hillview Primary School in Reservoir Hills were set alight during a violent service delivery protest.
Vehicles were damaged during protests in Ntshawini (Stanger), north of Durban.
Students at Walter Sisulu University in Mthatha took to the streets to raise a number of grievances, but the situation escalated when they clashed with university security guards.

On 9 May 2017, police fired rubber bullets, stun grenades and teargas to disperse a crowd in Ennerdale, Johannesburg (Gauteng), during a demonstration for housing. Several roads have been barricaded with burning tires and rocks. Demonstrators also pelted officers with stones. At least 52 people were arrested. [size=at least 52]
Protests in Kuyga (Port Elizabeth) gathered outside the Department of Education offices.

column9: Civilians (International); Labour Group (South Africa); Labour Group (International)
column17: On 9 May 2017, a group set several establishments on fire in Coligny (North-West) after Caucasian farmers allegedly killed a teenager on 20 April 2017. During the two-days event, foreign-owned shops were also set on fire and looted. [size=no report]
About 50 UCT catering workers protested today about working conditions.
Protesters used front loaders to flip police vehicles and tear up roadside barriers at the Richards Bay Harbour. Police fired shots at the earth-moving machines in their attempt to keep them at bay.
Vehicles were damaged during protests in Ntshawini, north of Durban, which continued for a second day
In Vhulaudzi, Limpop, protesters barricading road access to a police station. The station and two vehicles were torched.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: 200 workers (aligned with NEHAWU) staged a protest at the university in Grahamstown, trashing rubbish bins and littering inside and around the main administration building where they had assembled.

column9: Civilians (International); Labour Group (South Africa); Labour Group (International)
column17: On 10 May 2017, a group set several establishments on fire in Coligny (North-West) after Caucasian farmers allegedly killed a teenager on 20 April 2017. During the two-days event, which started on 9 May, foreign-owned shops were also set on fire and looted. [size=no report]
In a second day of protests in Kuyga (Port Elizabeth) outside the Department of Education offices, police used stun grenades and teargas to disperse protesters during mass protest action.
A bus was torched in Bapong near Brits during a protest.
Residents and Police clashed in Finetown, Johannesburg. Residents pelted them with stones. Police used tear gas and rubber bullets against the protesters.
A large portion of Gugulethu, Cape Town, was cordoned off with burning barricaded in a protest over a decades-old rezoning dispute with its roots in apartheid-era political violence.

Ten people have been arrested after criminal elements took over during a protest at Laudium in Tshwane. Police fired rubber bullets at protesters when some tried to trespass neighbouring houses and a mosque in the area.

column7: UHPDA: United Homeless People Development Association
column17: Members of the United Homeless People Development Association participated in a service delivery protest in Steenberg, Cape Town.
A large group of KwaZulu-Natal-based musicians and singers have protested at the Durban City Hall to condemn a decision that could see the falling away of the 90 percent local content rule.
Parents and students at a primary school in Port Elizabeth (Motherwell) shut down their school, demanding more teachers.
A few hundred people from across Msunduzi municipality marched against crime in Pietermaritzburg.
During a protest in Helenvale in Port Elizabeth, police shot at protesters. Roads were blocked by burning tyres, rocks and even a mattress, and protesters pelted vehicles with stones.
At least a 100 residents against the protest protested outside a school in Ennerdale. Police used rubber bullets and teargas at protesting residents who blocked roads with burning tyres.
Protesters have barricaded the N1 north and south near Orange Farm with rocks and tyres.
Several roads around Davidsonville near Roodepoort west of Johannesburg are closed to traffic due to an on-going community protests.

Traffic was brought to a standstill on when protesters blocked the N2 in Chesterville, Durban. Protesters burned rubble and tyres, blocking the highway. There were reports of gunfire between protesters and metro police, and cars being stoned.
Protesters in Johannesburg are pelting cars with stones and have blocked the Golden Highway.
The situation at the Lonmin mine in Marikana is tense due to ongoing protests by residents demanding that the company create 1000 jobs for the unemployed youth.

Protesters blocked roads in Motherwell on the weekend after a prolonged electricity failure. A vehicle was torched and all major roads into the township blocked with burning tyres and debris. Five cars were badly damaged.

In a second day of protests, traffic was brought to a standstill on when protesters blocked the N2 in Chesterville, Durban. Protesters burned rubble and tyres, blocking the highway. There were reports of gunfire between protesters and metro police, and cars being stoned.

Merafe hostel dwellers in Soweto went on a two day protest where they allegedly vandalised a nearby shopping centre and also set some of the shops alight. residents went to nearest shops where they vandalised the shops and burnt some of them.
Residents of Forest Glade, in Eerste River, have protested against the erection of a cellphone tower.

Merafe hostel dwellers in Soweto went protest for a second day where they allegedly vandalised a nearby shopping centre and also set some of the shops alight. residents went to nearest shops where they vandalised the shops and burnt some of them.
Protest action broke out in Ntshawini (Stanger) with protesters blockading the R102. They were blocking the road with burning tyres and stones.

column7: COPE: Congress of the People; DA: Democratic Alliance
column17: Johannesburg - A group of Cope and Democratic Alliance supporters braved to protest outside Eskom's Megawatt Park in Midrand, Johannesburg, saying they did not want Brian Molefe to be reappointed as CEO of the parastatal.

Protest action continued in Ntshawini on with protesters blockading the R102 resulting with traffic having to be redirected to the N2. A car was also set alight in the area. Two suspects were arrested and charged with public violence.

Schooling at Setumo-Khiba Secondary School in Mabopane was cancelled after pupils refused to enter the school premises and protested because of poor conditions, among them overflowing sewage and blocked toilets.
North West police have confirmed seven women were arrested in Ikageleng near Zeerust during a protest over municipal services in the area.
A march in Braamfontein was in support of an application brought by the United Democratic Movement (UDM) to enforce a secret ballot for a parliamentary vote of no confidence in Zuma.
In Durban, Zuma's backers took to the streets too in his defence with regards to the Constitutional Court ruling over the secret ballot.
The Western Cape SACP on Tuesday staged an illegal protest in front of the Cape Town Convention Centre (CTICC), calling for the entire Eskom board to resign.
Police are monitoring the situation in Kagiso on the West Rand after a service delivery protest broke out. Protesters barricaded the road with burning tyres and rocks allegedly over power outages.
The community of Ntshawini (Stanger) blocked the road again using stones and burning tyres in the area.

Tugela Ferry residents protesting over water shortages left a trail of destruction after embarking on a violent demonstration marked by the blockage of roads, stoning of vehicles and the looting of shops. Shots were fired at police officers who had been attempting to stop the crowd.
Stutterheim came to a standstill as protesters closed parts of the road leading to the town, demanding houses long promised to them. The protesters blockaded the road with burning tyres.

The service delivery protest continued in Kagiso, causing major traffic delays on the R41 next to Leratong; Impala Road, Randfontein Road, Quellerie Street, and other roads as police monitored the streets.
Parents marched to the provincial education department's offices in Pholokwane to demand more classrooms at the Mahwetse High School in Masemola village, south of Polokwane

About 30 people were arrested after they blocked Grayston Drive in Sandton during a protest. Police reportedly fired rubber bullets and stun grenades at employees of telecommunications equipment company Huawei
Residents of the informal settlement in Princess burnt two trucks and torched a business establishment in protest over housing.
Supporters of the residents of Bromwell Street and Reclaim the City Activists protested outside the Western Cape High Court.

In the Mutale policing area outside Thohoyandou, angry communities in Tshibvumo, Tshamulingwi, members of the community allegedly attempted to burn her house, but due to the swift reaction by the police public order unit they were unsuccessful.

Police dispersed a group of protesters in Diepkloof Soweto who were blocking the entrance to the Chris Hani Baragwanath Hospital over housing. Protesting residents have blocked the Patrick and Chris Hani Roads with rocks and burning tyres. They later regrouped on Immink road.
A group of community members who stoned a 24-year old man to death in Mankweng outside Polokwane.
A boy was shot and killed during a protest in Standerton, Mpumalanga. Police reportedly fired rubber bullets and live rounds at protesters.
The community of Vaalwater Two village went on the rampage and burnt two thatched houses and a six-roomed house belonging to an old man.
In the Mutale policing area outside Thohoyandou, angry communities torched a house and a supermarket.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Health Workers (South Africa); Teachers (South Africa)
column17: Three protesters have been arrested following a brief clash with police earlier at the University of Pretoria (UP) where teargas was deployed and Nehawu members retaliated by throwing stones and bricks.

Hundreds of mourners gathered inside and outside a small hall in Soweto , while a few men took turns to stand around Mokoena's white casket carrying placards with messages of no violence against women.
At Hlogotlou members of the community hunted down and killed a man who allegedly abused his girlfriend, after he allegedly doused her in petrol and set her alight.

Hundreds of people gathered at a protest in Pretoria over the rising tide of violence against women. At the same time, a small group of student protesters tried to disrupt the University of Pretoria (UP) open day.
A group of East London women gathered outside the Fleet police station to protest against gender-based violence.
A second bus was set alight in dyuring protest in Makhaya, Khayelithsa.

Informal settlement residents took to the streets of Sydenham in an attempt to oust a man who also lives in the area and is accused of shooting several people. They blockaded the road with burning tyres and trees. They also stoned the police vehicles.
A foster care home has been vandalised and its guard room and factory burnt during a protest in Cottonlands in Verulam

On 22 May 2017, residents of the Makause informal settlement took to the streets in Germiston (Gauteng) in a demonstration against the lack of development in the area. The demonstrations lasted for two days, and several foreign national shops were looted. [size=no report]
A man was left seriously injured after he was assaulted members of the community and thrown into a dumping site along Olivehout Road in Olievenhoutbosch (Centurion).
African National Congress councillor Mduduzi Shibase was gunned down by unknown assailants at his homestead at his homestead in Gugwini, Ward 14.
Northlink College says a planned march by some of the students concluded in a peaceful manner.

On 23 May 2017, residents of the Makause informal settlement took to the streets in Germiston (Gauteng) in a demonstration against the lack of development in the area. The demonstrations lasted for two days, which started on 22 May 2018, and several foreign national shops were looted. [size=no report]
Protesters closed off Clare Road by barricading it with tyres, rocks and debris which they then set alight in Clare Estate. A nearby soup kitchen was vandalised and had to close.
A bus was set alight in Makhaya, Khayelithsa as protesters burnt tyres they used as barricades alongside overturned rubbish bins, blocking off several roads.
Commuters torched carriages on a train they were travelling in after it came to a halt because of mechanical problems in Kenville, Durban. They again threw stones and debris at passing vehicles.
Gauteng police used teargas and stun grenades to disperse protesters who were blocking several roads in Diepkloof, Soweto.
DA members and Seed Community representatives were singing and protesting in support of Karabo Mokoena in Johannesburg.
A group of people allegedly stormed the building and set a section of it alight. The mayor of Ditsobotla Local Municipality in Lichtenburg was held hostage by the community.
Workers blockaded Long Market Street in Pietermaritzburg before marching on City Hall.
Protesters from the Princess informal settlement in Roodepoort, Johannesburg petrol bombed a metro bus, injuring four people
Protesters gathered outside the Gugulethu Community Health Centre at KTC Day Hospital in response to the murder of a health worker. The event was organised by the Treatment Action Campaign (TAC).

Classes at the main campus of the Tshwane University of Technology (TUT) were cancelled after classes were suspended following protest action by staff who are part of the #OutsourcingMustFall movement.
Students from a number of universities in Gauteng protested against gender-based violence and a culture that tolerates rape by stopping traffic on Nelson Mandela Bridge in Johannesburg.

Streets in Bekkersdal were barricaded with rocks and burning tyres as residents stopped to search vehicles in what they claimed were attempts to ensure that no children were being kept hidden in them.
Protesters blocked roads in gang hotspot Elsies River ahead of an expected visit from Police Minister Fikile Mbalula.
Classes at Walter Sisulu University (WSU) in East London came to a halt after students embarked on a protest about the institution's city residences.

About a hundred members of civil society organisations and social grant recipients gathered outside the gates of Parliament to demand an end to illegal deductions, outsourcing and an increase to the amount of grant money paid out. Protesters sang struggle songs.

Classes at the main campus of the Tshwane University of Technology (TUT) were suspended for a second day as protest action by security guards, who are part of the #Outsourcingmustfall movement, continued.

A road in Belhar was closed in both directions between De La Rey and Borchards Quarry Road due to protest action in Cape Town. Protesters blocked the road wth burning tyres and were only dispersed after police fired at them with rubber bullets.
In protests, parents locked the gates and prevented staff and pupils at a school in Lavender Hill.
At least 500 students, mostly women, marched at Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University in Port Elizabeth to raise awareness about gender violence.
Police and Durban Metro Police were forced to use stun grenades to disperse protesting tow truck operators who blockaded the N2 Freeway to Umhlanga.
Men took to the streets of Bloemfontein to march in protest of atrocities.
Hundreds of Durban University of Technology (DUT) students marched against violence and abuse on women.
A group of DA supporters and a group of Zambian nationals supporting Lungu held a small protest outside the embassy of Zambia in Pretoria.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Nehawu members had been involved in a violent incident and malicious damage to property at the University of Pretoria's Onderstepoort campus in Pretoria.
Concerned citizens gathered outside the University of Johannesburg Soweto campus to stand up against gender-based violence in South Africa.
About 50 people took to the streets of Cape Town in a march calling for an end to women and child abuse.
protesters took to the streets, blocking Chris Hani Road and others, while calling on human settlements MEC Paul Mashatile to address them.
A fatal shooting of one of the Khayelitsha backyarders leaders took place in Khayelitsha.
Parliament's staff used their lunch break to protest a potential 0% increases or retrenchments on the parliamentary precinct.

column9: ABMSM: Abahlali Basemjondolo Shack Dwellers Movement
column17: Abahlali baseMjondolo said the Foreman Road Abahlali branch had organised a road blockade protest after their demands were not dealt with. Police started shooting tear gas at the protesters and a baby was killed.

On 29 May 2017, foreign-owned shops were looted in a violent demonstration that erupted in KwaMashu, Durban. Police came under fire when they responded to the chaos. Demonstrators stoned journalists' cars as they entered the township. [size=no report]
Violent student protest took place in the East London CBD as Walter Sisulu University (WSU) students reportedly stoned cars, barricaded roads and ignited fires.
Thousands of school pupils took to the streets of KwaMashu protesting against the abduction of children and women abuse.
The N2 highway near the R102 in Macassar, Cape Town was closed due to protest action. Protesters barricaded the road with burning tyres.
Friends and family of a murdered student held a silent protest outside a court in Stellenbosch.
Durban protesters marched on Sydenham Police Station after claiming a two-week-old baby had died as a result of tear gas inhalation during service delivery protests.

On 29 May 2017, several shops and vehicles (some owned by Somali asylum seekers) were looted and destroyed during marches in Ntuzuma and Richmond Farm, Ntuzuma (KwaZulu-Natal), after social media reports began circulating about children being kidnapped, mentioning the involvement of foreign nationals. During the events, a child was shot and injured by a private security officer. [size=no report]

A violent protest erupted Breidbach after angry residents clashed with police and Buffalo City Metro law enforcement officers during a protest. Protesters burnt tyres, blocked the road and threw stones at police and police firing rubber bullets, stun grenades and teargas. Vehicles were pelted with stones.
University of KwaZulu-Natal students pelted police with rocks, stoned passing cars and threw objects off a high rise building after the bus that apparently picks them up for class did not arrive
Residents and land activists blocked the entrance into the the small hamlet of Suurbraak, burning tyres and other objects along its Main Road.
Angry residents protested outside a courthouse after a murder accused was put on trial at the Klerksdorp Magistrate's Court.

Primary schools were closed by the Western Cape Education Department (WCED) in Lavender Hill followed the first day of protests by teachers in the area to force authorities to come up with a plan to protect pupils.
Scores of DA supporters picketed outside the SAPS Maupa Naga premises in Arcadia, Pretoria demanding tougher intervention on the rape of women and children.
600 King Hintsa Willowvale campus (Butterworth) students marched to hand over a memorandum, while Teko campus students near Centane also met with management without reaching a solution.
There were small crowds protesting in the Chesterville, near Westville.

Schoolchildren took to the streets of KwaMashu following violent riots and the looting of foreign national-owned shops in the north Durban township. The nature of the schoolchildren's protests is unknown.
Hundreds of pupils from Roman Catholic Junior protested outside the Port St John's Magistrate's Court.
A demonstration was held outside his the SACP deputy's home by ANC's liberation army Umkhonto We Sizwe.
Looting continued unabated in parts of KwaMashu, north of Durban where mobs fought running battles with thinly stretched police after a break-out of violence linked to xenophobia.

Primary schools were closed by the Western Cape Education Department (WCED) in Lavender Hill followed a second day of protests by teachers in the area to force authorities to come up with a plan to protect pupils.
SJC staged a protest inside the council chambers at the City of Cape Town showing their rejection of the municipal budget.
Protests in Breidbach continued, closing at least two routes to East London. Protesters burnt tyres, trees and poles demanding that a new project steering committee be appointed.
In Chesterville, burning tyres were dragged into the busy intersection of Booth and Spine Roads. Police fired stun grenades and rubber bullets to disperse crowds so they could clear the road.
Minibus taxi operators in Durban and surrounding areas have blocked the roads in protest in the Durban CBD.
There were reports of traffic being obstructed in some parts of East London as the students protested and burned trash.
Minibus taxi operators in Durban have blocked roads in protest ahead of their protest to Toyota in Prospection, Isipingo
Minibus taxi operators in Durban and surrounding areas have blocked roads in protest in Umlazi.
The Yende family and community members went to a electricity substation to picket ""peacefully"" to get Eskom to tell them what exactly happened to the slain employee Thembisile Yende.
There were reports of traffic being obstructed in some parts of East London as the students protested and burned trash.
A municipal building and library were torched in Schweizer-Reneke, North West when residents protested the replacement of the acting municipal manager.

Residents in Sobantu, Pietermaritzburg, took to the streets last week to protest against 40% deductions on prepaid electricity. Roads were barricaded with burning tyres and tree branches. Police used stun grenades and rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.
About 3500 residents from Schaumberg informal settlement near Hekpoort in the North West marched to demand services especially water, but also sanitation and refuse removal.
Protesters demanding land closed off part of Vusi Mzimele (Bellair) Road in Cato Manor by barricading it with burning tyres, broken bottles and uprooted trees.
After a series of evictions, residents staged a protest. Rubber bullets were fired at them. A man whose car was stoned crashed into another vehicle.
Mdantsane residents in East London protested and blocked a road after discovering the bodies of two women in the area.
A group of Port Elizabeth EFF members staged an unusual protest at a Shoprite store.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: Over 200 people led by the Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU) marched in Cape Town on Sunday to demand an end to violence against women and children
Around 100 protesters blockaded the M35 road, burning tyres and throwing stones at passing vehicles.
Passing vehicles were being pelted with rocks and a truck was torched in Roodepoort as protests took place.
A man believed to be the murderer and rapist responsible for two bodies found is fighting for his life after he was stoned and beaten by angry NU2 residents in Mdantsane.
Parents staged a picket after a teacher was fired plagiarism claim in Welkom.
Patensie residents marched to the town's magistrate's court where two murder suspects were appearing for bail hearings in two separate incidents.

column7: ANC: African National Congress; DA: Democratic Alliance
column17: Outside the Springs Magistrate's Court, protests were held by angry residents, ANC and DA supporters.
About 40 police call centre agents demonstrated outside the Western Cape Police offices in Alfred Street, Cape Town, demanding a salary increase and better working conditions.
At least five vehicles were damaged two of them petrol-bombed when land occupiers in Motherwell, Port Elizabeth, were served a High Court order to vacate the land in 48 hours.

column7: SAFTU: South African Federation of Trade Unions
column17: A group of 10111 emergency call centre workers brought traffic to a standstill in Pretoria central as they demanded better salaries and improved working conditions. The South African Federation of Trade Unions, led by general-secretary Zwelinzima Vavi, also joined the protest.
Gugulethu residents staged a protest with civil society following the rise in violence against women and children. The Non-profit organisation (NPO) Ilitha Labantu led the protest.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Women (South Africa)
column17: Members of the National Health Education and Allied Workers Union, and some Pietermaritzburg Girls' High School alumni, picketed outside the school after the suspension of a Grade 11 pupil over a racist rant.
A man was assaulted in an alleged mob violence incident in Valhalla Park.
Dozens of parents demonstrated outside Khozi Primary School in Joe Slovo Park near Milnerton after the Western Cape Education Department (WCED) executed an interdict to remove the makeshift school.

Dismissed Transnet Rehabilitation, Maintenance and Emergency (RME) and Transnet National Ports Authority employees have embarked on a protest action against the company in Durban demanding reinstatement and payment for the time that they had been out of their jobs.
Police had to hold an angry crowd of 300 residents at bay on the street outside a court in Mdanstane as the two suspects made their first court appearance.
Members of Equal Education (EE) held a picket outside the Eastern Cape legislature in Bhisho ""to draw the attention"" of government to the bad state of the schools in the province.
These were some of the jibes by DA supporters on Emfuleni mayor Simon Mofokeng during their protest at municipal offices.
Two people were seriously injured and 27 others escaped fairly unscathed after protesters lobbed stones and petrol bombs at a passing Algoa bus in Motherwell.
Men were urged at a protest march in Rustenburg to protect women and children.
A suspected kidnapper is in hospital after a group attacked him after he allegedly tried to kidnap a child at Seshego Zone 1 on Sunday.

Commuters at Cape Town's central train station toyi-toyed, destroyed two cell phone shops, smashed glass, stoned a bus and burnt trains in frustration on Monday evening. In the afternoon trains across the city stopped running.

Protesters blocked all entrances and exits out of Davidsonville, Roodepoort using burning tyres and rocks. Police fired tear gas and rubber bullets in an attempt to push protesters back into the township.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: The City of Tshwane does not have any relationship or employment contract with South African Municipal Workers' Union (Samwu) workers who staged a protest outside Tshwane House.

After begging for water for three years, residents of New Forest, outside Bushbuckridge, staged a protest. The Mhala police arrived at the protest, where some residents were burning tyres, and fired rubber bullets.

On 13 June 2017, protesting bakkie owners and parents have called on the government to provide alternative solutions to the bakkie transport system as they marched on City Hall in Port Elizabeth. [size=no report].
On 13 June 2017, at City Hall, Port Elizabeth, dozens of members of Nelson Mandela Bay Transport Services (NMBTS) staged a protest. [size=12].
Activists protested against the South African National AIDS Council (SANAC) at the opening of the South African AIDS Conference in Durban.
Outside the Western Cape High Court, supporters from different organisations held up posters and sang struggle songs in support of the group
Minibus taxis which used their taxis to set up road blocks near Muizenberg. They were said to be angry about unlicensed vehicles intruding on their route.
A small group of African National Congress caucus members and supporters picketed outside the Western Cape legislature to call for the removal of Helen Zille as premier.
At least 30 arrests were made as taxi operators shut down Prince George Drive (near Muizenberg) using their taxis as roadblocks for the second day to protest against illegal operators on their route.
Another train carriage has been gutted in Cape Town (Koeburg) in an arson attack near Stellenbosch.
Protesting taxi drivers went on a rampage, using their vehicles to block major highways. They also hijacked numerous heavy trucks, using them to block the roads.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Traffic in the Mthatha CBD came to a standstill as hundreds of civil servants in red T-shirts (NEHAWU) marched to the regional offices of the department of roads and public works.

Sex worker activists demonstrated during Deputy President Cyril Ramaphosa's speech at the South African National AIDS Conference in Durban. Ramaphosa is chairperson of South African National AIDS Council (SANAC).
During Youth Day, a group of protesters chanted ""Zuma must fall"" as Zuma was starting his speech in Ventersdorp.
Backyarders marched to Lingelethu police station (Khayelitsha) to demand the arrested land occupiers be released and for the police to investigate the murder of Mthunzi 'Ras' Zuma
Four trucks were set alight when angry residents in Motherwell protested against being forcefully removed by the municipality.

At least four houses were torched and shops were looted at Ga-Mothapo village east of Polokwane after a man was stabbed to death at a local tavern. Some of the some residents started throwing stones at the officers.
A protest began in Imbali in Piteremaritzburg, with protesters gathering all kinds of material for the blockade. Police fired teargas and rubber bullets as they attempted disband the protesters,.
The City of Ekurhuleni has condemned the torching of a customer care centre in Winnie Mandela Park, Tembisa.
150 unemployed nurses have been sleeping outside the Eastern Cape health department offices (Bhisho) since Monday in protest.
A team made up of UWC students acting under the name of the #FeesMustFall (FMF) movement disrupted exams in both the morning and afternoon sessions in protest.
Protest action began when a truck carrying local produce was stoned in Doringkop (near Stanger)
Another train has been torched in Cape Town (Nyanga Junction) due to apparent commuter frustration.
A group of protesters held up a truck and set it alight during a protest in Doringkop near KwaDukuza, north of Durban.

column7: VAC: Voice of Africans for Change
column17: A march was organised by Voice of Africans for Change (VAC) to commemorate World Refugee Day. About 60 people marched from Keizersgracht Street to Plein Street to deliver a memorandum of demands.
A community attacked and beat up 2 young men in Salvokop in Pretoria.
There had been disruptions at the Wells Estate community hall and voting had stopped as angry residents protested.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: A battle has erupted in Bloemfontein after more than 1 000 members of the South African Municipal Workers Union allegedly set fire to the city hall. Police used stun grenades, rubber bullets and water to disperse them.
Two groups of residents clashed over electricity and water. Both sides blamed each other for initiating the fight.
Democratic Alliance ward councillor Xolile Gwangxu was shot dead in Philippi East after wrapping up a meeting
An Uber vehicle was set alight and two drivers were attacked on the streets of Sunnyside in Pretoria.
In a third day of protest action, a timber truck has been set alight during a protest at Doringkop.
Residents protested in Zwide and shut the voting station for a few hours.
The situation is tense in __Mahube Valley (Mamelodi)_ after residents took to the streets again. The residents blockaded streets, demanding an end to illegal water and electricity connections.
Clashes outside the SA Nursing Council (SANC) in Pretoria took place protesting nurses and security guards.
Angry relatives, friends and Lavender Hill residents protested outside Wynberg Magistrate's Court to oppose the release of 13-year-old Rene Tracy Roman's alleged killer on bail.
Mineral Resources Minister Mosebenzi Zwane had to be whisked away from an angry crowd closing in on him at a community meeting in Middelburg, Mpumalanga.
The shack of a 28-year-old security guard was burnt down by angry residents of Town Two, Khayelitsha, following allegations of child rape.
NUMYS (National Union of Mineworkers Youth Structure ) supporters marched through the streets of Rustenburg to raise issues affecting workers in the mines.

Angry residents took to the streets after a speeding taxi hit and killed a man while he was crossing Mew Way at Ndlovini informal settlement in Khayelitsha. They made own speed hump and blocking the street with a shipping container.
More than 200 residents from Suurbraak and neighbouring towns joined land activists during a service delivery protest to the Swellendam Municipality at the weekend.

A small but vocal group of Congolese immigrants protested outside the Sefako Makgatho presidential guesthouse in Pretoria, as President Jacob Zuma hosted the president of the Democratic Republic of Congo, Joseph Kabila
A MyCiTi bus was torched followed by two buildings in the Milnerton area.
Protesters barricaded roads with burning tyres and rocks in Actonville near Benoni. Police fired rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.

column7: ABMSM: Abahlali Basemjondolo Shack Dwellers Movement
column17: The Abahlali baseMjondolo movement led thousands of shack dwellers through the streets of Durban to the City Hall, with the hope of handing over their memorandum to the mayor
A hall in the Joe Slovo area in Milnerton was set alight during protests, causing extensive damage to it following long-awaited repairs to the facility.

Vrygrond exploded with violent protests as residents took to the streets to vent their anger at the removal of taxis by traffic cops, and the issue of availability of land. Large groups of rioters gathered near the taxi rank where they burned tyres and other flammable items.
At least two people were killed during an altercation between Prasa security guards and angry community members when the protest moved to the Nancefield station.

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Private Security Forces (South Africa)
column17: Hundreds of security guards, led by the Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF), contracted by the City of Tshwane demanding permanent employment and outstanding wages marched to the newly built Tshwane House
Angry protesters over service delivery in Soweto set alight the municipal offices in Dobsonville.
Protests took place at Clare Estate as angry residents took to the streets. Litter and tyres were burnt.
A group of Black First Land First (BLF) supporters picketed outside the Gandhi Square Absa branch in the Johannesburg CBD.

Protesting Nancefield community members in Soweto have again taken to the streets demanding housing and to protest earlier deaths in altercation with Prasa guards. The local Metrorail station was suspended as a result.

Miners from North West province marched on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange (JSE) to demand an end to retrenchments and a fairer share of the economic wealth being extracted by the mining companies operating in the area
On 27 June 2017, miners protested against mining in Mabola outside the Pretoria High Court. An agreement was found with authorities later. [size=no report].

On 27 June 2017, members of the South African African Police Service removed scores of Zimbabwean nationals who were protesting at the embassy in Pretoria, demanding the diaspora vote. [size=no report].
Two people were injured when protestors threw a petrol bomb into the truck they were travelling in at uMgeni Road, just after the N2 interchange (Clare Estate).
Members of Black First Land First staged a protest outside the home of Peter Bruce, the editor at large of the Tiso Blackstar Group in Parkview, Johannesburg.
ANC ward councillor Sfiso Mkhize was gunned down in a hail of bullets in Richmond.
Refugees protest outside the Cape Town offices of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees demanding that three employees be fired.
Shebeen owners picketed outside Parliament (Cape Town) to express their concerns about a new law seeking to clamp down on illegal liquor outlets and report non-compliance to the police.
Residents of Acornhoek who are frustrated with the number of apparent ritual killings for muti purposes have marched to the police station to demand that more should be done to address these crimes.

All roads in and out of Hout Bay were closed due to protest by disgruntled residents in the informal settlement of Imizamo Yethu (Hout Bay). The result was road closures as tyres and rubbish bins were set alight. Police fired teargas and stun grenades to disperse the determined crowd.

Protests entered their second day in Hout Bay as residents were angry over a lack of housing after a fire. A set of traffic lights were damaged as a result of the protest action. Some of the poles and road signs were set alight and vandalised.
Blind workers protested in Ga-Rankuwa demanding the reopening of a workshop where they have plied their trade for decades.

Vehicles have been overturned, windows smashed and temporary food trucks destroyed as Hout Bay protests. Stun grenades were used to disperse an estimated 100 protesters in the area. One demonstrator killed.
In Meyerton, south of Joburg, residents of Sicelo Shiceka informal settlement embarked on first day of protests.

More than a dozen protesters, most of them women, gathered outside the Hanover Park Community Centre. They held signs reading ""Councillor van der Rheede must step down"" and chanted ""Give us our office back"".
Several roads in Hout Bay remained closed as protest action in the area enters its fourth day
Tension boiled over in Meyerton, south of Joburg as residents of Sicelo Shiceka informal settlement embarked on a second day of protests.

column8: Police Forces of South Africa (1994-) Prison Guards
column17: The Department of Correctional Services (DCS) says a Kgosi Mampuru II official and a prisoner were injured after violence erupted at the correctional facility.
Security guards contracted to the City of Tshwane took another turn yesterday when they marched to the EFF offices in Pretorius Street, accusing the party leaders of being sell-outs.
Police fired rubber bullets to disperse protesters who blocked several roads with burning tyres and rocks in Soweto.

Tension boiled over in Meyerton, south of Joburg, yesterday as residents of Sicelo Shiceka informal settlement embarked on their third consecutive day of protests. Protesters threw stones at motorists. Police used stun grenades to disperse the crowd.
Two Uber vehicles were set alight in Sunnyside, while metered taxi operators claimed four of their cars were damaged.
PAC members protested peacefully outside the Soshanguve Magistrate's Court demanding that charges against Nonhlanhla Mbokoto be dropped unconditionally.
A crowd of South African Communist Party supporters protested outside Parliament.

About 150 people blocked a road in Hangberg, Hout Bay with a burning barricade over a dagga arrest. Protesters stoned passing cars near a barricade of burning tyres and rocks at the intersection of Harbour and Atlantic Skipper roads.
TRANSNET said it had experienced interruptions to its operations on the Richards Bay coal line as a result of violent community protests in certain areas of northern KwaZulu-Natal.
Ocean View community members protested outside the Simon's Town Magistrate Court, carrying placards and hurling abuse at the accused.

column7: ABMSM: Abahlali Basemjondolo Shack Dwellers Movement
column17: Two protesters have been arrested while 15 others were injured in a violent protest by shack dwellers and Abahlali Basemjondolo in George Hill, Sydenham, Durban. Police assaulted protesters with their batons and fired shots at others using shotguns while protesters burnt tyres.

Traffic in the Joburg CBD came to a standstill midday as Soweto taxi drivers marched to the Office of the Premier, parking their taxis in the streets and demanding to be allowed to operate on their routes again.
About 400 people and 30 civil rights organisations from around the Western Cape's rural Langeberg region took to the streets to march against the spike in drug abuse in their areas.
Residents of Ocean View in Cape Town formed a human chain to show unity in the fight against crime in the area.
Protests and the burning of tyres flared up briefly on the M19 near Reservoir Hills.
Protests and the burning of tyres flared up briefly on the Mangosuthu Highway in Umlazi.
Protests and the burning of tyres flared up briefly near near Chesterville.
A small group of protesters set alight a municipal bus in Mayville, Durban.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: Operations at the Transnet offices in Richards Bay are expected to come to a standstill as the National Union of Metalworkers of SA (Numsa) embarked on a protest march.
Security guards went on the rampage and police fired rubber bullets in Princess Park in Pretoria. Guards turned away motorists and blocked the road with chairs, sticks and anything they could find.

The entrance to the Pretoria Zoo was blocked by striking National Zoological Gardens (NZG) workers with the Trade Union Congress after their demand to be paid overtime for working weekends deadlocked last week, resulting in National Trade Union Congress (NTUC) giving the zoo management with a strike notice.
A group of Diepsloot residents have barricaded roads with burning tyres and are throwing rocks at passing cars.
Alexandra residents have blockaded parts of the N3 north highway and London road with burning tyres and rocks.
Two buses were torched and a third damaged in Atteridgeville, Tshwane during protests about housing which saw more that 150 residents take to the streets.
Equal Education members staged a protest outside the department's offices in Pietermaritzburg.
Over a dozen Woodstock residents and their supporters held up posters and banners on Father Basil van Rensburg Bridge during peak hour traffic in Woodstock.
DA Members of Parliament led picketers outside the National Prosecuting Authority (NPA) head offices in Silverton, Pretoria.
A protester from GaMampa village, was killed after police clashed with residents who were protesting over mining issues in Sefateng.

Community members from Steelpoort, Limpopo, travelled over three hours to Pretoria to plead with the Department of Mineral Resources (DMR) to intervene with mines failing to provide them with employment opportunities.
Equal Education members staged a protest outside the department's offices in Durban.

About 1 000 Zone 8 residents (Goerge) blockaded roads and burnt tyres, obstructing the main road and the N2 to Mossel Bay. Public Order Police fired several stun grenades in a bid to disperse the protesters.

Residents of Nellmapius in Mamelodi East took to the streets in protest, after being without electricity for 24 hours. Protesters blocked various parts of the road with stones and rubbish, which they set alight.

A man was shot and injured during a protest in Nkobongo area near Umhlali. The 30-year-old man was shot by an person in a group of about 50 residents who blockaded the road with burning tyres and rubble.
An all-men march brought Rustenburg to a standstill to kick start the Mandela Day activities.

In Lenasia South' another protest action is under way' affecting motorists travelling from Ennerdale and Orange Farm. The Golden Highway is affected as community members have covered the road with rocks and tyres.

Close to a thousand protesting residents of Gomora informal settlement in Pretoria West have battled with police. Police fired hails of rubber bullets, dozens of tear gas canisters, and stun grenades while protesters returned fire with slingshots and threw stones at police.
A truck has been set alight and Van Der Hof Steet is closed in Pretoria West after angry community members took to the streets.
Three African National Council (ANC) councillors from uMzimkhulu were shot, while they were at a local shop together. One of the victims eventually succumbed to his wounds on 4th September 2017.
Protesters took to the streets of Johannesburg against women and child abuse
Lawyers under the leadership of the Black Lawyers Association marched to the Union Building to demand equality
Machinery worth millions of rands, owned by a contractor appointed to install underground water and sewerage pipes for residents of a new residential suburb in Mthatha, were torched by an angry mob.
In two days of violent protests, six trucks and two buses were set alight during protest action in Bapong.
In Siqalo informal settlement near Mitchells Plain two people who were stoned to death for allegedly stealing a cellphone.
Disgruntled security guards gathered at Church Square in Pretoria before deciding to march to the office of the mayor, located at Tshwane House.

column9: ANC: African National Congress; Women (South Africa)
column17: The council speaker (ANC controlled) of the Raymond Mhlaba Local Municipality in Fort Beaufort, Eastern Cape, has been shot dead, just weeks after her office received an ominous death threat.

Hundreds of security guards with the #OutsourcingMustFall movement marched to Tshwane House in Pretoria CBD, demanding that City of Tshwane Mayor Solly Msimanga permanently employ 3 000 security guards and end outsourcing.
In two days of violent protests, six trucks and two buses were set alight during protest action in Bapong.
On 18 July 2017, a Somali national was killed by unidentified individuals near Johannesburg (Gauteng), in an apparent xenophobic attack.
On 18 July 2017, a Somali national was killed by unidentified individuals in a city on the border between South Africa and Mozambique (Sabie chosen as location), in an apparent xenophobic attack.

Hundreds of people, led by the group of Elders, had gathered in the Cape Town CBD for a symbolic march. Meanwhile, a group of supporters of Recaim the City carrying placards and standing outside the fourth annual Affordable Housing Africa Conference held at a hotel in Cape Town's CBD.

About 45 call agents from the 10111 South African Police Service (SAPS) call-center with the support of the South African Policing Union downed phones and left their offices in Maitland. They protested outside on Jan Smuts Drive. Passing motorists hooted in support.

A protest took place in Nkandla informal settlement in Polokwane. Protesters blockaded the road, burnt tyres and treesand flung rubble into the streets. Police were firing rubber bullets into group of residents.
DA members marched to the Treasury head office in Pretoria against state capture by the Gupta Dynasty.

Protesters in Imizamo Yethu, Hout Bay, burnt down an ANC councillor's house during ongoing protest action in the area. Protesters also threw petrol bombs and stones at officers when authorities tried to clear 52 illegally constructed structures.
Protestors burning tyres and blocking roads in two separate incidents in Langa, Cape Town
Burning tyres and blocked roads greeted authorities as a service delivery protest broke out in Mamelodi East, north-east of Pretoria.
In Ravensmead, taxi drivers protested on the corner of Connaught and Owen roads.
In Hout Bay, protesters pelted police members and Nyalas with stones and objects in ongoing violent protest.

One man was shot dead in unknown circumstances, while an ANC office and the houses of community leaders were set alight during a volatile night in Mandela Park and Imizamo Yethu informal settlement in Hout Bay. There were no reports of clashes with police.

Taxi drivers operating the Solomon Mahlangu Drive in Mamelodi East, Pretoria assumed the role of police yesterday and stopped protesting residents from barricading the roads.Two Toyota Quantums packed with taxi drivers confronted protesters who had blocked the busy road since the morning for a service delivery protest. The protesters had placed stones, bricks and burning tyres across the road.
Gender activists in Daveyton on the East Rand took to the streets to voice their frustrations over local police. The police apparently failed to rearrest a well-known businessman for rape.
Residents of Bramley, northern Johannesburg, took to the streets yesterday demanding shacks erected close to their homes be removed
Klipspruit-Wes Secondary School pupils were forced to miss the first day of the third term when angry parents barred them from class in a protest against the appointment of a black principal.
In Lombardy East, residents embarked on protest action. Residents have barricaded roads with burning tyres and are throwing rocks at oncoming traffic in the area.
The Hadernburg road outside Maluti was closed with burning tyres, rocks and a dead horse by people demanding better roads.
Protesters have shut down the R74 in Muden, Mooi River. Protesters had blockaded the road with stones and rubble.
A group of Steenvilla residents took to the streets and burnt mattresses, tyres and wheelie bins. Police fired rubber bullets and used stun-grenades to disperse the group of about 200 residents.
At least 600 people were bussed in from Vuwani to Thohoyandou as residents embarked on a peaceful protest.
The communities of Factreton and Kensington took to the streets to demonstrate how fed up they are with gang violence and frustrated by the lack of adequate policing in the area.
Buildings and cars where set alight and damaged on the Bellville campus of the Cape Peninsula University of Technology in protest action by students.

column7: DA: Democratic Alliance; IFP: Inkatha Freedom Party
column17: Opposition party councillors ( DA and IFP) gathered at Durban's city hall to call for the firing of eThekwini's African National Congress (ANC) mayor, Zandile Gumede, accusing her of bringing the city to the brink of collapse.
Cape Flats moms march to Parliament over children killed in gang violence.

The Durban University of Technology's Steve Biko campus erupted in chaos after a student protest disrupted classes. The students forced people out of the building, let off fire extinguishers, turned bins over, threw a student's phone by the window and threatened people.
In another round of violence in Glebelands hostel, two people were killed.

In reaction to the increase in security at the al-Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem, local Muslims joined the Muslim Judicial Council (MJC) and the Al Quds Foundation on a march to Parliament. They are demanding peace for the people of Palestine.

On Thursday evening, BLF (Black First Land First) supporters disrupted a debate about state capture and the Gupta emails, hosted by the amaBhungane Centre for Investigative Journalism. A person attending the event was reportedly punched during the altercation.

Residents of the New Horizon development near Pelican Park clashed with their neighbours from Phumlani Village informal settlement during a violent protest which saw a petrol station torched yesterday. Hundreds of residents from Phumelela Village, Jim se Bos and Riemvasmaak informal settlements near Strandfontein brought the area to a standstill when they barricaded both ends of Old Strandfontein Road with burning tyres and stones. They were protesting for housing and other basic services. Cars were also attacked. Two people were arrested. The two groups threw rocks at each other and brandished weapons before police intervened.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Hundreds of Tshwane employees, mainly metro police officers affiliated to the SA Municipal Workers Union (Samwu), took to the city streets yesterday, protesting against the implementation of ""unilateral decisions"" without consultation.
A protest was held outside the Zimbabwean consulate in Cape Town by Zimbabweans demanding the right to vote in their country's upcoming presidential elections
Community members kidnapped and killed two suspected criminals and attempted to kill two others in Polokwane.
A suspected armed robber has been killed by community members and three others have been arrested following an armed robbery at a liquor outlet in Apel, Limpopo.
Around 30 July 2017 (as reported), three Somali nationals were killed in Lembobo area in Cape Town (Western Cape) and several shops were set on fire in apparently targeted attacks.

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students
column17: About 100 Congress of South African Students' (Cosas) members gathered at Burgers Park to make their way to the South African Reserve Bank (SARB) in Pretoria. At the same time, a crowd has gathered outside the Gauteng High Court, Pretoria to protest against the legalisation of dagga.

Parents and learners of Uviwe Senior Secondary in Scenery Park township in the Eastern Cape (East London) shut the school down. This came after their requests for scholar transport to the Department of Education went unanswered.
Three men were shot and wounded at Glebelands Hostel in ongoing violence.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: National Education and Health Allied Workers' Union (Nehawu) members marched on the Pietermaritzburg offices of the National Health Laboratory Services (NHLS) as part of the ongoing national strike against the country's main provider of diagnostics to the public health system.
A group of mothers marched to Parliament (Cape Town) to protest against the killing of innocent children.
Hanover Park parents have made a desperate plea for help to keep children at Blomvlei Primary School safe and staged a protest outside the school.
A bus and a five-ton truck were set alight as angry KwaDwesi residents protested against a lack of service delivery.
Several security guards were pushed out of Gauteng hospitals by protesters angry at the extension of irregular security contracts meant to expire in September last year.

Roads were barricaded and women took off their clothes during a protest in Tlhabane near Rustenburg. Security guards fired rubber bullets when the group looped stones over the corrugated roof sheets covering the construction site, while some of the corrugated sheets were removed.

column7: NUM: National Union of Mineworkers; SACCA: South African Cabin Crew Association
column16: International Business Times; Cape Argus; SABC News
column17: The National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa (NUMSA) and the South African Cabin Crew Association (SACCA) protested at the SAA's Johannesburg headquarters. Members of the National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) have marched to the Anglogold Ashanti Headquarters in Johannesburg to demand that the company cancels its plan to retrench 8 500 workers.

Two students were arrested during ongoing protest outside the Nelson R Mandela Medical School. Police reportedly started hitting students and two people were put into a van and taken to the police station. No serious injuries reported
Gunshots were fired and a brick hit a policeman during a service delivery protest because of an electricity outage in parts of Othongati (Tongaat).
Reclaim the City activists gathered outside Western Cape Premier Helen Zille's official residence early following a call to hold authority accountable.
Police were on the scene of a protest in Klipspruit-Wes in Soweto on where a Putco bus was earlier set alight. The road was also blocked by burnt tyres.

Police have confirmed that a 30-year-old woman was shot dead by unknown suspects at the notorious Glebelands Hostel in Umlazi, KwaZulu-Natal. Glebelands Hostel has become known as a centre of political violence headed by local leaders.
Several police cars were damaged when a group of people attacked them during a night vigil for two men killed during a robbery in Inanda.
A group of community members in Thohoyandou went on a rampage and burnt the house of a man accused of robberies. The man died in the fire.

Members of the National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) marched to AngloGold Ashanti's head office in Johannesburg in protest against the mining firm's move to issue a Section 189 process to retrench about 8500 workers.
A man was shot and wounded at Umlazi's Glebelands Hostel, bringing the number of attempted murders at the hostel to four in the last eight days.
Nursing students at University of Fort Hare (UFH) in East London have demonstrated and demanded that the acting head of the department be permanently removed, accusing her of prejudice.
The #UniteBehind coalition took to the streets of Cape Town in a bid to pressurise MPs to oust President Jacob Zuma during a motion of no confidence set to take place.

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; UDM: United Democratic Movement
column17: The United Democratic Movement (UDM) and Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) led an anti-President Jacob Zuma march in Mthatha ahead of the vote of no confidence against the president in parliament this afternoon.

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; DA: Democratic Alliance; COPE: Congress of the People; ACDP: African Christian Democratic Party; ANC: African National Congress
column17: Thousands of protesters marched to Parliament before the vote of no confidence in Jacob Zuma. Several opposition parties came together, calling on parliamentarians to vote Zuma out. The political parties included, the DA, COPE, EFF and the ACDP. ANC members also took to the streets in Cape Town.
Supporters of the Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) marched to the Union Buildings in Pretoria on Tuesday before the vote in Parliament of no confidence in President Jacob Zuma.
Major roads in the Johannesburg area were blocked with burning tyres and rocks on Tuesday morning ahead of the vote of no confidence in President Jacob Zuma in Parliament: Braamfontein.
Major roads in the Johannesburg area were blocked with burning tyres and rocks on Tuesday morning ahead of the vote of no confidence in President Jacob Zuma in Parliament: Hillbrow.

ANC supporters in KwaDukuza region, on the KwaZulu-Natal north coast, came out in large numbers to rally in support of President Jacob Zuma ahead of a secret vote on the motion of no confidence in Parliament.
An ANC member, who was a former councillor and regional executive member of the ANC Youth League, was killed by men in police uniform just outside Scottburgh.
Major roads in the Johannesburg area were blocked with burning tyres and rocks on Tuesday morning ahead of the vote of no confidence in President Jacob Zuma in Parliament: Soweto.
Major roads in the Johannesburg area were blocked with burning tyres and rocks on Tuesday morning ahead of the vote of no confidence in President Jacob Zuma in Parliament: Turffontein
Marchers dressed in black to mourn the loss of their freedom at a march in PE on Women's Day
In Kwadwesi in PE, a municipal truck, a bus and a car were torched by angry residents complaining that they had been neglected by the municipality.
Members of the Democratic Alliance (DA) protested against women abuse at the Diepsloot Police Station, where they handed in a memorandum calling for assistance for survivors of rape and abuse.
Health workers marched in Mthatha to demand protective gear, backpay and job security.
The University of KwaZulu-Natal said one of their buildings came under attack by a petrol bomb on its Westville campus.
Burning of the Jongintaba Senior Secondary School during a scholar transport protest by the local community in Mqhekezweni village outside Mthatha.
The City of Cape Town's decision to remove illegal settlers prompted a protest, in which protesters torched a MyCiti bus and vandalised a MyCiti station in Milnerton.
10111 employees on strike at the call centre in Midrand, in ongoing protest, hurled objects at, and damaged, state vehicles.
A minibus driver in Polokwane was left in a coma after an angry mob assaulted him for allegedly running over a four-year-old girl, killing her.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: Several services at both Ugu and Ray Nkonyeni municipalities have been disrupted after SAMWU workers downed tools and marched in the Port Shepstone CBD.
A protest took place outside Durban's City Hall by hundreds of supporters of the alleged sex pest pastor, Tim Omotoso.
Striking 10111 call centre workers burned tyres and blocked off the entrance to the Durban Central SAPS and the Magistrate's Court as part of their ongoing strike action for improved wages.
A flat was burnt down following eviction orders by Sohco Property Investments at the Steen Villa complex in Steenberg. This after three residents were evicted the day before.
Mothers and recovering drug addicts joined demonstrators outside the Gauteng High Court, Pretoria, to add their voice to calls for cannabis not to be legalised.
Classes at Cape Town campus of the Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT) were suspended after protesting students brought the university to a standstill.
Hundreds of informal miners, known as zama-zamas, marched to the Department of Mineral Resources in Pretoria.
Two trucks and a van were burnt down during a protest in Majakaneng near Brits following allegations that a farmer shot a 24-year-old man for stealing oranges at his farm.
Hundreds of residents from Imizamo Yethu from Madiba Square, the Shooting Range site, Petersen and Dontse'Yakhe marched to the Civic Centre in Cape Town.
Dozens of residents from the Howell Road community in Durban's Sydenham area protested outside the Durban High Court against what they believe are 150 unlawful evictions.
A protest in Ga-Rankuwa north of Pretoria took place where community members have barricaded several roads. There were no reports of violence reported.

Workers of the South African Bank Note Company want their bosses at the South African Reserve Bank to subsidise their medical aid as promised and increase their wages. They marched to the Reserve Bank in Pretoria, taking longer than intended due to a taxi strike in the CBD.
Right2Know KZN held a Marikana commemoration march to the Umlazi police station in Durban.
Break the silence, disrupt rape culture were some of the messages displayed on the placards carried by Durban University of Technology students during their silent protest

Taxi Drivers embarked on an illegal protest action in Tshwane by blocking several roads and railway lines and pelting passing cars with rocks. A young man was severely beaten, allegedly by taxi drivers who went on a rampage in Pretoria CBD during the protest.
Supporters of Right2Know and other organisations protested at Parliament in Cape Town in support of the victims of the Marikana Massacre and their families.
About 300 entrepreneurs from the Sundays River Valley Municipality in the Eastern Cape marched to call for more state contracts for local businesses

column7: SATAWU: South African Transport and Allied Workers Union
