column17: Workers aligned to the South African Transport and Allied Workers' Union marched on the office of the transport minister, demanding intervention into 'rampant abuse of power' by e-toll management.
George Campbell School of Technology pupils in Durban protested outside their school claiming that black pupils are being called monkeys.
At Jijana Grounds in Soweto-on-sea (Zwide) a person was attacked and killed by a group of about 100 people.

column8: Police Forces of South Africa (1994-) Anti-Land Invasion Unit
column17: The city of Durban tried to remove shack dwellers in Cato Manor resulting in violent clashes between residents the the City's land invasion unit.
A man has been injured and two vehicles set alight during protests in Emalahleni in Mpumalanga.

A small group of residents blocked the road leading to the Hout Bay harbour in apparent dissatisfaction over service delivery. Green municipal bins were set alight, while rocks and concrete also lay about the area. Police at one point fired two stun grenades to disperse a small offshoot of protesters who were blocking one side of the road.
A Bonela home was petrol-bombed in ongoing violent protests in Cato Manor.

Members of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) have been protesting outside the Department of International Relations and Cooperation (Dirco) in Pretoria where the SADC summit is being held.
A person was stoned and set alight with flammable substances and tyres in a street in Jijana grounds (Zwide). He died as a result of the attack.

A dispute over housing in Khayelitsha turned violent as people set alight and vandalised a community centre that contains the local ward councillor's office. They also vandalised the councillor's house.
About 500 protesters took to the streets to march to Tshwane House (Pretoria) to hand over a memorandum to executive mayor Solly Msimanga.

Angry residents from Mariannridge took to the streets on to protest over houses promised. Residents burnt tyres, wire, metal and wood and later clashed with police officers who fired rubber bullets and tear gas.
Parents barricaded the school gate at the Braamfischerville Primary School in Soweto as they demanded that the Gauteng Education Department renovate the premises.
Hundreds of residents of the Ikamvelihle settlement (Motherwell) in Nelson Mandela Bay barricaded roads with burning rubble and tyres and demanded to see the Deputy Mayor.
Hundreds of Bramfischerville Primary School (Soweto) parents, including pupils, blocked streets in protest over the school having to use containers as classrooms for the past 17 years.
Another person believed to be a former peace committee member at the infamous Glebelands Hostel was shot and killed in Umlazi.

In Wolseley, a team from the Red Ant Security Relocation & Eviction Services was called in to enforce an eviction order, with assistance from police. In response, a crowd of locals started throwing stones while the Red Ants were demolishing. Police dispersed the crowd with tear gas, stun grenades and rubber bullets.
Thousands of Majakaneng residents south of Brits marched to the Mooinooi police station, to demand the arrest of a farmer who allegedly shot a man for stealing oranges.
An ANC ward councillor in Mpumalanga has allegedly shot a 16-year-old pupil who was part of protesters demanding new toilets be built at a school.
A group of pupils and parents protested at Mpumelelo Primary School in Middelplaas, south of Malalane
Outside the Goodwood Magistrate's Court, a group of men and women kept up a vigil with posters made in memory of a murder child in a form of protest.

Parents with children attending Assegai Primary School in Wentworth, south of Durban shut the school down in protest after they were informed by the Department of Education that Sharon Ndlovu who was recently appointed as principal will begin her duties.
The residents of Cork village near the Kruger National Park took to the streets in protest. The residents torched a school bus blocking the R536 road between Kruger Park and Hazyview.
Accommodation problems plagued the University of Kwa-Zulu Natal Edgewood Campus, with students staging a protest on , blockading roads and burning rubbish.
Herskool Pretoria West campus turned into a hive of activity as pupils protested and demanded to be allowed to wear tight-fitting trousers instead of the grey school uniform cut.
The Deputy Rural Development and Land Reform Minister was briefly held hostage by a group of ANC protesters at the African National Congress regional headquarters in Port Elizabeth.

column7: ANC: African National Congress; DA: Democratic Alliance; EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters
column17: A crowd of people including ANC, DA and EFF members sing and dance together in protest outside the Middelburg Magistrate's Court in Mpumalanga in support of coffin assault victim
Klawer North residents, incensed by the death of a community member, marched to accused murderer's home and set fire to five houses in the same street.
Hundreds of Estcourt residents protested outside a court in Estcourt, opposing bail of alleged cannibals.
Hundreds of a pastor's supporters gathered outside the Port Elizabeth court house to show support.
Protesters in Riverlea set fire to a Rea Vaya Bus station on Commando Road. Protesters had also barricaded Main Reef Road and Commando Road with rocks and burning tyres.
About 50 learners at Thandokhulu High School in Mowbray, Cape Town protested demanding that a teacher they accuse of sexual assault be fired.
Residents in Ventersdorp shut down municipal offices, protesting over electricity billing issues. Local farmers supplied tyres to protesting residents to burn in front of the municipal offices.

Violence broke out in the Kleinmond CBD as scores of residents of the Overhills township took to the streets to protest against a cleaning tender awarded to someone from a neighbouring community. Some shops were stoned as residents barricaded the roads with burning tyres and rubble.

column7: DENOSA: Democratic Nursing Organisation of South Africa; NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; PSA: Public Servants Association; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: A breast and cervical cancer policy launch at Frere Hospital (East London) was marred by a small group of people protesting for more staff. The six protesters said they were representing the Democratic Nursing Organisation of South Africa(Denosa), Nehawu and the Public Servants Association of South Africa (PSA).
Residents protested outside the Butterworth Magistrate's Court demanding an alleged serial rapist be kept in jail.
Police fired rubber bullets, teargas and stun grenades to disperse students who blockaded part of the N2 in front of the Nelson Mandela Drive (Mthatha) site with burning tyres.
Gravel roads between Hardenburg and Matatiele were closed with burning tyres and big rocks by angry Matatiele residents demanding better roads and clean water. Police used teargas to disperse them.

column7: BLF: Black First, Land First; Students (South Africa)
column17: Six members of the Black First Land First Student Movement were arrested after an anti-racism protest at Durban's George Campbell School of Technology soured.

The Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT) closed its Cape Town campus after a student protest, apparently over the availability of student accommodation. Meanwhile, several women demonstrated outside the Western Cape High Court in Cape Town during the hearing on Muslim marriages.
A large crowd have gathered at the University of Cape Town to stand in solidarity and protest with sexual assault victims and rape survivors.
An ANC councillor has been killed after an evening meeting near Camperdown.
People protested outside the Mitchells Plain police station over the case of an alleged rapist.
A herbalist who claimed he could raise the dead was himself beaten to death by a mob at Fama village in Qhumanco near Ngcobo.
On 30 August 2017, a Nigerian national was allegedly tortured and killed by the police in Vryheid (KwaZulu-Natal). The victim and a friend had been arrested for suspected drug possession.
Community members sang and danced outside the Mdantsane Magistrate's Court calling for bail to be denied for a murder-accused.

Students allegedly threw stones during a protest at CPUT Cape Town Campus. A small group of protesting students were attacking private security personnel and protesting students were later dispersed by police using a water cannon.

Seven people were arrested after the service delivery protest turned violent in Merlewood (Port Shepstone). The freeway was reported blocked and vehicles were being stoned. Police are reported to have firef rubber bullets to disperse the protest.
More than 200 women farm workers marched from Keizergracht Street in Cape Town to the provincial legislature and then to the Department of Labour

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: University of the Witwatersrand EFF Student Command (EFFSC) members took their fight for affordable student accommodation to the Gauteng Human Settlements department's offices in Johannesburg and held a protest march.

After a car knocked down and killed a pensioner, Philippi residents have closed a road in protest, forcing motorists to use alternative routes. Residents burnt tyres, and dug trenches on the 400m stretch of road, and set alight at least one car.

column7: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union
column17: AMCU members have disrupted a memorial in protest near Carletonville for the five Harmony Gold miners who died last week.
Police dispersed crowds which gathered to demand the implementation of resolutions announced by President Jacob Zuma in July, after months of protest over a demarcation dispute.

Residents from the Westville area in Kwadwesi blockaded the roads leading to and from Uitenhage on the R75. Tyres were burnt on the roads and residents were stoning vehicles as well. A truck was also set alight in the Westville area
Students continued protest action, which entered its third week, by padlocking the main gate to the FET college Msunduzi.
Two vehicles were pelted with stones during protests in Vuwani.
Members of the Social Justice Coalition protest outside the Western Cape High Court during sentencing proceedings against a man accused of rape in Cape Town.

On 5 September 2017, a Nigerian national was killed by police in Springs (Gauteng). The victim was taken from his shop by 10 police officers, who claimed he had drugs. The man was tortured with a plastic bag around his head at the station.
Three buses were set alight and roads blocked in Ikageng near Rustenburg
On 5 September 2017, a violent mob beat, stabbed and stoned to death two men whom they believed had kidnapped a child in Pinetown.
Angry supporters, who blamed local municipal and ANC leaders for the murder of a politician protested in Umzimkulu.
A handful of residents gathered outside the Wynberg magistrates court in protest as five people appeared in connection with the murder of a child.
Several people were arrested after a violent service delivery protest which saw them blocking the R67 about 28km from Fort Beaufort towards Komani. Protesters attacked a Parmalat truck.
Debris was set alight on Austerville Drive in Wentworth as parents protested over the selection of the Principal of a school.
Three cars were torched in a Johannesburg business district on Thursday in the latest clash between drivers with ride-hailing service Uber and traditional cabbies.
Angry residents in Sheffield Road, Philippi, barricaded a street, which they claimed is a street of death after a woman was knocked over and killed on the road.
Two roads leading to Kleinmond were closed as 300 people burnt tyres in protest action.
About 50 residents of Kensington in the Cape Town northern suburbs picketed along Voortrekker Road demanding more police to combat gangsterism in the community.
CPUT's Cape Town campus was petrol bombed on September 11, and stun grenades were fired by police during protests at the institution.
Protesting pupils set eSokheni Secondary School, in Greytown, near Pietermaritzburg, ablaze during unrest.
Angry community took to the streets and blocked the road in Mmakau in support of the Mmakau kraal, endorsing its legitimacy to royal status.
A group of about 60 fishermen marched on the office of the Department of Agriculture Forestry and Fisheries (DAFF) in Cape Town.

About 100 BLF members gathered at Gandhi Square in the Johannesburg CBD under the watchful eye of police to march to FNB Bank City following a failed meeting with FNB chief executive, Jacques Celliers.
Furniture was dragged from a restaurantin Hout Bay and set alight to form a burning barricade during a fishing quota protest.
Police used stun grenades to disperse a group of protesting nursing students who were approaching the East London campus.

Two men were killed when a service delivery protest turned violent at the Marry Me informal settlement near Soshanguve in Tshwane. Protesters shut down roads with rocks and burning tyres. The tewo deceased are believed to have been killed by protesters.
Three women and a man were arrested for public violence after illegal structures were demolished in Thembalethu, George. Police officers had to use stun grenades to disperse them.
Residents of Marikana informal settlement in Philippi necklaced three suspected robbers to bring the government's attention to the spike in crime in their area.

column9: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union
column17: An Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union (Amcu) official was gunned down at the Impala mine in Rustenburg.
More than 200 demonstrators gathered in the parking area outside the Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT) Cape Town campus.

A senior Netwerk24 photographer was assaulted and robbed of all his belongings by protesters in Mooi Uitsig, Kleinmond. Violent protests have occurred as informal settlement residents express displeasure that a local resident had not been awarded a tender to clean up the town's streets.
Some university students abandoned their studies and flocked to the Randburg Magistrates' Court to show their support for Mduduzi Manana who faces assault charges.
Two Taxify vehicles were set alight in Sunnyside, Pretoria during ongoing taxi violence in the province.
Two more women were arrested as disgruntled Thembalethu residents blocked streets for a second day. 300 people blocked the main entrance to the Thembalethu and the N2 with burning tyres.
Merebank residents and South Durban Environmental Alliance activists took to the streets to protest against a logistics park development at the former Clairwood Racecourse.
Over a thousand people marched to Parliament to protest against the killings of Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar. The march was led by the Muslim Judicial Council.

A Limpopo township (GaKgapane) was completely shut down amid violent service delivery protests in the area. Police had to remove some of the burning tyres and large rocks used to blockade the entry road into the area from the R81.
Members of the National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa (Numsa) have downed tools and protested at Mpact Plastics in Pinetown in Durban in protest against unequal wages and employee benefits.
A man was dragged from his shack, beaten in the street and killed by vigilantes in Phillipi. His shack was set alight, 50m from where he was killed.
The Golden Highway in Lenasia South, Johannesburg has been blocked off by burning tyres and rocks due to a protest that flared up in Ennerdale, Johannesburg.
The KwaDukuza community turned up in their numbers outside the KwaDukuza Magistrate's court for the appearance of two murder suspects.
A truck and a bus were torched in violent a protest in Marapong outside Lephalale, Limpopo

NUM embarked on protests at the Exxaro mine on (Thohoyonda) after the union failed to reach a wage increase agreement with the employer through the Commission for Conciliation, Mediation and Arbitration
The Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) marched to the Gupta-owned Shiva Uranium Mine in Hartbeesfontein near Klerksdorp on demanding the dismissal of the mine's human resource manager.

CPUT classrooms and equipment were damaged during ongoing protests protests. Violence entered the fourth day after private security guards disrupted a student gathering near the Sadenburg residence at the Cape Peninsula

Chaos erupted at the Burmese Embassy in Pretoria after a crowd of protesters affiliated to the #SA4Rohingya campaign gathered to picket against the plight of Rohingya refugees who have fled Myanmar. Some people within the protesters started shaking the perimeter fence and throwing stones and garbage into the diplomatic mission's premises. Police fired stun grenades to quell the protesters.

Several hundred people gathered outside the South Gauteng High Court in support of a R60-billion Constitutional Court class action bid to change legislation to prevent the sale of re-possessed houses at very low prices

About 600 people protested outside the Philippi East Police Station in Lower Crossroads. When angry protesters began to burn tyres outside the police station, the police dispersed the crowd with rubber bullets and teargas
ANC leaders fromtwo factions within the party fought in the Ladysmith town hall at a meeting of the Ukhahlamba regional general council. Five people were injured.

Over 500 people from Parkwood Estate participated in a peace walk against gangsterism, crime and other social ills, which have in recent times claimed a number of lives, including those of children, and terrorised the community.
Learners from a school in Bloekombos have been protesting against the school's policy on hair and clothing.
A MyCiTi bus was torched on the N2 near Delft, about 29km east of the Cape Town CBD during a taxi strike.
Rubber bullets were fired into a group of people throwing stones at buses and police in Du Noon, north of Cape Town as a taxi driver strike took hold.
On Potsdam and Wellington roads in Fisantekraal, a group of people threw stones at police and traffic officials
On the N1 at Joostenbergvlakte, a burning barricade blocked the road during the taxi strike.
Buses were also stoned at Site C in Khayelitsha and a Dairy Bell truck was torched on Govan Mbeki Road near the electrical depot.
Buses were stoned at Borcherds Quarry near the Cape Town International Airport during the taxi strike.
Examinations were cancelled for students at Klipspruit West Secondary High School in Soweto as a small group of parents protested outside the main gates.
At least 13 people were arrested, shops were closed and commuters were left stranded as protesters blocked roads with burning tyres in Matatiele. Police had used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.
A staffroom was also torched in Mowbray campus of CPUT in ongoing protests.
A group of #FeesMustFall students has stormed into the University of Cape Town library and disrupted classes and study sessions.
At the Bellville campus of CPUT, a petrol bomb caused significant damage to a financial aid office.
Members of Right2Know (R2K) and the Diepkloof Voices of Poor Concerned Residents picketed outside the head offices of several cellphone companies in Gauteng to demand cheaper airtime and data.

column9: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: A member of the Association of Mineworkers and Construction Unions (Amcu) was shot dead at Impala and another wounded at Lonmin in Marikana near Rustenburg.
A lecture theatre at the Cape Town campus of the Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT) was set alight in ongoing student protests.
Hundreds of angry locals took to the streets and blockaded with burning treest on the N2 in Murchison (Port Shepstone) , on the KwaZulu-Natal South Coast, to protest poor service delivery.
Protest turned violent in Humansdorp as protesters were were singing and dancing peacefully when teargas and rubber bullets were unleashed on them.
Leaders from five OR Tambo ANC branches protested outside the party's Nelson Mandela Drive offices (Mthatha) accusing the regional leaders of sidelining them
Members of the Gauteng Emergency Medical Services sang and danced as they marched through Newtown during a protest in Johannesburg.
Police and about 150 residents of Ocean View in Cape Town's south peninsula clashed. This was the second consecutive day of protests
Two people were killed during a tense clash between illegal dwellers and red ant officials over land in Lenasia, south of Johannesburg.
Hundreds of people from across the Western Cape gathered at the department of agriculture, forestry and fisheries (DAFF) in Cape Town to protest the current fishing quotas.
Residents from an informal settlement near Sir Lowry's Pass Village took their frustration to the streets causing road closures. The angry residents barricaded the road with burning tyres.
110 disabled students at the University of Limpopo staged a protest on campus.
Some students at the University of Fort Hare blocked the R63 at the entrance to the university. Students had thrown stones.
Whoonga addicts and vagrants in Pietermaritzburg have been brutally beaten and chased out of part of the city centre by angry residents.
A group of about 30 people pelted a block of flats with rocks in Umlazi. Gambushe was outside, watching events unfold.
About 25 winery workers picketed outside Leeuwenkuil Family Vineyards in Stellenbosch.
SASCO Protesters held a march at the Cape Peninsula University of Technology called for classes to be restarted and private security to be removed from campus.

The historic St Mark's Church in District Six in Cape Town has been damaged after a protester threw a petrol bomb at the building amid continued unrest at the nearby Cape Peninsula University of Technology.
A group of 45 artisanal miners protested outside the Koffiefontein Magistrate's Court after they were arrested for trespassing and malicious damage to property

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: The Cosatu march in Port Elizabeth took place as part of a nation-wide action.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: A Cosatu march in East London took place as part of a nation-wide action.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; SACP: South African Communist Party
column17: In Cape Town, SACP and COSATU members protested outside parliament.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: In Durban, police monitored a COSATU-led march which was led by Cosatu president Sdumo Dlamini and provincial SACP's Themba Mthembu.
A man with a mental illness was allegedly beaten to death by Red Ant Security Services in Midvaal during a service delivery protest in which protesters threw rocks at Red Army militia.
Community members marched to the municipal offices in Pietermaritzburg to demand that a politician step down, questioned whether the pistol was licensed.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: In Polokwane, anti-state capture protesters led by COSATU chanted, ""We are ready for Ramaphosa.""
A protest march to Remgro in Stellenbosch by Black First Land First (BLF) was a warning to billionaire businessman Johann Rupert and others.

A violent protest broke out at Makro in Woodmead. Protesters rampaged on the carpark outside Makro, throwing rocks at cars. Dozens of people were forced to stay in stores. The employees had been on strike for a week.
About 150 workers at the only Makro store in the Eastern Cape are on strike. The workers picketed at the entrance to the store at Kabega Park in Port Elizabeth.

Members of the United Democratic Front (UDF) picketed alongside Right2Know and the newly-formed organisation #UniteBehind outside the National Prosecuting Authority's offices in Cape Town to protest state corruption.
Police fired stun grenades to disperse a group of ANC members near the gates of the International Convention Centre in East London.
Residents of the Marikana informal settlement stormed the Philippi East police station demanding that police take action after 11 people were killed.

Over 200 people took to the streets of Soweto to celebrate the 2017 edition of Soweto Pride. Members of the gay community marched through Meadowlands and Dobsonville in Soweto protesting against hate crimes against them.
A former African National Congress councillor and long-time activist in Mtubatuba near Richards Bay, north of Durban, has been gunned down.
THE former branch chairman of the ANC in Nkumba in Bulwer was gunned down outside his girlfriend's home.
A mob attacked a taxi vehicle at the corner of Symphony Way and Stellenbosch Arterial Road in Cape Town.
Students at the Alice campus of the University of Fort Hare are protesting about fees, water outages and power cuts. The campus closed down. A student centre was set on fire
Hundreds of Nelson Mandela University students gathered in protest at the South Campus Kraal on following the alleged rape and robbery of two students.
No arrests have been made after several vehicles belonging to the Bapo-Ba-Mogale community in Bapong near Brits were set alight.
Traffic in Ngcobo came to a standstill and shops shut for about five hours as ratepayers and taxi operators united in a peaceful protest to demand better service delivery from municipal bosses.
Officers from the Tshwane Metro Police Department's VIP protection unit used pepper spray to force the group of about 100 student protesters.

Police used stun grenades to disperse about 150 Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT) students who were marching to Parliament to hand over a memorandum to the Department of Higher Education and Training yesterday.
Service delivery protests flared up in Cato Manor. They also broke bottles and threw them along the road. They pelted police with rocks. Police had to use rubber bullets and stun grenades.
A small group of DA supporters braved the cold and rain to march close to the Gupta family's Saxonwold compound in Johannesburg to protest against state capture.
Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT) students protested against financial exclusions. 200 people participated in the protests at the Cape Town campus.

At the Bellville campus, students were protesting over financial exclusion and caused damage to the admin building when clashes with private security broke out. Private security at the residence used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.
Following a criminal incident, a local community mobilised themselves, followed a suspect criminal and assaulted him to death at his shack in the town of Tzaneen in Limpopo Province.
After an attack in Mokgoba near Modjadjiskloof, the local community had mobilised and had gone to the attacker's house, where they proceeded to severely assault the man, who died from his injuries.
Students, led by the organisation Equal Education held a march in Pretoria.

Protest action by people wearing Economic Freedom Fighters T-shirts, led to the closure of Shoprite's doors at the Greenacres shopping centre in Port Elizabeth. Police then had to use stun grenades to disperse the protestors.
There were no leassons at some KwaDabeka and Clermont schools as pupils embarked on a protest demanding the arrest and suspension of a teacher they accused of murder.

Mattresses, bookshelves and bottles were thrown out of a Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT) residence in Cape Town during ongoing student protests. Stones rained down on the armoured car of a private security company and some of the onlookers laughed when the security guards fired a few shots from their rifles.
A small group of students protested in the rain outside a court house in Port Elizabeth.
Students at CPUT marched on administration building on the Bellville campus, wanting to meet CPUT executive management.
THE N2 between Dutywa and Butterworth was closed due to an electricity protest. The protest was peaceful.
A group of residents from the Blydeville community in Lichtenburg torched a truck on the R503 Lichtenburg-Coligny Road.
After a group of protesters took to the streets burning tyres and torching a truck, a unknown man shot at the crowd and killed a boy.
A police officer was hospitalised and five others were injured as an angry mob attack police officers in Vanderbijlpark.

After a boy was shot and killed, community members took to the streets again to barricade Lichtenburg's main road while they waited for the mayor to address them. Burning tyres, rocks and tree branches lay on Dr Nelson Mandela-Rylaan in Lichtenburg, North West.
The Democratic Alliance held a silent protest at the AB Xuma Primary School in Orlando East.
Mfuleni parents took to the streets to demand that the Western Cape Department of Education build a permanent school at Bardale Primary School in Mfuleni
A supermarket was looted and a building torched in Tigane outside Klerksdorp, North West during protest action.

column7: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union
column17: Thousands of Sadtu members protested in the Durban central business district against the state of affairs in education in the province.
St George's Park in Port Elizabeth was ringed by hundreds of protesters who took part in an anti-slavery #WalkForFreedom.
A group of people started a protest by closing down roads and stoning the main municipal building in Embalenhle
Around 15 October 2017 (month of), a woman was assaulted by police with a thick rod, a leather belt and an empty glass bottle in Hopefield (West Coast, Western Cape).

column7: Police Union of South Africa; SAFTU: South African Federation of Trade Unions
column17: Striking 10111 police emergency call centre workers, affiliated with the South African Policing Union (Sapu) and its labour federation, the SA Federation of Trade Unions (Saftu), gathered at the Pretoria Art Museum and made their way through the streets, marched to the Union Buildings in Pretoria.
Protesters in Embalenhle, Mpumalanga, looted Somalian shops and burned down municipal buildings during an ongoing service delivery protest.
Angry small-scale and nearshore fishers blocked the entrance to the Department of Agriculture, Forestry & Fisheries offices at the Foreshore in Woodstock in protest.

Pupils from Mahlare High School in Mhlaba Cross demonstrated outside Nkowankowa Magistrate Court in support of their fellow learner who accused the doctor of raping her in his rooms last Monday afternoon.

column7: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union
column17: South African Democratic Teachers' Union members gathered, chanting and dancing in Marabastad (Pretoria), near the Putco Bus Depot ahead of a national protest march they are set to embark on.

Students and members of Equal Education (EE) picketed outside the Port Elizabeth offices of the Coega Development Corporation (Coega), one of the agencies responsible for building and upgrading schools in the Eastern Cape.
In Pietermaritzburg, pupils allegedly stoned teachers' cars in protest. 18 students were arrested.

Students and members of Equal Education (EE) picketed outside the East London offices of the Coega Development Corporation (Coega), one of the agencies responsible for building and upgrading schools in the Eastern Cape.
In Litchenburg, protesters demonstrated outside the court house during the hearing of a murder accused.
Mbizana residents and pupils yesterday marched to the local police station demanding the speedy arrest of those who killed, beheaded and dissected a schoolgirl.
About 25 learners from ID Mkizhe and Fezeka high schools in Gugulethu marched from the local mall to the police station.
About 50 supporters of Public Transport Voice, the Treatment Action Campaign and Right2Know Campaign marched through Cape Town train station to protest the deteriorating railway system.
36 students were arrested on the Bloemfontein campus late after a group of students clashed with members of the private security company and the South African Police Service (SAPS).
Three people were shot and wounded at uMlazi's notorious Glebelands hostel.
Metrorail has terminated trains travelling from Cape Town to Bellville via Lavistown due to protest action.
Two students at the QwaQwa campus of UFS were allegedly shot and injured by private security guards.
A handful of Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) members at Ikemeleng in Kroondal in the North West, marched to the Rustenburg municipality, demanding houses, water and electricity.
A man alleged to have attempted to rape a young girl has been stoned to death by angry residents from an informal settlement in Clare Estate, Durban.
In Pongola, pupils allegedly broke school windows during a school meeting in one of the high schools in protest.
UCT has confirmed a group of students attempted to disrupt classes on Upper Campus in ongoing student protests.
The police have arrested five men aged between 20 and 31 in connection with the torching of a Cape Peninsula University of Technology bus.
About 150 university students marched to the National Assembly where Minister of Finance Malusi Gigaba was delivering his medium-term budget speech.

The Tanzanian High Commission in Pretoria visited by a crowd of protesters demanding the release of 13 people, including two South African human rights lawyers, who were arrested for allegedly promoting homosexuality in the capital Dar es Salaam.
Fire alarms were set off, lectures interrupted and a library evacuated, as an estimated 1 000 University of Cape Town (UCT) students marched on campus to demand free higher education.

At the Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT), private security guards used stun grenades to disperse a group of protesting students who the university said attempted to storm the Bellville library.
On the UFS Bloemfontein campus, roughly 50 students gathered outside the Steve Biko House student centre to call for free higher education.
Seven University of the Free State (UFS) students, including two SRC members, were arrested at the QwaQwa campus and detained in a police van for four hours.

Residents of Zandspruit in Johannesburg have vowed to reconnect electricity connections which were disconnected by the city which led to clashes between the community and police. Residents barricaded the road with rocks and burning tyres.
A few hundred Fees Must Fall protesters attempted to shut down the University of Cape Town (UCT).
Members of a community allegedly stoned a 50-year-old man to death in Rabokala near Brits.
A group of Right2Know campaign members picketed outside the city hall demanding that the full council reject proposed amendments to the Rules of Order.
A group of pupils allegedly stole cash and laptops from the staff room and set the school property alight in ongoing violence.
Classes were suspended at UCT as students again disrupted the academic programme in protest.
A design studio was set alight at Cape Peninsula University of Technology's (CPUT) Cape Town campus as sporadic protests continued at the institution.
The R21 and R24 highways near OR Tambo International Airport have been blocked by a taxi protest. Two Uber vehicles were set alight during protests on the R21 and R24 highways.

About five thousand people from various organisations, including parents and school children marched in support of safe schools and communities in the Western Cape. The protest was led by Equal Education (EE). They marched from Keizersgracht Street to Parliament and handed a memorandum to Allan Subban from the Department of Basic Education.
A village in Mdantsane went on the rampage and burnt a police bakkie as they tried to attack suspected criminals. Police dispersed the angry community with rubber rounds.
At least 18 000 people and 5 000 vehicles have gathered at Kanonkop, a farm in Klapmuts near Stellenbosch in protest against farm murders.
Kwanobuhle residents burnt tyres after various parts of the area had not had electricity for several days.
Farmers in Cape Town protested over the murder of farmers throughout the country.
Angry small, medium and micro enterprise owners and residents in Mdantsane shut down major construction sites in protest demanding BCM give local construction projects to its residents.
An Eastern Cape university student has been beaten to death, allegedly by fellow students in Mthatha.
Pietermaritzburg and Midlands farmers joined the nation-wide protest against farm murders and attacks, causing backlogs in traffic on the N3 highway in Pietermaritzburg.
About 80 private doctors protested in Port Elizabeth demanding police action against armed robbers targeting their surgeries.
Farmers in Pretoria protested over the murder of farmers throughout the country.
A handful of people gathered at the Memorial Circle in Kimberley in support of the national protest against farm murders.
A multi-vehicle crash resulted in two people suffering serious injuries after a truck collided with a group of protesters on the N4 outside of Middleburg

Supporters of Imam Nazeem Taliep, of Ghiedmatiel Islamia Mosque in Taronga Road, Crawford, picketed outside there in opposition to what they have characterised as persecution by the board of trustees.
Parents of pupils from Uitzig High School in Elsies River barricaded the provincial Education Department's metro offices, following the announcement that the school will be shut down next month.

A hospital in Vosloorus came under scrutiny after footage emerged showing security guards clashing with police officers during a strike at the hospital. The guards were protesting after they pitched at work only to be told that their services had been terminated and that another company had secured the contract.
The UniteBehind campaign, led by veteran UDF members, started civil disobedience and staged a protest at the NPA offices in Cape Town.
A man was beaten but left alive in Umhlatuzana, Chatsworth by an angry mob.
Economic Freedom Fighters national leadership led a protest to the Israeli Embassy in Pretoria. Hundreds of EFF supporters gathered at the mission, in solidarity with Palestinians.

A group of roughly 200 people, believed to students, attempted to disrupt academic activity at the University of Cape Town. Western Cape police used stun grenades to disperse protesters and arrested one protester who tried to damage the university's shuttle service.
Hundreds of SABC employees - among them journalists - took to the streets of Cape Town, demanding a 10% wage increase from the public broadcaster.
Hundreds of SABC employees - among them journalists - took to the streets of Durban, demanding a 10% wage increase from the public broadcaster.
A small group of SABC employees protested outside the broadcaster's headquarters in Johannesburg demanding a 10% salary increase.
The members and supporters of the Ancestral Burial Ground Committee protest outside St George's Cathedral in Cape Town.
A number of taxis operators staged a sit-in in front of the Glen Manor Office Park in Menlyn (Pretoria) where the Cross-Border Road Transport Agency has its office.

The NTA and its affiliated taxi associations descended on Tshwane CBD in protest to hand over memoranda, which listed the grievances and issues affecting the taxi industry. Two taxi drivers were arrested after allegedly assaulting a female Tshwane Metro Police officer.
Students protested in Pietermaritzburg over the lack of transport. This action was part of an Equal Education-led protest for government to provide needy children with scholar transport.

column7: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union
column17: Amcu members protested outside the Brits Magistrate's Court, after NUM member Nkosinathi Mantashe, accused of attempted murder, was granted bail.

Commuters from villages and residential areas along the R61 found themselves stranded as taxi operators joined residents of Mthatha West in a protest march to the King Sabata Dalindyebo municipal offices.
A bodyguard of the Msunduzi municipality speaker was shot dead by two suspects in Caluza near Pietermaritzburg.
The bodies of two men, riddled with gunshot wounds, were found at the infamous Glebelands Hostel in Umlazi.
Three separate houses were set alight by angry community members in Rustenburg following the disappearance of a teenage girl.

Members of the ANC in the Boland region in the Western Cape protested outside the party's provincial offices in Cape Town demanding to know why their regional secretary, Jonton Snyman, had been suspended.
Two more houses have been torched by angry community members in Rustenburg following the disappearance of a teenage girl.

column16: Congress of South African Trade Unions
column17: The house of a NUM youth leader was burnt down by alleged Amcu members in Orange Farm.

Earthlife Africa, supported by Greenpeace Africa and partner organisations, marched in Johannesburg opposing South Africa's planned nuclear power station build programme as part of the global day of action on climate change.
In Mitchells Plain, residents clashed with police after news spread that a teenage boy had raped a 6-year-old girl. They pelted police officers with rocks and burnt tyres on the road.
Battle Churchgoers clashed police and metro officers in Hillbrow because they towed away an illegally parked car, one cop badly hurt.
The police were on high alert as a crowd protested, with some screaming "" women beater"" during the trial of a politician accused of assaulting a woman at the Randberg Magistrate's Court.
More than 20 shops closed their doors at the Cleary Park Shopping Centre when a service delivery protest spilled over into the centre.
Residents who wanted to force their way into the Qumbu Magistrate's Court, where a Facebook serial rape and murder accused was appearing, went on a rampage damaging cars and property.
Residents of Letlhabile near Brits took to the streets demanding the resignation of the Letlhabile Community Radio station manager and the board of directors

More than hundred residents protested outside the Polokwane high court in support of Michael Komape's family who is suing the department of education over poor sanitation which they say led to his death in 2014

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; ANC: African National Congress
column17: Scores of rubber bullets were fired at an angry crowd protesting outside the Bronkhorstspruit Magistrate's Court. The crowd of EFF and ANC members threw stones and bottles at the police and broke windows of the court's building before rubber bullets were fired.
A female train driver on the Durban/Stanger route was left traumatized on after commuters who were late for work reportedly threw stones at her when she refused to proceed past a red stop signal.
Unite Behind activists protested against the state of train services in Cape Town saying dodgy tenders and corruption was draining money meant to fix issues that railway commuters encounter daily.
Residents blocked the N2 with burning tyres in Beacon Bay. A ward councillor's office was wrecked in the protest.
Over 800 marchers belonging to various associations affiliated to the Eastern Cape Liquor Forum in Beacon Bay submitted a memorandum demanding transparency and answers in 14 days.
Police have used stun grenades to disperse peaceful protesters in Steenberg, Cape Town.
17 November. An activist involved with the Sisonke Village land occupation was shot and killed by an unidentified armed group in Cato Manor, eThekwini.

Hundreds of Zimbabweans of all creeds and races took to the streets of Johannesburg to celebrate what they hope is the imminent departure of President Robert Mugabe who is under pressure from the military and the ruling party to resign.

19 November. An unidentified armed group stabbed a man to death. He worked for the waZulu-Natal provincial council in eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal. The attack reportedly stemmed from the  victims work on human rights in informal settlements.
19 November. A South African rights defender was killed in Saskone, near Lamontville, by unidentified assailants.
An alleged child rapist from Delft was assaulted by an angry mob on Monday after an 11-year-old girl was attacked.
Macassar residents went on a rampage, allegedly killing two murder suspects in mob justice attacks.
On 20 November 2017, ten people were arrested for the alleged attempted murder of a sangoma in a vigilante attack. The sangoma was admitted to hospital.
On 20 November 2017, in Harrismith, 1000 protesting community members spontaneously tipped over a police sedan and a bakkie that was parked nearby and set both alight. [size=1000].

Police and residents of Walmer township in Port Elizabeth have been in a tense standoff after protesters barricaded roads with burning tyres. Public order police responded with rubber bullets, stun grenades and tear gas.
Members of the Unemployed Forum allegedly blocked the road linking Sun City and Pretoria and set a bus alight near a shopping complex in Bapong.

column7: SJC: Social Justice Coalition; EE: Equal Education
column17: About a hundred people marched to Parliament on to demand more equal policing. The Social Justice Coalition and Equal Education took part.

column7: MKVMA: Mkhonto weSizwe Military Veterans Association
column17: Umkhonto we Sizwe Military Veterans in KwaZulu-Natal held a march in Marianhill to highlight the plight of black farm workers.
An influential member of the ANC's Youth League in KwaZulu-Natal was gunned down in his house outside Pietermaritzburg.

Police were monitoring a protest near the multi-million rand Longlands luxury estate development near Stellenbosch amid claims that a developer had reneged on a promise to build low-cost houses for farmworkers who lived on the land before it was sold.
Hundreds of white South African farmers took to the streets of Pretoria, demanding government action over a wave of murders targeting their communities in rural areas.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: Former finance minister Pravin Gordhan has denounced the behaviour of a large crowd of protesting people who interrupted him and threw sewage outside a venue in KwaDukuza, north of Durban, where he was supposed to deliver a speech. The protesters were believed to be ANC Youth League members.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Several pro-Palestinian organisations joined a protest with NEHAWU in Pretoria,accusing government of betraying the Palestinian struggle by what it calls 'continuously strengthening ties with Israel'.

column7: Private Security Forces (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: The Gauteng Department of Health has terminated the contract of a private security company ""with immediate effect"" after its employees staged a protest at the Steve Biko Academic Hospital. The protesting security guards used stones and rubble to block the entrance to the hospital in Pretoria and vandalised signage and vegetation.
A protest march took place outside the Pretoria courts over housing issues.

EE picketed at Kwadedangendlale Secondary in Soweto to protest against the failure of the Gauteng provincial government to fix infrastructure that poses an immediate threat to the safety of learners at the school.
EE members marched to the Limpopo Department of Education in Polokwane where they released their new report on the provision of water and sanitation in schools in the province

column7: EE: Equal Education; Students (South Africa); Teachers (South Africa)
column17: Members of EE, learners, and teachers from Bardale Primary and High Schools as well as members of the Mfuleni Education Forum marched to the Western Cape Education Department (WCED) Metro North District Office.

Members of EE and learners from several schools held a night vigil at Vukile Tshwete Secondary School in Keiskammahoek. The school is made out of wood, the ceiling is collapsing, and some classes have no electricity.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: The National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa's (Numsa) members picketed outside Eskom head office in Johannesburg expressing unhappiness over a host of issues, including a looming electricity tariff increase.
Hundreds of #UniteBehind supporters gathered outside the Cape Town train station, calling for the arrest of President Jacob Zuma and for the trains to be fixed.
The Democratic Alliance held a #HandsOffMashaba march from Pieter Roos Park in Parktown.

A group of 15 Greenpeace activists have blocked the main entrance of the Department of Enviromental Affairs in Pretoria with nuclear barrels to send a message to the department to stop nuclear as they said it was never safe.
04 December. In Sikonke, a human rights defender was dragged out of his home and stabbed to death by unidentified perpetrators.
Rape Crisis supporters and some residents picketed outside the Khayelitsha Magistrates' Court, calling for a dedicated sexual offences court for the area.

column7: SAFTU: South African Federation of Trade Unions; Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Paramedics aligned with the Federation of Unions of South Africa (FEDUSA) marched to Parliament to demand better protection against attacks, especially during the festive season.
About 50 people from at least 20 civil society organisations picketed in the rain outside the International Convention Centre (ICC) in Durban.

column7: SACTWU: Southern African Clothing and Textile Workers Union
column17: Sactwu members stand up against gender-based violence by protesting at Gunners Circle in Epping
Labour issues brought 50 protesters to the Jozini city centre and blocked the roads with stones.
Police in Motherwell in the Eastern Cape have condemned the mob murder of an 18-year-old man, who was suspected of killing his mother.
Workers at Agni Steel brought production to a halt again at the Coega business as they picketed while demanding better wages.

Philippi East residents and members of the Social Justice Coalition (SJC) picketed outside the Cape Town Civic Centre, calling on the City to fix street lights following the electrocution of two children in November.
Hundreds of African Diaspora Forum members and their associates took to the streets in Pretoria, expressing anger at the modern-day slavery in Libya.
A protest took place again the recent events in Israel at Parliament in Cape Town.
About 200 girls and young women marched through the streets of Johannesburg to demand that Google and Facebook respect African culture.

Residents from Clairwood and Merebank as well as members South Durban Environmental Alliance protested outside the Durban High Court this week, where the South Durban Community Environmental Alliance and the Clairwood Racecourse Association have challenged the KwaZulu-Natal government's approval of the logistics park.
Residents from Clairwood and Merebank as well as members South Durban Environmental Alliance marched through the streets of Merebank.
Member of the Communications Worker Union (CWU), held a protest outside the SABC offices inAuckland Park.

Security Company personnel opened fire on the illegal miners as attempts to reopen a dirt road, adjacent to the miner's Samaria Road informal settlement, left several people injured and also damaged the private property of at least one innocent bystander.

Two cases of assault with the intention to do grievous bodily harm have been opened at Olievenhoutbosch police station as EFF and ANC members clashed in the middle of a controversial RDP houses allocation.
A group of Khoisan men and women held a protest outside Nasrec in Johannesburg during the African National Congress's national elective conference.
For a second day, a group of Khoisan men and women held a protest outside Nasrec in Johannesburg during the African National Congress's national elective conference.
Seven people were shot and wounded after security guards fired rubber bullets at them during a protest at an estate in Rustenburg in the North West. No reports of violence by the protesters.
A group of Mthwakazi people from Mathebele Land protest outside Zimbabwe embassy where hundreds of business people are expected to meet with President Emmerson Mnangagwa.
Residents of Aliwal North in Walter Sisulu municipality brought Aliwal North to a standstill, protesting against power cuts in the two areas.
Angry protesters from affected residential areas of Sharpeville, some parts of Sebokeng and other neighbouring areas turned their anger on motorists by pelting their cars with stones.
A councillor in Jozini, KwaZulu-Natal was murdered on New Year's day.
Community members attacked and prevented emergency crews from attending to the fires in Ekurhuleni, which resulted in the death of the mother and the house burning to the ground.
Members of the community in Aliwal North have been blockading the N6 road, and despite being chased off and the road cleared, they have returned to cause havoc for perplexed travellers.
A group of protesters gathered in Protea Glen in Soweto, to demand help after their homes were damaged during a recent storm. They burnt tyres and put pipes in the road.

Residents of Maijane Village in Polokwane allegedly burnt a minibus taxi and stoned four others, after a group of taxi operators forced a resident to use a taxi, instead of hitchhiking, near the Seleteng taxi rank, police.
Residents held protests outside Tinley Manor Primary School on the Dolphin Coast.
A girl was shot in the knee with a rubber bullet and a man was injured in the head on 4 January when police dispersed Philippi residents who had occupied private land and protested.

Police have warned motorists to avoid driving along the Golden Highway and Welgevonden Road, towards Orange Farm, due to protest action. Protestors are allegedly burning tyres and throwing stones at passing cars.
A man suspected to have raped a nine-year-old girl in Tafelsig, Mitchells Plain, was beaten by residents but survived.
About 100 contract workers employed under the Expanded Public Works Programme (EPWP) by the department of Durban Solid Waste (DSW) protested outside the DSW's head office in Durban.
Protests took place by community members in Ladismith over the cancellation of taxi transort. Roads were blocked with rocks and burning tyres.
A post office was torched and a 30-year-old woman arrested for public violence following a protest in Ottoshoop near Mahikeng.

column7: Taxi Drivers (South Africa); Vigilante Group (South Africa)
column17: On 8 January 2018, a series of attacks against Nigerian nationals were registered in Rustenburg (Bojanala Platinum, North-West) after taxi drivers accused foreign nationals of selling drugs. Houses and vehicles were set on fire. The attacks lasted until 10 January. 4 Nigerian nationals were severely injured; a woman and her child were beaten. [size=no report]
An early morning service delivery protest left the bustling R102 near KwaDukuza, north of Durban, blocked. A truck was set alight, as well as trees and tyres.

Protests in Ottoshoop continued for a second day. They also pelted a police station and a house used to accommodate police officers with stones. The said house which is next to the police station, was also partially burnt.

column7: Taxi Drivers (South Africa); Vigilante Group (South Africa)
column17: On 9 January 2018, a series of attacks against Nigerian nationals were registered in Rustenburg (Bojanala Platinum, North-West) after taxi drivers accused foreign nationals of selling drugs. Houses and vehicles were set on fire. The attacks started on 8 January and lasted until 10 January. [size=no report]

A group of protesters took part in demonstrations along the N2 in Chesterville. Residents from the nearby informal settlement took to the busy highway armed with rocks and other items and blocked the road.

On 10 January 2018, a man was shot dead during a demonstration at the Bafokeng Rasimone Platinum Mine in Rustenburg. Security personnel had opened fire with rubber bullets and paintballs. It was difficult to confirm whether the person was shot by mine security personnel or one of the community members who were reported to have had sharp ammunition.

column7: Taxi Drivers (South Africa); Vigilante Group (South Africa)
column17: On 10 January 2018, a series of attacks against Nigerian nationals were registered in Rustenburg (Bojanala Platinum, North-West) after taxi drivers accused foreign nationals of selling drugs. Houses and vehicles were set on fire. The attacks started on 8 January. [size=no report]
Along the Golden Highway in Enfuleni, lies debris from two recent protests in Sebokeng, when residents demonstrated over the lack of water.
Along the Golden Highway in Enfuleni, lies debris from two recent protests in Palm Springs, when residents demonstrated over the lack of water.

11 January. Demonstrators blocked roads in a demonstration for land rights in Durban, eThekwini. Police forces fired shots to disperse the group. A man fleeing the shots stepped onto a live electrical wire, which killed him. [size=no report]
11 January. Police forces opened fire on protestors, during a demonstration against the demolished dwellings in Solomondale. One activist was killed. [size=no report]

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column9: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: The Economic Freedom Fighters Student Command shut down proceedings at the University of South Africa's Sunnyside campus. ANC youth and EFF students allegedly clashed at the campus.
A protest by the Delangokubona Business Forum took place at the Toyota plant in Prospecton.
A man was burnt to death in Zoeknog Trust, Acornhoek, in an apparent mob justice attack.
Police have confirmed that rubber bullets were used to disperse protestors wearing EFF regalia at the East Rand Mall.
A mob of people who burnt down four houses of villagers whom they accuse of practising witchcraft at Ntswaneng village outside Burgersfort in Limpopo.
Guests at a resort in Shongweni were unable to leave as protesting residents from the Mangangeni area had barricaded the reserve's exit and entry points, and burnt tyres.
Angry residents protested inside Court C at the Krugersdorp Magistrate's Court as a man appeared for bail application for allegedly shooting dead another man.
On 15 January 2018, tenants at the Mall of Africa in Midrand have closed their doors after a group of about 30 EFF protesters descended on the H&M store. [size=30].

column7: NUPSAW: National Union of Public Service and Allied Workers; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 15 January 2018, members of the National Union of Public Service and Allied Workers (NUPSAW) went on strike and protested at Dis-Chem warehouse in Midrand, Johannesburg. [size=no report].
Chaos erupted at Thekwini TVET College's Centec Campus in Morningside.
In Umhlanga, Gateway Shopping Centre's H&M store was prompted to evacuate and close its doors ahead as EFF protested.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: Unisa's current and prospective students are angry at a group of protesters outside the Sunnyside campus. The group was under the umbrella of the National Education, Health and Allied Workers' Union (Nehawu)

column7: SASCO: South Africa Students Congress; ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League; YCL: Young Communist League
column17: Several student groups rallied together at Durban University of Technology (DUT) to protest against the institution's demand for registration fees from all students, including those who qualify for free education. The protest group included members from the South African Students Congress (SASCO), Young Communist League (YCL) and ANCYL.

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; ANC: African National Congress
column17: Ten people have been arrested for public violence following protest action in front of Hoerskool Overvaal in Vereeniging. Police had to fire the rubber bullets after protesters refused to disperse and started burning tyres. Six EFF members and four ANC members were arrested.
Roads leading towards Somlingo Primary School in Verena in Mpumalanga was barricaded by a group of residents protesting over a lack of water.
UniteBehind activists were allegedly assaulted by security guards during a protest at the Cape Town Station.
A 33-year-old ANC activist was shot dead in eSikhawini, on the KwaZulu-Natal north coast.
In Grahamstown, a small demonstration outside the city hall took place with about 200 people.

Motherwell residents embarked on violent protest action, causing serious damage to property estimated at R3-million. The protesters, who are demanding electricity, threw stones at passing motorists, set alight a municipal truck and caused serious damage to a tractor and other vehicles.
Protesters gathered outside Hoerskool Overvaal in Vereeniging in a second day of protest.

Some members of the community spent a few hours at Intuthuko Senior Secondary School in Maphotla Village in Mpumalanga, where they demanded the resignation of the principal for allegedly failing in his duties
Parents protested at the Kwadedangendlale Secondary School in Zola, Soweto over lack of infrastructure.
South African Police Service (SAPS) officers and paramedics have rescued two men after they were seriously assaulted and thrown into a deep water hole in an apparent mob justice in Polokwane.

Angry parents demonstrated outside Bloekombos Primary School in Kraaifontein on Monday, demanding that the Western Cape Education Department put up prefab classrooms for children who were turned away from local schools.
Police officers shot at protesters, who had gathered at the Kagiso police station in Krugersdorp, with rubber bullets.
Roads in Mogale City on the West Rand have been barricaded with burning tyres and rocks as part of a community-led shutdown over crime in the area.
Residents from Thembelihle informal settlement, south of Johannesburg took to the streets in a service delivery protest in Lenasia.
Munsieville police came under attack from angry residents who torched vehicles and also tried to burn the police station. Police had to disperse the crowds with rubber bullets and teargas.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: Operations at the Bhisho Legislature came to a halt when almost 100 workers with NEHAWU downed tools. The protesters demonstrated at the main entrance to the legislature, while they later gathered near the Raymond Mhlaba chamber, where they sang protest songs.
On or around 23 February 2018, Bashir Saleh family, the former head of Libya's Africa Investment portfolio, was shot by unknown gunmen in Johannesburg. He was wounded by two bullets.
A group of dismayed parents staged a second day of protests outside the Bloekombos Primary School in Kraaifontein demanding the enrolment of more than 300 pupils who are on the waiting list.

In Krugersdorp, rocks and branches lay scattered across the roads and several shops and bottle stores were looted in protest action. Two houses, not far from where the protest action took place, were burnt down.
In Mdantsane, residents staged a protest that spanned 3km leading to their ward councillor's house. Traces of rubbish, buckets of faeces, and burnt tyres could be seen after the protest.

More than 100 students from the world's largest university have blocked off roads in Durban's CBD, demanding the opening of a regional office. There were no injuries thus far, but the roads have been blocked off by bricks and stones. It appears that students are protesting around the registration processes.
Protesters from Thembelihle informal settlement, south of Johannesburg, continued to protest and barricaded the K43 road in Lenasia and stoned passing cars.
Protesters were burning tyres around the Beyers Naude Drive area of Zandspruit, west of Johannesburg.
Uber and Taxify drivers protest outside the Boksburg magistrate's court after the murder of a driver.
At least one vehicle has been set alight and several others have been pelted with stones during a strike by minibus taxi drivers in the Pietermaritzburg CBD.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; ANC: African National Congress
column17: The Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu) and the ANC in Vereeniging protest and demanded that Hoerskool Overvaal in admit all 55 pupils who were previously denied access to the school by a court order.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: On 26 January 2018, hundreds of Wits University workers and union members marched to the main campus to demand a 12% salary increase. Nehawu members began the strike. [size=100].
The group called ""All Tshwane Vat Alles Employees"" are marching to the Union Buildings in Pretoria over jobs.
Public order policing units and Durban metro police gathered outside the headquarters of the ANC in Durban following intra-ANC protests in the city's CBD.
ANC protesters continued to picket outside the party's provincial headquarters in Durban, KwaZulu-Natal, were told the interim leadership team would meet them next week.

Residents flocked to the Howick court during the trial of an alleged murderer and stoned it. They were not happy with the way police handled the case. Police used teargas and rubber bullets to disperse the protesters.
Hundreds of people joined outside the civic centre to protest against the City of Cape Town's management of the water crisis

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students
column17: Striking Durban University of Technology (DUT) staff members and South African Students' Congress members who belong to various unions were met with rubber bullets when they attempted to disrupt registration processes on campus.
Protests by Jozi@Work employees began after the expiry of their temporary contracts with the city.

Port Elizabeth police arrested three people for armed robbery and saved their lives from a vigilante community mob in Motherwell. 150 people were assaulting the suspects who they alleged were street robbers in the area.
At a school In Windsorton, two groups of pupils attacked each other with garden spades, sheep shears, pangas, knives, hockey sticks, golf clubs and sjamboks.

The community of Mpophomeni location in Emagwababeni, Pietermaritzburg protested outside Howick Magistrates' court, demanding no bail for a 39-year-old man accused of raping and strangling a grandmother who, according to her family, was over 100 years old
Two trains belonging to Metrorail were set alight in Durban allegedly by irate passengers.
Protesting students at the University of SA (Unisa) brought operations to a halt at the main campus in Pretoria.
Three vehicles were set alight when taxi drivers shut down the Pietermaritzburg CBD over traffic fines.
Students on the Barberton Campus of Ehlanzeni Technical Vocational Education Training College embarked on a violent protest, torching a vehicle in the process.
Shondoni Secondary School in Lwamondo village in Vuwani was set alight in another arson attack.
Motorists have been advised to avoid the Rosettenville area as residents have embarked on a protest - blocking several streets with burning tyres and stones.
Anti-abortion activists took to the streets of Pretoria, voicing their dismay with legislation dating back 20 years, on the termination of pregnancies.
A memorandum was handed in by protesting Methodist young people and the EFF during a convention at the Voortrekker Monument in Pretoria.

Police and Unisa students clashed outside the Durban campus. Police fire teargas rubber bullets and stun grenades. A woman was detained as she tried to flee on Stalwart Simelane Street. The students later dispersed.

column7: BLF: Black First, Land First; ANC: African National Congress
column17: Black First Land First (BLF) members and ANC members marched in Johannesburg in support of President Jacob Zuma. Things turned violent and the two groups clashed with police. Two people were injured

Pupils at the Dikgwale and Bingweni Secondary Schools in Leeufontein near Vaalbank protested. They blockaded the R568 road with burning tyres, rocks and other objects and pelted police and passing motorists with stones. The situation then compelled the police to disperse the protesters using rubber bullets and stun grenades.

Hundreds of pupils and teachers at Mavimbela Primary School in Mkhuhlu near Bushbuckridge, Mpumalanga were forced to stay at home yesterday after their school was vandalised and set alight by angry community members.
Protest action in QwaQwa, Phuthaditjhaba took place as residents barricaded roads with burning tyres and rocks.
About 20 protesters gathered outside the Cape Town Magistrate's Court to demand that a sexual assault case against a businessman be reopened.
Ex-combatants gathered outside the Department of Military Veterans building (DMV) in Hatfield, east of Pretoria's CBD, threatening violence unless they received benefits from the government.

column9: ANCWL: African National Congress Womens League
column17: The house of an African National Congress Women's League (ANCWL) Kenneth Kaunda regional secretary was stoned and damaged in an apparent intimidation act in Khuma, near Stilfontein.
Protests from parents at the school gates in King Williams Town as they demanded that the education department build new toilets.
Bus commuters in Hammanskraal set alight a local taxi association's office in an attempt to stop taxi drivers from barricading the R101 route to Pretoria with burning tyres.
A group of fishers from Port Nolloth gathered outside the offices of the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries in Cape Town, as they are yet to receive their boat licenses.
Shops were looted and damaged while residents demanded residential sites from the authority in the town of Vredefort.

Hundreds of Tshwane University of Technology students have shut down academic proceedings again at the institution's Soshanguve North and South campuses. Students carrying sticks left a burning tyre at the main gate.
Unisa students, frustrated over funding issues, took to the streets outside its Durban campus. A 400-strong crowd marched and dragged concrete rubbish bins on to the road.
Police say calm has been restored in eMbalenhle after violence erupted during a protest against Sasol and labour brokers.

Protesters shut down Rustenburg, demanding that Nigerian nationals should leave the city. The police used rubber bullets and smoke grenades to disperse a crowd chanting outside the magistrate's court, this was after they threatened to burn down the court building.
Residents of Endumeni protested during the court case in Pietermaritzburg.
At the South Rand Hospital in Rosettenville, a crowd of protesters made their way into the hospital under public order policing supervision.
Residents of Dunoon took to the streets on 10 February and nearly destroyed the MyCiTi bus station near Dunoon taxi rank with bricks, stones, and burning tyres.
Members of the Pakistani and Kashmiri communities in Johannesburg gathered to protest in front of the Wanderers Stadium, where the India-South Africa cricket match was being played.

Parents, learners and community members protested and threatened to close Sandisulwazi Secondary School in Paterson, Eastern Cape, if Afrikaans, the mother tongue of numerous learners at the school, is not taught
Protesters of the #ZumaMustGo movement took to the streets in the Pretoria CBD where the ""national shutdown"" was supposed to kick off.
About 100 teachers marched through the streets of Durban demanding employment.
On 12 February, demonstrators in Dunoon, mostly women, pushed two shipping containers onto Usasadza Street in protest over a lack of toilets.
Protesters handed a memorandum of grievances to Dr Sipho Nzimande of the Department of Higher Education and Training in KwaDlangezwa, KZN.
In Uitengahe, about 30 parents picketed at the Department of Education's district office, demanding the appointment of four permanent teachers at the school.
University of Fort Hare management and student leaders were locked in a meeting as students protested at East London campus.

Following a Xenophobia attack in Rustenburg, police fired rubber bullets and teargas to disperse a crowd of protesters who complained after the police took the victim away. Protesters barricaded the road near the taxi rank with burning objects and rubble and pelted the police with stones.
In Rustenburg, a Nigerian man was stabbed and doused with petrol in a suspected Xenophobia attack. The man survived.
Pupils at Dudumayo Senior Secondary School in Mqanduli have blocked access to their school for more than a week in protest against the departure of their school principal.
In Uitenhage, hundreds of Gamble Street High School pupils were locked out of school by irate parents due to an ongoing teacher shortage.
The community of Makoxa village in Giyani recently blocked and trashed streets in in protest.
A man was burnt to death in his vehicle following an attack near Ga-Mokgotho village in Limpopo.
A protest was reported at Atok, about 80km north-east of Burgersfort. No further details.
Protests erupted along Jakes Gerwel and the R300 in Mitchell's plain.
Hundreds of residents and former municipal workers in Pietermaritzburg marched to the offices of Msunduzi Local Municipality on Monday to protest against alleged corruption in the municipality.
An event was briefly disrupted by protesters from Right2Know (R2K) and the LGBTI community in Ghallager Convention Centre in Midrand.
A group of mineworkers staged a demonstration outside a court in Pretoria to protest against being excluded from the weekend's consultations between the President and Chamber of Mines.
Hundreds of backyard dwellers had tried to invade land in Phillipi and burnt tyres which was followed by clashes between the police and backyard dwellers.
Protesting staff gathered at the Steve Biko Campus at DUT in ongoing protest action at the college.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: About 200 employees of the National Student Financial Aid Scheme (NSFAS) with NEHAWU protested outside its offices in Wynberg, Cape Town, demanding higher salaries and other improvements.
A group of unemployed teachers staged a picket outside the department of education's headquarters in Zwelitsha, demanding jobs.
Protests erupted outside a school in Seaview when hundreds of pupils stormed a neighbouring property. Large bricks and shattered glass lay across the road.
Hundreds of members of the National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) marched at the Optimum Coal mine in Middelburg, owned by the Gupta family, to express their concerns about its viability.
A crowd of more than 100 students marched on the DUT's city campus in Durban.
Clashes between locals and police in Marikana, with police using stun grenades and rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.
A group of farm workers, mostly women, demonstrated at the gates to the Stellenbosch Wine Festival.
At least one vehicle was set alight and a supermarket was looted by protesters in Gugulethu, Cape Town.
A case of public violence was opened after a group of violent protesters blockaded the N2 highway near Shaka's Head, outside Ballito. They pelted passing cars with stones.
Two primary schools in Gugulethu were forced to close for a day after violent land invasion protests flared up again. The highway was temporarily closed by protesters who burned tyres and rubble
Steen Vuilla housing tenants, who say they have been experiencing constant threats of eviction for nearly a year, began a hunger picket in the CBD of Cape Town
Members of the Engcobo community in the Eastern Cape, still reeling from the bloody events, gathered outside the magistrate's court to oppose bail for 12 suspects.
Striking staff at the Durban University of Technology (DUT) received a boost of support after a group of students marched in solidarity with them to their vice-chancellor's office.

Outside the Witbank Magistrate's Court in Mpumalanga, a crowd protested and tried to kill traditional healer. Police were forced to fire rubber bullets to disperse the crowd, which resulted in a stampede. Some of the protesters threw rocks and other objects at the police.
After allegedly being forced off Mayibuye buses by taxi drivers last week, Khwetyana (Mdantsane) residents staged a march and forced their way onto the buses.
The Democratic Alliance in KwaZulu-Natal picketed outside the Royal Showgrounds in Pietermaritzburg.
In Nyanga, angry parents, pupils and residence took part in a protest outside Mvula Primary School in support of its former principal.
North West police used rubber bullets to disperse residents from Popo Molefe informal settlement near Rustenburg.
Classes were suspended at the University of Zululand in Ongoye, KwaDlangezwa as students allegedly set alight a police vehicle during a protest over meal allowances not paid out.
About 1000 pupils and their parents protested outside Nkululeko Secondary School in KwaNobuhle after contractors stopped working on a revamp of an old school building.
Several hundred learners from Bulumko Secondary School in Khayelitsha marched to the Western Cape Education Department (WCED) to demand more teachers at Khayelitsha schools.
About 500 ANC members protested outside the party's provincial headquarters, Calata House, in King William's Town.
Two Walter Sisulu University students were rushed to hospital after they were hit by what is believed to be stray bullets by security guards on the Mthatha campus turned violent.
Two South African Social Security Agency vehicles were torched while other cars were stoned during sporadic incidents of violent protests in Gugulethu over land occupation.
Protesters dumped rubbish on the Mangosuthu Highway in Umlazi causing traffic delays. The protesters had dispersed but the refuse was still strewn across the road
More than 150 Philippi High School pupils marched to Parliament to voice their concerns over conditions at their school and a shortage of teachers.
Property destruction: The home Two law enforcement officers was gutted in a suspected petrol bomb attack.
About 60 tenants facing eviction together with supporters of Reclaim the City, picketed outside the home of the Mayoral Committee Member for Transport and Urban Development in Newlands.
Kwanomzamo informal settlement in Humansdorp erupted as hundreds of residents, fed up with using bucket toilets, took to the streets, setting a library and community hall alight.
A former ANC councillor and current provincial executive committee member was shot dead while his wife was wounded in what the family believe was a hit in Crossroads.
Hundreds of security guards took to the streets of the capital to march against exploitation, poor working conditions and unlawful deductions from salaries.
Angry students overturned a car with their bare hands causing substantial damage at Buffalo City College's John Knox Bokwe campus.
At least 10 men were arrested for public violence following a protest in Mfuleni, Cape Town.
Two separate groups of people burnt houses and cars in apparent vigilante mob attacks at Burgersfort and Tzaneen.
Two separate groups of people burnt houses and cars in apparent vigilante mob attacks at Burgersfort and Tzaneen.
