In protest, students have stopped classes at the University of KwaZulu-Natal (UKZN), Pietermaritzburg campus. Police chased a group of protesters. Teargas was used to disperse the protesters.
The Metrorail newly-launched train that was stoned at Pretoria Station by angry commuters.

Protest action along Harry Gwala (Spine) Road led to the closure of the road during peak hour traffic. Traffic had to be diverted back down the lower end of the road, while Metro Police cleared branches, smouldering logs and other debris from the road.
Communities living in the mining area of Northam Platinum mine in Limpopo braved the rain to hand over a memorandum to the mine during a protest.
University management resolved to close the Butterworth campuses indefinitely following the outbreak of violent protests that damaged property and put lives at risk.
University management resolved to close the Buffalo City campuses indefinitely following the outbreak of violent protests that damaged property and put lives at risk.
Scores of Tshwane University of Technology students and Uber and Taxify vehicles took to the streets of the pretoria demanding justice for a murdered Taxify driver.
In the Free State, a tent erected as a temporary voting station in Harrismith was burnt down, another was stolen in Kroonstad by residents and a third was demolished and destroyed by residents.
In the Free State, a tent was stolen in Kroonstad by residents and another was demolished and destroyed by residents.
An African National Congress (ANC) elections coordinator in the village of Imfume in KwaZulu-Natal and two community members were shot dead.

On 10 March residents of Olievenhoutbosch invaded a land that they demarcated themselves by putting up shacks. The police fired rubber bullets and teargas at the people who retaliated by pelting them with stones.

Several voting stations around the country were disrupted by community protests this weekend and could not open on time. The IEC revealed that some of the affected areas included Katlehong in Gauteng, where seven voting stations were disrupted by protests over the installation of prepaid electricity meters. Service delivery protests in parts of Wonderkop in North West, QwaQwa and Harrismith in the Free State, also derailed voter registration. A tent, used as a temporary voting station, was burnt down in Harrismith while another was stolen in Kroonstad. In Vuwani in the Vhembe district, Limpopo, at least six voting registration stations were forced to operate outside school gates after disgruntled community members refused to allow the IEC to conduct registrations inside the schools. A local electoral supervisor, who wished to remain anonymous, told Sowetan that she arrived on Saturday morning to find the gates of Tshivhulana Primary School locked.

On 12 Marcg the KwaDukuza Municipality has appealed for calm as it deals with persistent electricity cuts that sparked violent protests: a security guard on duty at a nearby business premises was shot in the back.
On 12 March two people were shot during a riot on the R102 near Groutville on the KwaZulu-Natal north coast
On 12 March students at Buffalo City campus in Southernwood protested. They boycotted classes at other three Walter Sisulu University campuses including in Butterworth and Mthatha.

On 13 March the KwaDukuza Municipality has appealed for calm as it deals with persistent electricity cuts that sparked violent protests: according to IPSS Medical Rescue, a protester was shot in the leg.
On 14 March the advocacy group called Speak the Truth protested against alse prophets and pastors extorting money from the poor and abusing vulnerable women.

On 14 March, a security guard shot dead a man fishing at a farm in Eshowe area in Kwazulu Natal. After the incident, angry residents barricaded the R66 with burning tyres and rubble, and burned the farmer's house at the Gqobhokani farm, his sugarcane plantation as well as at least two neighbouring plantations.
On 14 March an alleged robber was assaulted by at least 30 pupils after he allegedly mugged a female pupil of her cellphone with a knife in Verulam, north of Durban

On 14 March, a security guard shot dead a man fishing at a farm in Eshowe area in Kwazulu Natal. After the incident, angry residents barricaded the R66 with burning tyres and rubble, and burned the farmer's house at the Gqobhokani farm, his sugarcane plantation as well as at least two neighbouring plantations.
On 15 March 2018, rubber bullets were fired into a crowd to disperse people evicting foreigners from city-owned houses. 31 people were arrested for public violence. [size=at least 31]

On 15 March, Jacksonville residents burnt tyres and barricaded the road in the informal settlement and also threatened to burn tyres outside the home of the ward councillor, due to a range of service delivery complaints.

Around 15 March 2018 (month of), a crowd attacked foreign nationals in Zwelihle (Overberg, Western Cape), during demonstrations over housing and substandard service delivery. The crowd looted and burned down some of the shops. [size=no reports]
On 16 March, a mob severely beat several people alleged to have tried to abduct a schoolgirld in Johannesburg.
On 16 March, a brutal murder prompted a planned anti-crime protest by the more than 900 pupils at Lungisa High School in KwaDwesi where the victim worked.
On 18 March, members of the Federation for Radical Economic Transformation disrupted the disciplinary hearing of municipality deputy.

On 20 March, an office belonging to the South African National Roads SOL Limited was burnt down by protesters and four employees at the Mvoti Toll Plaza were treated for injuries. The protest stems from a labour dispute between one of its contractors and its employees has caused traffic disruption close to some of its toll plazas.

On 19 March, protests over electricity cuts turned violent as the protesters blocked roads with burning tires and trees. Police intervened to disperse them. An unknown person driving shot a protester in the leg and a security guard in the back.
On 19 March, residents of B section - in KwaMashu, north of Durban - have blockaded roads with burning tyres and rubble following the murder of a taxi driver at the nearby KwaMashu Hostel.
On 19 March, during a service delivery protest, a 62-year-old man was reportedly shot dead after police dispersed an angry crowd with rubber bullets.
On 19 March, about 500 students of KwaZulu-Natal University demonstrated against living conditions and security issues at their places of accommodation.

On 20 March, the highway was temporarily closed - and then reopened - near the suburb of Dunoon as protesters took to the streets. A truck ran into trouble across the highway while trying to avoid protesters and was engulfed in flames.
On 20 March, communities of Ntshawini and Glenhills in Groutville continued to protest by blocking roads with burning tyres demanding that KDM authorities come and address them.
On 20 March, the South African National Taxi Council was joined by other taxi associations as they took to the streets of Ekurhuleni in protest over the delayed bus rapid transport system.
On 20 March, government officials, including the mayor, were forced out of their offices by a mob, following the killing of a protester, in Keiskammahoek.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: On 20 March, NEHAWU embarked on a protest action to highlight the crisis in the Department of Health and the high levels of corruption. The march was allegedly marred by intimidation from police and a crowd of hooligans.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; DENOSA: Democratic Nursing Organisation of South Africa; HOSPERSA: Health and Other Service Personnel Trade Union of South Africa; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: On 20 March, hundreds of National Education, Health and Allied Workers' Union (Nehawu), the Democratic Nursing Organisation of SA (Denosa) and the Health and Other Services Personnel Trade Union of SA (Hospersa) marched to the provincial legislature in Mahikeng demanding that Mahumapelo resigns from his position as a premier within 14 days.
On 22 March, thousands of residents marched to the Civic Centre in Cape Town. Activists demanded steps to advance the human rights of residents ot access decent housing, land and security.
On 22 March, residents in the Kleinmond area protested as their shacks were being demolished. Protesters tried to throw stones at oncoming vehicles.

column7: NUPSAW: National Union of Public Service and Allied Workers; Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: On 22 March, about 80 community healthcare workers and members of NUPSAW marched from Keizersgracht to the provincial legislature in Cape Town demanding to be integrated to the public service by the Department of Health
On 24 March, residents of Molelema village burnt down a local primary school, as they demand roads and houses.

On 24 March, running battles between protesters and police around land grabbing. A satellite police station, a municipal building, a library and a vehicle belonging to law enforcement officers were torched.

On 26 March, police arrested about 30 people after violent protests in which demonstrators tried to occupy state-owned land and set a police station on fire. Police fired tear gas and rubber bullets at rioters who looted shops, vandalized buildings and threw stones at vehicles.
On 26 March, residents in ward 19 barricaded Montshiwa Road in Galeshewe with large boulders, a tree stump and empty buckets as the city-wide water shutdown entered its fourth day.
On 26 March, about 100 Imizamo Yethu residents protested outside the police station in Hout Bay. Residents want electricity, water and sanitation
On 27 March, dozens of Water Sisulu University students at Majestic residence in Southernwood were seen lying on their mattresses outside the building as a form of protest against power cuts.

On 28 March, students at the Durban University of Technology demanded the closure of the campus until their financial aid benefits have been paid out. They allegedly threw stones in front of the main administration offices in the Steve Biko Campus, while police used stun grenades to disperse the students.
On 29 March, a delivery protest near Humansdorp blocked traffic on the N2 and R106 and caused huge backlogs.
On 29 March, a small group of people claiming to be Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) members used a vehicle to block the gates at New Brighton Clinic in Port Elizabeth
On 29 March, about 200 protesters took to the streets and burnt tyres in Thornhill.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: On 30 march, Nehawu staged a protest in front of the department's national office and complained to the Human Rights Commission.
On 1 April, a man was killed during a mob justice attack while he was in his home in Stellenbosch.
On 1 April 2018, residents attacked foreign nationals and set abandoned houses and shops on fire in Mamelodi, Tshwane (Gauteng). No reports on injuries. [size=no report]
On 2 April, residents of Ntuzuma, north of Durban, blockaded Thendele Road with burning tyres, branches and rocks to demand speed bumps.
On 2 April, protesters barricaded the route heading towards the Mooi River toll plaza and began looting from burning delivery trucks stuck in traffic.
On 2 April, six people died and several were seriously injured when a petrol bomb was thrown at a bus transporting them to work at a mine outside Burgersfort.
On 2 April, a group of MK Military veterans protested over jobs near the mayor's office in Durban. Police intervened to disperse them.

On 5 April, a protest took place on the road between Port Elizabeth and Uitenhage over land. The protesters threw stones at police officers demolishing plots in the area and blocked several roads with burning tires and rubble.
On 6 April, at Durban High Court, hundreds of ANC marched from the King Dinizulu Park in support of former president Jacob Zuma.
On 6 April, members of the ANC in Roodepoort protested outside a man's house to denounce a post he made while drunk.
On 6 April, the community in Benoni barricaded several roads with burning tyres and rocks.

On 6 April 2018, about 15 people picketed outside the offices of the National Prosecuting Authority (NPA) and the office of the Western Cape Police Commissioner to demand justice for the murders of Mthunzi 'Ras' Zuma and Philela Gilwa. [size=15].

On 6 April, some 300 residents of Port Elizabeth set up burning barricades across the M14 at Izinyoka, Kwadwesi leading to Kleinskool, as well as the R75 in protest at the demolition of shacks. Protesters threw stones at incoming police forces.
On 6 April, nurses at the Karl Bremer Hosptial protested outside the provincial legistature in Cape Town.
On 7 April, a protest including members of the Ban Animal Trading was held at a Pretoria east hotel over the alleged maltreatment of feral cats and claims of canned lion hunting.
On 8 April , about 200 residents took to the streets of Manenberg.
On 8 April, protesters took to the streets in an informal settlement in Chatsworth and proceeded to burn tyres as anger ensued over the death of a child.
On 9 April, nursing students at a college in Johannesburg protested and sang outside their classroom over the lack of learning materials.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: On 10 April, government employees with NEHAWU protested in the CBD of Cape Town.
On 10 April, protest action took place when residents of Danville and Lomanyaneng (Mahikeng) picketed in the North West province.
On 10 April, during the court appearance of protesters, hundred of people came out and protested in support in Hermanus.
On 10 April , residents of Moutse in Groblersdal protested against a decision not to renew a HIV-prevention contract.
On 10 April, residents began a protest and prevented students from entering over the lack of transportation in Winterveld near Pretoria.
On 11 April, parents of a primary school in Durban protested after all learners failed their exams.
On 11 April, residents continued a protest and prevented students from entering over the lack of transportation in Winterveld near Pretoria.
On the week of 8 April, students barricaded a street with rocks and tyres during a student protest in Pietermaritzburg.
During the week of 8 April, members of the community protested and damaged property in Finale village near Hoedspruit outside Phalaborwa.The reasons for the protest were not reported.
On 12 April, parents protested otuside a school in a suburb of East London over the lack of school transport.
On 12 April, a group of 150 residents protested and blocked the streets with burning tyres and rubble in an informal settlement in Port Elizabeth.
On 12 April, activist demonstrared outside the Strand Magistrates' court over the release of a murderer.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; SAFTU: South African Federation of Trade Unions
column17: On 12 April , COSATU and SAFTU protested outside parliament over the water crisis.
On 12 April, a petrol bomb was thrown and numerous vehicles damaged during a political meeting in Port Elizabeth when residents disrupted the meeting.
On 13 April, municipal workers protested in the CBD of Pretoria dumping rubbish on the streets.
On 13 April, outside parliament in Cape Town, a memorandum was handed over during a protest over water management.
On 13 April, in an informal township outside Umhlanga, residents took to the street in anger over the lack of electricity. Tyres were burnt in the protest and vehicles were burnt.
On 13 April, violentclashes erupted between police and taxi drivers in Mthatha. No casualties were reported.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: On 13 April, NUMSA members protested outside a steel factory in Nigel, Ekurhuleni

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Government of South Africa (1994-)
column17: On 14 April 2018, EFF leaders and a MP representing the EFF are accused of assaulting a police officer during the state funeral of a political activist at the Orlando Stadium in Soweto (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng). The reason for the assault was not reported. [size=at least 3]
On 16 April, students marched to the offices of the TVET campus in Pietermaritzburg in protest.
On 16 April, a man was killed in the infamous Glebelands hostel where political killings are commonplace.
On 16 April, protesters took to the streets and burnt tyres to block roads as demanded proper housing and land in Vrygrond, Cape Town.
On 17 April, community members in Inanda, Durban protested after the stabbing of a student.
On 17 April, violent protests continued in Vrygrond, Cape Town over the allocation of housing.
On 17 April, students protested at the TVET campus in Pietermaritzburg. Police used rubber bullets and teargas to disperse the student. The vehicle of the principle was damaged in the protest.
During the week of the 16 to 21 April, liquor store members protested in Atteridgeville as they want the president of the association removed.
On 18 April, protester blocked a road in Hammanskraal, demanding access to housing, water, sanitation and better roads. They later clashed with police who opened fire on them.

On 18 April 2018, residents took to the streets in Mahikeng (Ngaka Modiri Molema, North-West) to demand the resignation of the province's leader. Roads were blocked, and tires and vehicles were set on fire. Shops and several tuck shops in the area belonging to both foreign nationals and South African citizens were looted. More than 1000 foreign nationals were displaced in the area. Police fired rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. Demonstrations were registered until 21 April. [size=no report]
On 19 April, residents of Seaview in the Eastern Cape protested and disrupted a meeting. They were angry over housing issues in the community.

On 19 April 2018, residents took to the streets in Mahikeng for the second day (Ngaka Modiri Molema, North-West) to demand the resignation of the province's leader. Roads were blocked, and tires and vehicles were set on fire. Shops and several tuck shops in the area belonging to both foreign nationals and South African citizens were looted. More than 1000 foreign nationals were displaced in the area. Police fired rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. Demonstrations were registered until 21 April. [size=no report]
On 19 April, protests in Mahikeng over the removal of the premier spread to the town of Wolmaransstad.
On 19 April, protests in Mahikeng over the removal of the premier spread to the town of Makwassie.
On 19 April, students protested outside a school in Beacon Bay. They were protesting over the lack of a science teacher.
On 20 April, the African Disabled People's Movement (ADPM) held a march against lack of compliance with the Employment Equity Act at the City of Tshwane's municipal offices in Pretoria.

column16: MSF; News24 (South Africa); African News Agency; Xenowatch
column17: On 20 April 2018, residents took to the streets in Mahikeng for the third day (Ngaka Modiri Molema, North-West) to demand the resignation of the province's leader. Roads were blocked, and tires and vehicles were set on fire. Shops and several tuck shops in the area belonging to both foreign nationals and South African citizens were looted. More than 1000 foreign nationals were displaced in the area. Police fired rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. Demonstrations were registered until 21 April. [size=no report]
On 20 April, Pro-Zuma (former President) and ANC member gathered and protested in Durban calling for fresh elections within the ANC

column7: FEDUSA: Federation of Unions of South Africa
column17: On 20 April, FEDUSA picketed outside the AGM of Steinhoff over irregularity and fraud.

On 21 April 2018, residents took to the streets in Mahikeng (Ngaka Modiri Molema, North-West) to demand the resignation of the province's leader. Roads were blocked, and tires and vehicles were set on fire. Shops and several tuck shops in the area belonging to both foreign nationals and South African citizens were looted. Many foreign nationals were displaced. More than 1000 foreign nationals were displaced in the area. Police fired rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. Demonstrations were registered from 18 April. A person died during the demonstration and 23 people were arrested. [size=at least 23]
On 22 April, in Pietermaritzburg. Residents protested and burned tyres. The protest was over housing and infrastructure.

On 22 April 2018, a Nigerian national was chased, set on fire, and killed by a group of people in Rustenburg (Bojanala Platinum, North-West). The group intercepted the victim, demanding to know if he had drugs; the victim informed that he had a shop, but was still chased. The police suggested that officers had tried to stop the attack, however this was not supported by witnesses. [size=no report]
On 23 April, Keiskammahoek protesters torched an old ANC constituency office in ongoing service delivery protests.

On 23 April, violent protest continued in the province of North West, this time in the town of Taung. Protesters looted several shops, set buildings alight and attacked police. A boy died in the violence.

On 23 April, residents in Durban took to the streets and protested the destruction of homes in an informal settlement, setting some property alight. Police fired rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. One injured.

On 23 April, on the road leading to Vryburg, protesters could be seen stoning passing cars and using slingshots to hit police officers. A police nyala later entered the area and used rubber bullets and teargas to disperse the mob.
On 23 April, construction work on the multi-billionrand Oceans uMhlanga project came to a standstill after more than 100 protesters blocked the entrance to the site.
On 24 April, protests broke out in the town of Jan Kempdorp in the Northern Cape. The protest was regarding service delivery. Protesters set fire to a police van and torched a shop.
On 24 April, protests broke out in the town of Warrenton in the Northern Cape. The protest was regarding service delivery. Protesters set fire to a police van and torched a shop.
On 24 April, shops were looted in ongoing violent protests in Klerkdorp.
On 24 April, shops were looted in ongoing violent protests in Potchefstroom.
On 24 April, rocks shattered glass and a tank in Delaeyville in ongoing protest. Cars were stoned and police were attacked. Police used rubber bullets and tear gas.
On 24 April, stores were looted and a building set alight in ongoing violence in the North West, this time in Stella. Police were also attacked.
On 24 April, Keiskammahoek protesters torched their public library late in ongoing service delivery protests.

On 24 April, striking workers trashed a hospital in Parkton, Johannesburg. Police used rubber bullets to disperse them. Some Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) supporters were also among those who had to be expelled.

column7: SAFTU: South African Federation of Trade Unions
column17: On 25 April, thousands of SAFTU members protested over the minimum wage of R20 in Durban.

column7: SAFTU: South African Federation of Trade Unions
column17: On 25 April, thousands of SAFTU members protested over the minimum wage of R20 in Port Elizabeth.

column7: SAFTU: South African Federation of Trade Unions
column17: On 25 April, thousands of SAFTU members protested over the minimum wage of R20 in Cape Town.

column7: SAFTU: South African Federation of Trade Unions
column17: On 25 April, thousands of SAFTU members protested over the minimum wage of R20 in Johannesburg.
On 25 April, protests took palce in Alexandria in JHB over service delivery. There were no reports of violence.
On 25 April, protests took place in Midrand, JHB and handed over a memorantum regarding economic exclusion and empowerment to the authorities at the Mall of Africa.
On 25 April, protests took place in Zandspruit in JHB over wages.
On 25 April, protesters took to the streets in Pelican Park (Muizenberg) and attempted to disrupt the traffic. They blocked roads and police used tear gas to disperse the protesters.
On 25 April, a peaceful protest took place in Phumlani in Cape town. No signs of violence were reported.
On 25 April, protesters took to the streets in Sir Lowry's pass. They threw stones and burnt tyres. The cause of the protest was unknown.
On the week of the 25th April, protesters took to the street in Hartswater and looted stores.
On the week of the 25th April, protesters took to the street in Pampierstad and looted stores.
On 26 April, two cases of malicious damage to property were opened at Colenso police station in KZN after two trucks were torched by angry community members.
On 28 April, a bus carrying international tourists who had been on a wine tour was stoned as it headed to the Cape Town International Airport.

On 29 April 2018, demonstrators took to the streets in Mooi River over the employment of foreigners as truck drivers. Some 35 trucks were set alight and stones were thrown as police got involved. A total of 54 people were arrested. [size=no report]
On 30 April, protest action continued in Mooi River. Stones were reportedly thrown at cars
On 30 April, protesters blocked the Golden Highway in Zakariyya Park, Johannesburg, with burning tyres, rocks and branches
On 30 April, a sports clubhouse was torched at Seawinds (Vrygrond) during protests.
On 30 April, a municipal building was set alight in Macassar in an arson attack.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: On 30 April, hundreds of waste management workers with South African Municipal Workers Union occupied the streets of Pretoria in a march against the municipality to use outsourced service providers.
On 1 May, stone-throwing protesters briefly caused the closure of the N2 in Cape Town, near Macassar.
On 1 May, a driver was attacked by protesters in Vrygrond. The driver sustained injuries while protesters threw petrol bombs and stones.

On 2 May, Khayamnandi Extension residents from Ward 41 in Despatch launched a service delivery protest, blocking roads with rocks and burning tyres. The residents demanded that the municipality build them proper toilets and housing and supply clean water.
On 2 May, campuses at Nelson Mandela University (NMU) were shut down due to mass student protests organised by SASCO.
On 2 May, police fired rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse a stone-throwing and petrol-bombing crowd who were protesting in Ginsberg, Kings Williams Town.
On 2 May, protests took place in Mitchells Plain over housing issues. 11 people were arrested as protesters burnt debris and blocked roads.
On 2 May, protesters used burning tyres and rubble to barricade the N12 near Eldorado Park and Freedom Park in protest over elecriticity.
On 2 May, four vehicles were set alight and several businesses were looted in a violent protest in Kuyga, Port Elizabeth.
On 2 May, residents of informal settlements put down mattresses outside the Civic Centre in Cape Town, together with the Social Justice Coalition, to protest the City's 'illegal evictions'.
On 2 May, in Soweto, several roads have been barricaded with burning tyres and rocks as residents protested.
On 2 May, arsonists are suspected of setting alight the Great Kei municipal offices in Komga and torching two municipal trucks.
On 2 May, residents protested in Lehae in which communities barricaded roads with burning tyres and rubble.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: On 2 May, at a hospital in Klerksdorp, protesters stormed the hospital and forced staff out as part of a strike by NEHAWU.

column7: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union; NATU: National Teachers Union
column17: On 3 May, hundreds of Grade R teachers, who are members of SADTU and NATU, protested outside the KZN legislature in Pietermaritzburg.
On 3 May, thousands of students have marched to the Durban Magistrate's Court where a man accused of murdering his student girlfriend is appearing. The accused faces a charge of murder.
On 3 May, followers of a famous pastor protested outside Gupta-linked 24-hour television news channel Afro Worldview in Midrand, where they demanded that his canned church programme be reinstated.
On 4 May, the N2 in Cape Town was closed near Macassar following violent protests. Protesters threw stones at vehicles and blocked the road
On 6 May, several roads in the Protea Glen, Johannesburg were barricaded with burning trees and rocks, and police fired rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse protesters trying to occupy the land
On 7 May, police fired rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse a group of protesters that barricaded the R559 Randfontein Road in Protea Glen, south of Johannesburg in a second day of protests.
On 7 May, supporters of the Eastern Cape premier (ANC members) marched on party headquarters Luthuli House, Johannesburg, to protest against the unruly elective conference that put Mabuyane in power.
On 7 May, police fired rubber bullets and a teargas and arrested 17 residents in Khayelithsa when they tried to protest against demolitions.

On 7 May, police used rubber bullets to disperse protesters in Rustenburg in the North West as residents took to the streets demanding low-cost housing, barricading the R565 road linking Rustenburg and Sun City with burning tyres, rocks and tree logs at Boshoek near Ledig.
On 7 May, an African National Congress (ANC) regional party leader was killed at his house in Margate.
On 8 May, about 100 people with disabilities in the OR Tambo district took to the streets of Mthatha and brought traffic to a standstill, demanding that closed taxi ranks be reopened.
On 8 May, members of EFF members marched alongside the workers and delivered a memorandum of demands to a coal mine in Middleburg.
On 8 May, protest action broke out along the R55, near Sunderland Ridge in Pretoria. A road closed off with burning objects.
On 8 May, the three campuses of PE College came to a standstill as students locked the gates, demanding financial assistance equal to that given to their university counterparts.
On 8 May, a group of about 200 protesters blocked the entrance to the harbour in Durban, resulting in trucks not being able to get into the port and staff not being able to enter at N-Shed.
On 9 May, protesters were quickly dispersed with teargas and stun grenades by police after they protested on the N2 at Colchester over demolitions. One person arrested.
On 9 May, former private security guards at the Steve Biko Academic Hospital in Pretoria, who were dismissed following allegations of misconduct, protested outside the health facility.
On 9 May, municipal workers blockaded roads in the Ladysmith CBD and allegedly assaulted a municipal official after embarking on a wildcat strike.
On 9 May, about 70 people picketed outside the Pan African Parliament in Midrand, calling for the Director of UNAIDS to step down.
On 9 May, in ongoing protest action in the North West Province, a handful of protesters barricaded roads with burning tyres in Montshioa (Mahikeng).
On 9 May, protesters blocked healthcare workers from entering Tshepong Hospital in Klerksdorp as protests continue in the North West following the possible resignation of Premier Supra Mahumapelo.

On 10 May, EFF supporters protested outside the Embassy of the Kingdom of Morocco in Arcardia against the illegal occupation of Western Sahara has started with the crowd chanting and dancing to Struggle songs.
On 10 May, protesters marched in Wolmaraans Street in central Johannesburg and burnt barricades of trash, causing serious traffic delays.
On 10 May, protesters in Mahikeng called on all shop owners who are foreign nationals to leave the province.
On 10 May, one man was killed when a mosque in Verulam, KwaZulu-Natal came under attack by unknown assailants. Police found a bomb in the mosque three days later.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; NUM: National Union of Mineworkers
column17: On 10 May, COSATU and National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) members picketed outside the Chamber of Mines in Johannesburg's city centre. The several dozen protesters demanded better safety precautions for miners.
On 11 May, rival groups of DA protesters gathered outside the high court in Cape Town ahead of former Cape Town Mayor Patricia de Lille's bid to interdict the DA from appointing a new mayor.

On 13 May, a DA councillor in Vrygrond, Cape Town has her car torched by residents in violent protests in which protestors have also thrown stones at other vehicles and petrol bombed buildings. Protesters were angry over the demolition of shacks in the area.
During the week of 13 to 19 May, a dozen protesters have camped out on the veranda of the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries offices in Port Elizabeth.
On 14 May, teaching was disrupted at Zamokuhle Primary School in D Section, KwaMashu, Durban, after angry parents locked the school gate
On 14 May, a vehicle that was allegedly stolen and burnt violent protests in Eshowe. Residents also burnt a farmhouse and allegedly stole a vehicle.

On 14 May, a fight between members of the EFF and those of a newly formed organisation calling itself the Radical Economic Transformation Forum (RETF) has left at least three people, including a councillor, injured in Polokwane.

On 14 May, protests have flared up again in the Capricorn area (Vrygrond) in Muizenberg, Cape Town over the destruction of houses. A restaurant was also petrol bombed and bricks were hurled through its windows while patrons were inside

On 15 May, protests took place in Port Elizabeth after Israeli soldiers killed over 50 Palestinians in the Gaza Strip. The Gaza protests were against the moving of the United States Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

On 15 May, protests took place in Cape Town after Israeli soldiers killed over 50 Palestinians in the Gaza Strip. The Gaza protests were against the moving of the United States Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

column7: SAFTU: South African Federation of Trade Unions
column17: On 15 May, Zwelinzima Vavi' the SA Federation of Trade Unions secretary general' and members of his union held a sit in at Imperial Cargo's premises in Bellville,Cape Town.

On 15 May, protests took place in Johannesburg after Israeli soldiers killed over 50 Palestinians in the Gaza Strip. The Gaza protests were against the moving of the United States Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.
During the week of 13 to 19 May, a former ANC ward councillor was shot dead in Pietermaritzburg.
During the week of 13 to 19 May, a member of the Inkatha Freedom Party was shot dead in Ulundi.

On 16 May, protesters gathered at the corner of Main and Eloff Street in the Johannesburg CBD preventing the Metro buses at Ghandi Square from operating as they protested over poor transportation services.
On 16 May, EFF members in the City of Tshwane stormed into a mayoral committee meeting in protest, demanding the immediate removal of the chief of staff whose qualifications were in question.
On 16 May, police used live ammunition on protesting pupils from Thuto-Kitso Technical School in Fochville.
On 16 May, service delivery protests took place in Ngcobo. No reports of violence were reported on the first day.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: On 16 May, NEHAWU members embarked on a march demanding better working conditions; improved salaries; and a stop to corruption in Mahikeng.
On 17 May, police fired rubber bullets to prevent a group of protesters from entering the Abagold abalone plant in Hermanus. The protest was over land issues.
On 17 May, six wagons of a freight train carrying steel coils were torched by a group of protesters between Orkney and Leeudoringstad in the North West. The motivation of the protest was unknown.
On 17 May, protests continued in Ngcobo but no violence was reported.
On 18 May, at the Kusile Power Station in Mpumalanga, a violent protest by employees of SGB took place.

On 18 May, a new group of Hermanus protesters took to the streets, littering roads and setting fires, demanding that they too be given land. Stun grenades were fired by police to move protesters who were setting up a burning barricade at the turn-off to Schulphoek Road.
On 19 May, about 150 people marched to the Delft police station, Cape Town, demanding that police take action in the murder case of local man.
On 20 May, nine students were treated for minor bruises and cuts after students clashed with the guards as students accused guards of harassing students.
On 20 May, in Parkwood (near Vrygrond) a crowd of protesters threw petrol bombs and also hurled stones at police officers in protests over housing.
On 21 May, academic activities were disrupted as students protested to try and have a security company removed.

column7: ABMSM: Abahlali Basemjondolo Shack Dwellers Movement
column17: On 21 May, about 200 protesters affiliated to the Abahlali movement blockaded roads around the bellair area with burning tyres and tree logs in protest over the lack of basic services.
On 21 May, parents shut down Empumalanga Primary School in Motherwell in Port Elizabeth in a protest over escalating vandalism in the school.
On 21 May, violent protests broke out over housing in Vrygrond in Cape Town. A crowd of people threw stones at the police who retaliated by using tear-gas and rubber bullets.
On 21 May, hundreds of residents rallied, burnt tyres and debris in Bo-Kaap over the issue of gentrification in the CBD.
On 21 May, the University of Limpopo in Polokwane decided to postpone examinations schedule as a result of disruptions and protests by students and workers protesting over outsourcing.
On 21 May, dozens of angry pupils froma school gathered outside the Department of Education district offices in Umbilo demanding answers about alleged corruption at their school.
On 21 May, a farewell event for the outgoing UCT vice-chancellor was cut short when a group of students and workers interrupted proceedings and staged a protest at the campus in Rondebosch.
On 21 May, residents of KwaZakhele in Port Elizabeth protest over housing issues and are unhappy with their local ward councillor. Protesters blockaded roads, stoned a bus and torched another.
On 22 May, drug users participated in a peaceful protest in Durban by the local branch of the SA Network of People Who Use Drugs (Sanpud).
On 22 May, a group of Kewtown residents, mostly members of the EFF, protested against a lack of housing and access to health services.
On 22 May, hundreds of residents rallied, burnt tyres and debris in Bo-Kaap over the issue of gentrification in the CBD.

On 23 May, a portion of Robert Sobukwe Road near Cape Town International Airport has been closed as a result of protest action (unknown reasons for the protest). A traffic light was set alight, while burning tyres were placed across the road and passing vehicles were stoned.
On 23 May, protesters set the house of Koster Mayor alight in protest over service delivery. Earlier in the day, protesters blocked the roads with burning tyres and objects.
On 23 May, hundreds of residents rallied, burnt tyres and debris in Bo-Kaap over the issue of gentrification in the CBD.

On 23 May, protesters in Parkwood set tyres, couches, garbage bins and two tall trees on fire to protest against the demolitions of recently built shacks. The police formed their own line and shot rubber bullets when protesters approached. Police also used armoured vehicles, tear gas and water cannons to disperse the crowd. One police officer shot into Gerda Court residence courtyard after a protester threw rocks at him from beyond the walls.

column9: Government of South Africa (1994-); Women (South Africa)
column17: On 23 May, the Kgetlengrivier mayor's house, her guesthouse and another building belonging to her were set alight by protesters, who also made off with appliances. At least six cars were also torched. Protesters were angry over access to basic services.
On 23 May, hospital staff at Osindisweni Hospital in Verulum, have embarked on a strike and protest over poor working conditions, no medication and being understaffed among other complaints.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: On 23 May, Nehawu staged a lunchtime picket at the main campus of Sol Plaatje University, demanding that catering services be insourced.

column9: ABMSM: Abahlali Basemjondolo Shack Dwellers Movement
column17: On 24 May, the chairman of Abahlali was killed in the Mariannhill near Durban.

On 24 May, tenants of the popular 320 building on Dr Pixley Ka Seme (West Street, Durban) protested against the building's management alleging that building is in a run-down state, the toilets are filthy, the lifts do not work and the water in the taps is brown.
On 24 May, youth dodged stones at police over housing in Parkwood, police responded with teargas and rubber bullets.
On 24 May, 50 residents of Taiwan informal settlement in Khayelitsha marched to the ward councillor's office demanding decent living conditions and adequete services like housing and sanitation.
On 24 May, a councillor's house was torched and 14 people arrested during protests in Koster outside Rustenburg. Protesters were angry over access to basic services.
On 25 May, parents protested outside a school in Wentworth in a bid to get urgent attention for ""health hazard"" conditions and management problems at the school.
On 25 May, ANC supporters outside the Port Elizabeth Magistrate's Court held demonstration as a controversial councillor Andile Lungisa went to court.
On 25 May, backyarders from Philippi, Gugulethu and Mxenge protested in Philipi, burning tyres and blocking Govan Mbeki Road over housing issues.
On 25 May, 3 people were in the hostel at the Cremona Cheese Factory in Tshepisong west of Johannesburg when angry land occupiers set the building alight during protest. They were not hurt.

On 25 May, police have deployed additional public order police to the Zaaiplaas (Sehlakwane) area outside Groblersdal, after the school administration block at Leriane Secondary School was set alight. A police van was torched and a police officer injured.

On 26 May 2018, 43 foreign nationals from the Democratic Republic of Congo and Burundi, who were seeking asylum in the country, were violently expelled by community members in Mapoteng, Kathu, Northern Cape. [size=no report]
On 27 May, approximately 60 taxis in Chatsworth staged a protest following disputes over taxi routes. Police fired rubber bullets to disperse the unruly crowd.
On 27 May, several people, mostly dressed in EFF T-shirts and berets, picked up stones and threw them at each other in Pretoria. The dispute was over leadership contentions in the province.
On 28 May, parents continued to protest outside a school in Wentworth in a bid to get urgent attention for ""health hazard"" conditions and management problems at the school.

On 28 May, as many as 2 000 employees took to the streets at Walter Sisulu University after wage negotiations collapsed. Union leaders held gatherings on four campuses to report on the stalemate and to declare a full-blown protected strike.
On 28 May, police fired teargas and stun grenades at a crowd that gathered outside Chatsworth police station in Durban.

On 28 May, a protest started in Gansbaai after an alleged perlemoem poacher was injured while trying to jump into a rubber dingy to evade arrest. Some protesters had blocked the main road with a burning barricade.
On 28 May, a group of people also tried to barricade the R43, near Stanford, over what is believed to be a protest over land. Two people were arrested there for alleged public violence

On 28 May, in Hermanus about 2 000 people marched from Zwelihle ahead of the the court appearance a commmunity leader in the push to get a privately-owned plot signed over for development for backyarders.

On 28 May, police came under fire during a protest in Mitchells Plain, Cape Town, as the City called on land owners to take reasonable steps to protect their properties from invasion. Demonstrators started shooting at the police with one police car being hit by bullets.

On 28 May, 50 residents of EbuMnandini, an informal settlement in Tshepisong in the west of Johannesburg, protested outside Cremona Cheese Factory. The residents demanded that part of the factory's vacant land be given to the community for an informal settlement.

On 29 May, a road between Koster and Rustenburg in the North West was closed as fresh protests flared up in Koster over access to basic services Burning tyres were placed at the entrance of the Reagile township while rocks and rubble were used to block the road

On 29 May, shops mostly belonging to migrant nationals were looted, vandalised and torched when violence over land and housing flared up in Woodlands in Mitchells Plain. This followed running battles between protesters and police earlier in the day.
On 29 May, workers ranging from cleaners, technicians, drillers and truck drivers blocked streets in Johannesburg CBD. They were protesting over the poor quality of working equipment.
On 29 May, Ga-Rankuwa was affected by protest action. Roads were barricaded with stones and burning tyres by protesters as the protester took to the streets over service delivery.
On 29 May, Atteridgeville was host to protests and barricaded with stones and burning tyres by protesters. There are reports that in Atteridgeville the protests are related to taxi issues.

On 29 May, the M17 in Mabopane was affected by protest action. Roads were barricaded with stones and burning tyres by protesters as the protester took to the streets over service delivery. Metro police fired rubber bullets to dispense a crowd which was blocking the M17.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Health Workers (South Africa); Teachers (South Africa)
column17: On 30 May, a hospital in Johannesburg was barricaded and protesting NEHAWU workers set car tyres on fire blocking ambulance access, creating chaos for patients and reportedly disrupting operations.

On 30 May, Mohlakeng residents on the West Rand went on a rampage, blocking roads leading into the area, amid complaints that the Rand West City local municipality had failed to resolve their issues. Police fired rubber bullets in an attempt to disperse protesters while properties including the local police station, construction vehicles, an ATM machine and a library were damaged.
On 30 May, more than 200 members of the Women on Farms Project and farmworkers marched to the offices of Agri-Western Cape in Paarl.
On 30 May, ward committee members gathered and protested outside the Wool Board Exchange in Port Elizabeth demanding higher stipends and better equipment
On 30 May, in Centurion , thousands of workers fled as private security guards fire rounds of rubber bullets into a crowd of striking Shoprite workers.
On 30 May, in Mthatha, flaming tyres could be seen to block roads as protests took place in the town. Police fired rubber bullets in response. The reason for the protests were unknown.
On 31 June, the Charlotte Maxeke Johannesburg Academic Hospital re-erupted into chaos as entrances were blocked with rubbish, rocks and burning tyres. Workers were demanding higher wages
On 31 May, Grahamstown community members (and the Unemployed Peoples Movement) protested over water quality, carrying buckets of brown tap water and human excrement.
On 31 May, hundreds of protesters blockaded roads with burning tyres in Vastrap, demanding housing, electricity and other services. No arrests were made.
On 1 June, strikers engaged in unlawful behaviour to demand higher wages in Kirkwood, forcing hundreds of workers to shut down white-owned shops. Seven were arrested for public violence.
On 1 June, the community of Matshelapad settlement in Delareyville brought the small farming town to a standstill when they marched against poor service delivery.
On 4 June, protestors marched from Westlake to Alphen Centre in Constantia, demanding service delivery. Burning tyres barricaded Westlake Drive and Steenberg Road.
On 5 June, a group of Wentworth residents protested against what they labelled Engen Refinery's ""unjust interaction and treatment"" of the entire South Durban Basin (SDB) community.

column7: DEMAWUSA: Democratic Municipal and Allied Workers Union of South Africa
column17: On 5 June, members affiliated to the Democratic Municipal and Allied Workers Union of South Africa (Demawusa) embarked on a strike and blocked buses in Johannesburg.
On 5 June, a post office and a municipal building were set alight during overnight protests in the Western Cape town of Bot River. Service delivery was the reason for the protest.
On 5 June, in ongoing portests in Kirkwood over wages, at least two orchard store rooms and a tractor have been set alight.
On 6 June, two schools were burnt in Thabana village in Siyabuswa in Mpumalanga, allegedly by a crowd of community members who were dissatisfied with the outcome of a by-election

On 6 June, the entrance to the Moses Mabhida township was blocked by protesters as the wage-related protests by Kirkwood citrus industry workers continued. Protesters used rubble and burning tyres to block the entrance to the township
On 6 June, farm workers who face eviction picket outside the gates of Marlenique farm (near Stellenbosch) during a visit by Deputy Minister of Rural Development and Land Reform

On 6 June, Police dispersed a group of protesters in Lenasia South, outside Johannesburg as they were protesting over electricity. They closed off roads and barricaded streets with burning tyres and rocks.
On 6 June, a group of protesters stoned traffic lights on the Southfield side of Prince George Drive, opposite Parkwood.

On 6 June, two municipal trucks were set alight and at least one municipal employee was injured after being pelted with stones by protesters near Springfield. Protesters were angry over the demolitions of shacks.
On 6 June, Khoisan tribes gathered outside the South End Museum in PE and walked to the Port Elizabeth airport, demanding the changing of the airports' name.

On 7 June, protesting residents on the N2 between Bot River and Caledon clashed with police, torching two vehicles belonging to SAPS and the local traffic department. They were angry over the demolition of shacks.

On 8 June, traffic on Govan Mbeki Road, between Stock Road and New Eisleben in Philippi, Cape Town, was disrupted by violent protests in the area after vehicles and business properties were set alight. The violence was related to land and land invasions.
On 8 June, residents from District Six, as well as Mandla Mandela, joined an iftaar in Bo-Kaap and marched to show their support to the community in their battle against gentrification.
On 8 June, about 100 workers and students marched through the streets of Braamfontein, closing down shops. They were protesting over outsourcing.
On 9 June, residents tore down a shack belonging to an immigrant from the Democratic Republic of Congo and his wife in Siyahlala informal settlement, Khayelitsha. The attack was xenophobic in nature.

On 9 June 2018, hundreds of people took to the streets in Riebeek-Kasteel and Riebeek West (Western Cape) over housing. Demonstrations started on the 9th and lasted until the 11th. Police arrested 21 people, while foreign-owned spaza shops and bottle stores were looted, a clinic was set on fire and municipal buildings damaged. [size=hundreds]

On 9 June 2018, hundreds of people took to the streets in Riebeek-Kasteel and Riebeek West (Western Cape) over housing. Demonstrations started on the 9th and lasted until the 11th. Police arrested 21 people, while foreign-owned spaza shops and bottle stores were looted, a clinic was set on fire and municipal buildings damaged. [size=hundreds]
On 10 June, a goods truck was set ablaze on the N7 in Dunoon as residents vented their anger over the demolition of shacks.

On 10 June 2018, hundreds of people took to the streets in Riebeek-Kasteel and Riebeek West (Western Cape) over housing. Demonstrations started on the 9th and lasted until the 11th. Police arrested 21 people, while foreign-owned spaza shops and bottle stores were looted, a clinic was set on fire and municipal buildings damaged. [size=hundreds]

On 10 June 2018, hundreds of people took to the streets in Riebeek-Kasteel and Riebeek West (Western Cape) over housing. Demonstrations started on the 9th and lasted until the 11th. Police arrested 21 people, while foreign-owned spaza shops and bottle stores were looted, a clinic was set on fire and municipal buildings damaged. [size=hundreds]
On 11 June, protests flared up in Plettenberg Bay as residents blocked the N2 near the town's industrial area. Residents took to the streets over lack of housing.
On 11 June, residents from across Ingquza Hill local municipality protested outside the municipal offices in Lusikisiki, demanding water. The protest was organised by ANC members in the municipality.

On 11 June 2018, hundreds of people took to the streets in Riebeek-Kasteel and Riebeek West (Western Cape) over housing. Demonstrations started on the 9th and lasted until the 11th. Police arrested 21 people, while foreign-owned spaza shops and bottle stores were looted, a clinic was set on fire and municipal buildings damaged. [size=hundreds]

On 11 June 2018, hundreds of people took to the streets in Riebeek-Kasteel and Riebeek West (Western Cape) over housing. Demonstrations started on the 9th and lasted until the 11th. Police arrested 21 people, while foreign-owned spaza shops and bottle stores were looted, a clinic was set on fire and municipal buildings damaged. [size=hundreds]
On 11 June, children from Klapkorn Play Centre as well as members of #NotInMyName Bafazi and residents took to the streets of Mamelodi West to march against child abuse.

On 11 June, the Umngeni Road office of SASSA, a group of employees picketed outside the office. Apart from the salary increase the workers are demanding that their housing allowance of R1500 be increased to R2500.
On 12 June, protesters started pelting emergency service staff members with stones in unknown protests in Knysna. A police officer was rushed to hospital after a protest.

On 12 June, a contingent of cash-in -vehicles took place in Durban city centre to highlight the violent attacks on them in recent months. It is part of a national protest organised by the Motor Transport Workers Union (MTWU). On the same day, thousands of security guards marched through Durban to hand over memorandum asking for safer working condition.
On 12 June, in East London, about 300 private security guards marched to the Fleet Street police station to hand over the memorandum over the recent increase in cash-in transit attacks.

On 12 June, Tshwane mayor Solly Msimanga and DA leader Mmusi Maimane had to be escorted out of a youth development centre by the police in Ga-Rankuwa after a group of hostile community members threatened to disrupt their visit to the township.
On 12 June, a burning truck and tyres have resulted in road closures on the N7 highway near Dunoon in protest over anti-land operation.

On 12 June, armoured cash-in-transit vehicles joined a procession in Johannesburg where security guards gathered to hand over a memorandum demanding safer working conditions to government and their bosses after a spate of violent robberies across the country.
On 12 June, thousands of security guards marched through Nelspruit, Bloemfontein, Cape Town and Durban to hand over memorandum asking for safer working condition.
On 12 June, thousands of security guards marched through Nelspruit, Bloemfontein, Cape Town and Durban to hand over memorandum asking for safer working condition.
On 12 June, thousands of security guards marched through Nelspruit, Bloemfontein, Cape Town and Durban to hand over memorandum asking for safer working condition.

On 12 June, exams at the University of Fort Hare (UFH) were disrupted when more than 500 unionised academic and non-academic staff went on strike and switched off the electricity supply at both the East London and Alice campuses.
On 13 June, about 300 workers and students marched from Walter Sisulu University to Mthatha demanding the insourcing of staff.
On 13 June, riots sporadically flared up in Plettenberg bay and police had to intervene by using stun grenades. Residents took to the streets over lack of housing.

column7: NUM: National Union of Mineworkers; NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: On 13 June, about 150 workers from trade unions National Union of Metalworkers SA (Numsa) and the National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) protested outside Eskom's Mkondeni site in Pietermaritzburg after rejecting the power utility's offer of a 0% wage increase.

On 13 June, protests flared up outside the Bisasar Road Landfill Site in Springfield, Durban after residents were chased from rummaging through refuse dumped at the site. At least 7 were shot as protesters began throwing rocks and pelting police vehicles with stones.

On 13 June, two men were killed in an attack by a worshipper at a Malmesbury Mosque, where men live and pray at the mosque for the last 10 days of the Islamic holy month of Ramadan. Reasons unclear. After the attack, the assailant was killed in a confrontation with police.

On 13 June, Tshwane metro police have allegedly shot and injured several people, including an elderly woman, after they used rubber bullets to disperse protesters who had blockaded several roads in Eersterust. Roads were strewn with rubble and burning tyres as protests demanded housing and other services.
On 13 June, protests continued in Knysna for unknown reasons. Protesters are burning materials in the street and throwing stones at police.

On 13 June, two men were killed in an attack by a worshipper at a Malmesbury Mosque, where men live and pray at the mosque for the last 10 days of the Islamic holy month of Ramadan. Reasons unclear. After the attack, the assailant was killed in a confrontation with police.
On 13 June, state paramedics protested outside the department of health's Dukumbane Building in Bhisho, complaining about what they said was a lack of safety in their line of work.

On 14 June, protests flared up again in Eerterust. Stones were thrown police. Insults are being hurled at police while they shoot rubber bullets dispersing the crowd. Protesters have blocked Hans Coverdale road with burning tyres and boulders. Issues of service delivery were the cause of the protests.
On 14 June, in Plettenberg bay, rioters used petrol bombs to set properties alight as residents took to the streets over lack of housing.
On 14 June, angry protesters banged on a police van ferrying the Verulam rape accused stepfather as he left the court precinct.

column7: NUM: National Union of Mineworkers; NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: On 14 June, hundreds of disgruntled Eskom workers gathered outside the utility's New Germany site as protests over the 0% increase took place.

On 14 June, demonstrators protest outside Megawatt Park, Sunninghill. Eskom workers are demanding a 15% salary increase while Eskom has decided to cut completely any increases for this year, saying they simply do not have the funds.
On 15 June, service delivery protests in East London started. There were no signs of violence.

On 15 June, in continued protests, Eersterust residents have blocked the main entrance to their community at the intersection of Stormvoel Road and Hans Coverdale Street East with burning tyres, rocks and debris.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: On 15 June, SAMWU workers marched on the Port Elizabeth city hall to hand over their memorandum to acting city manager over pay issues.

On 15 June, service delivery protests in East London that entered its second day turned violent as police resorted to using rubber bullets and teargas to disperse crowds blocking access roads to parts of the city. Community members had used burning tyres to barricade Black Road and were throwing stones at passing vehicles.
On 16 June, a group of six protesters in Walmer prevented shoppers from entering the building, angry over working conditions

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: On 16 June, seven ANC youth league (ANCYL) members in the Ehlanzeni region, Mpumalanga, were injured after police fired rubber bullets during clashes with disruptive members.

column9: Civilians (Somalia); Labour Group (Somalia); Labour Group (International); Migrants (International)
column17: On 17 June 2018, a Somali shop owner was shot and killed, and another foreign businessman was shot and injured by an unidentified individual inside the Somali store in Cape Town (Western Cape) during an apparently targeted xenophobic attack.
On 17 June, a reverend had to break his Mdantsane NU17 Church door after he was locked out by a group of disgruntled church members who accused him of non transparency with church finances.
On 18 June, Dordrecht residents took to the streets and burnt tyres as they demanded to be addressed by the premier and cooperative governance and traditional affairs MEC over poor service delivery.
On 18 June, Emalahleni municipality came to a standstill as residents protested in Cacadu over service delivery, barricading the two towns' entrance roads with burning tyres from 4am

On 18 June, a group of about 40 people, comprising both subcontractors and their employees, descended on Moses Mabhida Stadium in Durban with trucks and bakkies laden with black refuse bags filled with rubbish that had apparently been collected in uMlazi.
On 18 June, police used rubber bullets to disperse protesters who had blockaded the R59 in Meyerton, Gauteng, and were stoning vehicles. The protest was about service delivery and housing.

On 19 June, traffic on the N3 north was brought to a standstill as Alexandra residents blocked part of the highway during a service delivery protest in the area. Tyres were burnt and two lanes blocked off by angry residents who were protesting service delivery and electricity supply.

On 19 June, protesting Soshanguve residents protested and dodged rubber bullets after blocking the M20 road in protest. A protest was sparked by a taxi driver who hit a pedestrian on the notorious main road and fled the scene instead of stopping to call for help.

On 19 June, Forty-three people have been arrested on charges of malicious damage to property following protests in Scottburgh. 1500 people barricaded Dududu Road from Amandawe with rocks and burning tyres, preventing vehicles from passing as well as set a sugarcane plantation alight. The protest occurred over service delivery.
On 19 June, Security Agency (Sassa) district office in Durban, Sassa employees abandoned their work stations and protested outside over poor working conditions and unsettled wage negotiations.

column7: Right2Know; Sonke Gender Justice; ADF: African Diaspora Forum
column17: On 19 June, activists from multiple civil society organisations including Right2Know, Sonke Gender Justice, African Diaspora Forum protested outside Lindela in Krugersdorp as part of World Refugee Day.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: On 19 June, striking municipal workers aligned to South African Municipal Workers' Union marched to the city hall in Port Elizabeth.

column7: Right2Know; Sonke Gender Justice; ADF: African Diaspora Forum
column17: On 19 June, activists from multiple civil society organisations including Right2Know, Sonke Gender Justice, African Diaspora Forum protested in Pretoria West as part of World Refugee Day.
On 19 June, two burnt-out trucks and concrete blocks littered the road in the aftermath of overnight service delivery protests along the N2 in George on the Garden Route.
On 19 June, the N2 before Mew Way (Khayelitsha) towards Cape Town was blockaded by protesters who placed a burning barricade on the road. The protests was over service delivery and housing.
On 19 June, a group of about 250 people blockaded the N2 near the Madadeni area. They were protesting over lack of service delivery. The protesters also allegedly pelted passing cars with stones.
On 19 June, the African National Congress has confirmed that its member of Parliament Sibusiso Radebe was shot dead in Roodepoort.

column7: Right2Know; Sonke Gender Justice; ADF: African Diaspora Forum
column17: On 20 June, activists from multiple civil society organisations including Right2Know, Sonke Gender Justice, African Diaspora Forum continued to protest outside Lindela in Krugersdorp as part of World Refugee Day.

On 20 June 2018, South African truck drivers blocked the Harrismith road with their trucks, along the Johannesburg-Durban (N3) Highway in a demonstration against foreign nationals, whom they accuse of taking their jobs and being responsible for bad work conditions. The police intervened and arrested about 63 people. [size=at least 63]
On 20 June, two paramedics and five truck drivers are in hospital after they were assaulted by protesters near Thabazimbi in Limpopo.
On 20 June, protesters have damaged four municipal vehicles at a municipal depot in Motherwell. Electricity was the reason for the protest.
On 20 June, demonstrations continued in Soshanguve over the death of a pedestrain.
On 20 June, Refugees marched outside Parliament in Cape Town on International Refugee Day.

column7: Right2Know; Sonke Gender Justice; ADF: African Diaspora Forum
column17: On 20 June, activists from multiple civil society organisations including Right2Know, Sonke Gender Justice, African Diaspora Forum protested in Pretoria West as part of World Refugee Day.

On 20 June, protesting employees of eThekwini Water and Sanitation Department (EWS) angry about their pay, used earthmoving equipment and graders to tear up a section of road outside their offices in Electron Road in Springfield Park.
On 20 June, sixty-two people were arrested as the N3 at Van Reenen's pass was reopened after a truck blockade by truck drivers.
On 21 June, residents of Gugulethu disrupted a stakeholder meeting in protest after law enforcement agencies dismantled their homes near NY112 on land owned by businessman Peter Motale.
On 21 June, residents took to the streets in ward 45 in KwaNobuhle, Uitenhage calling for repairs to their RDP houses and claiming that their councillor was serving ANC members only.

On 21 June, the South African Communist Party encouraged a Khayelitsha ward councillor to open a case against angry residents who torched and looted his house, after promises to electrify their homes never materialised.

On 22 June, the Lenasia South community has expressed its frustration over the lack of service from their local police station and marched in protest. Some burnt tyres in front of the Lenasia police station, while demanding to speak to the station commander
On 24 June, in Sherwood, residents protested after land invaders began clearing land near Piedmont Road.

On 24 June, land invaders in Silverglen, Chatsworth accused security guards of violent behaviour following clashes between the two groups. Rubber bullets were fired while protesters burtn tyres and barricaded the road.
On 24 June, three railway carriages were set alight on Leonard Radu Road in Philippi, Cape Town.

On 25 June, angry residents allegedly fired shots at police who were responding to the protest at Ridge View in Cato Manor, Durban. The community members were blocking the road with burning tyres and stones.

On 25 June, residents of Mothibaskraal, near Mankweng outside Polokwane, took to the streets to protest against the non-delivery of water tanks in their community. The disgruntled group blockaded parts of the R71 road with tree branches.

On 25 June, residents barricaded the N6 and other entrance roads to Ezibeleni township in Komani, calling on the Cooperative Governance and Traditional Affairs MEC to address them about service delivery. Two community halls in Ezibeleni were set alight and looted by the mobs. 21 people were arrested.

On 25 June, residents barricaded the N6 and other entrance roads to Mlungisi location in Komani, calling on the Cooperative Governance and Traditional Affairs MEC to address them about service delivery.

On 26 June, eight people were shot and injured during a legal march, after a private security company fired rubber bullets at a group protesting outside Glencore mine in Marikana. The protested assaulted security personnel, and pelted them with stones.

On 26 June, Uber and Taxify drivers blocked Somerset Street in Green Point with their vehicles and honked their hooters to raise awareness of what they termed ""unethical driver abuse"" from Uber, Taxify and the City.

On 26 June, about 150 to 200 Vrygrond residents marched from Keizersgracht Street to the Cape Town Civic Centre to hand over a memorandum to Mayor Patricia de Lille. Their key demand is for a piece of land known as Xakabantu to be developed for housing.

On 26 June, chaos broke out as angry protesters stormed the construction site of the R60 million building project of the new Nkululeko Secondary School in KwaNobuhle, Uitenhage. They burnt tyres, cardboard and plastic on the site and vowed more violence.
On 26 June, members from Bhambayi community, near Phoenix, burned tyres and threw stones at passing motorists in protest. A police officer was shot in the protest.

On 27 June, five private vehicles were gutted and burning tyres were spread along Govan Mbeki Road at the Gugulethu municipal office, over an apparent threat that people would be evicted from the nearby Ramaphosa informal settlement.

On 27 June, about 1000 people marched in Scottburgh. They burnt tyres and blocked the roads. Although there was strong police presence, no violence was reported. The march was over the plan to hand over a memorandum.

On 28 June, 400 people, consisting of taxi owners and drivers from the Cape Amalgamated Taxi Association (CATA), together with Imizamo Yethu residents, protested against the confiscation of three CATA taxis by traffic police. They burnt tyres and barricaded the roads. Police dispersed the protesters with teargas.

On 28 June, residents of Matlwangtlwang in Steynsrus protested because they were unhappy about the appointment of 10 people to the municipality. They set a Community hall of Matlwangtlwang and a motor vehicle of a resident of Viljoenskroon alight
On 29 June, more than 2000 EFF protesters marched to Steve Biko Academic Hospital and Tshwane District Hospital in Pretoria. Their aim is to rectify the poor service delivery at hospitals.
On 29 June, about 50 South African Communist Party members and Edendale residents marched in Pietermaritzburg, calling for better policing in the community.

On 29 June, service delivery protests in Steynsrus continued, with protesters petrol-bombing the local town hall, a financial office of the Moqhaka Local Municipality and the house of a local police officer

On 30 June, a Police public order officer was rushed to hospital after she was hit on the head by a rock during violent service delivery protest on the M25 highway near Dube Village, in Inanda. A group of about 150 Dube Village residents blocked the highway, burnt tyres and threw stones at the police demanding service delivery of houses, water and electricity from eThekwini Municipality.
On 30 June, the community of Bonteheuwel held a picket, calling for a better police presence in the area and recreational resources for children, to prevent crime
On 30 June 2018, a mob chased down a man who allegedly murdered an off-duty police officer in a stabbing attack and killed him in Inchanga.

On 1 July, community members in Colenso held protests and closed roads with burning tyres and rubble. The protest comes after water and electricity supply to parts of the small town were allegedly ""cut off"".
On 1 July, community members in Shallcross embarked on protest action over service delivery. They were burning tyres and blocked off the road.
On 2 July 2018, about 100 unemployed graduates - some dressed in their robes - took to the streets of Durban in a protest march to raise awareness about their lack of employment. [size=200].

On 2 July, community members in Colenso continued to protest and closed roads with burning tyres and rubble. The protest comes after water and electricity supply to parts of the small town were allegedly ""cut off"".

On 2 July, police have been deployed to Link Road in Shallcross, Chatsworth, after protests erupted in the area. Residents took to the streets to burn debris and protest for better service delivery. Due to the volatile nature of the protest, the road was closed off to traffic.

column7: PAPPI: People Against Petrol and Paraffin Price Increase
column17: On 2 July 2018, a group of activists belonging to the #FuelPricesMustFall campaign and part of the organisation ""People Against Petrol and Paraffin Price Increase"" held a placard awareness demonstration at the busy intersection of Sandile Thusi Road and the M4. [size=no report].
On 2 July, over 100 South African Social Security Agency (SASSA) employees in Pietermaritzburg downed tools over wage hike negotiations and marched in the city.

On 2 July, patients went untreated at Leatitia Bam Health Centre in KwaNobuhle, Uitenhage as health workers went on strike and protested. The workers are demanding that better safety measures be implemented at the centre.
On 3 July, drivers in Pretoria and Johannesburg held a demonstration and attempted to hand over a memorandum of grievances about high petrol prices to Uber in Pretoria.
On 3 July, 400 Uber and Taxify operators assembled at Uber's offices in Kramerville Johannesburg to hand over a list of demands to their employers
On 4 July, tenants of the housing company Communicare, joined backyarders and those in informal settlements in a march over evictions, land and housing opportunities in Cape Town.
On 4 July, about 200 grooms protested at Summerveld near Shongweni days before South African racing's biggest showcase. A wage dispute was the cause of the protest.
Defusal: On 5 July, two devices one planted in the Gateway in Umhlanga outlet and the other in the Pavilionin Westville were detonated causing fires.
On 6 July, informal traders and supporters marched to the City Hall in Durban to protest proposed regulations which they say will prevent many people from earning a living.

column7: SACP: South African Communist Party; NUM: National Union of Mineworkers
column17: On 7 July, around 200 members of the SACP and the National Union of Mineworkers moved through the streets of Bellville in protest at looming electricity tariff increases, the implementation of independent power providers and calling for a review of the Eskom executive and the recall of chief executive Phakamani Hadebe.
On 7 July, a small group of animal rights activists (Ban Animal Trading) gathered outside Durban's Greyville Racecourse to protest against the country's biggest horse-racing event.
Defusal: On 7 July, two explosive devices were discovered in Morningside near Greyville Racecourse, where thousands of people had gathered for the Vodacom Durban July.
On 9 July, a library worth close to R2m was torched during service delivery protests in Ixopo.
Defusal: On 9 July, police performed a controlled explosion after a suspicious device was found at a Spar store in Wentworth.
On 9 July, protesters allegedly blockaded the N2 south freeway near uMgababa with tyres and stones complaining about an increase in minibus taxi fares.

On 10 July, a protest near Jubilee Hospital in Hammanskraal, north of Pretoria, briefly prevented staff and patients from accessing the medical facility. A large crowd blocked the roads while protesting for cleaner water (Burning tyres and rocks on the roadway) .
On 10 July, residents moved from the Ennerdale Civic Centre, in protest over the demolition of shacks in the area. They were met with rubber bullets from the guns of JMPD officers.

On 10 July, rubber bullets and teargas were fired in Zwelihle, Hermanus as unrest flared up over claims that the arrest of a local community activist was imminent. There were reports of incitement of violence and destruction of public property.
On 10 July, the #100MenMarch took place in Pretoria to raising awareness of violence against women and children in the country.

column7: NULAWU: National Union of Leather and Allied Workers Union; FEDUSA: Federation of Unions of South Africa
column17: On 10 July, in Pietermaritzburg, striking workers belonging to the National Union of Leather and Allied Workers Union (Nulawu), a Federation of Unions of SA (Fedusa) protested and resorted to throwing eggs at those inside the Eddels Shoe factory premises .

On 11 July, the busiest route to the Durban Harbour container terminals in Bayhead has been blocked off by angry protestors. A group of people picking up stones from the curb and stoning cars at the intersection.
On 11 July, Pietermaritzburg residents barricaded roads leading to Copesville with burning tyres and rubble, and demanded the removal of their ward councillor.
On 11 July, tyres were burning, roads were barricaded, and incidents of stone throwing were reported over claims that the arrest of a local community activist was imminent.
On 11 July, angry residents destroyed shacks belonging to community leaders and robbed them of their belongings in Siyahlala informal settlement, Khayelitsha.
On 11 July, the people of Bo-Kaap built shacks in the area in protest against a lack of social housing.
On 12 July, angry business owners blockaded the entrance to the hall and officials were locked in in the area of Kwamashu. The protesting crowd would not allow anyone to leave the hall.
On 12 July, one person was burnt in a mob justice attack at Yomelela Street in Dunoon. Another 3 people were killed in similar circumstances mid-July in Dunoon.

On 12 July, Several people were injured by rocks in Kimberley following a service delivery protest. Police had to fire rubber bullets when chaos erupted. Crowds of protesting residents marched through the streets over apparent service delivery issues and high tariffs.
On 12 July, protesters set the Gugulethu Fire Station in Cape Town alight, forcing firefighters to vacate the premises.

On 12 July, Zwelihle residents set a local recycling centre alight after battling the police for a third day in a row. Police started firing rubber bullets and teargas at protesters near the burning recycling centre.

column7: BLF: Black First, Land First; Solidarity and AfriForum
column17: On 12 July, opposing groups protested outside the Randburg Magistrate's Court during former President Zuma's son's trial. Black First Land First and Afriforum were the main groups.
On 12 July, men from various law enforcement agencies in Rustenburg marched through the town's streets to raise awareness about the abuse of women and children.

On 12 July, about 50 people braved the rainy weather to protest outside the municipal in Fezeka, Gugulethu.
