They were protesting over a range of issues, including housing, evictions by law enforcement, sanitation, corruption in the municipality, and 'inadequate' assistance from Cape Town Disaster Risk Management.
On 13 July, angry residents destroyed shacks belonging to community leaders and robbed them of their belongings in Siyahlala informal settlement, Khayelitsha.
On 13 July, the premier of the Western Cape was pelted with stones when attempting to address angry residents in Zwelihle.

column7: POPCRU: Police and Prisons Civil Rights Union (South Africa)
column17: On 13 July, police officers and other SAPS staff under the banner of POPCRU picketed over grievances at the Union Buildings in Pretoria. They were raising challenges of employment.
On 13 July, a group from Mothutlong chained the entrance to an office in Brits, Madibeng, accusing the municipality of removing R18 million allocated for the paving of streets.
Mid-July, three people were killed in mob justice attacks in separate incidencts in Dunoon. Coded as three separate incidents.
On 15 July, Ban Animal Trading South Africa (Batsa) protested outside a circus in Amanzimtoti over the treatment of animals.
Mid-July, three people were killed in mob justice attacks in separate incidencts in Dunoon. Coded as three separate incidents.

On 15 July, 1000 residents brought Zwelihle to a standstill, torching property. Four police and one person were injured. They were demanding the release of arrested community leader Gcobani Ndzongana.
On 16 July, hundreds of nurses from across KwaZulu-Natal (KZN) marched to the provincial legislature in Pietermaritzburg asking MEC Health Dr Sibongiseni Dhlomo to be removed.
Mid-July, three people were killed in mob justice attacks in separate incidencts in Dunoon. Coded as three separate incidents.
On 16 July, traffic on the N1 south at the Samrand turnoff in Centurion was blocked as protesters walked on the highway.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: On 17 July, mid-year exams at the university were disrupted when Nehawu members protested outside exam venues at the Alice and East London campuses.The protest was over wages.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: On 17 July, mid-year exams at the university were disrupted when Nehawu members protested outside exam venues at the Alice and East London campuses. The protest was over wages.
On 17 July, tyres were burnt in front of the door to the office of ANC Uitenhage Councillor as people protested over the a controversial employment appointment.
On 18 July, nine drivers were arrested after blockading roads to protest a fuel price hike on the N3 highway in Pietermaritzburg, towards Durban.
On 18 July, residents from the Siqalo informal settlement in Cape Town protested and delivered a shack to Western Cape Premier Helen Zille's home in Cape Town.

On 18 July, Treatment Action Campaign (TAC) members occupied the trauma ward of Khayelitsha Day Hospital on Mandela Day. About 50 people entered the hospital during visiting hours, posing as visitors to patients.

On 18 July, about 1000 ANC members from eight wards in Mlungisi location in Komani marched to the Komani City Hall demanding that Bhisho drop plans to dissolve the embattled Enoch Mgijima municipality.

column7: PAPPI: People Against Petrol and Paraffin Price Increase
column17: On 18 July, People Against Petrol and Paraffin Price Increases (Papppi) staged a demonstration outside the Sasol garage in Masabalala Yengwa (NMR) Avenue, near Durban Station over the high prices of petrol.
On 18 July, some shacks in Brakpan belonging to new occupiers who had rebuilt after Metro police had demolished them were reportedly burnt by community members.
On 19 and 20 July, some Parkwood residents allegedly brought Prince George Drive to a standstill when they staged protests. The protests were over housing.

On 19 July, students at UNISA (University of South Africa) locked the gates of the Pietermaritzburg campus. They threatened to shut down all UNISA's campuses in KZN if management does not address their issues.
On 19 July, a member of the Public Order Policing Unit was assaulted and robbed as protests continued in Zwelihle, Hermanus. He was admitted to the hospital.
On 19 July, a group of protesters gathered outside the KwaNobuhle police station in Uitenhage, supporting two community members who were detained by the police the day before.
On 19 July, about a thousand people joined a DA march from Manenberg to Nyanga to call for the army to be deployed in Cape Town's crime hotspots
On 19 and 20 July, some Parkwood residents allegedly brought Prince George Drive to a standstill when they staged protests. The protests were over housing.

column9: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: On 21 July, an ANCYL leader in KwaZulu-Natal was shot dead in apparent politically motivated killing in Umlazi.
On 22 July, one person was killed and 4 injured as protests turned violent in Kempton Park area over illegal occupation of land.

On 23 July, angry contractors dumped rubbish on the N2 near Isipingo over non-payment from the eThekwini Municipality for their services. The contractors, aligned to the Delangokubona Business Forum (DBF) were given contracts to collect rubbish in uMlazi.
On 23 July, a protest action led to the temporar closure of the N2 highway near Mossel Bay towards Cape Town and George.
On 23 July, a large group of angry residents gathered at the Hermanus Magistrate's Court as 18 people made their first appearance for crimes related to last week's protest.
On 23 July, A Knysna ward councillor was gunned down just metres from his home.
On 24 July, Economic Freedom Fighters supporters marched to protest alleged exploitation of workers. A number of leading businesses in East London were forced to shut doors temporarily.
On 24 July, tires were burnt in widespread protests on the N2 highway in Durban, uMbogintwini area.
On 24 July, protesters in Yellowwood Park area in Durban used burning tyres to block the N2 highway near the NPC Cement factory In Coedmore. The cause of the protests was unclear.

On 25 July, ward committee by-elections taking place in Nelson Mandela Bay were marred by a protest in Motherwell, Port Elizabeth. Angry residents are believed to have disrupted voting and trashed ballot boxes.

column7: SAFI: South African Friends of Israel
column17: On 25 July, a crowd organised under the banner of South African Friends of Israel (Safi) marched to the Union Buildings in Pretoria, demanding the reinstatement of South Africa's ambassador to Israel, recalled in May after Israeli armed forces killed 41 Palestinians.
On 25 July, five houses were set alight in Ramokokastad near Mogwase outside Rustenburg.
On 25 July, two separate peaceful demonstrations took place around the Sandton Convention Centre where the BRICS Summit is being held for the next three days.
On 25 July, one of the marquees which were said to be used to host the Durban Business South Regional Fair was allegedly set alight in Umlazi.
On 26 and 27 July, students used rubbish bins to block the gate at the head office in Uitenhage and burnt tyres over the struggle to access funding.

column9: Government of South Africa (1994-); Women (South Africa)
column17: On 26 July, a Buffalo City Metro councillor's house was torched as she slept in Mdantsane.
On 26 July, about 50 people picketed outside the SA Metal Group in Epping, demanding an end to the buying and selling of stolen copper.
On 26 July, protests took place in Chesterville over the demolition of dwellings. The protesters threw debris into the road and a few cars were stoned. Some cars were allegedly set alight.
On 26 July, part of the M57 highway, parallel to the R21 in Centurion, were closed following violent protests. A truck and a bus were set on fire. No one was injured in the process.

On 26 July, Turkish security personnel pounced on a crowd of civic society group members belonging to the Turkey Solidarity Network (TSN) who were picketing outside the Turkish Embassy in Pretoria ahead of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's visit to the mission. Some protesters were allegedly kicked in the face and bled.
On 27 July, about 20 Observatory residents picketed outside Malta Park to protest the leasing of the park and what they say is privatisation of their open public space.
On 26 and 27 July, students used rubbish bins to block the gate at the head office in Uitenhage and burnt tyres over the struggle to access funding.

On 30 July 2018, a large group of community members, armed with sticks and stones, attacked and injured a Malawi national in Zeerust (Ramotshere Moiloa, North-West). The attack came as community members accused foreign nationals of dealing in drug in the area. [size=large]
On 30 July, about 100 Gautrain workers protested outside the Gautrain Depot in Midrand after wage negotiations between the Gautrain's operating company Bombela, and the Union broke down last week.

On 30 July, UNISA students took to the streets in Pietermaritzburg and blockaded Langalibalele Street with old bins and burning garbage. They were angry over the lack of resources at the institutions.

On 30 July, protest by students at Eastcape Midlands College in Uitenhage, Eastern Cape, has led to the shutdown of all eight campuses. Students burnt tyres and blocked the gates to the Uitenhage head office.

On 30 July 2018, police officers targeted foreign shop owners with tear gas and rubber bullets, and looted goods in Pietermaritzburg (uMgungundlovu, KwaZulu-Natal). They insulted the owners and ordered them to go back to their home country. The Police were investigating the attacks. No reports on injuries.

On 30 July, the SRC at the University of Fort Hare barricaded the R63 connecting Alice and Fort Beaufort with their desks and placards, in a bid to draw attention to the prolonged strike at the university.
On 30 July, six people were arrested following violent protests in the area. The communities of Kwarung and Bosehla villages in Malebogo area, started to block the roads burning tyres and rubble.
On 30 July, some roads in Kimberley were barricaded with rocks and tyres. Passing cars were damaged after they were pelted with stones. The protesters were angry over the price of electricity.

On 31 July 2018, a boy, accused of carrying drugs, was beaten by community members in Zeerust (Ramotshere Moiloa, North-West). The group was armed with sticks and stones, led by a woman, and had been threatening foreigners in the region, accusing them of drug dealing in the region. [size=no report]

On 31 July, informal traders blockaded Joseph Nduli Road, Durban, by piling up sacks on the road. They are demanding the municipality collect burned debris after a fire swept through part of the traditional medicine market in Warwick Junction.
On 31 July, UNISA students continued to protest in Pietermaritzburg. They were angry over the lack of resources at the institutions.
On 31 July, students at the university of Fort Hare in Alice barricaded the entrance gates to express their concerns over the continued strike.
On 31 July, numerous people including DA members have gathered at Church Square in Pretoria to picket against the high general fuel levy at the nearby National Treasury office.

Around 1 August 2018 (as reported), foreign nationals shops were looted and set on fire by unidentified individuals in Inanda (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal). The attacks were taking place after local shop owners threatened foreign shop owners, ordering them to leave. No reports on injuries. [size=no report]

Around 1 August 2018 (as reported), foreign nationals shops were looted and set on fire by unidentified individuals in KwaMashu (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal). The attacks were taking place after local shop owners threatened foreign shop owners, order them to leave. No reports on injuries.

On 1 August 2018, a shop owner was beaten by a woman who was leading a group, armed with sticks and stones, in Zeerust (Ramotshere Moiloa, North-West). The group had been threatening foreigners in the area, accusing them of drug dealing in the region. [size=no report]

On 1 August, a group of community members protested outside the municipal building in Harding, disrupting municipal operations including water provision in most areas falling under the Umuziwabantu Municipality.

column7: ANCWL: African National Congress Womens League; Women (South Africa)
column17: On 1 August, ANC Women's League (ANCWL) joined the #TotalShutDown march against women and children outside Luthuli House in Johannesburg CBD where hundreds of women in ANC regalia had gathered.
On 1 August, about 200 women wearing black clothes marched in Port Elizabeth in solidarity with women who have been raped or murdered.
On 1 August, about one thousand women, children and a few men marched in Cape Town city as part of the #Totalshutdown protests around the country.
On 1 August, about 1,000 women gathered at Curries Fountain and marched to City Hall in Durban as part of the #Totalshutdown protests around the country.

On 1 August, police and protesters taking part in the #TotalShutDown march have clashed in Tshwane after officers forcibly tried to remove marchers blocking the road in front of the main entrance to the Union Buildings.

column7: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union
column17: On 2 August, more than 100 teachers, part of the SA Democratic Teachers' Union (Sadtu), sat outside the Umbumbulu district offices demanding their colleagues return to the school.

On 3 August, police have fired rubber bullets at protesting students from the University of Venda (UniVen). The students were apparently protesting at the university over delayed allowances from the National Student Financial Aid Scheme (NSFAS), a day after the university suspended lectures and requested students to vacate the campus.
On 4 August, Mdantsane residents held a #JusticeForKamva march. Residents marched to the home of two of the three accused of stripping a man and demanding they hand themselves over to the police.
On 4 August, a man was beaten to death in what is believed to be a mob justice attack in Port Elizabeth.
On 5 August, a 33-year-old man was allegedly beaten to death by an angry mob in Port Elizabeth.

On 5 August, residents of Colenso, Kwazulu Natal, rioted over service delivery, barricading the R74 between Colenso and Weenen with rocks, setting a tractor alight and looting another. When police officers attempted to open the road, they were stoned and shot at, and their vehicles damaged. One killed with gunshot wound.

On 6 August 2018, a group marched to a block of flats rented by foreign nationals in Yeoville, Johannesburg (Gauteng), invading some residencies, and ordering foreigners to leave. They also destroyed several stalls of foreign nationals in the marketplace. A bystander was beaten and injured, and a child was slapped. As they marched, the group was singing a song regarding the return of South-African land to South Africans. The Police arrested several people the following day, taking them out of the invaded residencies. [size=no report]
On 6 August, elderly people protested outside the ANC headquarters Luthuli House in Joburg demanding title deeds for their properties
On 6 August, students at Nelson Mandela University in Port Elizabeth suspended classes and protested in solidarity with a student who said she had been raped by her boyfriend at the weekend.
On 6 August, Mdantsane residents marched to the NU1 police station, demanding that the three women who allegedly stripped naked and publicly humiliated 21-year-old Kamva Dala, be brought to book.

On 6 August, about 100 people renting RDP houses and living in backyard shacks took to the streets in KwaNobuhle township, Uitenhage. Protesters blew whistles, sang freedom songs and blocked busy Nomakhwezana Street with rocks, mattresses and burning tyres.
On 6 August, residents of Ngcobo closed the busy R61 to Cofimvaba with burning tyres, stones and trees, demanding better roads in their area. Police fired rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.
On 6 August, buses were set alight in Khayelitsha and thousands of commuters were left stranded during a taxi strike.

On 7 August, hundreds of people from civil society and organised by the TAC gathered at Mary Fitzgerald Square in Braamfontein before marching to the Gauteng Provincial Legislature against corruption in the Gauteng Health Department.

On 7 August, angered by the desecration and clearingof a cemetery, protesting farm dwellers and community members blocked off the R74 between Kranskop and Greytown with logs, tyres and broken bottles and set alight some farmlands.
On 8 July, Ocean View residents marched against gun violence in the area. Gunshots heard after their peaceful demonstration only amplified their cause for peace.

On 7 August, former Pikitup workers protested to be reinstated outside the Pikitup Selby Depot. There was an exchange of bullets and stones in running battles between protesters and the police at Pikitup's Selby depot.

On 8 August, a handful of residents picketed against the fencing of Malta Park In Observatory, claiming the City didn't follow due processes of having public participation for the fencing and leasing of the park.
On 8 August, hundreds of unemployed people in Madibeng municipality in North West demanded 1000 jobs from each mining company within Madibeng

On 8 August, a group of students embarked on protest action on the UKZN Westville campus. The protesters disrupted lectures and caused damage to property, including security vehicles. There were reported clashes between police and students.
On 8 August, more than 200 residents of Lawley in Johannesburg took to the streets to protest the occupation of open land in Ennerdale Ext 9, saying that land grabbers have residents living in fear.
On 8 August, a large and vocal crowdgathered outside the Verulam Magistrate's Court calling for a rape and murder suspect not to be released on bail.

On 8 August, Manenberg police came under attack by residents while raiding the house of an alleged drug merchant and member of the Hard Livings gang. They pelted police with stones and damaged two police vehicles as they arrested the man for possession of tik worth R5 000.

On 9 August, protesters were involved in violent clashes with the police after scores of backyarders invaded privately owned land in Stellenbosch. Shop windows were broken, cars were vandalised and stores in especially the Bird Street area were looted.
On 9 August, the Young Men's Guild (YMG) of the Methodist Church took to the streets to lead a march to the New Brighton police station to highlight women and child abuse.

column7: SJC: Social Justice Coalition; Women (South Africa)
column17: On 9 August, about 100 people marched through Khayelitsha to the Site B Police station on Women's Day, against gender-based violence in the community. The protest was organised by the Social Justice Coalition (SJC), South African National Civic organisation (SANCO) and the African Ministers Forum.

On 11 August, about 50 cemetery workers staged a four-hour protest in Mdantsane when they locked the gates of the cemetery. The police used rubber bullets to disperse the protesters and arrested the 12.

On 12 August, believing that members of an anti-poaching patrol had killed a fisherman from their community, protestors shut down Hout Bay harbour, setting alight two government buildings and the home of a local fisheries official.

On 13 August, police used rubber bullets to disperse community members protesting in Kanyamazane, Mbombela. The protesters went on a rampage, looting foreign nationals' shops and a Shoprite liquor store.

On 13 August 2018, a group tried to set a marketplace in Yeoville, Johannesburg (Gauteng) on fire in response to its closure. The police intervened, dispersing the group and shooting to the air. [size=no report]

column7: PAPPI: People Against Petrol and Paraffin Price Increase
column17: On 13 August, a group of about one hundred people aligned to PAPPI marched in the Durban CBD to protest the recent fuel price hikes.

On 13 August, seventeen students have been arrested for public violence after clashing with police at the University of KwaZulu-Natal's (UKZN) Westville campus. Police vehicles were damaged during the violent protest.

On 13 August, protesters in Hangberg, Hout Bay took to the streets, a day after violent protests, to ""fight for their brother"" who went missing during an anti-poaching operation at sea, burning boats.
On 14 August, community protests in Kanyamazane in the Mbombela Local Municipality disrupted schooling for a second day.

column7: FAWU: Food and Allied Workers Union
column17: On 14 August, members of the Food and Allied Workers' Union (Fawu) joined tobacco farmers and informal traders as they marched to the National Treasury offices in Pretoria CBD, protesting about the thriving inflow of illegal cigarettes.
On 15 August, unionised employees picketed at the entrance of the department of health building in Pretoria. Police intervened to let staff in.

On 15 August, protests took place in Khayelitsha, Uitenhage. Scores of learners stood outside the gates, demanding six more teachers for grade 10, 11 and 12 classes. The learners, with satchels on their their backs, sang and burnt tyres in front of the school.
On 15 August, a group of health officials and residents closed part of the Kwazakhele clinic and protested in an ongoing wage dispute over understaffing and security issues at the facility.

column7: MKVMA: Mkhonto weSizwe Military Veterans Association
column17: On 15 August, MKMVA members locked Richmond municipal workers out of their offices in protest over jobs and houses.
On 15 August, 3 suspected gang member were attacked and set alight by vigilantes in Daveyton. 2 died.

On 15 August, Athlone residents joined by domestic violence advocacy group Ilitha Labantu protesting outside the Wynberg court during the bail application of a man accused of raping a 13-year-old girl.

column8: Police Forces of South Africa (1994-) Anti-Land Invasion Unit
column17: On 16 August, eThekwini land invasion unit demolished 15 shacks and clashed with the occupiers in Verulam. Rubber bullets were fired, injuring two people, including a young woman.

On 17 August 2018, a group of locals took to the streets in Zeerust (Ramotshere Moiloa, North-West) in a demonstration against foreigners, who they claim are dealing drugs in the area. [size= no report]

On 17 August, activists chained themselves to the Cape Town civic centre to express solidarity with ten Social Justice Coalition (SJC) members who are possibly going to receive criminal records for having done a similar protest in 2013.

On 17 August, twelve students were arrested during riots at the University of KwaZulu-Natal's Westville campus. Students set up road blocks, burned properties and clashed with police and Mi7 security guards on the campus.

On 19 August, a series of service delivery protests erupted in Ceres. An unknown group of people set alight a post office in Chris Hani Avenue and the old Nduli police station. Protesters blocked roads with stones and tyres, as well as threw stones at police officers.
On 20 August, dozens of Khayelitsha teachers gathered in Cape Town's city centre to demand that their schools be made safer.

column7: SANCO: South African National Civics Organization; COSAS: Congress of South African Students
column17: On 20 August, ""illegal protest action"" co-ordinated by the SA National Civic Organisation (Sanco) and the Congress of South African Students led to the shutting down of nine schools in Khayelitsha, affecting 9000 students.

On 20 August, workers at the stationery manufacturing company, Bidvest Waltons workers walked off the warehouse floor and local stores in a wage protest. They carried placards on outside the warehouse at Riverhorse Valley (Newlands East) highlighting what they say are poor working conditions and demanded 100% bonuses.
On 20 August, parents of pupils at Shakaskraal Primary have shut down the premises, demanding the principal be removed after a 5-year-old girl was allegedly raped at the school.
On 20 August, Sigubudwini residents closed the R61 road between Mthatha and Ngcobo with burning tyres and stones, demanding electricity and water.
On 21 August, shops were looted and property vandalised during a violent protest over housing in Atlantis.

On 22 August, about 150 people - from the township and the suburbs, and taxi drivers - protested outside the Humansdorp court ahead of the 48-year-old accused's appearance. They were carrying placards reading ""Stop raping our Children"", and ""No Bail"".
On 22 August, students marched in Cape Town to ask President Cyril Ramaphosa to grant amnesty to students who had been charged during the #FeesMustFall protests

On 22 August, outside the East London magistrate's court, around 100 unruly ANC supporters, including BCM councillors, hurled insults, manhandled and threatened to assault a press contingent covering Mandela funeral funds scandal court cases.
On 22 August, a couple were travelling on the R558 from Azaadville to Lenasia, Gauteng, when they were attacked by an angry mob. Their vehicle was stoned and they sustained minor injuries.
On 22 August, unemployed graduates have for the second time this year taken to the streets, marching to the Durban City Hall to express their frustration at not being able to land jobs.
On 22 August, a 30-year-old man was beaten and stoned to death, allegedly for stealing washing powder at a local store at the KwaMashu hostel.
On 22 August, about 40 residents in Mandalay stoned three men to death after they were caught breaking into a house.
On 23 August, more than 100 Buffalo City Metro workers downed tools to picket outside the East London City Hall.

On 23 August, one person was shot dead and buildings set alight by unknown gunmen during the Tshwane University of Technology (TUT) Student Representative Council (SRC) elections. There had been allegations of vote rigging.

On 23 August, protesting residents of the Isipingo transit camp, south of Durban, have accused the eThekwini municipality of neglecting them. The residents, who were moved to the camp more than 10 years ago, blockaded Isipingo Old Main Road with burning tyres and rubble.

On 24 August, the King Sabata Dalindyebo TVET College in Mthatha asked students to vacate campus following days of no academic activity. A number of students were injured when the college's private security officers fired rubber bullets to disperse students protesting outside the premises of the institution.
On 24 August, backyarders from Langa, Gugulethu and Nyanga marched to the Civic Centre in the Cape Town CBD to hand over a memorandum demanding housing.

On 24 August, residents of the Cape Town suburbs of Kensington and Facreton blocked a major arterial route during rush hour in a desperate attempt to get national government to pay attention to gang violence in the area. The protest was peaceful.
On 24 August, Ekurhuleni EFF members protested outside the home of a man who made racist comments.
On 26 August, a man died following a mob assault at Newline Section, in the Maboloka village outside Brits. In a separate incident, another man was beatan for suspected crimes but survived.

On 26 August 2018, a village headman in the town of Bizana was attacked and killed at home by a mob armed with sharp objects, dragged outside along with his furnishings and he and his goods were burned to a cinder.
On 27 August 2018, two suspects were badly beaten and handed over to the police by the community in Mitchells Plain as they tried to rob people using a toy gun. [size=no report]

On 27 August, police at Mbizana in the Eastern Cape have closed off the R61 road to town as hundreds of people from Dindini village tried to march to the police station in Bizana over the death of the local chief.
On 27 August, UNISA College of Law, Black Law Academics and staff members joined other students outside the Union Buildings in Pretoria to support the #Feesmustfall movement.

On 27 August 2018, demonstrations were reported in Ratanda (Sedibeng, Gauteng) over electricity cuts by the local municipality, and escalated to looting and property destruction of foreign owned shops. Clashes between the police and locals were registered. The attacks lasted until the following day. [size=no report]

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Teachers (South Africa); Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: On 27 August, a mass protest over alleged corruption briefly affected the smooth running of Chris Hani Baragwanath Academic Hospital in Soweto. NEHAWU joined in the protest.
On 27 August, a group of protesters in KwaMaphumulo, on the north coast of KwaZulu-Natal, took to the streets and accused their mayor of maladministration and corruption.
On 27 August, men participated in a planned march in Khayelitsha, Cape Town over gender violence.

On 28 August, Johannesburg metro police have cut down a banner proclaiming 'more coal' more deaths' no water' suspended from the iconic Nelson Mandela Bridge in Braamfontein by a group of protesting Greenpeace Africa activists.

On 28 August, four hundred workers in Addo marched to the offices of the Sundays River Citrus Company where they handed over a petition over employee rights. At the same time workers in Kirkwood handed over a petition to employers with the same demands, though it is unclear if they protested.

On 28 August 2018, demonstrations reported in Ratanda (Sedibeng, Gauteng) over electricity cuts by the local municipality, and escalated to looting and property destruction of foreign owned shops. Clashes between the police and locals were registered. The attacks started on the previous day. 54 people were arrested, including 12 minors. [size=at least 54]
On 28 August, King Sabata Dalindyebo municipality workers stormed acting municipal manager Mbulelo Sigaba's office in Mthatha, accusing him of not recognising their union.

Over 27-28 August, protests in Ratanda in Heidelberg over electricity cuts by the local municipality escalated to looting and the destruction of property, as well as clashes between police and locals.
On 29 August 2018, an Ethiopian shopkeeper was injured after armed men set his shop on fire in KwaDabeka (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal).

column16: Xenowatch; Daily Sun (South Africa); News24 (South Africa)
column17: On 29 August 2018, four people were killed during attacks against foreign business shop owners in Soweto, Johannesburg (Gauteng). The residents went on the rampage and looted dozens of foreign-owned shops around the township over the suspected selling of expired and counterfeit products. The police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse perpetrators. 27 people were arrested. [size=at least 27]

On 29 August, students from Tshwane University of Technology ran riot through the CBD demanding justice for the late law student Katlego Monareng. They hurled insults and burnt items. Police officers tried to put out the fires and take away the tyres, but the students overpowered them.

On 29 August, stun grenades were used to disperse a group of protesting Bonteheuwel residents in Cape Town who had taken to the streets to protest gang warfare. While the protesters blocked the road there were no reports of violence or destruction of property reported.
On 29 August, a group of about 100 people sang outside the Western Cape High Court in Cape Town. They were protesting land issues in and around the Stellenbosch area.

On 30 August, UKZN medicine students protested at the campus in Durban over living conditions. Police were then forced to use water cannons to disperse the unruly crowd. No injuries were reported but police arrested 10 suspects aged between 18 and 27.

column7: PAPPI: People Against Petrol and Paraffin Price Increase
column17: On 30 August, People Against Petrol and Paraffin Price Increase protested outside the Sasol garage on Masabalala Yengwa Avenue (NMR) in Stamford Hill in Durban.
On 30 August, an Ethiopian trader's shop was burnt down in what appears to be a xenophobic attack in KwaDabeka, Pinetown.
On 30 August, garbage collection protesters set a depot alight in Johannesburg in protest.
On 30 August 2018, arsonists burned down foreign owned shops in Newlands West, to the north of Durban [size=no report]

On 30 August, about 50 Equal Education members picketed outside the Gauteng education department in Marshalltown, Johannesburg. They demanded that MEC for Education Panyaza Lesufi prioritise the replacement of all classrooms built both entirely and partially from asbestos.

On 30 August, about 200 learners and Equal Education members protested outside the Western Cape legislature on after school. They called for MEC of Education Debbie Schafer to withdraw her department's appeal against a recent court judgment on school norms and standards.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union
column17: On 31 August, Samwu workers marched to the ANC offices in Komani in defence of Enoch Mgijima municipal manager.

column7: NUPSAW: National Union of Public Service and Allied Workers
column17: On 31 August, workers at Onderstepoort Biological Products protest outside their office in the city. Employees affiliated to the National Union of Public Service and Allied Workers (Nupsaw) took to the streets.
On 3 September, protesters caused major traffic delays by blocking roads ahead of a planned march to Lanseria International Airport in Gauteng.
On 3 September, community members protested against Mayor Mangaliso Matika's stay in office.

On 4 September, Chatsworth residents protested outside the local ANC office over allegations that a Youth League leader, who allegedly called fellow party members the K-word, was still working at the office while disciplinary procedures were pending against her.

On 4 September, an allegedly illegal march has seen taxis blocking off all main roads in Ladysmith.The march, instigated by the Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP), had not been approved by Alfred Duma Local Municipality and did not comply with the requirements for a march, and as such is most likely illegal.

On 4 September, an ANC ward councillor, who was the party's branch chairperson in Ward 12 eThekwini in Kwandengezi township, was gunned down outside his home shortly after a branch executive committee (BEC) meeting.
On 4 September, Boikhutsong informal settlement residents in Mabopane blocked roads with trees, rocks and tyres demanding the DA led administration give them services.

On 4 September, student activists did a 310 kilometer walk from Mafikeng to Pretoria, appealing to President Cyril Ramaphosa to give a reprieve for all students charged or in custody for crimes relating to #FeesMustFall protests.
On 5 September, Lenasia South residents barricaded roads, protesting against land grabs in the area. 60 people used burning tyres and rubble to barricade Wimbledon Road and Drakenstein Street.

On 5 September, scores of angry Kwangwanase community members in KwaZulu-Natal marched to the iSimangaliso Wetland Park Authority, demanding rights to mine dunes and calling for a bigger pie of the proceeds from the park.
On 5 September, residents from informal settlements in Uitenhage burnt tyres and blocked Kamehs Road. They were protesting over a lack of toilets, water and electricity.
On 5 September, activists from the Social Justice Coalition and residents of Cape Town marched on Parliament demanding better policing, as the latest crime statistics were released.
On 6 September, Solidarity members and white employees protested outside Sasol's Secunda plant over racial descrimination.
On 6 September, a group of demonstrators who were opposed to a land eviction in Stellenbosch sang outside the Western Cape High Court in Cape Town.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: On 6 September, workers at the Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries staged a total shutdown and marched to the offices in Arcais demanding president Cyril Ramaphosa suspend their minister.
On 7 September, Congolese protesters in Cape Town expressed distrust over the use of electronic voting machines in the upcoming DRC general election and marched in Cape Town.
On 8 September 2018, a shop owner of Bangladeshi descent, and his brother, narrowly escaped death when their shop was torched in Brixton, Johannesburg (Gauteng). They were uninjured. [size=no report]
On 8 September, about 80 girls and women marched in Duncan Village to protest against women abuse and gender-based violence in the township.
On 9 September, students protested at Soshanguve in ongoing protests at the campus.
On 9 September, a Zimbabwean national was stabbed in the chest and died while at his store in Klerksdorp, allegedly by taxi drivers.
On 9 September, residents of Dindini village in Mbizana refused to allow the local burial of their headman who was beaten to death and his body set alight. They protested as part of their refusal.
On 10 September, about 300 protesters in Ngonyameni near Umlazi over water issues and used burning tyres to blockade the road. A police vehicle was also stoned during the fracas.
On 10 September 2018, violence between taxi drivers and foreign nationals erupted in the Klerksdorp, which resulted in the torching of buildings and vehicles. [size=no report]

On 10 September, DA members in Whittlesea braved the rain and picketed outside a Whittlesea school demanding that a principal accused of sexually assaulting a 12-year-old pupil be removed from the school.

On 10 September, police used rubber bullets and stun grenades during a housing protest in a informal settlement in Morningside. The crowd had set alight tree branches, tyres and littered Alpine Road with rocks and bricks.

On 10 September, Eastern Cape nurses have staged a sit-in at the health department's headquarters in esperate Eastern Cape nurses have staged a sit-in at the health department's headquarters in Bhisho since Monday to demand jobs.
On 11 September, residents blocked the road between Hendry and Umgeni Road with tree branches, rocks and household refuse in Morningside.

On 11 September, residents of Machadodorp in Mpumalanga went on a rampage, burning a store and trucks after two security officers working for a private security company allegedly assaulted a community member earlier in the week.

On 11 September 2018, residents of Letlhabile barricaded the road linking Letlhabile and Brits with stones and burning tyres, complaining about conditions of the road. They allegedly pelted passing motorists with stones. Public Order Police managed to disperse the crowd and four people were arrested for public violence. [size=no report].

On 11 September 2018, a motorist fired shots at protesters during violent protests engulfing Madibeng municipality. One person sustained injuries due to a bullet that was fired from the Mercedes Benz. [size=no report].
On 12 September, around 100 residents from Bishop Lavis, Cape Town took to the streets to protest against gang violence in the Western Cape.
On 12 September, TVET students in Kimberley embarked on protest action, where roads leading to the Phatsimang and Moremogolo campuses were barricaded with rocks and burning tyres.

On 12 September, a Durban school was trashed by angry protesters demanding land to build shacks in Cato Manor. The vandals burned books and broke classroom windows and desks, forcing the school to send frustrated pupils home.
On 12 September, in Brits the police dispersed two groups that attacked each other near Madibeng municipality offices.

On 13 September 2018, a group set a spaza shop and vehicle of a foreign national on fire in Tshamahansi (Waterberg, Limpopo). The foreign national was being accused of shooting and killing a man after he tried to break into his shop. [size=no report]

column7: YNITU: Young Nurses Indaba Trade Union; Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: On 13 September, about 30 community healthcare workers marched to the Eastern Cape Department of Health demanding full-time employment and a monthly salary of R12 500. The protesters are members of the Young Nurses Indaba Trade Union (YNITU).
On 13 September 2018, around 400 national Department of Health employees, who work at a building in Tshwane, staged a protest to demand that they be moved for their own safety. [size=400].

column7: DASO: Democratic Alliance Students Organisation; DA: Democratic Alliance; Students (South Africa)
column17: On 13 September 2018, DA leaders led a picket with the DA Student Organisation students in Pretoria with a call for political parties to set their differences aside and advise their student structures to stop violent and disruptive protests at the Tshwane University of Technology in Soshanguve. [size=no report].

On 14 September, roads in Springfield, Durban were closed following a violent protest over housing and basic service delivery in the area. The protesters from the nearby informal settlement had earlier blockaded roads with burning tyres and rubble, and threw stones at passing vehicles.
On 14 September, dozens of shack dwellers marched to their ward councillor's office to demand electrification in Samora Machel in Philippi.

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students
column17: On 14 September, scores of aggrieved pupils from various schools in Tshwane have flooded the streets of Pretoria to march to the Unions Buildings. The crowd is led by the Congress of South African Students who sought a national shutdown to demand food security in foreign owned spaza shops, the release of #FeesMustFall activists, among other demands.
On 15 September, an IFP local government councillor was killed in an apparent ambush between Estcourt and Colenso in KwaZulu-Natal.
On 16 September, students at the University of Zululand resorted to mob justice, stoning and kicking an alleged killer.
On 17 September, a protest by scores of students who demanded to hand over a memorandum of grievances to management at two Durban University of Technology (DUT) campuses caused disruption.

On 17 September, a bus and a field were set alight by Kranskop residents demanding that police act against a farmer they accused of desecrating graves. The violence led to the arrest of two people for public violence.
On 17 September, 76 workers of consumer and hardware giant, Boardman Bros, protested against wage increases and conditions of employment at the company's Stutterheim premises.
On 17 September. Students of the University of Fort Hare, Bhisho stormed lecture halls after not being allowed to enroll in the new class.

On 18 September 2018, about 200 people attacked the shop of a foreign national with bricks in Coronationville, Johannesburg (Gauteng), looting the store during the event. No one was arrested. [size=about 200]
On 18 September, students and others held a 'silent protest' against abuse of women at the University of KwaZulu-Natal's Pietermaritzburg campus.
On 18 September, a peaceful protest about wages by Denel personnel on Atlas Road in Benoni has turned volatile when police started firing rubber bullets. Protesters were protesting for better wages.
On 19 September. Taxi drivers peacefully protest for a increased scholar transport subsidy.
On 19 September. An alleged gang member was killed and several others taken to hospital after community members beat them up in Boitumelong near Bloemhof in the North West.

On 19 September, in Mdantsane, near East London, a group of taxi drivers burnt tyres in Qumza Road near the NU6 mall. Taxi drivers were armed with pangas and sharp instruments and police had to disperse the crowd using rubber bullets.
On 19 September, in ongoing taxi strikes, taxi protesters burnt tyres on the R102 near Berlin.

On 19 September, in Cofimvaba, roads were blocked at Ngcobo near Nyanaga. In Grahamstown taxis blockaded and burnt tyres along the N2 at Peddie preventing motorists from entering or exiting the town. A road to Nompumelelo Hospital in Peddie was also blockaded.
On 19 September, hundreds of residents of Zandspruit informal settlement marched to Honeydew Police Station to demand better policing.
On 19 September, roads around VW in Uitenhage were barricaded as part of taxi strikes and protests.

On 19 September, people living with disability marched from Artscape on the Foreshore to the Cape Town Civic Centre. They are demanding a better service from Dial-A-Ride transport and that the service extend to informal settlements.
On 19 September, several cars were reportedly damaged and one person injured when a vehicle was stoned in Kwazakele, Port Elizabeth during province-wide taxi strike in the Eastern Cape.

column7: SANTACO: South Africa National Taxi Council
column17: On 19 September, Santaco members marched to the ANC's provincial headquarters at Calata House in King Williams Town to hand over a memorandum of grievances to ANC Provincial Chairperson, Oscar Mabuyane.

On 19 September, in Grahamstown taxis blockaded and burnt tyres along the N2 at Peddie preventing motorists from entering or exiting the town. A road to Nompumelelo Hospital in Peddie was also blockaded.
On 20 September. A group of residents renting in an informal settlement in Reservoirs Hills is demand housing. The protesters blocked roads with rubble and tree branches.
On 20 September. The sale of Australian higher education institution Monash South Africa (MSA) to a local entity caused a student protest.

On 20 September, about 1 000 residents took part in a protest march in Barkly West, calling for dismisslas in the Dikgatlong Municipality, as well as the immediate suspension of the chief financial officer (CFO).

On 20 September, about 80 students from Monash South Africa (MSA) peacefully protested the proposed sale of the private university to education conglomerate Advtech outside their campus in Johannesburg.
On 20 September. Taxi drivers violently protest labour practices in Philippi, blocking and damaging an ambulance car in the process.
On 20 September. A court ruling which impedes housing benefits causes residents of the Morningstar area to gather and prevent the handover of state-subsidised homes.
On 21 September. A man was arrested and a police officer was injured when community members turned on police during a joint police operation in Kensington in Cape Town.
On 21 September. A train station in uMlazi was damaged and four cars were set alight after angry commuters went on the rampage when the trains did not arrive on time.
On 23 September, Klipfontein View residents blockaded roads with burning tyres in Midrand. They were protesting about water shortages in the area.

On 23 September, police fired targas at anti-mining demonstrators on the Wild Coast (Xolobeni). A human rights attorney was arrested after a heated fracas with the mineral resources minister Gwede Mantashe in the context of the protest.

On 24 September, a policeman was injured when officers came under attack in Kensington while conducting a crime-prevention operation. Officers were shot at, attacked with petrol bombs and pelted with stones. Police used stun grenades and rubber bullets to disperse the rioters.
On 24 September, about 40 EFF members staged a protest at Shoprite, Greenacres calling for the release of jailed AbaThembu King Buyelekhaya Dalindyebo.

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; AZAPO: Azanian Peoples Organization
column17: On 24 September, EFF national chairperson Dali Mpofu with local AZAPO members marched with supporters, traditional leaders and members of the SA Council of Churches in East London calling for the release of jailed AbaThembu King Buyelekhaya Dalindyebo.

On 25 September, altercation between protesters and police on Jakes Gerwel Drive in Bonteheuwel. Police used stun grenades and rubber bullets to disperse the protesters during the violence. Eight arrested.

On 25 September, more than 30 residents, including children, blockaded the entrance to Hanover Park at the Turfhall Road intersection in Athlone, holding posters and chanting â€šÃ„Ã¶âˆšÃ‘âˆšâˆ«enough is enoughâ€šÃ„Ã¶âˆšÃ‘âˆšÏ€
On 26 September, Silverton high school pupils in Pretoria disrupted classes during a protest. There were no reports of violence.

On 26 September, firefighters at 30 stations across Cape Town held a lunchtime picket over their working conditions, including the lack of danger pay, promotion obstacles and the decreasing rate of pay for 24-hour shifts.
On 26 September, protesters in Stofland blocked the N1 highway at De Doorns, in the Cape Winelands district, with rocks and threw stones at vehicles.
On 26 September, taxi drivers were seen picketing and holding banners on the N2 in Athlone. The reasons for the protest were uncertain.

On 26 September, about 30 residents of Despatch in the Eastern Cape protested outside the Uitenhage Magistrates Court, demanding action against what they say is an increase in armed robberies and murders in their area.
On 27 September, protests again flared up in Reiger Park over electricity woes. Police was accused of dispersing the protesters with too much force.
On 27 September, residents have blocked roads around Westbury in Johannesburg with rocks and burning tyres after a woman was shot dead. She was caught in the crossfire of a shootout.
On 27 September, protesting former Ekurhuleni municipal workers were met with rubber bullets, teargas and the k-word when they marched to the Germiston Civic Centre.

On 27 September,  Mzamomhle (Gonubie) residents gathered outside their local clinic to protest against what they say is a shortage of nurses. About 20 people were brandishing placards demanding extra nurses be hired.

column7: DeafSA: Deaf Federation of South Africa
column17: On 28 September, members of the Deaf Federation of South Africa (DeafSA) Western Cape marched to the offices of the provincial education minister in Cape Town.
On 28 September, hundreds of people from various civil society organisations marched through the streets of Braamfontein to increase awareness about unsafe abortion and reproductive rights
On 28 September, some tyres were burnt on the N3 freeway Durban bound near Spaghetti Junction - in what could possibly belinked to fuel protests around the city.
On 1 October, Protesters burned tyres on a road near Mossel Bay. The reasons for the protest were not immediately clear.
On 1 October, bikers gathered to stage a mass ride to Cape Town Magistrates' Court to protest at the murder case of Zelda van Niekerk, who was shot and robbed over the weekend.
On 1 October, students at the Durban University of Technology (DUT), embarked on a protest over allowances. They vowed to intensify the strike in the coming days if their concerns are not addressed.

On 1 October, angry residents used burning tyres, rubbish and rocks to block the roads to protest rampant crime and gangsterism in Westbury in Johannesburg. Some residents threw petrol bombs at the police. The police retaliated by firing rubber bullets and teargas, leavng 15 injured.

column7: POPCRU: Police and Prisons Civil Rights Union (South Africa); Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 1 October, about 20 members of Popcru from Johannesburg joined members of the Correctional Services and protested in Pretoria over working conditions.
On 2 October, protests took place outside the Pretoria Magistrate's Court as a man appeared for the rape of a 7-year-old girl at Dros in Silverton.

On 2 October, One Rea Vaya station in Westbury was torched overnight and roads were blockaded, wreaking havoc with traffic in and around the suburb. The protest was over rampant crime and gangterism in the community.
On 3 October, two children were killed when an unknown assailant petrol bombed a house at Sekgakgapeng village in the Mahwelereng Policing precinct outside Mokopane.
On 3 October, over 200 people marched from Keizergracht to Parliament and the Western Cape government provincial offices as part of the #WesternCapeShutdown against gang violence.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 3 October, angry SA Municipal Workers' Union (Samwu)-affiliated workers brought Aliwal North and Burgersdorp to a standstill as they blocked roads with tyres and rocks and threw rubbish on the streets. They held the two top officials hostage at Mpungose's office.
On 4 October, about 100 learners marched for scholar transport in Wellington.

On 5 October, scores of frustrated Enkanini residents from Cato Crest informal settlement marched to the human settlements department office in Durban demanding to be included in the City's development projects
On 5 October, people protested against marginalisation and neglect by the government in Ennerdale, throwing stones at passing cars and at officers deployed to the area.

column7: ANC: African National Congress; SANCO: South African National Civics Organization; COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; SACP: South African Communist Party; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 5 October, hundreds of ANC members from greater Johannesburg - in collaboration with alliance partners Sanco, the SACP and Cosatu - marched to the offices of Mayor Herman Mashaba, Premier David Makhura and Eskom to hand over memorandums demanding service delivery.

column7: HOSPERSA: Health and Other Service Personnel Trade Union of South Africa; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 5 October, KwaZulu-Natal community care givers (CCGs) and HOSPERSA members, data captures and nurses marched to the office of the premier in Pietermaritzburg.

On 5 October, Eldorado Park residents joined in the ""JHB South Shutdown"" to protest against the marginalisation of the coloured community in democratic South Africa, setting rocks and tyres on the golden highway.
On 5 October, hundreds of civil society activists and commuters gathered outside the Cape Town station in protest over the failing train system.
On 6 October, a crowd of people protested against drugs and drug dealers in Hillbrow . Police fired rubber bullets at angry protesters as people were reportedly attacking suspects and properties.
On 7 October, frustrations over a two-week power outage and municipal silence drove residents of Madeira Park in Komani to the streets in protest.
On 7 October, a man died and two others were injured when a mob attacked them, accusing them of terrorising the community in Olievenhoutbosch, Centurion, Pretoria.
On 8 October, residents took to the streets demanding the delivery of the N14 development project promised to them in 2006 in Ventersdorp.
On 8 October, police fired rubber bullets at protesting residents who were pelting vehicles with stones in Barkly West.
On 8 October, a protest at the King William's Town township took place at the ANC provincial headquarters in Calata House.

column9: Civilians (South Africa); Shangaan Ethnic Group (South Africa)
column17: On 8 October 2018, several attacks and looting were registered against Shangaan and Mozambican individuals in Duduza (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng) after a baby was found dead. Residents suspected that the perpetrator of the crime was of Shangaan origin. The attacks lasted until 10 October 2018. 3 people were arrested. [size=at least 3]

column7: ABMSM: Abahlali Basemjondolo Shack Dwellers Movement
column17: On 8 October, over 150 activists linked to the Abahlali Basemjondolo Shack Dwellers Movement marched from the Methodist church in Greenmarket Square to the Cape Town police station. They carried makeshift coffins in remembrance of the activists that have been killed.

On 8 October, protesters in Freedom Park sang as they marched to the office of the Department of Human Settlements in Eldorado Park. They were protesting over 'empty land promises by the office for human settlement'.

On 8 October, dozens of shack dwellers who live in a Temporary Relocation Area (TRA) in Wallacedene marched to Kraaifontein police station to deliver a memorandum of demands to the City of Cape Town over the provision of housing.
On 8 October, protests over power outages continued, albeit briefly, in Komani.

column7: ABMSM: Abahlali Basemjondolo Shack Dwellers Movement
column17: On 8 October, shack dwellers movement, Abahlali baseMjondolo took to the streets of Durban in protest over what they allege is repression by the members from the city.

column9: Civilians (South Africa); Shangaan Ethnic Group (South Africa)
column17: On 9 October 2018, several attacks and looting were registered against Shangaan and Mozambican individuals in Duduza (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng) after a baby was found dead. Residents suspected that the perpetrator of the crime was of Shangaan origin. The attacks started on 8 October 2018 and lasted until 10 October 2018. [size=no report]

On 9 October, members of the Total Shutdown Gauteng grouping marched on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange (JSE), demanding a full audit of coloured representation in listed businesses and a commitment to rectifying the lack of coloured representivity.
On 9 October, about 100 shack dwellers marched to the Civic Centre in Cape Town to demand that the City provide basic services in New Monwabisi Park, Khayelitsha.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 10 October, during a NEHAWU strike, in Cape Town, about 15 protesters stood at the Eerste River office. A handful of protesters were also seen outside the Mitchells Plain office. Both offices were open and operating though.

On 10 October, violent protests erupted in Ventersdorp over the government's failure to deliver the N14 development project promised to them since 2006. There was a running battle between the police and protesting residents as residents pelted the police with stones fired from catapults and the police fired rubber bullets and teargas to disperse the protesters. 11 arrested.

column9: Civilians (South Africa); Shangaan Ethnic Group (South Africa)
column17: On 10 October 2018, several attacks and looting were registered against Shangaan and Mozambican individuals in Duduza (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng) after a baby was found dead. Residents suspected that the perpetrator of the crime was of Shangaan origin. The attacks started on 8 October 2018. [size=no report]

On 10 October (on or around), three security guards in Bonela were attacked by land invaders. The mob hurled stones and other objects at the guards and one of them was stabbed during the invasion. The three men were treated in hospital.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 10 October, during a NEHAWU strike, SASSA employees picket outside the Motherwell office in Port Elizabeth.
On 10 October, a protest at the King William's Town township took place at the ANC provincial headquarters in Calata House.
On 11 October, more then 150 workers at Unisa protested outside the main building this morning after making their voices heard for allegedly being unfairly dismissed.
On 11 October, protesters threw rocks at cars on the N2 between Grabouw and Blikkiesdorp in the Western Cape.
On 11 October, protests in Ventersdorp continues as a van was reportedly pelted with stones, damaging the windscreen. Protests were over the lack of development on the N14.
On 11 October, Sweet Waters residents in King Williams Town demanding a graveyard and better roads have torched an HIV and children's NGO centre and a community hall in a second day of protests.
On 12 October, the community in Riverlea took to the streets and barricaded roads with materials. The reason for the protests was not clear.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 12 October, Cosatu protests against higher fuel prices and VAT took place at the Marianhill toll plaza. Police fired stun grenades at protesting Cosatu members.
On 12 October, the community of Cato Crest embarked on a protest and blockaded the Vusi Mzimela (Bellair) Road with burning tyres, stones and rubble. A car was also damaged in the violence.
On 15 October, workers assembled at the Sunnyside Campus to protest an interdiction from entering the main campus in Muckleneuk.

On 15 October, about 200 MyCiTi bus employees protested in front of the Cape Town Civic Centre to demand better working conditions. The peaceful protest was dispersed as at least 10 stun grenades were detonated.
On 15 October, roads were blocked with rocks and burning tyres in Zandspruit as residents were unhappy about children being electrocuted by illegal electricity connections.
On 15 October, nursing students refused to write their second exam in community nursing science and decided to hold a sit-in protest at their campus in Johannesburg.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 15 October, workers (SAMWU) who are demanding permanent positions, took their grievances to the street in Ngcobo, burning tyres and blocking roads. Garbage piled up on the streets of the small town.

On 16 October, an estimated 100 community members took to the streets to protest against unemployment in Stutterheim. Three municipal buildings had been burned down in the process. Police shot rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. One male was shot and taken to hospital for treatment
On 16 October, roads was blocked with rocks and burning tyres in Zandspruit for a second day as residents were unhappy about children being electrocuted by illegal electricity connections.

On 16 October, a group of around 100 workers trashed the Kimberley civic centre (EPWP workers strew rubbish and broken bottles around the municipal offices and smashed computer parts) and were blamed for the cancellation of a Sol Plaatje City Council meeting.

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 16 October, bus drivers protested outside the Cape Town Civic Centre forcing the city to close its doors. The Economic Freedom Fighters have also joined in the strike supporting workers.
On 17 October, more than 200 hundred residents from Wallacedene in Kraaifontein demonstrated outside the Western Cape High Court over a land invasion case against the city.

On 17 October, about 30 protesters gathered outside the Coca-Cola company offices in Rosebank where they demanded that the international drinks firm stop advertising and selling its sugary products at schools.
On 17 October, a pastor's lawyer was harassed and followed to his car by a group of angry protesters outside the Port Elizabeth High Court. There were no reports of violence.

On 17 October, angry commuters torched two train carriages at Germiston Station in Ekurhuleni in frustration over being late for work for a second day running after scheduled trains experienced delays.
On 17 October, Mkhuhlu community members clashed with a pastor's supporters outside the Calcutta Magistrate's Court during a hearing.
On 17 October 2018, properties belonging to foreign nationals have been looted after a 26-year-old man was arrested for murder in Middelburg, Mpumalanga. [size=no report]
On 18 October, an African National Congress councillor was gunned down in uMlazi, south of Durban.

On 19 October, a protest took place in Atlantis over the construction of a building resulting in seven people were arrested. Residents blockaded the roads with burning tyres, rubble and other objects. Police used stun grenades and rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.
On 20 October, members of the Seshego community hunted down a murder suspect and killed him with various objects in a incidence of mob violence in Seshego, Limpopo.

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; ANC: African National Congress
column17: On 21 October, a church in Port Elizabeth has been temporarily shut down after protesters raised various issues with the church, including it being based in a business zone. EFF and ANC members, protested outside the premises.
On 21 October, an ANC Ward Councillor and his cousin were shot dead in Bloemkombos.

On 21 October 2018, a large crowd of people set several foreign owned shops on fire in Hillbrow' Johannesburg (Gauteng) as they accused foreigner nationals of housing drug dens. Shop owners stated that the attacks were xenophobic. [size=large]
On 22 October, residents - mainly elderly women - picketed outside ANC headquarters in Johannesburg , demanding land.
On 22 October, about 30 residents of Freedom Park (Eldorado Park) in Johannesburg South barricaded the Golden Highway with burning tyres and rocks to demand land for houses.
On 22 October, parents locked the gates to Greenbury Primary School in Phoenix and protested to prevent the newly appointed principal from entering.

On 22 October, nursing students protested outside the offices of the MEC for Health in Kimberley as well as at the entrance to a hospital, the South African Nurses Council (SANC) would be reducing its intake of nurses.
On 23 October, students marched down from the TUT Soshanguve campus, chanting and holding up placards.

On 23 October, five striking MyCiTi bus drivers were arrested after police used stun grenades to disperse strikers at the Civic Centre station in Cape Town. There was no reports of violence on the part of the strikers.

On 23 October, police used rubber bullets to disperse a group of protesters at Ikemeleng in Kroondal near Rustenburg. The police were removing rocks used to barricade roads when protesters pelted them with stones, prompting them to fire rubber bullets into the crowd.
On 23 October, pupils at a school in Lusikisiki started protesting over exam issues they were not happy with.

On 23 October, angry residents of Mayibuye, near Rabie Ridge in Ekurhuleni protested, burnt tyres in the area, barricaded streets and later attacked a sub station. Residents were protesting over the disconnection of illegally connected electricity in the area
On 23 October, a bus was stoned in Khayelitsha amid an ongoing ""wildcat"" strike by drivers who are demanding insourcing and better working conditions.
On 23 October, the Right2Know campaign held a placard demonstration outside the SABC in Sea Point to protest the turnaround strategy of the corporation.
On 24 October, traffic on the N2 between Butterworth and Dutywa was disrupted by protesting students from King Hintsa TVET College. Some road signs were damaged during the protest.
On 24 October, members of the KaMhlushwa community looted and burnt shops at a local shopping complex, after a shop owner allegedly assaulted an employee. 10 people have been arrested.
On 24 October, several church leaders and civil society held a march against gender based violence in Port Elizabeth.
On 24 October, an ANC KwaZulu-Natal councillor's house has been set alight by unknown suspects in Mazabekweni, in Ixopo.
During the week of 24 October (unkwown exact date), a group of striking workers stoned the ALPLA SA plant in Isando.
On 24 October, matrics at a Lusikisiki protest assaulted the school's deputy principal and torched the school's admin block in ongoing protests.
On 24 October, police were forced to use stun grenades to disperse angry community members outside the municipality's offices in Koffiefontein who were protesting against poor service delivery.
On 25 October, members of the Ocean View community in Cape Town took to the streets to voice their frustrations at shootings and other violence in the area. Tyres were burnt in the street.
On 25 October, in Nyanga, protesters set two trucks alight to protest poor service delivery and unemployment.

column7: Solidarity and AfriForum; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 25 October, trade union Solidarity marched to Sasol's headquarters in Sandton' Johannesburg' as it continued to protest against the company's share scheme' which it claims excludes white employees.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 25 October, around 100 people sang outside a court Cape Town during a land seizure case. Meanwhile, firefighters also marched in the Cape Town CBD with SAMWU and handed over a memorandum of demands.
On 25 October 2018, about 200 former municipal workers marched to the Civic Centre in Germiston to demand they be reinstated as permanent employees of Ekurhuleni Municipality. [size=200].
On 25 October 2018, hundreds of ANC supporters also gathered outside the Civic Centre in solidarity for Ekurhuleni mayor Mzwandile Masina ahead of the DA's motion of no confidence. [size=100].

column7: Labour Group (South Africa); EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters
column17: On 26 October, EFF members as they picketed outside the ELM main building in Vanderbijlpark before handing a memorandum to the acting Mayor Robert Thema on Friday.
On 27 October, residents of Hillbrow have taken to the streets against drugs in the area and marched to the police station.
On 28 October, a business was burnt to the ground in Ladybrand during ongoing labour strikes.
On 29 October, expanded Public Works Programme workers stormed Durban City Hall to demand that their salaries be paid to them.
On 29 October, Sterkstroom residents went on a rampage and set a municipal building alight after a meeting meant to elect ward committees did not materialise.

On 29 October, students at Tompi Seleka College of Agriculture embarked on a three-week strike, in which properties were damaged. The students demanded that their concerns around the maintenance of the college building and surroundings be attended to.
On 29 October, 'Black Monday' protesters marched to the US Embassy and the Australian High Commission in Pretoria.

On 29 October, twenty-seven people were arrested for public violence and malicious damage to property after an illegal march in Stellenbosch. Protesters damaged several properties, threw dangerous projectiles such as bricks and beer bottles, and physically threatened municipal staff with knobkerries.
On 30 October, protests began over allegations of nepotism and issues over social grants.

column7: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 30 October, AMCU member demonstrated outside the Brits Magistrates Court during the trial of murder accused.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 30 October, NUMSA members picketed peacefully outside the local Mpact Plastics company in Pinetown.
On 29 October, expanded Public Works Programme workers stormed Durban City Hall to demand that their salaries be paid to them.
On 30 October, a group of employees protested outside the Civitas Building in Pretoria over unsafe working conditions.
On 31 October, President Cyril Ramaphosa arrived at the Union Buildings to accept a memorandum from #TotalShutDown protesters who had marched to the buildings against gender-based violence.
On 31 October, NGO Ilitha Labantu held a march march in Khayelitshato encourage victims of domestic violence and women and child abuse to speak out and educate residents about violence.
On 31 October, aggrieved workers at the controversial West Rand municipality in the west of Johannesburg brought the municipality to standstill in protests over a pay dispute.

On 31 October, about 800 angry youngsters from Stutterheim's Mlungisi Township protested and clashed with police who used rubber bullets, tear gas and stones to disperse them. Stones were reported to have been thrown and protesters barricading roads with rocks, woods and burning tyres.
On 31 October, two ALPLA non-striking staff were hospitalised after they were attacked in their homes. A business owner in Kempton Park was also attacked during the violence.
On 1 November, an ALPL delivery vehicle was petrol bombed during a labour strike in Johannesburg.
On 1 November, three people were injured (one was shot, one was stoned) when they were trying to escape from a mob that was stoning them at a church in Zuurbekom, Randfontein.
On 1 November, police and protesters clashed over land in Hermanus over housing issues. Stun grenades were fired to disperse people who had set tyres alight.

column7: ANC: African National Congress; COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; SACP: South African Communist Party; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 2 November, thousands of ANC members, marching with Congress of SA Trade Unions (Cosatu), the South African Communist Party, civic society organisations like Organisation Undoing Tax Abuse (Outa) and members of the public on a march to the Union Buildings, demanding that e-tolls be scrapped.
On 4 November, Lentegeur residents in Cape Town took to the streets to highlight their concerns about gang violence in the area.
On 5 November, hundreds of Mala-Mala land claim beneficiaries picketed outside the Communal Property Association (CPA) offices at Lilydale, in Bushbuckridge, Mpumalanga.
On 6 November, residents in Makana Municipality are asking for the council to be dissolved when they protested in Makhanda (Grahamstown).
On 6 November, a group of people demanding jobs shut down the Ditsobotla Municipality in Lichtenburg in protest.
On 7 November, the house of a DA councillor in Johannesburg has been burnt to the ground. Unclear reasons for the protests at time of reporting.
On 7 November, a MyCiTi bus has been set alight in Khayelitsha during ongoing bus strikes.
On 7 November, a MyCiTi bus has been set alight in Milnerton during ongoing bus strikes.
On 7 November, chaotic scenes played out at the ANC's Nelson Mandela Bay headquarters, Florence Matomela House, as provincial executive leaders were barred from holding a meeting by angry protesters.

On 7 November, residents of Mtwaku location in Flagstaff, Eastern Cape, marched on the magistrate's court, the police station and the municipal offices, demanding better policing, tougher action against rapists and other criminals and better living conditions
On 8 November, residents from Rosettenville gathered at the public hospital to demand that staff alleged to have ill-treated patients be removed from the facility.
On 8 November, disgruntled Ward 41 residents in Joe Slovo marched to councillor Simphiwe Tyukana's office in protest.

On 8 November, a truck was stoned on Malibongwe drive during violent protests by residents of an informal settlement in Kya Sands in Randburg, North of Johannesburg. It's not yet clear what the protest is about.

column7: Labour Group (South Africa); TUSO: Trade Union Security Organisation
column17: On 9 Novermber, members of the Trade Union Security Organisation (TUSO) marched to the Department of Labour offices in George to handover a list of grievances against their employer.

column7: CWU: Communication Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 9 November, in an attempt to save their jobs, SABC employees with the Communication Workers Union wore black and held a lunch-hour picket at the headquarters in Auckland Park.
On 10 November, about 100 farm workers and their supporters marched to Endulini Fruit Farm in Patensie, Eastern Cape, to hand over a list of demands to managers. The farm is a leading fruit exporter.
On 10 November, residents of Eersterust marched to Tshwane House in protest.
On 11 November, a ANC councillor's office in Asherville was burnt in what appears to be an internal dispute.

On 12 November, about 20 young men blocked the entrance to Mlungisi township in Stutterheim with bricks and tree branches protesting over service delivery. They also threw stones and bottles at five police officers. As the protesters got closer, police fired rubber bullets and used tear gas to disperse the small crowd.
On 12 November, residents of Budeli, Tshikhudini, Mphego and other nearby villages around Madzivhandila Agricultural College in Thoyando over the lack of jobs.
On 13 November, residents took to the streets with sjamboks, sticks and knobkieries to demand better service delivery in Vredenburg. They clashed with police resulting in the injury to one officer.
On 13 November, residents took to the streets over land and housing and used burning tyres and logs of wood to blockade a road in Mariannridge near Pinetown.

On 13 November, Mpumalanga police arrested five protesters after they disrupted examinations and badly beat up a police officer at the University of Mpumalanga in Nelspruit. Three vehicles were damaged.

On 14 November, about 1,000 people protested in Vredenburg for the second day in a row, demanding housing and cheaper water and electricity. Armed with sjamboks and sticks, demonstrators blocked the streets with burning tyres and rubble, preventing vehicles from entering or leaving. A police station had been stoned during protests and ten police vehicles had been damaged

column7: Labour Group (South Africa); EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters
column17: On 15 November, members of the Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) staged a demonstration outside the gates of Edenglen High School.

On 15 November, a march took place in Saldanha Bay with burning tyres and throwing stones in the roads and at police by a group of about 5 000 people. A lack of housing, high water and electricity tariffs, and the municipality's ""unfair subsidy terms"" were some of the concerns voiced by protesters.

On 15 November, a group of about 200 demonstrators from the Motsoaledi informal settlement damaged glass doors in the Johannesburg Metro Centre building in Braamfontein as they protested over housing.

column7: Labour Group (South Africa); EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters
column17: On 15 November, in Rosslyn, thousands of EFF supporters marched to factories in a campaign meant to shut the industrial park down for the day.

column7: Labour Group (South Africa); NUPSAW: National Union of Public Service and Allied Workers
column17: On 16 November, Canal Walk shopping centre in Cape Town, where Dis-Chem shops were located, experienced disruptions for about two hours as staff members protested. The protest was part of a strike organised by the National Union of Public Service and Allied Workers.

column7: Labour Group (South Africa); NUPSAW: National Union of Public Service and Allied Workers
column17: On 16 November, in Sandton, where Dis-Chem shops were located, experienced disruptions for about two hours as staff members protested. The protest was part of a strike organised by the National Union of Public Service and Allied Workers.

column7: Labour Group (South Africa); NUPSAW: National Union of Public Service and Allied Workers
column17: On 16 November, Gauteng police used rubber bullets to disperse about 2 000 workers belonging to the National Union of Public Service and Allied Workers (Nupsaw), who were protesting outside Dis-Chem's offices in Midrand, Johannesburg. There were no reports of violence from the protesters.

On 16 November, dozens of people marched from John Ross Park to the Johannesburg City Council in Braamfontein, to protest the municipality's charging of fees to protest. The march was organised by the Right2know.

On 16 November, protests continued in Saldanha over various service delivery issues as a community hall, a municipal office and part of a local holiday resort were burnt. Several homes and vehicles were damaged and a local butchery was ransacked. The local clinic was also burnt.
On 16 November, dozens of City of Cape Town employees marched to the Civic Centre in Cape Town to demand permanent employment and the right to join unions.
