column7: Labour Group (South Africa); NUM: National Union of Mineworkers
column17: On 17 November, workers union joined forces with trade union NUM to march against the power utility's signing of Independent Power Producers contracts and the possible privatisation of Eskom. They gathered at the Union Buildings in Pretoria.
On 17 November, two schools and a clinic have been set alight in Ramokokastad outside Rustenburg in the North West. It was not clear as to who is behind this or what triggered the incident

On 17 November, unrest started when Mogale City's mayor met with community members in Hekpoort. The community was unhappy, demanding promised housing. They became angry and violent, burning tyres and throwing stones at officials. Police used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd.

column7: Labour Group (South Africa); EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters
column17: On 19 November, workers sang and danced outside the East London factory in West Bank in front of plant manager Kevin Scott, accused the firm of exploiting them. The EFF joined the protest.

column7: Labour Group (South Africa); EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters
column17: On 19 November, the EFF protested outside the venue of a testimony delivered by the Public Enterprises Minister at the state capture inquiry in Parktown, Johannesburg.
On 19 November, a service delivery protest took place in Boksburg on the East Rand. The group of residents barricaded roads with burning tyres.

column7: Labour Group (South Africa); NUPSAW: National Union of Public Service and Allied Workers
column17: On 19 November, Dis-Chem employees demonstrated and picketed outside the Western Cape Distribution Centre in La Belle Road, Stikland, demanding a monthly wage of R12500. The protest was part of a strike organised by the National Union of Public Service and Allied Workers.
On 20 November, protesters set two trucks alight in protests in Stutterheim in the Eastern Cape. Police was deployed to disperse the crowds.

On 20 November, police used stun grenades to disperse protesters who took to the streets to highlight ongoing gentrification in the historic neighbourhood. They were reported to have clashed with police.
On 20 November, protesters burnt tires in a municipal strike in East London. Police fired rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse the crowds.
On 20 November, protesters burnt tires in a municipal strike in King Williams. Police fired rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse the crowds.
On 20 November, residents of France location in Lusikisiki protested outside the Magistrates' Court in support of five men accused of murder and assault after a man died last week.
On 21 November, miners shot at employees of the Sibanye-Stillwater mine in Welkom during overnight protests. One employee was killed and others were injured.
On 21 November, a MyCiTi bus was torched on Koeberg road in Cape Town as part of the ongoing bus strike. one person was arrested.
On 21 November (date not known), members of the community in Leboeng near Burgerfort caught three suspected criminals and beat them up.

column7: Labour Group (South Africa); NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union
column17: On 21 November, the National Education, Health and Allied Workers' Union (Nehawu) held a picket outside the offices of the Health Professions Council of South Africa (HPCSA) in Pretoria.
On 21 November, residents picketed outside the municipal office in Mitchells Plain to highlight their grievances over high water bills.

On 21 November, the City of Cape Town's civic centre was locked down after a group of MyCiTi protesters entered the ground floor of the building. The protest became violent as stun grenades were let off in the area outside the entrance while strikers outside the civic centre threw stones at police in retaliation.
On 21 November, residents in Koffiefontein marched to the local magistrate's court and barricaded roads with burning tyres and stones. the residents were demanding equal treatment from police.
On 21 November (date not known), Amy Foundation employees protested outside their Athlone.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 21 November, hundreds of workers from the Buffalo City Metropolitan Municipality (BCMM) marched outside the City Hall in East London, calling for the permanent employment of temporary workers and an improvement in their working conditions. The workers are members of the South African Municipal Workers' Union (SAMWU). .

On 21 November, upset about high utility bills, Wesbank residents in Malmesbury took to the streets. Most of them were women. Some pushed babies in prams. They marched to the Swartland municipal office.
On 21 November, protest action took place in the KwaDwesi area. The protesters allegedly set alight a truck in Mission Road, Port Elizabeth.
On 21 November, service delivery protests closed the R67 between Grahamstown and Port Alfred.
On 21 November, fires burnt in King Williams Town and an electric boxes near Shoprite are also burning in ongoing protests. Rioters threw stones at the police vehicles. No arrest were made.
On 22 November, a small group of angry parents gathered outside a school in Kwadabeka to support striking teachers.
On 22 November, five Cape Town communities joined with social justice movements to march to the Cape Town Civic Centre.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 22 November, about 200 members of COSATU and other allied workers unions marched to the office of the premier in Pietermaritzburg demanding changes to labour policy.
On 22 November, a group of about 40 protestors from Kwathema, a township in Ekurhuleni, marched to a fertiliser manufacturing plant to object to its use of chemicals.
On 22 November, a crowd gathered outside the Bronkhorstspruit Magistrate's Court to support a rape and sexual assault accused prophet.

On 23 November, residents of Westville, Port Elizabeth held protests, demanding a meeting with the mayor over service delivery. Four vehicles were torched in the protest and police arrested two people for public violence.

On 24 November, police used rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse a group of angry residents in Kensington. Five police vehicles were damaged. The incident happened as South Africans were gearing up to join the world in commemorating International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women and Girls
On 24 November, during a protest, Kensington residents tried to lynch a man believed to be a family friend of a teenager who he is accused of raping.
On 26 November, a councillor was killed in Riba Cross outside Burgersfort.
On 26 November, several community members took part in a march in George to support activism against violence against women and children.

On 26 November, Environment MEC and leaders of SanParks and the EC parks and tourism agency led a 300-strong march of activists, citizens and private and ECPTA game rangers in Makhanda to protest rhino poaching.
On 26 November, residents from Newlands East once against held a demonstration outside the Unilever offices at Riverhorse Valley demanding that locals be considered for jobs.
On 26 November, about 200 land invaders, believed to be from uMlazi and surrounding areas, headed for the D'Moss nature reserve on Riviera Road, where they burned tyres.
On 26 November, three trucks were set alight at a packaging industry strike in Isando, Johannesburg. Striking workers are suspected to be responsible for the blaze.
On 26 November, protest action stretched from Philip Nel Park to Danville in Pretoria, protesters barricaded roads with rocks and burning tyres on Staatsartillerie and Rebecca streets.

column7: NUM: National Union of Mineworkers; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 26 November, over 1,000 workers aligned to NUM protested outside the Optimum Mpumalanga mine in Middelburg.
On 26 November, activists gathered outside the Pretoria Magistrate Court to support the family of a girl who was allegedly raped an d call to protect women and children
On 26 November, ANC members protested outside the Richmond Magistrate's Court where two men held for the murder of slain municipal manages made a brief appearance.
On 26 November, workers shut down the Fort Napier Medico Legal Mortuary in Pietermaritzburg. They barricaded the road, blocking the mortuary gates with mortuary vans.

On 26 November 2018, two people were arrested after protests flared up again in Stutterheim. Protesters had blocked the main road with dustbins and demanded business owners close shop. Police shot rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. [size=no report].
On 27 November, service delivery protesters forced a truck carrying manganese to dump its load in the road in the middle of Barkly West in the Northern Cape.
On 27 November, supporters of Jade September picket outside the Cape Town High Court.

On 28 November, social housing activist group Reclaim the City staged a protest at the home of deputy mayor Ian Neilson in Table View, to object to the delay in the investigation into the Site B land auction on the Foreshore.

column7: Private Security Forces (South Africa); Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 28 November 2018, about 40 members of the Masibonisane Security and Cleaners' Forum marched to Parliament to try to hand over a memorandum about working conditions to President Cyril Ramaphosa and to the Economic Freedom Fighters Party. [size=no report].

On 28 November 2018, about 80 members of Equal Education, mostly school students, braved the cold weather and wind to sleep outside Parliament in a protest over government's failure to implement basic infrastructure for schools. [size=no report].

On 28 November, young people from different political formations and civic society group picketed outside the Pretoria Magistrate's Court as a man appeared for allegedly molesting a seven-year-old girl at a Dros restaurant.

column7: DEMAWUSA: Democratic Municipal and Allied Workers Union of South Africa; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 29 November 2018, about 100 people from the Extended Public Works Progamme, MyCiTi, and the Municipal and Allied Trade Union of South Africa marched to the civic centre in Cape Town to deliver a third memorandum addressed to the mayor. [size=100].

On 29 November 2018, about 40 principals of educare centres in Khayelitsha, all women, all dressed in black, protested outside the Department of Social Development in Cape Town asking for improved pay and fee allocation to child care centres. [size=40].
On 30 November, employees unhappy with their working conditions and pay protested in Seapoint.

30 November. Members of the Khoisan ethnic group have begun a sit-in outside the Union Buildings, asking to be recognised as the first indigenous nation in South Africa and to be given land and resources to continue their cultures and traditions. The protests were ongoing as of February 2019.
On 30 November, a security guard sustained critical injuries after protesting workers set fire to a building in Boksburg. Several other people were injured and vehicles and property were set alight.
On 1 December, residents of the crime-plagued communities of Gelvandale and Bethelsdorp threw their weight behind a crime awareness roadshow and protested in Schauderville.

On 2 December, a group of Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) members vandalised an outlet of the mobile communications company Vodacom at the Mall of the North in Polokwane. They were protesting over a photograph used by a speaker at the Vodacom Journalist of the Year event the previous week

On 2 December, a handful of EFF members gathered to shut down the Vodacom store at The Bridge in Port Elizabeth as part of a national call by EFF leaders fuming over a photograph used by a speaker at the Vodacom Journalist of the Year event the previous week. They were dispersed by police but the store closed.

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 3 December, scores of Buffalo City Metro workers who arrived at work were forced out of their work stations by striking workers in East London. This was part of the ongoing illegal strike action by South African Municipal Workers Union (Samwu)-affiliated workers.

On 4 December, a group of ANC members camped outside the African National Congress (ANC) headquarters Luthuli House in the Johannesburg CBD overnight in an attempt to hand over a memorandum to the ruling party in which they demand the removal of their local mayor.
On 4 December, social housing activists Reclaim the City erected shacks at Site B along the Foreshore to protest what they said was the selling of public land by the City to the highest bidder.
On 4 December, the descendants of former farm workers of the Longlands farm were forcibly removed from a Stellenbosch Council meeting after holding a silent protest in the chambers.
On 5 December, a small group of people staged a protest in Westbury. There were no reports of violence.
On 5 December, the Democratic Alliance marched to Gauteng premier David Makhura's office in Johannesburg to protest against the controversial e-tolls and demanding that they be scrapped.
On 5 December, a petrol bomb was hurled at a Myciti bus in Mitchells Plain. There have been transport strikes in the last few weeks.
On 5 December, two groups marched to the Union Buildings in Pretoria. The groups requested President Cyril Ramaphosa receive their memoranda.

column7: NUPSAW: National Union of Public Service and Allied Workers; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 5 December, 200 NUPSAW workers demonstrated in front of the Dis-Chem store in Canal Walk, Cape Town, demanding better wages and working conditions. Police scuffled with demonstrators who insisted on protesting in front of the shop.
On 6 December, in Alexandra, angry residents attempted to stone a man who was accused of starting a fire. He is currently in police custody.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 6 December, striking NEHAWU workers barricaded the gates of the Fort Napier Medico Legal Mortuary in Pietermaritzburg in protest.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 6 December, members of the National Health, Education and Allied Workers' Union (Nehawu) peacefully protested in Hilton as they called for two KZN MECs to be fired. However, police and traffic officers acted swiftly though to disperse the crowd who were singing and dancing on the busy highway.
On 6 December, about 50 Bo-Kaap residents, who were protesting, celebrated as a crane moved out of the Bo-Kaap as a court ruling told the developers not to continue their work.
On 6 December 2018, residents marched along the Durban Beachfront Promenade against proposed offshore oil and gas exploitation, voicing their concerns on placards. [size=no report].
On 6 December 2018, people protested outside a courthouse in Durban over a sexual abuse trial case. [size=no report].
On 7 December, protesters held a protest at Vodaworld in Midrand as Vodacom is yet to pay 'please call me' inventor, Noksana Makate.
On 7 December, around 2 000 people marched from Zwelihle to the Hermanus municipality, peacefully protesting over service delivery in the area.
On 8 December, a mob in Mphephu outside Thohoyandou in Limpopo attacked and killed 3 men, suspected of killing another man at a tavern.
On 10 December, about 15 people gathered outside the Wynberg Magistrates Court to protest outside the bail hearing of the man accused of attacking 63-year-old Dianne Case.
On 10 December, a crowd of people allegedly got off a bus at the Woodmead Retail Park and stormed the local Dis-Chem branch, pelting it with stones and rock

On 11 December, employees from several plastic companies protested and attacked the Gundle Plastic group in Germiston. They allegedly barged through the gate and assaulted two workers and damaged 30 cars, of which three were set alight.

Around 11 December 2018 (as reported), two refugees from the Democratic Republic of Congo were burnt to death, and their bodies found in the Adams Mission area in Durban (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal). Authorities linked the deaths to a xenophobic attack.

On 11 December, more than 40 people, individuals and representatives of various organisations - 350africa.org, Fossil free for South Africa, Project 90 by 2030, Green Anglicans among others - picketed at the Energy Week Gas summit at the Westin Hotel in Cape Town
On 12 December, community members held a short demonstration outside the Ekangala Magistrate's Court

On 12 December, farmers marched along with their cattle to the Enoch Mgijima municipal offices in Komani demanding that the municipality provide them with more land for grazing. The march brought the town's main road, Cathcart Road, to a total standstill, resulting in the municipality scheduling a meeting.
On 12 December, siblings accused of being witches were burnt to death in Ngonyameni village, Emaxesibeni near Mt.Ayliff before their houses were also razed.
On 12 December, a group of about 25 people claiming to be members of the ANC branches in the North West province held a protest outside the party headquarters in Johannesburg.
On 13 December, a man was arrested following an exchange of rocks and stun grenades between fired Cape Town MyCiTi drivers and police, as a council meeting was being held in the Civic Centre.

On 13 December, angry Hillside township residents in Cradock barricaded roads with burning tyres demanding water from the Chris Hani District municipality after spending more than two months without the natural resource.
On 14 December, as part of the 16 Days of Activism campaign, the Sinika Uthando Foundation held a peaceful march and placard demonstration in Durban.

On 15 December, a protest broke out in Jabulani in Soweto where residents are calling for an improvement in water and sanitation conditions in the area. Demonstrators blocked roads with rocks and set tyres alight.
On 19 December, two dozen activists gathered in an hour-long vigil outside the Makhanda (Grahamstown) City Hall, renewing their call for the Makana Council to be dissolved.

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 20 December, the National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa (Numsa) and other trade unions took to the streets in Cape Town to protest against police brutality and low wages.

column6: Police Forces of South Africa (1994-) Anti-Land Invasion Unit
column17: On 20 December, 46 shacks were demolished and three torched, allegedly by a land invasion unit, during evictions at the Khenana Informal Settlement in Cato Crest.
On 23 December, a woman was burnt to death at Booksneck village in EmaXesibeni (Mt Ayliff) after being accused of witchcraft. This is the second attack in as many weeks in the area around witchcraft.
On 27 December, residents protested outside the Bishop Lavis police station to hand over their demands to reduce crime and gangsterism in the community.
On 28 December, #ReclaimClifton protesters gathered and protested on Cape Town's popular Clifton beach after reports that private security guards had removed the public from the beach.
On 31 December, two men suspected of being house robbers died after they were severely assaulted by community members in Pienaar.

On 1 January, a Msunduzi Municipality (Pietermaritzburg) bodyguard who was being investigated for possible links to political killings in KwaZulu-Natal was shot dead at midnight (assumed unarmed at the time of the attack).
On 3 January, four men were abducted and three were tortured and killed by community vigilante after being kept in a secret location in Vosman (Emalahleni) for allegedly hijacking taxis in the area.
On 3 January, #FeesMustFall activists deliver memorandum to Presidency after two-week trek from KZN to Pretoria as part of a protest march.

04 October. Demonstrations have been reported in Chesterville. The demonstration was caused by the demolition of some shacks that were build illegally in the area. Roads were barricaded with debris, tyres and bricks. Stone pelting at vehicles have been reported. Demonstrates also attempted to set alight a truck carrying fuel. Police was on the scene. [size=no report].
On 4 January, the Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) held a protest in Strandfontein against gang violence.

column7: SANCO: South African National Civics Organization
column17: On 4 January, Pretoria residents affiliated to the South African National Civic Organisation (Sanco) blocked the entrance of Shepherd Bushiri's Enlightened Christian Gathering (ECG) church in Pretoria against a prophet.
04 October. Residents of Setlagole outside Mahikeng in the North West gathered at the court, demanding the prosecution of older men who are impregnating young school girls. [size=no report].

On 5 January, three people have been arrested after South African Police Service (SAPS) officers came under attack from an unruly mob and some were injured while they were going about their drug-fighting duties in Shallcross in Durban.

column7: APSA: Academic and Professional Staff Association
column17: 01 May. Workers, led by Academic Professional Staff Association (APSA), at the Voortrekker Monument, Pretoria, blocked the entrance with burning tyres. The demonstration was in response to wages. [size=no report].
01 May. Unitas Park residents in the Vaal, Vereeniging, staged a demonstration over service delivery issues. The community has been without electricity since last week. [size=no report].
01 May. Reclaim the City activists demonstrated at the Green Point Bowling Green in Cape Town, demanding that the area to be used for affordable housing. [size=no report].
01 May. Cosatu demonstrated in Constantia over gangsterism in the area. [size=no report].
01 May. A man has been killed by a mob in Hoopstad. The deceased was accused of stabbing another community member. Four people have been arrested [size=4].
On 6 January, Bathembu High School in uMzinyathi district in Msinga, northern KZN, were damaged in suspected arson attacks.
On 6 January, three more houses have been torched in Blybank in Carletonville amid apparent union rivalry near Sibanye-Stillwater gold mine.
On 6 January, Mvuzo High School in France township in Pietermaritzburg were damaged in suspected arson attacks.

On 7 January 2019, as part of a national shutdown of its campuses, students protested at the Durban, Pietermaritzburg and Wild Coast campuses. Students coming to register at the Durban campus were turned away as unions pulled out their workers for safety concerns. [size=no report].

On 7 January, as part of a national shutdown of its campuses, students protested at the Durban, Pietermaritzburg and Wild Coast campuses. Students coming to register at the Durban campus were turned away as unions pulled out their workers for safety concerns.

On 7 January, as part of a national shutdown of its campuses, students protested at the Durban, Pietermaritzburg and Wild Coast campuses. Students coming to register at the Durban campus were turned away as unions pulled out their workers for safety concerns.

On 7 January, residents in Grahamstown barricaded a road in protest against dumping in the area and because they say they have been neglected by the municipality. Tyres were burnt and the streets were rubbished.
On 7 January, a former City and uMgungundlovu District councillor was ambushed and killed at his home in Imbali
On 7 January, a fresh round of protest action over service delivery by communities around the Kruger National Park shut down access to the reserve from the Numbi gate.

column7: MKVMA: Mkhonto weSizwe Military Veterans Association
column17: On 7 January 2019, members of the ANC's uMkhonto weSizwe Military Veterans Association (MKMVA) stormed the party's provincial offices in Durban in KwaZulu-Natal, demanding that their concerns be attended to. [size=no report].

On 8 January, chaos erupted at the University of South Africa (Unisa) Pietermaritzburg campus as protesting students blocked off a street by burning tyres, calling on management to address their demands.

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: On 8 January, a protest by the ANCYL against racism in Bronkhorstspruit took place, where the entire central business district of the small town was shut down.
On 8 January, protesters marched to the provincial legislature in Nelspruit to submit a memorandum of demands to the MEC for public works.
On 9 January, t Chumani Primary School in Reeston, East London parents picketed outside and demanded keys to the office that contain the school's resources.
On 9 January, the first day of the school year at Cape Town's Bergville Primary School in Bishop Lavis kicked off with a picket to highlight complaints over teacher shortages and poor safety.
On 9 January, a group of protesters disrupted three schools in Malmesbury. Protesters demanded that the Western Cape Education Department (WCED) expand and upgrade Naphakade Primary School.
On 9 January, parents of learners from a 50-year-old small church school in Herold near George in the Southern Cape have protested and vowed to do everything to prevent it from closing down.
On 10 January, several parents of children who attend a North West school embroiled in a race controversy, fetched their children from the school as protesters demonstrated on the premises
On 10 January, residents of Bophelong protested with burning tires, stones and branches after their local councillor allegedly had not responded to their pleas for help.
On 10 January, Prpotesters outside Wynberg Magistrates Court call for the death penalty against a paedophile who will be appearing for a bail hearing.

column7: AMCU: Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 10 January, protesting members of the Association of Mineworkers and Construction Union (Amcu) blocked the road in front of the Oberholzer magistrates' court.

column7: SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 11 January, South African Democratic Teachers Union (SADTU) members have gathered outside Pinetown Senior Primary with banners asking for the redeployment of 11 assistant teachers who were 'retrenched' among other issues.

On 11 January, a violent protest that forced the closure of the N3 in the vicinity of Howick in KZN Midlands was sparked by the arrest of community members who had allegedly invaded a private property in the area. Protesters burning tyres and tree logs, after the arrest of the alleged trespassers.
On 13 January, the N3 were blockaded by truck drivers in protest at Van Reenen's pass. Four truck drivers were arrested and their trucks impounded
On 14 January, parents staged a sit-in at the department of education's offices in Butterworth over education.
On 14 January, dozens of parents protested outside a school in Eldorado Park over the termination of temporary teachers' contracts.
On 14 January, a man was burnt to death and his friend severely injured after a mob severely assaulted and later set them alight in Hillbrow.
On 14 January, a protest took place in Greyton. The protest was over the cutting of water supplies.
On 14 January, barricaded roads and flashing police lights reported in large parts of the Lowveld (Pienaar)

On 14 January, pupils and parents forced their way onto the school premises to protest the closure of the school in Uitsig, demanding the return of their teachers and the resumption of academic activities.
On 15 January, registration at the University of Fort Hare in East London had to be called off after angry students stormed registration venues and demanded the process be halted.
On 15 January, Olievenhoutbosch community members took to the R55 to protest following the disappearance of a child. No incidents of violence had been reported.
On 15 January, three men suspected of committing several crimes have been stoned to death in Tshandama outside Thohoyandou in Limpopo.

column8: Police Forces of South Africa (1994-) Anti-Land Invasion Unit
column17: On 15 January, police fired stun grenades at rival factions in an ANC meeting shortly before the council was due to elect a new mayor, speaker and chief whip in Stutterheim. This was after supporters dressed in ANC T-shirts clashed with police

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; ANC: African National Congress
column17: On 15 January, parents of aspirant pupils of Polokwane's Laerskool Ivy Park in Limpopo, joined by the EFF and ANC, protested on the school premises demanding space for their children.
On 16 January, a group of Zimbabwean people protesting outside Zimbabwe's embassy in Pretoria over current crisis in Zimbabwe over fuel hikes.

On 16 January, chaos erupted in Xolobeni in the Eastern Cape at the end of a ""consultation"" meeting between the community and Minister of Mineral Resources. Police also fired stun grenades as community members fled from the back of a huge white marquee, picking up and later slamming chairs to the ground.
On 16 January, Democratic Alliance (DA) supporters in Johannesburg marched in the city and have called for a change of the national leadership with the country going to the polls in May.
On 16 January, a group of residents protested and tried to push their way into Laerskool Schweizer-Reneke in the North West.
On 17 January, a Glebelands Hostel man was shot and killed in his home. This hostel is a notorious hotbed for political violence.
On 17 January, about 40 Zimbabweans living in Cape Town marched from the Grand Parade to the Zimbabwean Consulate protesting against their government's crackdown.
On 17 January 2019, residents from Nolukhanyo township started burning tyres, blocking traffic and demanding that the Mayor address them over service delivery issues. [size=no report].

column8: Police Forces of South Africa (1994-) Anti-Land Invasion Unit
column17: On 17 January, a group of irate shack dwellers gathered on Mary Thiphe (Cato Manor) Road and put tree trunks and branches onto the road following shack demolition efforts in Cato Crest the day before.
On 18 January, police are investigating a case of arson after suspects set alight the house of a local councillor at Msizazwe Locality in Mbizana.

On 18 January, about 40 employees of conveyor belt manufacturer ContiTech picketed outside the company's Uitenhage factory to show their dissatisfaction with its payroll system that they say is deducting too much from their earnings.
On 18 January, delays in compensation payments led family members of Life Esidimeni tragedy victims to stage a protest outside Gauteng Premier David Makhura's offices in Johannesburg.
19 January. Residents marched in Carletonville against lack of service delivery.
19 January. unknown assailant tried to strangle the deputy president of Black First Land First (BLF) in what BLF claimed was a politically motivated act.
21 January (on or around). Parents shut down the Patensie High at Ramaphosa village over prolonged transport issues, which have seen some pupils walk about 10km to get to school.
21 January. People protested against a leaking sewer saw in Mqanduli and Xhora, burning material.
21 January. Protesters blocked a road in Maboloka near Brits with burning tyres, tree branches and rocks during a protest over demands that the ANC provincial task team to be disbanded.
22 January. Workers at the Civitas Building in Tshwane staged a protest outside its headquarters against structural challenges in the building.
22 January. Angry residents shut down a clinic in Umlazi, demanding the head of the department to be fired for ignoring them over a water issue.
22 January. Hundreds of students protested outside the tertiary institution in Durban.

22 January. The Madadeni community erupted in protest after a six-year-old boy died while playing at a local park. A group gathered outside the local clinic, burning tyres and other objects. The residents felt that if the local clinic had been opened, the boy could have been saved.
On 22 January 2019, clashes between armed residents in Mamelodi over occupation of a newly built hostel by foreign nationals have been reported.
22 January. Residents of Philippi set alight four men accused to be behind a spate of house robberies, murders, and stabbings in the community.

column9: Government of South Africa (1994-); Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: 23 January (on or around). Armed contractors prevented access to municipal workers and to trucks to a waste management site in the Madibeng area. They were still preventing access to the site as of three weeks later.

23 January. Parents protested in front of the Veyisi Primary School in Matiwaneskop and closed it off, denouncing the lack of fairness in the teachers' employment process and asking to see the education inspector.
On 23 January 2019, residents protested alongside the Democratic Alliance outside the Phoenix health centre due to the clinic staff's work attitude. [size=no report].

column7: Government of South Africa (1994-); Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 23 January 2019, city contractors started protesting over payments not received for work done in December. [size=no report].

24 January. Members of the community of Boikhutsong near Ventersdorp barricaded the R30 road with burning tyres and stoned passing vehicles stoned asking for a meeting with delegates of the department of education over schools and school transport.
25 January. Residents of Phomolong village in Welkom, fatally stabbed a man who allegedly stabbed his wife.
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including in Amahlati; Mbizana; Thabankulu (Eastern Cape).
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including in Amahlati; Mbizana; Thabankulu (Eastern Cape).
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including in Amahlati; Mbizana; Thabankulu (Eastern Cape).

26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including: Gauteng: Tshwane (Mooiplaas; Pienaarspoort); Ekurhuleni (Kathlehong; Boksburg; Sebokeng); West Rand (Munsieville); Johannesburg (Lawley; Ivory Park).

26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including: Gauteng: Tshwane (Mooiplaas; Pienaarspoort); Ekurhuleni (Kathlehong; Boksburg; Sebokeng); West Rand (Munsieville); Johannesburg (Lawley; Ivory Park).

26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including: Gauteng: Tshwane (Mooiplaas; Pienaarspoort); Ekurhuleni (Kathlehong; Boksburg; Sebokeng); West Rand (Munsieville); Johannesburg (Lawley; Ivory Park).
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including Limpopo: Elias Motsoaledi, Polokwane, Ramamabolo, and Giyani.
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including Bloemfontein (Free State).
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including Limpopo: Elias Motsoaledi, Polokwane, Ramamabolo, and Giyani.
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including KwaZulu-Natal: Ulundi, uMsunduzi, and Ndwedwe.

26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including: Gauteng: Tshwane (Mooiplaas; Pienaarspoort); Ekurhuleni (Kathlehong; Boksburg; Sebokeng); West Rand (Munsieville); Johannesburg (Lawley; Ivory Park).
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including KwaZulu-Natal: Ulundi, uMsunduzi, and Ndwedwe.
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including KwaZulu-Natal: Ulundi, uMsunduzi, and Ndwedwe.

26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including: Gauteng: Tshwane (Mooiplaas; Pienaarspoort); Ekurhuleni (Kathlehong; Boksburg; Sebokeng); West Rand (Munsieville); Johannesburg (Lawley; Ivory Park).
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including Limpopo: Elias Motsoaledi, Polokwane, Ramamabolo, and Giyani.
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including: Mpumalanga: Gert Sibande, Sekunda, and Bushbuckridge.

26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including: Gauteng: Tshwane (Mooiplaas; Pienaarspoort); Ekurhuleni (Kathlehong; Boksburg; Sebokeng); West Rand (Munsieville); Johannesburg (Lawley; Ivory Park).
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including: Mpumalanga: Gert Sibande, Sekunda, and Bushbuckridge.
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including Dikgatlhong.

26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including: Gauteng: Tshwane (Mooiplaas; Pienaarspoort); Ekurhuleni (Kathlehong; Boksburg; Sebokeng); West Rand (Munsieville); Johannesburg (Lawley; Ivory Park).
26 January: A voting station in Shallcross, South of Durban, was burnt and vandalised. Two were later arrested.

column9: Government of South Africa (1994-); Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: 26 January. A voter registration centre was petrol bombed by rioters in Burlington due to a lack of service delivery.
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including Gugulethu.
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including: Mpumalanga: Gert Sibande, Sekunda, and Bushbuckridge.
26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including Rustenburg.

26 January. Sporadic community protests affected the opening and operations of several voting stations around the country, including: Gauteng: Tshwane (Mooiplaas; Pienaarspoort); Ekurhuleni (Kathlehong; Boksburg; Sebokeng); West Rand (Munsieville); Johannesburg (Lawley; Ivory Park).

27 January. The African National Congress (ANC)'s regional office in Sedibeng, Vereeniging was set alight. This region has been grappling with leadership battles since the disbandment of the regional executive committee of Sedibeng.
27 January. Rioters petrol bombed a train at Orient Hills near Krugersdorp, west of Johannesburg.
28 January. Rioters set alight refuse and tyres along the N2 near the M4 split into Durban. Reasons for riot not currently known.
28 January. A protest action took place in Sunninghill. The protesters were challenging a court ruling that was made in 2012 in relation to Massmart.

29 January (on or around). Vigilantes from Motherwell, Port Elizabeth beat a man to death after a seven-year-old girl claimed that she had been raped by the man. They later realised that he was innocent.
29 January. Employees of the plastics industry rioted in Kempton Park, setting four trucks alight and damaging six light motor vehicles.
29 January. Supporters of the Life Chain protested against abortion in Ballito.

28-29 February. Students from the University of KwaZulu-Natal blocked Hospital Road, Durban, by burning mattresses and various other items including a fridge. The protest was in response to living conditions at university residences. Police was called onto the scene to disperse the protesting students. [size=no report].
30 January. Community members burned the house in which an alleged rapist was staying in Tafelsig and pelted police who intervened with stones.

30 January (on or around). Residents from Masoyi outside Mbombela, Mpumalanga attacked an elderly couple for allegedly poisoning and killing their grandson. They set the couple on fire with a burning tyre, leaving them injured.

column9: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 30 January 2019, a SAMWU Limpopo deputy provincial secretary was fatally shot by unknown persons in Thohoyandou (Vhembe, Limpopo). SAMWU was calling for removal of mayors who illegally invested money with the now-liquidated VBS Mutual Bank.
30 January. Economic Freedom Fighters members protested at the North West High Court in Mahikeng ahead of the appearance of two men convicted of killing a teenager, demanding a life sentence.

column9: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 31 January 2019, a SAMWU official was fatally shot by unknown persons in Makwarela township in the Thohoyandou area (Vhembe, Limpopo). He was the second official to be killed following a call for the removal of mayors who illegally invested money with the now-liquidated VBS Mutual Bank.
31 January. Residents from Ext 8 in Lekwa Municipality protested lack of water for days. They protested on 31 January as well as on 1 and 4 February.
31 January. Protesters gathered in front of the Vodacom Head Office demanding the compensation for a former employee for his creation of the Please Call Me Service.
31 January. Protesters demanded water and sanitation, electricity and basic services for their areas outside the Cape Town Civic Centre.
31 January. Residents protested in eMalahleni. Reasons for protest unknown.
30 January, week of. City contractors protested again over payments not received for work done in December.
31 January. Rioters burned tyres in the Pretoria West area. The reason for the riots are unknown.

On 31 January 2019, ward 21 residents from Nkowankowa rioted at the site of a new road. The protest evolved into a riot after police arrested some of them, with tires burnt at the site and property vandalised. The demonstrators accused Ward Councillor, Thandi Mpenyana of not following the right procedure when appointing community members for the contract. [size=no report].

On 31 January 2019, ward 19 residents from Nkowankowa, Section A and B, burnt tires on the roads during a demonstration over employment. Police intervened to disperse them. The section B residents did not want to share employment positions with those of section A after Councillor Zandamela said they will employ 24 people from both sections. [size=no report].

column7: SANCO: South African National Civics Organization; Students (South Africa)
column17: 01 February. Learners from Bardale Primary School smashed school windows with stones, damaged teachers' cars and demanded that learners leave classrooms at a primary school in Mfuleni. SANCO as well as unplaced learners and their parents appeared to be involved in the protests. The protests are in response to overcrowding in Cape Town's schools this year.
1 February. Violent protest action took place on the N2 Northbound carriageway. Protestors burned tyres on the freeway.
01 February. Residents from Ext 8 in Lekwa Municipality protested lack of water for days. They protested on 31 January as well as on 1 and 4 February.
On 1 February 2019, a municipal truck was set alight by contract workers during a protest on the Mangosuthu Highway in uMlazi. [size=no report].

02 February. Violent protest action erupted at ga-Muila village. A group of community members burned down the house of the local Chief at Kwaaidraai, as well as six motor vehicles and damaged the property of a local mine. The motives behind the protest are unclear.

column7: SASCO: South Africa Students Congress; EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command; Students (South Africa)
column9: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command
column17: On 4 February 2019, SASCO protesters stormed the Durban campus of Rosebank College while prospective students were busy registering. Some damage was caused. The protest was aimed at closing various tertiary institutions to highlight various concerns relating to fees, allowances and security. Clashes with stick-wielding EFF Student Command (EFFSC) students also reported. [size=no report].

On 4 February 2019, students set alight two vehicles and a guard hous at the University of KwaZulu-Natal (UKZN) campuses and called for a total shutdown of institutions over National Student Financial Aid Scheme (NSFAS) payments and slow registrations. Students also protested at the Durban University of Technology and Mangosuthu University of Technology, blocking roads with burning tyres. [size=no report].
04 February (on or around). Eight men stoned three suspected burglars around Ga-Marishane village, leaving two killed.
04 February. Protesters from Zimbabwe protested outside Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town to demand that their vice-president Constantino Chiwenga does not get treated there.
04 February. Residents from Ext 8 in Lekwa Municipality protested lack of water for days. They protested on 31 January as well as on 1 and 4 February.

column7: Health Workers (South Africa); Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: 04 February. Doctors, nurses and support staff, protested over staff shortages and nepotism at Leratong Hospital on the West Rand.
04 February. About 200 protestors have blocked the R103 between Colenso and Ladysmith with burning tyres and set cargo trucks alight over service delivery.
04 February. Community members of Moyeni protested over service delivery, blocking the main roadway with rocks and other items.

04 February. Job seekers rioted, setting alight a municipal bus and damaging one of the entrance gates to the King Dinuzulu Hospital on Dr.R.D.Naidu Drive in Sydenham. Rioters demanded to be given jobs at the hospital instead of people from outlying areas.

05 February. Protesters of the Caleb Motshabi settlement, Phase 6, Bloemfontein, closed the M30 with stones and burning rubbish, over service delivery issues and the relocation of some residents to Phase 7. [size=no report].
05 February. 300 protesters barricaded the N14 road outside Olifantshoek with rocks and tyres and looted and torched a truck. The protestors protested against a lack of water delivery.

05 February. Students led by Wits Student Representative Council started a hunger strike and held a small demonstration to protest registration, financial and accommodation issues at at Wits University in Johannesburg. This led to a scuffle with a private security guard, one injured.

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command; Students (South Africa)
column17: 05 February. A Durban University of Technology student was shot and killed by police at the Steve Biko Campus during an EFFSC protest. Police claimed the students became unruly and hurled stones at staff members , while students denied.
06 February. Protest action took place after the Samora Machel offramp in Nelspruit's direction. The reason for the protest is still unknown.
06 February. Students at the Temple Valley Secondary School, Verulam, protested to demand the resignation of the principal. Stones were thrown at the buildings and refuse bins were burned.
06 February. Pupils held a peaceful protest during assembly at Sans Souci Girls' High School in Cape Town.
06 February. Residents protested over lack of water in Allandale Road near the intersection with Mastiff Road in Klipfontein View in Midrand.
06 February. Students from William Hills Secondary School, in Actonville, embarked on a peaceful protest due to shortage of teachers since the beginning of the year.
06 February. Protesters closed the entry and exit of Mqanduli, forcing hundreds of schools and clinics to shut down.
06 February. Employees of South African state power firm Eskom protested in front of the firm's headquarters in Sunninghill against potential job cuts and a proposal to split up the ailing company.

06 February. About 300 students from the University of Johannesburg (UJ), Wits and Central Johannesburg College marched from UJ's Doornfontein to Auckland Park Kingsway (APK) campuses to protest registration, financial and accommodation issues. They clashed with security forces guarding the university, while police intervened to disperse the two groups, firing rubber bullets.
06 February. Parents and school governing body members protested over teaching conditions at schools in Booysen Park.
06 February. Residents from the Zwelihle informal settlement in Hermanus protested outside the Western Cape High Court after they were taken to court for invading a piece of land.
07 February. Right2Know protestors held protests calling on President Cyril Ramaphosa to increase social grants.
07 February. Eastcape Midlands College in Uitenhage was shut down after students demanded accountability over 22 missing life orientation examination scripts.
07 February. Louis Trichardt residents held a peaceful march from the show grounds to the Makhado Local Municipality.
07 February. A municipal water truck was destroyed in Engonyameni, south of Durban during service delivery protests.

07 February. Fourth day of protest by Wits Student Representative Council to shut down the campus over registration, financial and accommodation issues. The protesters tried to fight private security guards who blocked the entrance gate leading to Empire Road. Stones were scattered at the Yale Road entrance.

7 February. Students from the Eastcape Midlands College in Makhanda (Grahamstown) have protested outside the campus over registration, transport, National Student Financial Aid Scheme (NSFAS) funding, textbook, toilet facilities, computer and internet issues. The students burned rubbish at the gates of the college during the protest.
On 5 February 2019, students protested outside the Western Cape Nursing College in Klipfontein Road, Cape Town,. They were demanding increased safety on campus and running water. [size=no report].

08 February. Protesting students held the audience of a comedy show 'hostage' at the University of KwaZulu-Natal in Glenwood, Durban, after demanding the closure of the theatre during student protests across the campus.

08 February. Protesters burnt tires and blocks roads in Marlboro Drive in Sandton, Gauteng, near the Gautrain station. Police fired rubber bullets, leaving some injured. The cause of the protests was what the protesters described as the encroachment of informal settlements onto their land.

08 February. Protesting parents and the school governing body (SGB) have locked students and teachers out of the Matodzi High School, Vuwani, demanding the removal of the principal, who is described as unreliable and do not communicate with parents. [size=no report]

08 February. Farmworkers led by the Tshintsha Amakhaya platform gathered outside the offices of the provincial Department of Rural Development and Land Reform to protest farm evictions. The protesters demanded the release of all records dating back from January 2016 to January 2019 relating to farm evictions, as well as that Western Cape farms be used as a testing ground for land expropriation without compensation.
09 February. Ban Animal Trading (Bat) protested for the release of an elephant outside the Johannesburg Zoo on Jan Smuts Avenue in the wake of worldwide campaign.
09 February. Protesters have blocked the Helpmekaar Road, in Ladysmith over water shortages.

column9: Women (South Africa); EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters
column17: 09 February. An unidentified armed group killed a female member of EFF, who was working on citizens' rights, in Khayelitsha, City of Cape Town.

column9: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Women (South Africa)
column17: On or around 9 February 2019, an EFF activist was fatally shot by unidentified persons in her house in Khayelitsha (City of Cape Town, Western Cape).

column9: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Women (South Africa)
column17: 10 February. An Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) activist was murdered in her home in Khayelitsha.

In early February 2019, a local vigilante group, known as Bonafide Organization, have been responsible for the illegal and forced eviction of 20 RDP houses, mostly foreign nationals in Alexandra. An ANC member said that the group of usually 50 men are armed ad use force against civilians. One man has been killed and 7 have been injured.
10 February. Residents from Dolphin Avenue held a peaceful demonstration over a newly erected cell phone tower said to have bad health implications.

10 February. Sea Cow Lake residents rioted at a car-modifying business after a man was killed by dogs, setting a truck and four cars alight. The rioters demanded that police deal with the dogs that continues to attack community members passing by the business.

column7: SATAWU: South African Transport and Allied Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: 10 February. Workers from Don't Waste protested outside the company's base in Cape Town. The workers said they were dismissed after they joined the South African Transport and Allied Workers Union (Satawu). They joined the union because of wage and working conditions complaints.

10 February. A man has been killed at Extension 39, Mahikeng by angry community members. The community members assaulted the man with various objects. The man died succumb from his injuries. [size=no report].

10 February. Nine people have been injured during a service delivery demonstration at Bathurst. The demonstration erupted during a motorcade by political party members (name not mentioned), when residents started throwing stones at the motor vehicles, attacking bystanders and burning homes. Five houses and two cars belonging to ANC members were set alight [size=no report].

11 February. The main entrance of the Vaal University of Technology (VUT) was blocked by protesting students over financial exclusion and the non-payment of allowances by the National Student Financial Aid Scheme (NSFAS). Students also protested at their residences over the shortage of accommodation. Stones and bottles were thrown by student to gain entrance to the residence. Police used rubber bullets to diffuse the riot.

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command; Students (South Africa)
column17: 11 February. Students from Tshwane University of Technology, led by the EFFSC, protested at Ga-Rankuwa, Arcadia and at the campus in Pretoria West, demanding management to deal with National Student Financial Aid Scheme (NSFAS) funding. They burnt tyres at the entrances of the campuses

column7: SASCO: South Africa Students Congress; Students (South Africa)
column17: 11 January. Students from University of South Africa protested in Langalibalele Street, Pietermaritzburg, burning tyres and refuse, over the National Student Financial Aid Scheme (NSFAS) not paying allowances and tuition fees. The protest was led by the South African Students Congress (SASCO).
12 February. Students from Cape Peninsula University of Technology, Bellville campus, built shacks on the campus and set fire to buses in protest against accommodation shortages.

12 February. Residents have used burning tyres and tree logs to block the R61, between Libode and Port St Johns, demanding the tarring of the road between St Barnabas Hospital and Hluleka Nature Reserve.
12 February. Learners from Nooitgedacht Primary School, Cape Town, protested against gang violence in the area. The protest was organised by Bishop Lavis Action Community (BLAC).

12 February. Ehlanzeni Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) College students marched to protest the exclusion of students from the National Student Financial Aid Scheme (NSFAS) funding.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; SATAWU: South African Transport and Allied Workers Union; SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union; SANCO: South African National Civics Organization; NUM: National Union of Mineworkers; Labour Group (South Africa); Teachers (South Africa)
column17: 13 February. Thousands of protestors, led by Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU), marched from Fitzgerald Square in Newtown to the Gauteng Provincial Legislature and the Chamber of Mines to protest job losses. Members of the South African Transport and Allied Workers Union (SATAWU), the South African Democratic Teachers Union (SADTU), the SA National Civic Organisation (SANCO), and the National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) also participated in the protest.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union; SACTWU: Southern African Clothing and Textile Workers Union; ANC: African National Congress; SACP: South African Communist Party; SANCO: South African National Civics Organization; Labour Group (South Africa); Teachers (South Africa)
column17: 13 February. Hundreds of protestors, led by Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU), marched from Njoli Square in Zwide to Nangoza Jebe Hall, Port Elizabeth, to protest job losses. Members of the SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union, SACTWU: Southern African Clothing and Textile Workers Union, ANC: African National Congress, SACP: South African Communist Party, SANCO: South African National Civics Organization also participated in the protest.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; POPCRU: Police and Prisons Civil Rights Union (South Africa); NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union; SACCAWU: South African Commercial, Catering and Allied Workers Union; SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union; SASCO: South Africa Students Congress; ANC: African National Congress; SACP: South African Communist Party; Labour Group (South Africa); Students (South Africa); Teachers (South Africa); Police Forces of South Africa (1994-)
column17: 13 February. Hundreds of protestors, led by Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU), marched from the stadium in Buffalo Road to the Department of Labour in Alexander Road to protest job losses. Members of the POPCRU: Police and Prisons Civil Rights Union (South Africa), NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union, SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union, SACCAWU: South African Commercial, Catering and Allied Workers Union, SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union, SASCO: South Africa Students Congress, ANC: African National Congress, SACP: South African Communist Party also participated in the protest.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: 13 February. Hundreds of protestors, led by Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU), marched from King Dinuzulu Park to the City Hall, Durban, to protest job losses.

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: 13 February. Hundreds of protestors, led by Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU), marched from the Thohoyandou Stadium to the Vhembe District Municipality offices, Limpopo, to protest job losses.

14 February. Protesters blocked Addo road, Port Elizabeth, with burning tyres. The residents are demanding water, electricity, sanitation, and Reconstruction and Development Programme (RDP) houses. Three trucks were also burned.
14 February. An African National Congress member was shot dead in his home in KwaPata, Pietermaritzburg.
14 February. Protestors blocked the R76, in Steynsrus, with stones and burning tyres in protest of a lack of service delivery.

column7: COSAS: Congress of South African Students; Students (South Africa)
column17: 14 February. Congress of South African Students (Cosas) protested outside the Sans Souci Girls' High School, showing support for a student who was slapped by a teacher after the student pushed her desk against the teacher.
14 February. Service delivery protests in Uitenhage, led to closure of the Rosedale Clinic.
14 February. Five rioters have been arrested by police after an Algoa bus was set alight during a service delivery protest in Vastrap, Port Elizabeth.
15 February. Residents from Makhanda (formerly known as Grahamstown) led by UPM protested at city hall over water shortages in the area.

15 February. Residents from Lilydale protested at the offices of Bushbuckridge municipality demanding water after the municipality terminated the water contract with Rand Water after it was unable to pay its debts, leaving residents without water.

15 February. One person was wounded by an unknown gunman during a violent altercation between ANC and IFP protesters in Vryheid. The protest was for better service delivery and was planned by community members. During the march, IFP members approached the protesting group where violence escalated.
15 February. The bodies of two men were found in Motherwell. The men have been 'necklaced' with wires after being kidnapped by a community mob over the murder of a women on the 14th of February.

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command; SASCO: South Africa Students Congress; Students (South Africa)
column17: 15 February. More than 100 students rioted at the University of Fort Hare's Alice campus, attacking the police, damaging vehicles and destroying the cafeteria. One police officer was injured. The protest was in response to NSFAS allowances not being paid and tuition and postgraduate registration fee increases. The Economic Freedom Fighters Student Command and the South African Students' Congress led the protests.
15 February. Gugulethu fire station was set alight by protesters. The motive behind the protest is said to be because of the demolition of illegal houses in Lotus Park. [size=no report]

15 February. ANC members protested outside the provincial legislature in Cape Town during the state of the province address by Helen Zille. The protestors held posters stating that the anti-gang unit and not the army should be used to fight against gangs in the Western Cape.

15 February. Female protestors from Cornubia in Verulam, stripped down and blocked roads in employment protests. The protestors said that refuse collection jobs were offered to residents from other communities, and they were not considered.

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: 15 February. Workers at the Msunduzi and Midlands TVET Colleges protested at the Msunduzi campus, led by the National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union (NEHAWU). Reports of tires burnt and people prevented from entering schools. Workers demand full time employment. Workers said that nine of their members were shot by police.

February, exact date not known, [reported 26 February]. A man, suspected of a break-in, has been killed by a mob after being found inside a house in Marikana, North-West. The man was assaulted with various objects. [size=no report]

16 February. The Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) marched to the Ivory Park Police Station, Tembisa to hand over a memorandum of demands. The demands centred around police corruption and the increase of drugs within the community. [size=no report]

17 February. All exit road in Greytown have been blocked by arund 200 Ward 7 protesters, using burning tyres and sticks. The protesters demanded that the major, Thamsanqa Ngubane, to step down. Residents are also demanding that all work construction work within the area be given to Ward 7 residents. Vehicles have been set alight.

17 February. Buildings and vehicles were burned at the University of Zululand's KwaDlangezwa Campus by rioting students, who demanded answers over their allowances and tuition fees not being paid. Police arrived at the scene, attempting to diffuse the situation. Some injuries have been reported. Size of demonstration unknown.
17 February. Members of the Christian Church NG Moedergemeente (Klipkerk), Vryheid, held a peaceful demonstration through picking up litter that have been thrown out of rubbish bins. [size=no report]

On 18 February 2019, students staged a demonstration and used rocks and bricks to block the entrance to Mangosuthu University of Technology. Police used teargas to disperse the crowds and arrested seven. The rioting students demanded financial aid and accommodation. [size=no report]

column7: EFFSC: Economic Freedom Fighters Students Command; Students (South Africa)
column17: 18 February. Classes at the Durban University of Technology have been disrupted by protesting Economic Freedom Fighters Student Command members (EFFSC) who chased students out of their classes. The protest was said to be in honour of an EFFSC member killed during a violent protest. [size=no report]

18 February. Rioters from Emalahleni informal settlement have damaged nearby houses after their illegal connected power was disconnected by City Power. Burning tyres, stones and branches were also used to close off the Progress Road in Grobler Park. [size=no report]
18 February. Students from the University of KwaZulu-Natal have burned their mattresses in protest against their bed in their university residence being uncomfortable. [size=no report]

column7: SAPSWU: South African Private Security Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: 18 February. Demonstrations have taken place outside the Bosasa, now known as African Global Operations (AGO), head office in Krugersdorp. Protesting workers, led by South African Private Security Workers Union (SAPSWU), demanded medical aid, transport allowance and wages. The company announced before the demonstration that it will be liquidated.
18 February. A new wave of protests by staff and students broke out at the Durban University of Technology. The protesters disrupted classes and intimidated staff and students. [size=no report]
18 February. protesters blocked the entrance of the Bosport Dam, Kroondal, demanding jobs. [size=no report]

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: 18 February. Workers at the Msunduzi and Midlands TVET Colleges protested at the Msunduzi campus, led by the National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union (NEHAWU). Workers demand full time employment. About 50 protesters blocked students from entering the campus.

19 February. Riot action on the N2 in Plettenberg Bay have been reported. The road was block by burning tyres and passing vehicles were thrown with rocks. The demonstration was in protest against a small amount of electricity units for the price of R60 (rand). [size=no report]

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: 19 February. Members of the Congress of South African Trade Union (COSATU) marched to the Cape Town Parliament in protest over future job losses at ESKOM. [size=no report]

19 February. Residents from the Lenasia informal settlement, Johannesburg, have block the Nirvana Drive with burning tyres and rocks. The protest came after City Power disconnected their illegal power connections. The Johannesburg Metro Police Department (JMPD) are monitoring the situation. [size=no report]
19 February. Service delivery protests have left Randfontein road close. [size=no report]
19 February. Residents of Mbekweni, Paarl, marched to the municipal offices, closing Jan van Riebeeck Drive, to demand prepaid meters due to a lack of electricity in the area. [size=no report]
19 February. Residents from Kwanokuthula, Bitou, protested, demanding that their electricity should be supplied directly by Eskom. [size=no report].
19 February. protesters have blocked the R40 via Dwarsloop to Bushbuckridge, Mpumalanga. protesters have also set the Civic Centre and some vehicles alight. Police are on the scene. [size=no report]
19 February. protesters have blocked Stanford Road, Port Elizabeth. It is believed that the protests are due to SMME payments. [size=no report]
19 February. Students protested outside the police station in Waterval Boven, demanding justice for a student from the TVET College who have been raped.
20 February. Residents from Qolweni, Bitou, protested over housing shortages. [size=no report].
20 February. The N14 in Johannesburg have been closed by protesters burning tyres. [size=no report]

20 February. Three homes were damaged with petrol bombs in Overport. This action is believed to be linked to a community protest in Alpine road on the 19the of February. protesters demanded jobs at the King George hospital. According to testimonies, live shots were fired at protesters from the houses that have been bombed. [size=no report]
20 February. Rioters from Ekuvukeni set the South African Social Security Agency (SASSA) offices alight due to service delivery issues, namely water and sewer systems. [size=no report]

20 February. A busload of people protested at the Glencore Mines, Witbank, disrupting the services. The busload of people want to mine the dumps at the mine, that Glencore plans to rehabilitate. Some of the administration staff have been forcefully removed from their offices. [size=no report]

20 February. The Krugersdorp highway have been blocked by protesters. The reasons for the protest are still unknown. The Johannesburg Metro Police Department (JMPD) and police is monitoring the situation. [size=no report]

February, exact date not known, [reoprted on 20 February]. Parents of learners of the Durban Deep Primary School have staged a protest, demanding that a new school needs to be build, promised to them bt the Department of Education. [size=no report]
21 February. Protesting students from the Walter Sisulu University, Butterworth, are demanding better living conditions. The protest has caused the Ibika campus to close. [size=no report].

21 February. Rioters demanded the release of six people who have been arrested for assault on 19 February. The situation escalated, three houses were set alight and police vehicles were damaged. On the 21st of February, protesters blocked roads.

21 February. protesters have blocked several roads in Cosmo City, Roodepoort, with burning tyres, some in protest for the councillor to step down, while other are protesting against the resignation. [size=no report].

column16: Daily Maverick (South Africa); Herald (South Africa); Citizen (South Africa); SABC News
column17: On 25 March 2019, a violent demonstration erupted in Kenville (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal). Shops owned by foreigners were looted and roads were blocked with burning tyres and rubbish. The mob also forced foreigners out of their homes and looted their homes. A woman died while attempting to flee from the demonstrators. A demonstrator was also shot dead by a shop owner after his shop was set alight. Police was on the scene. [size=100].

25 March. Students blocked the entrance at the Tshwane University of Technology (TUT), Arcadia. The demonstration was in response to the late payment of allowances by the National Student Financial Aid. [size=50].

On 25 March 2019, a crowd of local truck drivers blocked the South Coast Road near Durban (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal) and forced foreign truck drivers out of their trucks and reportedly assaulted them. One driver was stabbed. No casualties reported. [size=no report]

column16: Daily Maverick (South Africa); Sunday Tribune (South Africa); Xenowatch
column17: On 25 March 2019, a mob looted several homes and shops belonging to foreign nationals in Springfield (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal) in targeted xenophobic attacks. Two people were fatally shot by a shop owner. [size=no report]

25 March. Shops, a petrol station and a doctor's surgery were looted during a service delivery demonstration in Sea Cow Lake. Demonstrators also blocked the main road to Durban with burning tyres and rubbish. Police were on the scene to disperse the crowd. [size=250].

The demonstrators demanded that the mayor, accused of corruption, should step down. Police was on the scene to disperse the demonstrators. 12 people have been arrested for public violence. [size=250].

25 March. A demonstration was held in front the Umzimkhulu Magistrate's Court. The demonstrators, supported by African National Congress members, are demanding that the Harry Gwala district mayor and three of his co-accused should be denied bail. The accused have been charged with the murder of an African National Congress Youth League member in 2017. [size=no report].

25 March. Residents from Warrenton continued with a service delivery demonstration. Demonstrators threw stones at the house of the mayor of Magareng Municipality and threatened to set his house alight if he continues to ignore their grievances that include poor housing conditions, lack of running water, poor sanitation facilities, the tar road project no being completed and the lights near the Pumla garage not being installed. [size=no report].

26 March. Family members of a man who have been killed, demonstrated outside the Pinetown Magistrate's Court during the bail hearing of the accused. [size=no report].

column9: Labour Group (South Africa); NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
